HEADLINE: New U.S. Guards Promised Against Steel Import Surges

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The Clinton administration plans to take aggressive new steps to protect domestic steel producers from import surges, speeding up its use of antidumping measures and providing faster relief for companies and workers, according to a report the administration will release today.
The 240-page report, a copy of which was made available by an administration official, seems timed to help Vice President Al Gore shore up political support from steel workers and unions. Some union leaders sharply criticized Mr. Gore's support for the China trade bill this year, and many have expressed disappointment that the administration has not done more to guard against sudden increases in low-price steel imports. 
 The report, prepared by the Commerce Department, says the administration will start imposing duties on imported steel faster than it has in the past -- and in some cases even before reaching a final judgment on whether a foreign country is selling steel in this market below cost -- so as to minimize the damage to domestic companies and workers when dumping does occur.
Administration officials said they had also requested funds to set up an interagency "rapid response team" that would distribute aid to hard-hit communities as soon as it became clear that a sudden rise in import volumes threatened profits and jobs.
Many of the nation's leading trading partners, including Japan, South Korea, Russia and Brazil, have complained bitterly about United States antidumping laws, especially as used to shield the politically sensitive steel industry. The administration's pledge to use those laws more actively seems sure to inflame already tense trade ties with those nations, especially with Japan.
Just last month, foreign steel producers released their own study that contended that the American restrictions on imported steel had cost consumers here as much as $150 billion over the last three decades. Trade barriers and government subsidies effectively raise the cost of everything with steel components, from aircraft to kitchen utensils, said that study, which was prepared by lawyers for foreign steel makers.
The Commerce Department's study makes essentially the opposite claim. It suggests that if anything, the United States has erred on the side of free trade and needs to speed up and stiffen its response when the industry faces unfair competition from abroad.
The United States imposed antidumping duties on hot rolled steel from Russia, Japan and Brazil in 1998. The administration decided at the time that the United States was flooded with below-cost steel after the Asian financial crisis that began in 1997 led to devalued currencies and bankrupt companies abroad. Some steel industry and union officials have complained that it took the administration too long to respond to that crisis.
"This is designed to make sure that what happened to the industry two years ago doesn't happen again," a senior Commerce official said. "We want to move as fast and as aggressively as we can, because we know that it takes time for the remedies to work."
In the future, the report says, the administration will act faster to break out and distribute trade data on steel. That will help people spot evidence of potential import surges. When surges occur, the administration will act faster to head them off, the report says. Among other actions, the report recommends starting negotiations with trading partners as soon as it becomes clear that an import surge is in the works.
The report also says that the administration will work to address long-term "structural factors" that cause foreign countries to sell steel at prices the United States has determined are below the cost of production.
Russia, the report says, has allowed steel exporters to escape paying bills at home, allowing them to sell goods abroad below cost. Japan allows steel makers to coordinate with one another and keep prices artificially high at home to help promote low-price exports. South Korea has unsound banking practices that have effectively subsidized a glut of steel production capacity.
The administration will use its influence at the World Bank and other international lending agencies to end loans that expand steel production capacity, the study says. It will also propose that international economic bodies study how best to knock down informal barriers that protect and subsidize steel companies.

HEADLINE: Report on Black America Finds a College Gender Gap

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Among blacks, home ownership is at a record high and unemployment is reaching a record low, the National Urban League said in its annual overview on the state of black America.
"Our move towards the economic mainstream continues steady as it goes," Hugh B. Price, the league president, said in an interview. "The strong economy is proving a powerful magnet for growth. But we still have a way to go to achieve parity." 
 But while the study shows the black middle class swelling, it also points to a downside: blacks represent a disproportionately high number of adults and juveniles in prison and those dying of cancer, AIDS and other diseases.
The report also said that black men trail black women in educational success and that the gap is widening.
In many ways, the report, to be made public on Wednesday, offers a picture of two black Americas: one taking advantage of economic opportunities and another mired in deprivation.
"The strong demand for labor has lifted all boats in the American economy, and we are no exception," Mr. Price said.
The good economic times are transforming the urban landscape as neglected black districts such as Harlem in New York City and the U Street corridor in Washington are sprouting new stores.
"We are seeing Gaps and Home Depots and Sears moving to 125th Street in New York," Mr. Price said. "That would have been unthinkable just a few years back."
However, the other black America is still burdened by unemployment rates that are more than twice the rate among whites.
What Mr. Price described as one of the most troubling gaps does not divide black and white: the gulf between black men and black women in educational attainment.
The number of blacks in college has surged by 43 percent since the 1970's. But black women have far outpaced black men in both undergraduate and graduate school settings.
From 1977 to 1997, the number of bachelor's degrees awarded to black men increased by 30 percent, while the number increased by 77 percent for black women. For master's degrees, the increases were 8 percent for black men and 39 percent for black women.
"The numerical status of African-American men in higher education is a cause for concern," the report says.
Separately, the Journal of Blacks in Higher Education said this year that in 1997, 454,000 black women in the country had master's degrees, compared with 222,000 black men.
Michael Nettles, a University of Michigan education professor, said part of the explanation is that black men may have more options than black women after high school, noting that black men outnumber black women among college-age military recruits.
"There may be expectations that the family depends on them more than girls to earn the paycheck," Professor Nettles said.
In addition, he said black males are severely underrepresented in advanced placement settings and over-represented in special education classes for students with low test scores or behavior and discipline problems. Teachers, using "extremely subjective" criteria, may harbor lower expectations for black males, he said.
The implications are far-reaching. If few black men enter higher education, they will continue to be rare in corporate boardrooms and other spheres of power.
Mr. Price said the gap between black women and men could be troublesome for the future of the black family. "As the economic gap widens, questions of whether black women will find black men who can carry their share in the household will become more evident," he said.

HEADLINE: National Study Examines Reasons Why Pupils Excel

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Smaller class size in early grades and access to preschool appear to increase student achievement, particularly in impoverished communities, more than the salaries, education or experience of teachers, a national study released yesterday says.
The state-by-state analysis of standardized test results suggests that policy initiatives to raise student achievement have been effective, with math scores climbing steadily across the country at an average rate of about one percentile point each year from 1990 to 1996. Texas and a handful of other states that were among the leaders in adopting new standards and accountability systems have shown particular gains, including significantly higher scores by poor students and those from minority groups. 
 "Public education is reformable," declared David Grissmer, the principal author of the book-length study published by the Rand Corporation, a policy and research group based in Santa Monica, Calif.
"Five years ago, we were unsure whether reform in the states was working and if spending more money would make any difference in educational outcomes," Mr. Grissmer said. "We see gains in some states from reform efforts, and we see that resources, if they're properly targeted, can be very effective at raising achievement."
The study presents a mixed picture for politicians arguing over how to spend education dollars, and, in calling for increased federal spending to reduce disparities among states, is sure to provide fodder for debate in the presidential campaign.
Both Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore immediately highlighted the report on their campaign Web sites, with Mr. Bush celebrating the declaration of his state as a national leader and Mr. Gore noting that class-size reduction and universal preschool -- programs praised in the report -- form the centerpiece of his education agenda.
"I am proud of the results we have achieved in education in Texas," Mr. Bush, the presumptive Republican nominee, said in a statement. "As president, I will achieve the same results, ensuring that no child is left behind."
But William A. Galston, a senior adviser to Mr. Gore, the all-but-named Democratic nominee, pointed out that Mr. Bush did not even become governor until 1995, near the end of the period studied.
"I'm told, though I'm not a farm boy, that roosters crow when the sun comes up," said Mr. Galston, director of the Institute for Philosophy and Public Policy at the University of Maryland. "I am told by some farmers that some roosters are under the impression that they have caused the sun to rise, but they did not."
Beneath the partisan potshots, though, educators and state policy makers found crucial lessons in the report, which links scores on a national standardized test to census data and variables like per-pupil spending and class size for the first time. The study looked at seven math and reading tests administered in 44 states through the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a federal program that tests samples of 4th, 8th and 12th graders.
Among the findings were these:
*There is wide disparity in performance across the states for students from socio-economically similar families. Texas topped the list, with students scoring an average of 11 percentile points higher than their counterparts in last-ranked California. The states succeeding in this measure tended to spend more money per student, have lower student-teacher ratios and less teacher turnover, provide more public prekindergarten classes and have teachers report satisfaction with their classroom resources.
*Looking at raw scores, states clustered near the top were mostly northern and rural, including Minnesota, Montana and Maine, while the 10 lowest performers were eight Southern states, California and New Mexico. The study's authors attribute this largely to demographics.
*While math scores increased across the country, there was considerable range in gains among the states. North Carolina students improved nearly 2.5 percentile points each year, and those in Texas and Michigan 2 percentile points, more than twice the national average.
*Teacher salaries, their years in the classroom and the percentage of the teaching force with master's degrees appear to have little impact on student performance, though Mr. Grissmer said more study of these factors is necessary. The report said education dollars would be better spent on classroom-based resources to improve teacher working conditions, like computers and voice mail and curriculum materials, or on reducing class size than on wages.
"It's great to see such a sophisticated study confirming a truth too many people want to ignore: poor children achieve at lower rates because we give them an inferior education," said Kati Haycock, director of the Education Trust, a Washington group focused on disadvantaged students. "With targeted investments and high expectations, we can close the achievement gap once and for all."
But while most people praised the report's rigor, some questioned the usefulness of analyzing test scores that predate many state reform initiatives, and other aspects of its methodology.
Tom Loveless, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who is also studying NAEP data, pointed out that the math scores Mr. Grissmer used come from a new test that tracks curriculums introduced widely in the last decade, and that scores on an older form of the exam, which emphasizes basic skills such as arithmetic, have been flat in the 1990's.
Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, questioned whether the analysis of teacher pay and experience remains relevant now that the country is facing a teacher shortage.
And Susan K. Burr, California's interim secretary of education, noted that in the last two years, her state has cut class size in kindergarten to fourth grade from 28 students to 20; increased per pupil spending by nearly $1,000, and instituted an accountability system similar to the one in Texas.
The report, she said, is "ancient history."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
G.M. Unites Media Planning At New Shop

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
The largest assignment in the history of Madison Avenue was made yesterday when General Motors consolidated responsibilities for media planning -- deciding where to run ads with an annual budget of $2.9 billion -- at a new shop to be formed by a unit of the giant agency company known as the B Com3 Group.
The consolidation of media planning under the unit, the Starcom MediaVest Group, came after a monthlong review of three contenders and will affect all G.M. brands sold in the United States except Saab and Saturn. 
 "As you can imagine, this is a huge undertaking for us," Michael A. Browner, executive director for media and marketing operations at the General Motors Corporation in Detroit, said in a conference call to reporters to announce the decision.
Media planning is taking on additional strategic importance as marketers seek to increase the long odds that a potential customer -- busy with life and bored by most ads -- will pay attention to a sales pitch, particularly when many products are aimed at narrow demographic groups rather than mass audiences.
One way media planning works is to use tools like consumer research to try tailoring media schedules to the tastes of would-be buyers so they are more likely to encounter the ads, whether watching television, listening to the radio, surfing the Internet, passing by billboards or reading a newspaper or magazine. Another way media planning tries to improve the chances that consumers will see ads is to have them appear in unexpected places, from store floors and plastic bags wrapped around dry cleaning to elevators and airport baggage carousels.
"If we do our job well, the effectiveness of our advertising will be improved by putting ads in better places at better times," Mr. Browner said, "making sure we can reach more of the target audience more effectively."
The decision to select Starcom MediaVest was made by a committee of seven high-ranking G.M. marketing and advertising executives. There were two other agencies under consideration in the review: the Interpublic Group of Companies and Carat North America, part of the Aegis Group.
The decision by G.M. to consolidate media planning at a stand-alone shop came seven years after the company, the nation's largest advertiser and largest automaker, consolidated media buying -- the negotiations to determine how much ads will cost -- at G.M. Mediaworks in Warren, Mich., formed by Interpublic at G.M.'s request.
The creative duties for G.M. brands remain at the various agencies now handling those tasks, including Starcom MediaVest siblings like Leo Burnett in Chicago and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in Troy, Mich., as well as Interpublic agencies like Campbell-Ewald in Warren and McCann-Erickson in Troy. The creative agencies had also been handling media planning for their particular brands; so, for instance, Burnett took care of creative and planning tasks for Oldsmobile and D'Arcy did the same for Cadillac and Pontiac.
The goal of consolidation is to wring additional economies from the elaborate planning and buying processes that lead to the delivery of ads to consumers.
"Efficiencies come from improved effectiveness in the marketplace," John G. Middlebrook, vice president and general manager for vehicle brand marketing at G.M., said during the conference call.
That will best be accomplished, he added, by "the formation of a dedicated media-planning operation, tentatively titled G.M. Planworks," to consolidate the national and regional brand-planning duties that had been divided among 17 agencies. The responsibilities had been about evenly divided between agencies owned by B Com3 and Interpublic.
Starcom MediaVest will form G.M. Planworks -- in Detroit or a nearby suburb -- to handle the media planning for brands that include Chevrolet, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick, Cadillac and G.M.C. Currently, more than 200 people handle those planning tasks, developing and producing media schedules for each brand based on the intended audience for each car, minivan or truck. G.M. Planworks, which is to be fully operating by the first quarter of 2001, is to have 150 to 200 employees.
"This is all about trying to raise the bar higher," said Jack Klues, chief executive at Starcom MediaVest, which was formed by B Com3 in May by merging Starcom Worldwide, affiliated with Burnett, with MediaVest Worldwide, affiliated with D'Arcy. Other Starcom MediaVest clients include Coca-Cola, Philip Morris and Procter & Gamble.
 "We've always admired and respected" the performance of G.M. Mediaworks, he added. "Now our goal and purpose is to deliver that same quality of work from a strategic planning perspective."
Carat North America, unlike Starcom MediaVest and Interpublic, has not handled media planning for G.M. But the chief executive there, David Verklin, is well known to the automaker for his work at the San Francisco agency now known as Publicis & Hal Riney, which handles creative and media planning assignments for Saturn.
"The two 'inside' competitors and the one 'outside' competitor all came in with an equal opportunity to win the assignment," Mr. Browner said, adding that the criteria by which Starcom MediaVest was chosen included "the successes the agency has had for G.M. as well as with other companies" and "its strategic media research."
"We have had no dissatisfaction with the quality of the media plans done for our brands by the individual agencies," Mr. Browner said. "But we should benefit from the integration across the brands, the shared learning when you've got best-in-class research."
Riney continues to handle media planning for Saturn and the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., owned by Interpublic, continues to handle media planning for Saab.

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
Hot Schools, Hot Pursuit And a Touch of Hot Air

BYLINE: By Kate Zernike 

 BODY:
LAST fall, convinced that it could attract more students if it could just show them what happens in the classroom, Mount Holyoke College tried out a new marketing strategy: it sent professors to three cities to teach hourlong lectures, much like those they would teach back on campus, to prospective applicants.
At a time when colleges wrangle over who ranks highest on the "most wired" list, it seemed like such a quaint idea, almost naive: lure 'em with good teaching. 
 But it hooked me. I walked away from the biology lecture wondering not only why, when I looked at colleges in the 1980's, I hadn't considered a women's college, but also why I had not thought more seriously -- that is to say, at all -- about studying science.
Why not? Because I did as so many other people did, and do: with the wisdom typical of age 16, I chose the "hot" school -- so hot that it was pictured on the cover of The New York Times Magazine with the headline "The Hot School," so hot that it didn't accept me, leaving me to scramble for an alternative that worked out, but far from ideally.
Just punishment, then, that I should be assigned to cover education, a job that means I find myself at least once a week asking why I didn't consider this college or that, depending on whatever program I've just visited, whatever professor or college president I've just interviewed.
The point is not so much that I should have studied medicine or gone to Mount Holyoke (though I did discover that one dowager left a chunk of her fortune to ensuring the nightly tradition of milk and cookies in the dorms, which I found pretty appealing). The point is that like so many prospective college students, I never thought outside the "hot" box.
Hot has only gotten hotter since I set my sights on Duke, in vain. There are more than 3,000 colleges in the United States. Yet the "Harvard or bust" mentality has grown so frenzied that excellent colleges complain that they have to give more financial aid based on merit and less based on need because the only way they can attract good students away from the big names is to buy them.
I can't help but wonder whether if everyone did for a living what I now do -- or at least the parents and students out touring colleges this summer -- people might be less obsessed with the hot school and more interested in what schools work best for them.
The first thing they'd realize is how many interesting things are happening at so many different colleges. How about a place where the college president still teaches class, engagingly so? A place where alumni barons of the new economy come back to lecture in small seminars about what they've learned? A place with strong mentoring? A place that demands that students learn to write and speak well, whether they major in engineering or English? A state college that affords you the opportunity to take courses as well at the most exclusive liberal arts college in the nation, while paying less than $10,000 a year? These are all things happening at good colleges whose names aren't among the five or so hot schools that every student in the country seems to want to attend.
They might also see that hot is a pretty empty concept, based mostly on rankings that in themselves are fairly arbitrary. The most popular guides devise rankings based on the number of alumni donations, the number of students per faculty member, the number of applications rejected. Some schools have explicitly said they shape their budgets to make themselves look better in rankings. Others assemble teams of staff members specifically to figure out how to list information in a way that will lift the ranking; they can dance on the head of a pin to find the most flattering definition of "faculty" or "alumni." Which is better, a school that's figured out how to ace the rankings, or one that serves students well?
If I were going to do it all over again, knowing what I have learned from colleges across the country, I would consider the larger state schools, and smaller strong liberal arts colleges in the Midwest. I would sit in on classes, and not just English classes, but physics classes, too. As that lecture last fall taught me, a professor's ability to intrigue the uninitiated is a good indication of how dedicated a college is to teaching.
I would remember that college is about exploring your options, and look for a place strongly encouraging that. I would remember, too, that college is what you make of it, no matter where you are.
It's become easy to say that professors at research universities don't do enough teaching. That, too, isn't always true; I've met plenty of professors and deans at Harvard who care about individual students. But these aren't the schools for everyone. The trick, as guidance counselors try to convince their students every year, isn't to get into the best college. It's to find the best college for you.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Flood Victims Get $11 Million More in Aid

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
New Jersey received an additional $11 million in federal aid yesterday for some of the poorest residents affected by flooding in the aftermath of Tropical Storm Floyd last September.
The money is to be spent on repairs, rental assistance or new home purchases for residents whose incomes do not exceed 50 percent of the median in each of the nine counties most affected by the flooding. 
 The funds come in addition to a larger and more generally focused $30 million in public works and economic development assistance.
Both measures were passed by Congress this month and signed into law by President Clinton on July 13.
The money will be administered by the State Division of Community Affairs, which had determined months ago that there were still many in the state living with relatives, unable to repair their homes or running low on rent money while they awaited more permanent assistance.
Maureen Hassett, a senior policy adviser to the state agency, said that because the income levels in the nine affected counties vary so widely, a family of four in wealthy Somerset County, with earnings as much as $40,000 annually, would be eligible for the same kind of assistance as a similarly sized family in Passaic County earning just $16,000 a year.
The nine counties are Bergen, Somerset, Essex, Passaic, Union, Morris, Middlesex, Hunterdon and Mercer.
The extra help was announced by Andrew Cuomo, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and a bipartisan group of New Jersey's Congressional representatives.
Governor Whitman praised the federal agency for the speed with which it delivered the money.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 723 words

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Prescription for Failure

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In denouncing President Clinton's plan to extend Medicare coverage to prescription drugs, and in touting their own counterproposal, Republicans have rolled out the usual rhetoric. They excoriate the administration plan as a bureaucratic, "one size fits all" solution. They claim that their plan offers more choice.
And for once their claims are absolutely right. The Republican plan does offer more choice. Unfortunately, this is one of those cases in which more choice is actually bad for everyone. In fact, by trying to give people more choices the Republican plan would end up denying them any choice at all. 
 Where Democrats want to offer drug coverage directly to Medicare recipients, the Republicans propose to offer money to private insurance companies instead, to entice them into serving the senior market. But all indications are that this plan is a non-starter. Insurance companies themselves are very skeptical; there haven't been many cases in which an industry's own lobbyists tell Congress that they don't want a subsidy, but this is one of them. And an attempt by Nevada to put a similar plan into effect has been a complete dud -- not a single insurer licensed to operate in the state has shown any interest in offering coverage.
The reason is "adverse selection" -- a problem that afflicts many markets, but insurance markets in particular. Basically, adverse selection is the reason you shouldn't buy insurance from companies that say "no medical exam necessary": when insurance is sold to good and bad prospects at the same price, the bad risks drive out the good.
Why can't the elderly buy prescription drug insurance? Suppose an insurance company were to offer a prescription drug plan, with premiums high enough to cover the cost of insuring an average Medicare recipient. It turns out that annual spending on prescription drugs varies hugely among retirees -- depending on whether they have chronic conditions, and which ones. Healthy retirees, who know that their bills won't be that high, would be unwilling to buy insurance that costs enough to cover the bills of the average senior -- which means that the insurance plan would attract only those with above-average bills, meaning higher premiums, driving still more healthy people away, and so on until nobody is left. Insurance companies understand this logic very well -- and are therefore simply not interested in getting into the market in the first place.
The root of the problem is that private drug insurance could be offered at a reasonable price only if people had to commit to paying the necessary premiums before they knew whether they would need expensive drugs. Such policies cannot be offered if those who find out later that they don't require such drugs can choose to stop paying what turn out to be unnecessarily high premiums.
And while in principle one could write a contract that denies the insured the choice of opting out, just try to imagine the legal complications if a private company tried to force a healthy retiree to keep paying high premiums for decades on end, even though he turns out not to need the company's benefits. As a practical matter the only way to avoid this opt-out problem, to enforce the kind of till-death-do-us-part commitment needed to make drug insurance work, is to make the coverage part of a government program.
All of this is more or less textbook economics. So why are Republican leaders insisting on a plan that almost nobody familiar with the issue thinks will work?
Cynical politics no doubt plays an important role. So does money; the insurance industry is by and large against the Republican plan, but the pharmaceutical industry is very anxious to avoid anything that might push down drug prices, and fears that the administration plan will do just that. But sincere fanaticism also enters the picture. Republican leaders in the House, in particular, are true believers in the miraculous powers of the free market -- they are in effect members of a sect that believes that markets will work even when the businessmen actually involved say they won't, and that government involvement is evil even where conventional analysis says it is necessary.
The Republican plan is, in short, an assertion of a faith that transcends mundane economic logic. But what's in it for us heathens?

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1882 words

HEADLINE: IMPASSE AT CAMP DAVID: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON ENDS DEADLOCKED PEACE TALKS

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
At the end of two weeks of marathon negotiations with the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians, a visibly fatigued President Clinton announced today that they were unable to reach an agreement "at this time."
The president and other American mediators made clear that it was Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who balked in the end, and by all accounts the issue was Jerusalem, the Holy City both Israelis and Palestinians claim as their sacred capital. 
 Speaking at the White House, Mr. Clinton singled out the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, for his readiness to make hard compromises. "I would be making a mistake not to praise Barak, because I think he took a big risk," the president said. "The prime minister moved forward more from his initial position than Chairman Arafat, particularly surrounding the question of Jerusalem."
He also declared that the discussions at Camp David had been "really unprecedented" in raising issues "that had long been considered off limits." The issue of Jerusalem in particular had never been discussed before by Palestinians and Israelis in face-to-face encounters.
"Under the operating rules that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed, they are of course not bound by any proposal discussed at the summit," Mr. Clinton said. "However, while we did not get an agreement, significant progress was made on the core issues."
Mr. Clinton convened the summit talks in an ambitious attempt to reach a sweeping settlement before Sept. 13 on questions -- such as the shape of a new Palestinian state, the future Palestinian refugees -- that have kept the two sides in a state of conflict for 52 years.
No side announced any immediate plans to resume talks, and Mr. Arafat's declared intention to unilaterally proclaim a Palestinian state on Sept. 13 imposed the next serious deadline on a process that has seesawed from hope to despair and back since the Oslo agreements were signed in 1993.
In a somber parting statement, Mr. Barak laid the full blame for the setback on Mr. Arafat, and declared that Israel was prepared for "every possibility." But he did not exclude another try: "The vision of peace suffered a major blow, but I believe that with good faith, good will on all sides it can recuperate."
Mr. Arafat made no comment before departing the United States. But his chief negotiators, Saeb Erekat and Mahmoud Abbas -- more commonly known as Abu Mazen -- put an unexpectedly optimistic face on Camp David, saying that the negotiations had laid groundwork for an agreement by Sept. 13. "What happened at Camp David are seeds that will grow very fast," Mr. Erekat said.
The two-week sequestered talks at Camp David, which included round-the-clock negotiations -- much of the time with Mr. Clinton as mediator and go-between, as well as threatened walkouts and at least one narrowly averted breakdown, marked one of the most intensive mediating efforts by an American president in the Middle East since Jimmy Carter brokered a peace between Israel and Egypt in 1978.
In some respects, it was hardly surprising, Mr. Clinton said, that the summit meeting, with its qualities of an almost brutal showdown in close quarters, had not produced what he wanted. "This is like going to the dentist without have your gums deadened," he said.
At the end, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders left the rainy hills of Maryland for the Middle East confronting the potential for increased violence and political uncertainty -- particularly in Israel, where Mr. Barak faces criticism for considering concessions to the Palestinians.
In a briefing before he left for home, Mr. Barak put the onus of failure squarely on Mr. Arafat. "We were ready to end the conflict, we looked for an equilibrium point that will provide a peace for generations, but unfortunately Arafat somehow hesitated to take the historic decisions that were needed in order to put an end to it," the Israeli leader said.
Mr. Arafat flew out of Washington without speaking publicly. But his aide, Mr. Erekat, insisted that an agreement could be reached no later than Sept. 13. "The prospects for agreement on all permanent-status issues are stronger than at any time in almost nine years," he said.
Instead of the comprehensive agreement the White House had hoped for, the summit talks concluded with a five-point statement of "negotiating principles" agreed to by the Israelis, the Palestinians and the United States.
The document said that the two sides understood the "importance of avoiding unilateral actions that prejudge the outcome of negotiations" and that differences would be resolved "only by good faith negotiations."
More particularly, the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said it was Mr. Arafat who had a lot of thinking to do.
"Barak was far more willing to think out of the box, far more willing to consider, though he never accepted, solutions that could have broken the logjam," Mr. Berger said. "Arafat on the other hand, while he did make some compromises on Jerusalem, was not prepared at this point to crack open his traditional positions."
A best hope, Mr. Berger said was that the summit meeting would provoke a reassessment within the Palestinian delegation, a group of about a dozen of Mr. Arafat's top political and security aides.
Coinciding with the last days of the summit talks, the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, met with other Arab leaders in the Middle East in a spurt of diplomacy, the goals of which were unclear.
But a senior administration official said Mr. Mubarak did not help Mr. Arafat reach the bold decisions that the White House wanted. "I didn't see any evidence that a positive influence was being brought to bear," the official said.
According to officials involved in the negotiations, the prospects for an accord finally fell apart just after midnight Monday night, the second all-night session that President Clinton had led after returning to Camp David from Japan on Sunday evening.
On Sunday and Monday nights, Mr. Clinton worked with negotiators from both sides and progress was reported on the borders of a Palestinian state, on the fate of the three million Palestinian refugees scattered through the Middle East and on security arrangements.
"Then it came down to whether we could cut the Gordian knot on Jerusalem," a senior administration official said.
For what turned out to be the last effort by the president to get the Palestinians to agree to a deal on Jerusalem, Mr. Clinton met with Mr. Arafat sometime after midnight.
By then, Mr. Barak had made what the administration regarded as considerable concessions in relinquishing control to the Palestinians in the outer and inner suburbs of East Jerusalem.
The administration declined to go into precise details today, but in the last week of the summit talks, according to Israeli reports, proposals were put forward by the Americans on concepts of shared sovereignty in East Jerusalem. Mr. Barak was considering these ideas, which represented a radical departure from established Israeli policy that Jerusalem was the united, undivided capital of Israel.
"We believe that the ideas raised by the president were far-reaching and justified a kind of positive response from Arafat. They didn't," Mr. Barak said at his news conference.
But when Mr. Clinton spoke with Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader was unwilling to budge from his position that East Jerusalem must be the capital of the new Palestinian state.
The question of sovereignty over the holy sites in Jerusalem, home to major places of worship for Jews, Christians and Muslims, was at the heart of the problem, the administration official said.
"Think of Jerusalem as four concentric circles," the official said. "Outer suburbs, inner suburbs, the Old City and the religious sites. As you move into the center, the issues become more intense, historical, religious." There was surprising convergence on how different parts of the city would be managed but severe disagreement on the notion of sovereignty.
In that last conversation between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Arafat while the talks were still alive, Mr. Clinton tried to explain, once again, the advantage for Mr. Arafat in making a compromise on Jerusalem.
"The president described one again what was at stake: gaining a state, international legitimacy, international economic support," the official said.
Conversely, if Mr. Arafat let an agreement pass by, he could declare a state but it would be on 40 percent of the West Bank, and the Israeli reaction would be strong -- possibly the forcible annexation of the Jewish settlements.
After Mr. Arafat rebuffed Mr. Clinton, the president's senior aides -- Mr. Berger, the secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, and the senior coordinator for the Middle East, Dennis Ross -- met with one of the Palestinian negotiators.
They discussed, for one last time, the possibility of Mr. Arafat accepting a partial agreement that would deal with the shape of a Palestinian state, refugees and other matters, but would put the question of Jerusalem aside for the time being.
This last effort did not appeal to Mr. Arafat either, who, according to the administration's account, felt that he would lose some of his leverage over Jerusalem if he settled on the other issues first.
At 3 a.m., Mr. Arafat, ensconced in his cabin, called Birch, sent one of his negotiators to Mr. Clinton with a letter. The letter politely thanked Mr. Clinton for his efforts but said that Mr. Arafat could not accept the proposal on Jerusalem.
This morning, Mr. Clinton met separately with the Israeli and Palestinian leaders in sessions that focused on where the peace process would go now.
Then there was a brief meeting of Mr. Arafat, Mr. Barak, and Mr. Clinton, only the second formal session of the three leaders, although they had sat together at dinner several times.
Drained by the exhausting discussions, and in some respects pleased to be out of their confinement -- Mr. Barak referred jokingly to Camp David this morning as a prison -- the leaders went their separate ways.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Barak both focused on the dangers of violence as the Sept. 13 deadline for the unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state approached.
"We are at the end of an important stage of the peace process and at the threshold of an era of uncertainty," the Israeli leader warned before leaving for home.
"Every day they go past it will put more pressure on the Palestinians to declare a Palestinian state unilaterally and more pressure on the Israelis to have some greater edge and conflict in their relations as a result of that," Mr. Clinton said.
The threat of violence came as expected from Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of the militant Islamic group Hamas, who issued a familiar warning to Israel from his headquarters in Gaza. "This failure is another indication that the only choice we have is resistance," he said. "Only by force are we able to retain our rights."
The Israel armed forces chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Shaul Mofaz, said that the Israeli Army was preparing for the possibility of increased violence. "We don't want a confrontation in any way, and a lot is dependent on the Palestinians," General Mofaz said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Unfinished Business of the Camp David Talks"
Under the ground rules for the Middle East summit meeting at Camp David, there would be no agreement unless all issues were resolved. And although negotiators were reported to have made strides on several fronts, after 15 days the talks collapsed over the core issue of sharing Jerusalem. While Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel said that all is now null and void, this is where the talks stood when they ended, according to negotiators and other officials:

JERUSALEM -- Israel had long insisted on its sovereignty over all Jerusalem, whereas the Palestinians saw East Jerusalem as the capital of their future
 
BORDERS -- Israel discussed handing over about 95 percent of the West Bank and all of the Gaza Strip to Palestinian sovereignty in exchange for annexing the other 5 percent, including three major Jewish settlement blocs.
 They also considered swapping land in the Halutza area adjoining the Gaza Strip.

JEWISH SETTLEMENTS -- Israel would annex parts of the West Bank settlements where about 130,000 of the 170,000 Jewish settlers live. The remainder would be allowed to resettle in Israel or remain under Palestinian sovereignty, but with special security arrangements.
All Jewish settlements would be removed from the Gaza Strip.
 
PALESTINIAN REFUGEES -- Israel is believed to have agreed to admit about 100,000 Palestinian refu-gees in a one-time "family reunification program."
 An international body would be set up to monitor the resettlement and compensation of refugees, with an international fund to which Israel would contribute.
 Compensation would be paid to countries that received refugees -- Jordan, Syria, Lebanon and the future Palestinian state -- as well as to the refugees themselves.
 
During the talks, Mr. Barak agreed that the Palestinians could have sovereignty over certain parts of Arab East Jerusalem in exchange for Israel annexing several Jewish settlements adjacent to the Holy City.
The Palestinians were believed to have conceded the principle of Israeli sovereignty over West Jerusalem, as well as the Jewish Quarter of the walled Old City and the Western Wall, but continued to insist on full sovereignty over East Jerusalem. HEADLINE: THE CONCORD CRASH: THE SCENE;
A Symbol of France Crashes in Flames

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ROISSY, France, July 25

 BODY:
Witnesses described the brief, fiery flight of AF 4590 as a vision of hell or a kind of bomb, in flames from the time it rolled down the runway at Charles de Gaulle airport until it smashed three minutes later into a tiny, wooden hotel.
"It was like some bomb taking off," said John Palmerston, an Australian who saw the plane leave the runway from the airport here. "The whole back end of the plane was on fire. I thought it was going to crash right here at the airport." 
 In the little town of Gonesse, barely four miles southwest of the airport, there were reactions of shock and distress. "It was truly a hell; there were flames everywhere," a witness told the French television channel LCI. "There were pieces of the fuselage over more than 200 meters, pieces of plastic, of cloth, bits of metal, pieces of the wing, rivets. As for the hotel, there is nothing left; it was blown to pieces."
According to authorities, 109 people died on the airplane, and 4 more on the ground, apparently in the hotel Hotelissimo . A huge cloud of gray and black smoke surged into the sky, visible for at least 10 miles.
For Fabien Tillon, an official trying to manage the crisis from the local government offices in Cergy-Pontoise, the first crash of a Concorde was also a terrible blow to French pride.
"It's a big national shock," he said, as he tried to handle two telephones and a cigarette. "Many people died, but the symbol of the Concorde, too. The Concorde is a huge national idea for France, a symbol of engineering pride, and the fact that the Concorde crashed, and so many people died, and on the soil of France, it's a terrible shock."
The elegant, needle-nosed Concorde, the world's first supersonic passenger plane, was developed by the French and the British in the 1960's as a kind of response to the American and Soviet technological competition, another version of the cold war.
It also served to heal some wounds left over a veto by France in December 1967 of British membership in the Common Market, now the European Union -- hence the name of the plane. In more than 20 years of commercial flying, however uneconomical and however noisy, the Concorde had never crashed.
Firemen placed traffic cones across a blackened field, apparently marking the places where charred bodies were found. "Once you got used to looking through the smoke, the horror hits you," an emergency worker who had been at the scene told Agence France-Presse. "By the dozens, bodies or pieces of bodies, horribly mutilated. Here and there, shoes, books, parts of suitcases that are wasted away."
At the hotel, another witness told French television that onlookers had smashed a window and tried to get into the building, but the victims inside were already dead. "There was nothing we could do," that witness said.
At least one guest jumped out the window to safety, witnesses said.
Extraordinarily, it seemed, another hotel nearby, Les Relais Bleus, was untouched. "I thought the plane was going to land on my desk," the owner told Europe 1 radio. "I saw it heading for me in flames. I just let go of the telephone and ran."
Mr. Tillon said his staff was unbelieving at first. "Frankly, when we heard the news, we thought it was some kind of joke or an emergency exercise," Mr. Tillon said. "And then we had confirmation, that the Concorde had crashed and presumably everyone was dead. It really came like a blow."
Valerie Tourbon, a Frenchwoman flying today from Charles de Gaulle, echoed the normal sense of pride felt when a Concorde is spotted in the air. "It always excites me to see one," she said. "It makes me proud. It's awful what's happened."
Mr. Tillon described the "red plan" for national emergencies that went smoothly into operation in his department, Val d'Oise, which governs Gonesse. More than 200 firefighters were soon on the scene, along with 110 policemen and 80 gendarmes, 13 ambulances, three helicopters, the prefect and the prime minister, Lionel Jospin.
But even as more emergency workers arrived, their vehicles blocking the roads, there wasn't much to save, Mr. Tillon said. The passengers all appeared to have died, and after the fire was put under control, there came the grisly task of bagging the dead and taking them to the waiting line of hearses.
"First, there was a large explosion, then barely a second later, another large explosion," an office worker said. "We went to the window, and the flames were higher than the trees. When we went outside, pieces were falling down on us." One piece of metal fell on the roof of a colleague's car.
Another witness told French television: "I heard the noise, because each time the Concorde flies over, I always have a look. I saw it coming with an engine on fire, it tried to turn on its left, then it fell and fell onto the hotel."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Upgrading Buildings on Edge of Midtown

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Institutional investors avoided the Midtown South sector of Manhattan for a long time, concentrating on the larger and more glamorous properties in Midtown and downtown. Now, with rents soaring in the area from 34th Street to Canal Street, pension funds and opportunity investors are beginning to plunge in.
Starwood Urban, an affiliate of the the big real estate investor Starwood Capital, has bought the building at 430 West 14th Street, and the New York State Common Retirement Fund pension fund invested $115 million last fall in the old Port Authority inland terminal at 111 Eighth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets. 
 Recently, Koll Bren Schreiber, a pension fund adviser based in Boston, persuaded one such fund to buy two buildings from the late Harry Helmsley's dwindling portfolio, 245 and 261 Fifth Avenue, at 28th and 29th Streets, respectively. The company plans to upgrade the buildings to attract new-economy and service-industry tenants, who have flocked to the Flatiron Building at 23rd Street.
"We are a value-added investor," said Charles A. Valentino, a senior vice president of Koll Bren Schreiber. "We invest capital to improve the quality of a building we think is in an emerging market."
He said the elevators, heating, air-conditioning and lobbies of both late 1920's buildings would be renovated, with new windows going into 245 Fifth. Both buildings will be wired for the high-speed Internet access that virtually all tenants demand today, and bathrooms and common corridors will also be improved.
The two buildings are the first investments in Midtown South for the company, whose sole previous investment in the city was the building at 50 Broadway in the financial district. Mr. Valentino said the company, which controls 74 million square feet of real estate nationally, valued at $4.5 billion, was shopping for additional properties.
"We think New York City will outperform many other markets," he said.
Rental rates in the area have been shooting up in recent months, according to figures compiled by Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and real estate services company. After surpassing $30 a square foot in the first quarter of this year, the average annual rental jumped to $39.65 a foot by the end of June, and in some submarkets actually went over $40.
The effort to reposition the buildings from their current status on the fringe of the garment district to one more oriented toward the booming Flatiron area will be helped by the shortage of space in Midtown South, said Mitchell L. Konsker, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield.
With the vacancy rate in the district at 3.7 percent at the end of June, he said, companies are trying to protect their ability to grow by taking space in buildings where future expiration of leases held by other companies will give them room to expand. Midtown South is generally defined as the area between 34th and Canal Streets, river to river.
"With the tightness of the market, tenants are looking for buildings where there is space for expansion in a few years but where they do not currently have to pay rent," he said.
Matthew R. Astrachan, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, said the expiration dates for leases in effect meant that 250,000 to 300,000 square feet of space would be coming available over the next 24 months, much of it in easily marketable 20,000-to-30,000-square-foot blocks. He said those spaces would be marketed to publishing, advertising and other service industry tenants being squeezed out of streets closer to the Flatiron Building, streets on which rents are approaching $50 a square foot. He said there were now about 100 tenants in the two buildings, with some of them in small spaces.
The plan, Mr. Konsker said, is to reduce the total number of tenants, so that space can be assembled in the more attractive larger blocks.
There is retail space of about 14,000 square feet on the first floor of 245 Fifth Avenue that was formerly occupied by a branch of Chase Bank, which bought out its lease's remaining years. The site, Mr. Astrachan said, is going to be marketed to a "high end" restaurant, which will presumably be attracted by the well-paid professionals coming to the area.
Retail space is available at 261 Fifth Avenue as well, but a restaurant is not likely there because the Marble Collegiate Church is across the avenue and New York City law bans establishments selling alcohol from operating within 200 feet of a house of worship.
There are still garment industry tenants at 261 Fifth, who are so uninterested in the view of the Empire State and Flatiron Buildings available from upper floors that they block out windows in their showrooms so that buyers can see the goods as they will be displayed in stores. Those tenants will be consolidated on a few floors, rather than stay spread around the building, Mr. Konsker said, so that new tenants can enjoy the views and natural light.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RECORD IN CONGRESS;
Though Liked by House Democrats, Cheney Was a Consistent Conservative

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
In his 10 years as a Republican congressman from Wyoming, Dick Cheney had one of the most consistently conservative voting records in Congress.
He regularly voted for the tightest restrictions on abortions, including proposals to ban Medicaid coverage of abortions for poor women whose lives could be endangered by continued pregnancy. And he voted against all gun-control legislation, including measures like one to regulate what are known as cop-killer bullets that were supported by all but a handful of lawmakers from both parties. 
 On issues in which business and labor were on opposite sides, he invariably supported the business position. When developers and environmentalists were at odds, he was on the side of the developers.
He opposed a constitutional amendment to guarantee equal rights to women and voted against economic sanctions on South Africa.
During Mr. Cheney's time in Congress, from 1979 to 1989, Democrats controlled the House. As is normally the case with lawmakers in the minority party, he was not directly responsible for any major legislation.
While rigidly conservative on issues, he was not known for strident rhetoric and was well liked by Democrats. Mr. Cheney was not a visible leader in the fight to outlaw abortion, but the National Right to Life Committee said today that he voted against abortion rights on all the roll calls for which he was present.
For instance, he voted in 1984 to define "person" under discrimination laws to include fetuses. The sponsor of the measure -- which Al Gore, then a congressman, also supported -- said its purpose was to deny federal funds to all institutions performing abortions. Mr. Cheney also supported a constitutional amendment banning abortion, but the issue never came to a vote.
He was an unwavering advocate of the Reagan administration's economic policy of deep tax cuts, more spending for the military and less money for social programs. Annual vote analyses by Congressional Quarterly showed that in most of the years he was in the House, Mr. Cheney supported President Ronald Reagan more consistently than almost any other member of Congress.
In only his second term, he moved into the Republican leadership, and he was the Republican whip, the No. 2 position, by the time he left. Had he stayed in the House, he might well have become speaker when Republicans gained control.
Beyond his leadership responsibilities, Mr. Cheney was most deeply involved in foreign policy and intelligence matters. He strongly supported covert spending for guerrilla forces trying to oust communist governments in Nicaragua and Angola.
In 1987, Mr. Cheney served as the top Republican on the House committee investigating the Iran-contra affair. The committee determined that the administration had raised money selling arms secretly to Iran, then used the proceeds to finance the rebels, known as contras, in Nicaragua. Mr. Cheney voted against the final report, which accused Mr. Reagan of failing to meet his constitutional mandate to "take care that the laws be faithfully executed."
Some issues important when Mr. Cheney was in Congress are no longer in the news. For example, he repeatedly voted to produce the MX missile, a hugely expensive weapon designed to carry 10 nuclear warheads that was the symbol of what opponents considered the excesses of the Reagan nuclear weapons policy.
He also often voted against proposals to apply sanctions on South Africa to protest its apartheid policy, andvoted in 1986 against a nonbinding resolution calling for the release of Nelson Mandela from prison.
In his first year in Congress, Mr. Cheney voted for a constitutional amendment to ban busing for school desegregation. In 1980, he voted against strengthening the laws banning discrimination in housing.
The only time he turned against the Reagan administration on an important issue was in 1985, when he helped lead a revolt against a bill negotiated by the president and Democrats to overhaul the income tax system. He accused the administration of selling out. Even after the bill was modified by the Republican-controlled Senate and came back to the House in 1986, he voted against it.
President Reagan signed the tax bill and considered it one of his foremost legislative accomplishments.
Other issues from that era will be featured in this year's campaign.
On gun control, he was one of just 21 House members to vote against a bill regulating the manufacture, import and sale of armor-piercing ammunition known as cop-killer bullets. He was one of four who voted in 1988 against a proposal to ban firearms that did not contain enough metal to be picked up by a metal detector.
On education, Mr. Cheney often voted against Head Start, the federal preschool program. He voted in 1985 against federal aid to college students, and opposed the creation of the Department of Education.
On the environment, he voted in 1987 against extending the Clean Water Act and in favor of postponing sanctions against cities that did not comply with the Clean Air Act.
Appearing tonight on CNN's "Larry King Live" program, Mr. Cheney discussed his conservative record and said "I'm proud of it."
But he said some votes had been motivated by a concern for fiscal responsibility in an era when the nation did not have the projected surpluses it now had. "I would not vote against Head Start today," he said.
He also spoke in a tempered voice about abortion. "I don't think it should be a defining issue for our party," he said, adding that the party needed to be sensitive to different views about abortion rights.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RUNNING MATE;
The Armchair General: Richard Bruce Cheney

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The night allied warplanes began bombing Iraq in 1991, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney quietly flipped on CNN in his third-floor Pentagon office, ordered Chinese take-out and sat back to watch the Persian Gulf war unfold.
"Everyone was concerned about possible losses, but he was tremendously calm," a former top Cheney aide said. "I asked him why he wasn't more nervous, and he basically said that he was confident that everything was done that needed to be done. Once the airplanes were in the air, we just had to wait." 
 In choosing Mr. Cheney as his running mate, Gov. George W. Bush has turned to an unflappable Washington insider whose easygoing exterior masks a steely confidence, a man who, once he makes a tough decision, never looks back.
"He sort of chews on issues, and chews on them until he makes his mind up," said former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, "then he goes on and he doesn't second-guess himself. He has very good judgment."
Mr. Cheney, 59, who served 10 years in the House of Representatives and four as President George Bush's defense secretary, brings stature, decisiveness and decades of government experience to a campaign sometimes short on all three.
But the real secret to his success may be an ability to wrap a staunchly conservative ideology in a mantle of moderation and civility to get people to trust him and get things done.
It is not just Republicans who feel at ease with Mr. Cheney, who while in the House opposed abortion and gun control and supported aid to anti-Marxist rebels in Nicaragua and President Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" anti-missile shield. Mr. Cheney has a knack for working with political rivals, colleagues say.
Leon E. Panetta, a former Democratic congressman and White House chief of staff, recalled that Mr. Cheney was one Republican with whom he could confide during sensitive Capitol Hill budget negotiations.
"There was never any question he had conservative views, but he was always someone you could deal with and talk to, and never one to demagogue the issues," Mr. Panetta said. "I trusted that what I said would not be used against me in negotiations."
The Wyoming Republican has been a rising star in party circles since he was President Gerald R. Ford's chief of staff, at 34. But that political fire appeared to die out in 1995, when Mr. Cheney ended a brief flirtation with his own presidential campaign, dissuaded by an election shaping up over domestic issues, not security matters. Instead he became chief executive of the Halliburton Company, an oil services and construction company based in Dallas whose revenues have doubled, to $14.7 billion, under his tenure.
What remains in question is Mr. Cheney's ability to wage a punishing presidential campaign. He is not an electrifying speaker. He is a balding, overweight, middle-aged man who is not especially telegenic, though he comes across solidly on television. He never faced a tough race in conservative Wyoming. And he abhors the scorched-earth politics that came to characterize House Republicans under Speaker Newt Gingrich.
"Dick does not bring political sex appeal to the ticket," said Bill Frenzel, a longtime friend and a former Republican congressman from Minnesota. "What he brings is the competence and confidence that if anything happens to the president, the country will have a competent vice president to step in."
Mr. Cheney's selection is the latest in a series of turns that have shaped his personal life and political career.
He is an Ivy League dropout who became a doctoral student in political science. He was the No. 2 House Republican on the path to possibly becoming speaker when President Bush plucked him from Congress to run the Pentagon after the Senate rejected his first choice, Senator John Tower of Texas. He was a military neophyte, avoiding the Vietnam War with student and parent deferments, who steeped himself in military tactics and doctrine and became the most pivotal defense secretary since Robert S. McNamara.
As defense secretary, Mr. Cheney joined a national security team that included Secretary of State James A. Baker; the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Under Mr. Cheney, 24,000 American troops invaded Panama in 1989 to overthrow Gen. Manuel Noriega.
When Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, it was Mr. Cheney who flew to Saudi Arabia to present King Fahd with President Bush's offer to send up to 200,000 American troops to the kingdom. He clashed with General Powell, who recommended keeping economic sanctions in place longer, and prodded the military to plan a larger, more ambitious counterattack against Iraqi forces.
From the start, his stint as secretary was auspicious. A week after taking over at the Pentagon in 1989, Mr. Cheney publicly reprimanded the Air Force chief of staff, Larry D. Welch, for privately discussing options for updating land-based nuclear missiles with influential members of Congress.
A year later, Mr. Cheney abruptly dismissed General Welch's successor, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, for publicly discussing contingency plans for waging war against Iraq.
Even General Powell, a close ally, was not above reproach. General Powell recalled in his memoirs that after one meeting with President Bush during the gulf crisis, Mr. Cheney pulled him aside. " 'Colin,' he said, 'You're chairman of the Joint Chiefs. You're not secretary of state. You're not the national security adviser anymore. And you're not secretary of defense. So stick to military matters.' He made it clear that I had taken liberty for license."
While Representative Cheney had supported most of President Reagan's military buildup, Secretary Cheney presided over a 25 percent cut in the armed services and oversaw a bipartisan process to close hundreds of military bases. He stunned military analysts by canceling plans to build a $57 billion Navy attack plane, the A-12.
He vigorously opposed allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the armed forces. But when a magazine revealed that his longtime spokesman, Pete Williams, is gay, Mr. Cheney defended him, saying, "As long as they perform their professional responsibilities in a responsible manner, their private lives are their business."
Indeed, discretion is a Cheney byword. When President Bush met with his foreign policy advisers during the gulf crisis, Mr. Baker and General Powell typically briefed their senior aides afterward. Not Mr. Cheney.
"Cheney was absolutely mum," said Paul D. Wolfowitz, the third-ranking official at the Pentagon, who was forced to beg colleagues from the State Department and Joint Chiefs of Staff for a briefing.
Friends and colleagues say the perception of Mr. Cheney as boring belies his wry sense of humor. After Jimmy Carter was elected president and considered replacing the chief of staff's job with a decentralized "spoke-in-wheel" system, Mr. Cheney left a broken bicycle wheel in his office as a warning to the Carter team.
Mr. Cheney had three mild heart attacks before age 48 and underwent a quadruple coronary bypass operation more than a decade ago. Since leaving the Pentagon, he has battled a weight problem, gaining as much as 40 pounds. But he still hunts, fishes and hikes in the Grand Tetons near his home in Jackson.
Richard Bruce Cheney was born in Lincoln, Neb., on Jan. 30, 1941. But his father, an Agriculture Department soil conservation agent, moved the family to Casper, Wyo., where young Dick became a captain of his high school football team and president of his senior class.
Mr. Cheney received a scholarship to Yale University but dropped out in his second year because of poor grades. He traveled around the West, at one point laying power lines for an electric company, before settling down at the University of Wyoming, earning bachelor's and master's degrees in political science.
He married his high school sweetheart, Lynne, a political scholar and former head of the National Endowment for the Humanities. The couple has two grown daughters, Mary and Elizabeth.
Mr. Cheney entered graduate school at the University of Wisconsin and, at 27, was selected for a one-year fellowship in the office of Representative William Steiger, Republican of Wisconsin.
Mr. Cheney thrived in the political cauldron of Capitol Hill. When President Richard M. Nixon picked Representative Donald H. Rumsfeld of Illinois to head the Office of Economic Opportunity, Mr. Cheney sent him a 12-page memorandum on how to run the agency. Impressed by Mr. Cheney's ideas and audacity, Mr. Rumsfeld hired him to run the agency's Congressional affairs office.
As happens so often with aspiring aides in Washington, Mr. Cheney hitched himself to his powerful mentor's rising star for much of the next decade. When President Ford tapped Mr. Rumsfeld to become White House chief of staff, Mr. Cheney went along as deputy.
When Mr. Rumsfeld was named secretary of defense, Mr. Cheney, only 34, replaced him at the White House, one of the youngest men ever to hold that job. Dispensing with the perks of office, Mr. Cheney commuted daily to Washington in his 10-year-old Volkswagen, rather than a chauffeured government sedan.
Mr. Cheney's popular touch extended beyond Washington's power corridors. William F. Connelly Jr., a politics professor at Washington and Lee University who was a Congressional fellow in Mr. Cheney's office in 1985, recalled a visit to Wyoming with him.
A group of ranchers had demanded a meeting, angry over the military's plan to use more grazing land to base MX nuclear missiles.
"These big burly ranchers in sheepskin coats, including one guy chewing a nail, were fit to be tied," Mr. Connelly said. "But Cheney just talked them down. He said, 'Look, this is too important to America's defense.' "

HEADLINE: THE CONCORD CRASH: REACTION AT HOME;
News of Crash a 'Bombshell' to Luxury Tour Operator in Germany

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 25

 BODY:
The shaken owner of a German luxury tour operator appeared on national television today to confirm that his company had chartered the Concorde that crashed near Paris, killing 109 people on board and 4 on the ground.
Many of those who died had paid thousands of dollars to be whisked to New York and a waiting cruise ship. 
 Peter Deilmann of Peter Deilmann Reederei G.m.b.H. also expressed the dismay of many Germans who are about to begin their own vacations in August.
"The news was relayed by telephone to me by Air France and it came as a bombshell," Mr. Deilmann said. "We are in a state of deep shock. I can tell you that 99 passengers booked their passage on the aircraft through my company." Almost all were Germans.
Mr. Deilmann, whose company is based in the Baltic port of Neustadt, about 50 miles outside Hamburg, said the passengers came from many regions of Germany. The Foreign Ministry said the single largest group -- 39 -- was from Germany's biggest state, North Rhine-Westphalia.
There were 96 German victims, whom the ministry declined to identify until the families were notified. Most of the passengers traveled from Frankfurt to Paris before boarding the Concorde.
Air France said there were 100 passengers on board -- a figure that apparently included the 99 passengers mentioned by Mr. Deilmann and the lone American on board, who has also not been identified. Christopher Korenke, an Air France vice president, told reporters at Kennedy International Airport in New York that the American was a retired Air France employee.
Three of the passengers were children, the ministry said. The cruise was to have gone through the Caribbean to a final destination of Manta in Ecuador, with an option to sail on as far as Sydney, Australia, and the Summer Olympics.
The passengers on the Concorde had paid between $4,200 and $11,000 for a cruise that was to begin in New York on a luxury ocean liner, the Deutschland.
That ship, two two years old, was built in a Roaring 20's style, with chandeliers, a ballroom, a palm-filled winter garden and a salt-water swimming pool.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder expressed his condolences to the victims' families and canceled plans to see a performance of Goethe's "Faust" at the Expo 2000 world fair in Hanover. The German cabinet, headed by Mr. Schroder, said it would attend an ecumenical service for victims of the crash Wednesday at a chapel on the Expo grounds.
Germany immediately indicated that it intended to play a central role in the investigation of the crash, dispatching the transport minister, Reinhard Klimmt, to Paris and announcing that the federal agency that investigates air crashes would begin an inquiry.
The news punctured a generally upbeat mood in Germany as the chancellor prepared to go on vacation. A strong economy and the passage through Parliament of the largest tax cuts in Germany for many years have bolstered optimism and increased Mr. Schroder's popularity.
Mr. Deilmann said this was the fourth time that his company had offered a Concorde-cruise package -- and would be the last. But the cruise, which had 510 passengers booked, would not be canceled.
"There's no sense letting the ship lie there," he said. "Life goes on."
In New York, some passengers felt differently.
Gitta Schoneberg, 47, and her 48-year-old husband, Willi, were among the hundreds of passengers who had boarded the Deutschland in Germany and sailed into New York on Monday night.
"It will be a sad voyage for us," Mrs. Schoneberg said. "Whenever we look over at an empty seat, we will think of this tragedy."
"It's better to end the cruise here," said her husband. He said this was the most luxurious of the 25 cruises that he and his wife -- both teachers -- had taken since 1990. "I would ask the captain not to go on. We're not in the mood for a party."
