HEADLINE: Multinationals Sign U.N. Pact on Rights and Environment

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 26

 BODY:
Executives of DaimlerChrysler, Nike and Royal Dutch Shell filled a chamber today where diplomats usually conduct business, as the United Nations recruited many well-known multinational companies to help protect workers and the environment in places where governments do not.
Secretary General Kofi Annan organized the session to encourage companies that operate across borders to spread Western-style human and environmental values or risk seeing the erosion of the consensus that favors open trade and investment. 
 Some 50 multinationals joined 12 labor associations and watchdog groups to sign a "global compact" that commits them to support human rights, eliminate child labor, allow free trade unions and refrain from polluting the environment wherever they do business.
Several signers are among the leading targets of protest groups that say the companies exploit workers and abuse the soil, water and forests in poor nations.
"Companies should not wait for governments to pass laws before they pay a decent wage or agree not to pollute the environment," Mr. Annan said after he had presided over the daylong meeting here. "If companies lead by example, the governments may wake up and make laws to formalize these practices."
Since the collapse of world trade talks and noisy street protests last year in Seattle, multinational companies have been scrambling to forge alliances with some of their critics, including unions and human rights and conservation groups. The compact sponsored by the United Nations is the most visible example of such alliances, and it is an attempt by Mr. Annan to make the world body a more effective force for social and labor standards.
The effort seems highly unlikely to alter the global economic landscape immediately. The pact, which took 18 months to negotiate, binds the signers to a declaration of principles rather than a legal code of conduct.
Several watchdog groups said the United Nations was participating in a "bluewash," allowing some of the largest and richest corporations to wrap themselves in the United Nations' blue flag without requiring them to do anything new.
But the session showed how world governments and corporate leaders increasingly rely on each other to demonstrate that they are helping the people left behind when companies move capital and manufacturing plants around the world. The United Nations and other international organizations have tried to address the side effects of growing international trade and investment but have found it difficult to act in isolation. Multinational companies, particularly those subject to barrages of criticism about how they conduct business in poor countries, are now eager to join the organizations.
"This global compact has the potential to become an historic partnership," the chairman and chief executive of Nike, Philip H. Knight, said. "We hope it provides the framework for real global progress versus each of us struggling with these issues alone."
Critics say Nike practices or tolerates sweatshop conditions in its foreign factories and those owned by its contractors. Nike says it adheres to the highest international standards.
Other companies that participated today have also run into criticism for their international operations, especially Shell projects in Nigeria. Numerous watchdogs have said the oil company violated environmental and human rights standards.
Bayer, Dupont, Ericsson, Healtheon/WebMD and Unilever were among the signers, as were Amnesty International and the World Wildlife Fund.
United Nations officials acknowledged that they had trouble attracting some American companies because the companies feared endorsing an instrument that might legally bind them to act in a certain way and subject them to fresh scrutiny. A United Nations official declined to identify companies that decided not to participate.
In the 1980's, the United Nations made a similar effort to forge international standards for foreign investment and workers' treatment. But that collapsed after rights groups, United Nations officials and executives clashed over the terms of the agreement.
This time, Mr. Annan, who became secretary general in 1997, selected nine loosely worded principles drawn from international accords like the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, seeking to build agreement around long-established codes.
Mr. Annan stressed that companies should adhere to the standards even when the nations where they conduct business did not require them to do so. He said a company operating in a country that did not allow free unions should permit its workers to organize and bargain collectively, a position that could put companies at odds with the government of China, where almost all companies that signed the compact have investments.
The United Nations will not insist on strict compliance. Mr. Annan said the United Nations did not have the "capacity or the mandate" to police the companies. Several executives warned that the compact would fail if it became the basis for sanctions.
Some social and environmental groups, including Greenpeace, did not sign the accord. They wrote to Mr. Annan that some of the participants -- the letter cited Nike, Shell and Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining company -- had poor records of operating abroad and did not deserve to be United Nations partners.
The letter urged Mr. Annan to "reassess your overall approach to U.N.-corporate partnerships."
"The mission and integrity of the United Nations are at stake," it added.
Still, some outside observers see the partnership as vital as the world grapples with the reality that nations cannot regulate, tax and set standards for commerce as effectively when companies spread their operations over many countries, rich and poor.
Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, compared the process to regulating labor, food, safety and the environment in the United States, programs that took decades to accomplish.
"There are just a huge number of issues that have to be addressed globally and there is no real infrastructure to do it," Mr. Garten said. "They can only be dealt with in partnership agreements between governments, business and nongovernment organizations."

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 886 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Pulling All-Nighters for the Good of the City

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
RICHARD C. VISCONTI is talking about the highs and lows of a job -- his -- and tracing a jagged shape in the air. A mountain he'd love to ski? The Manhattan skyline his job makes him responsible for? No digressions, please. Mr. Visconti is methodical, focused, exacting, and not one to humor us by going off on tangents about metaphors.
So here are the highs: buildings that collapse, masonry that tumbles, scaffolding that twists in the wind. "Sometimes," he says, "this job's a pressure cooker." 
 And then there were the banner-bearing barges that floated by his office window.
Mr. Visconti is acting commissioner of the city's Department of Buildings. So he is one of the handful of officials who gather, grimly, at urban disasters. When a Brooklyn town house exploded two weeks ago, and when an architectural salvage shop in the East Village collapsed a few days later, he pulled all-nighters.
So what about that word "acting" in his title? He is not doing Shakespeare on the side.
"I can't really answer the question," he says, and neither could a City Hall spokeswoman who was asked why, after 14 months, Mr. Visconti has not been elevated or replaced. He suggests that his status has to do with word he sent to City Hall about the time he was promoted from deputy commissioner, in May of last year. His wife, Ronnie, had been in a serious automobile accident near their home in Jamaica Estates, Queens, and he was concerned about "this issue of timing": his job and her recovery.
She is fine now, and he carries on, a long-serving acting commissioner.
"I've never been concerned about the acting status," he says before listing changes he has had a hand in, from requirements that make new buildings more likely to withstand earthquakes to a new electrical code to a system for filing building permit applications by computer.
But after nine years at the department, first as the assistant commissioner for technical affairs, later as the deputy commissioner, he still sees himself as a "private sector person" and "an architect who had to interface with the department a lot." So he has a sense of the frustration that architects and builders feel about his agency.
"Every project in New York is a contentious project," he says. "You get these lawyers using the department to fight their battles."
Developers, of course, do the same. Once, several years ago, he met Donald J. Trump. "The Donald came in" and talked about the Empire State Building, Mr. Visconti said.
What kind of an impression did Mr. Visconti make? For once, the famously talkative Mr. Trump was silent. After relaying the question, an assistant to Mr. Trump said, "He really doesn't know the man, hasn't had anything to do with him, doesn't have any thoughts on him."
SOME officials suspect that his low profile is a result of his acting status. "We see him on TV, we read about him in the papers, we see him in hearings, but he's not someone we know well," said Lisa Daglian, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields. "The real problem we have is lack of staff at the Buildings Department, and that's something an acting commissioner is stymied by."
Mr. Visconti denies that his 700 employees are too few. "We got more inspectors in our 2001 fiscal year budget," he says. "We needed more inspectors, we testified at the Council that we needed more inspectors, the administration gave us more and the Council gave us more, so we're staffing up now. I feel comfortable with where we are."
That was the acting commissioner talking.
"I can go two, three days without sleep," he says, the private practice architect talking again. "In practice, you spend the day meeting, selling. And you spend the evening trying to do the work."
Mr. Visconti, 53, was a partner at the Manhattan firm Beyer Blinder Belle Architects from 1981 to 1991 and was the director of technical services, overseeing construction documents and specifications. He worked on projects at the South Street Seaport, a 25,000-square-foot ski house in Aspen, Colo., and an addition to the old Barneys store at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street.
"Things were going swimmingly until the economy turned and we had taken on too much overhead." The partners cut their salaries by 50 percent. Then he had to lay off 60 employees. "No one wanted to hear, 'Go to Richard Visconti's office.' Then one day it was my turn."
The firm's senior partner, Richard Blinder, says Mr. Visconti volunteered to leave. "There was a lot of talk about do we have too many partners," Mr. Blinder says. "He just said, 'Look, I'll leave, and he left.' He took the initiative."
Using an administration buzzword, Mr. Visconti calls the brouhaha over the barge banner, a Dirtpile.com sign, "a quality-of-life issue."
He complains about sign pollution, and about enforcement. "We have to take each and every sign violation to criminal court," he says.
The barge had the gall to float by as Mr. Visconti was staring out the window of his office at 60 Hudson Street, an Art Deco colossus that once was home to Western Union.
Mr. Visconti says that when he saw the barge, he said something that could not go in a telegram, a sentence with a four-letter word. How unlikely. How unfocused. But that was after an all-nighter at the Brooklyn explosion.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Calls for Defeat of G.O.P. 'Old Guard'

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 26

 BODY:
Warning against apathy within the Democratic ranks, Vice President Al Gore today urged members of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's organization, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, to set aside doubts about him and work to defeat the Republican "old guard" embodied in the ticket of Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney.
Speaking before a mostly black audience of more than 100 people in a hotel ballroom here, Mr. Gore said the dismaying imperfections of politicians had turned off many people. 
 But he implored his listeners to avoid cynicism, cautioning that their indifference could help elect Mr. Bush and thus allow the Republicans to undermine civil rights, workers' rights, the economy, the environment and health care programs.
"There can be absolutely no doubt that voters will go to the polls choosing between two very different visions for our future," Mr. Gore said. "It is the choice between the old guard that gave us deficits, division and social injustices, and a new vision for prosperity and progress, investment, inclusion and growth to lift up all of our people."
He added: "Do not look at the imperfections and use that as an excuse for closing your heart and turning away. You have to overcome the cynicism, overcome the reluctance, overcome the doubt."
Mr. Gore did not explain what he meant by "imperfections."
His speech capped several days of campaigning in which he has sought to reach out to the party's core liberal wing, which includes environmentalists, unions and black and Hispanic voters. Many polls have shown relatively little enthusiasm among those constituencies for Mr. Gore. And as if to hammer home that point, his audience today applauded only occasionally.
His advisers say they are counting on Mr. Jackson -- who closed his remarks today with a chant of "More with Gore" -- to energize black voters by raising questions about Mr. Bush.
In introducing Mr. Gore today, Mr. Jackson -- once a bitter rival who has become his close ally -- asserted that the Clinton administration's policies had improved the lives of black families. But he also warned that "prosperity fatigue" might be creating apathy among black voters. And then he opened a slashing attack on Mr. Cheney, a former five-term congressman from Wyoming and secretary of defense under President George Bush, the governor's father.
"Dick Cheney voted against Head Start," Mr. Jackson said. "He voted against equal rights for women. He voted against sanctions against South Africa, not once but six times. He voted against freeing Nelson Mandela from jail."
Saying Mr. Cheney's record rivaled that of Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican conservative from North Carolina, Mr. Jackson added, "Beneath the veneer lies an individual of extreme views."
"We all know that image is a big part of high-tech politics," he said. "How somebody looks on TV can hide flaws. Dick Cheney has an image that is palatable. But Jesus warned us to beware wolves in sheep's clothing."
Implicit in Mr. Jackson's remarks was the concern, shared by many Democrats, that the Republicans are winning the public relations battle, successfully wooing centrist independent and swing voters.
Mr. Gore acknowledged that concern, saying, "I do give our opponents some credit" for their tactics.
"They have concocted a strategy of phrases and photo opportunities to convey the impression of inclusion and moderation," he said. "But you and I know this is not about show business. It is about the lives and livelihoods of hard-working families. You know from a hard history and long struggle that talk is cheap. Deeds are what counts."
Mr. Gore also raised questions about Mr. Bush's commitment to civil rights, recalling that the governor had supported South Carolina's right to fly the Confederate battle flag over its state house.
"He took a look up there at the flag pole," the vice president said of Mr. Bush. "He saw the American flag; he saw the dome. But he did not see a symbol of injustice and oppression. Something was wrong with his vision."
In his remarks today, Mr. Gore avoided the raspy, high-energy Southern-preacher speaking style he sometimes assumes when addressing black audiences. Instead, he spoke in a calm, almost easy-going voice as he delved into his confessional themes.
"I ask you to turn away from any who say that politics is not worth your hearts," he said. "Many hearts have been broken. Many have been disillusioned, disappointed; many have turned away. And some of the best and most effective men and women in America now keep politics at an arm's length."
"I will not let you down," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RECORD;
Over the Years, Cheney Opposed U.S. Sanctions

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
During his early years as a White House official and member of the House, Dick Cheney, the expected Republican vice presidential candidate, consistently opposed unilateral American sanctions against nations including Iran, Cuba and South Africa.
More recently, as the chief executive of the Halliburton Company, an energy services company that is in the top 100 American concerns in revenues, Mr. Cheney became a lobbyist for lifting most sanctions. 
 Referring to "my favorite hobbyhorse, the question of unilateral sanctions," he argued in a 1998 speech that "they almost never work."
"It is very hard to find specific examples where they actually achieve a policy objective," he said.
As a new official in the Ford White House in 1974, Mr. Cheney saw the United States government, under pressure from Congress, impose sanctions against Turkey over the Cyprus issue. The action came not because it made sense from a policy standpoint, Mr. Cheney said, but "because the Greek-American lobby was significantly bigger and more effective" than its Turkish-American counterpart.
A decade later while serving in the House, Mr. Cheney twice voted to oppose sanctions against the apartheid government of South Africa.
In the 1990's, as Congress moved twice to increase sanctions against Cuba, Mr. Cheney said, he would have preferred setting up a West Berlin-type enclave of democracy and free enterprise at the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
But Mr. Cheney did back the multilateral sanctions against Iraq after the Persian Gulf war, aimed at curbing its production of weapons of mass destruction.
After he became chief executive of Halliburton, Mr. Cheney joined members of the United States Chamber of Commerce and pro-trade groups under the rubric of USA-Engage. The lobby led a failing effort to block the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act, which bars American investment in those oil-rich countries. Halliburton is also a member of the board of the National Foreign Trade Council, a lobbying group that recently won a victory in the Supreme Court, which struck down a Massachusetts state law imposing state-level sanctions on companies doing business in Myanmar, formerly Burma.
Mr. Cheney's company has already done business in countries still facing American sanctions, including Libya and Iraq, the enemy Mr. Cheney helped vanquish in the gulf war.
"Our government has become sanctions-happy," Mr. Cheney said in his 1998 speech.

HEADLINE: In America;
Retirement Risks

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
In their brief joint appearance on Tuesday, George W. Bush and Dick Cheney both mentioned Social Security first when they referred to some of the big issues facing the country. Both said that strengthening the Social Security system was a priority.
And yet a rigorous analysis by the nonpartisan Century Foundation of Mr. Bush's proposal to allow workers to invest part of their Social Security payroll taxes in personal retirement accounts has determined that the plan would either worsen the system's long-term deficit or lead to substantial cuts in Social Security benefits, or both. 
 The analysis of Mr. Bush's plan was conducted by Henry J. Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution; Alan Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton University and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; Alicia Munnell of Boston College; and Peter Orszag, president of Sebago Associates, an economics and public policy consulting firm.
It is understood that diverting revenue from the Social Security system to individual accounts, by itself, increases the system's projected deficit. The study said: "Compensating for this lost revenue and addressing Social Security's long-term deficit will require some combination of: higher payroll taxes; investing part of the Social Security trust funds in higher-yielding assets (such as stocks); general revenue transfers to Social Security; and/or reductions in Social Security benefits."
The authors went on: "Governor Bush has promised not to raise payroll taxes or invest the trust fund in stocks. He also has proposed tax cuts that would consume virtually the entire projected non-Social Security surplus, leaving no room for transfers to Social Security without causing a non-Social Security deficit. Governor Bush's plan would therefore have to rely on cutting Social Security benefits."
The study attempted to determine whether the proceeds from the individual retirement accounts would be enough to offset the benefit cuts. It came to conclusions that were frightening.
The authors based their analysis on a diversion of two percentage points of the current Social Security payroll tax into individual retirement accounts. And they assumed an inflation-adjusted rate of return on the accounts of 5.9 percent annually, which matched the assumption of Martin Feldstein, an advocate of retirement accounts and a top adviser to Governor Bush.
After extensive analysis, they concluded that substantial cuts in guaranteed benefits for workers 55 and under were inevitable.
"Social Security benefits for 30-year-olds would have to be reduced by 54 percent to extend the solvency of the Social Security system for the next 75 years," the study said. "Even if the stock market performs as well as it has historically, the combined income from the individual account and the scaled-back Social Security system would be 20 percent below current-law Social Security benefits for the average 30-year-old single earner."
That's what would happen if the stocks purchased by this hypothetical 30-year-old did well. But, of course, they might not.
"The conclusion," the authors wrote, "is that Governor Bush's proposal could cut Social Security benefits by more than 50 percent for young workers, and the proceeds from the individual accounts would (on average) make up only a portion of that cut while exposing individuals to significant risk."
Believe it or not, that's the rosier scenario.
The study said: "These estimates are based on assumptions we believe understate the likely reductions in Social Security benefits. Even with these favorable assumptions, the results are dramatic: Governor Bush's plan requires substantial reductions in Social Security benefits and increased exposure to market risks for future retirees. Indeed, the implied reductions in Social Security benefits for future retirees are so substantial, they raise questions about the viability of protecting benefits for current retirees, older workers, disabled workers, and survivors while diverting payroll taxes into individual accounts."
Governor Bush and Mr. Cheney will be rigorously cross-examined on this matter between now and November.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEBUT;
Voting Record Dogs Cheney As G.O.P. Team Campaigns

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CASPER, Wyo., July 26

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush and his new running mate, Dick Cheney, made a whirlwind visit today to the vice-presidential contender's home state, defending Mr. Cheney's conservative voting record and vowing that the ticket would "renew America's purpose."
In their first campaign trip, Mr. Bush struck more partisan tones than usual, hammering away at the integrity and trustworthiness of the Clinton administration. He presented the all-Western Republican ticket as the antidote. 
 "Dick and I both have roots in the West," Mr. Bush of Texas told a chanting crowd packed into the gymnasium of the high school Mr. Cheney, 59, attended more than 40 years ago. "The West is a place full of straightforward people who usually say what they mean and mean what they say."
Then Mr. Bush reached back to one of President Clinton's well-known evasions in the Monica Lewinsky scandal. "The West is full of people who understand the meaning of what the word 'is' is," he said.
A day after Mr. Bush announced that he had selected his father's former defense secretary as his running mate, the Texas governor was quickly hit with questions about Mr. Cheney's voting record in his six terms in the House. He and the Gore campaign engaged in a fierce cross-country competition to define what voters thought about Mr. Cheney.
"I obviously thought about the record," Mr. Bush said. "And this is a conservative man. So am I."
The governor and his aides said the selection of Mr. Cheney showed that Mr. Bush was putting political considerations aside to make a sober-minded decision on a running mate who could serve as commander in chief.
"He brings some strength to the administration," Mr. Bush said in a news conference.
"It speaks volumes that I'm willing to pick somebody who is as strong a man as he is," Mr. Bush said, "that I'm comfortable with having excellence by my side."
The Democrats also said the choice spoke volumes, about whether Mr. Bush really is a new kind of Republican or a throwback to the past. They pointed to Mr. Cheney's conservative voting record as well as his service in the administrations of Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and George Bush.
Mr. Cheney's record included votes against the Head Start education program, against banning so-called "cop-killer" bullets, against imposing economic sanctions on the government of South Africa and against a nonbinding House resolution calling for the release of the anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela.
"I'm generally proud of my record in the House," Mr. Cheney told reporters. He said that he could "probably find some" votes "that I might tweak and do differently."
Mr. Cheney defended his votes, largely cast in the Reagan administration, as appropriate to the 1980's "when we had huge budget deficits, no money and when we really had to be concerned about controlling federal spending."
"Today we're in a different era," he said. "We've got a surplus. We've got the opportunity now I think to go do some things we could not have done 20 years ago."
Pressed by reporters to explain his stance on Mr. Mandela, Mr. Cheney said he had voted against sanctions on South Africa because he has generally opposed unilateral sanctions.
The Republicans also turned aside Democratic questions about their links to the oil industry. Mr. Cheney is stepping down as the chief executive of the Halliburton Company, a worldwide oil services companies based in Dallas.
"I'm very proud of Halliburton," Mr. Cheney said. "I have nothing to apologize for." He described it as a company that had started small as the brainchild of one man and become "the quintessential American success story." Mr. Bush said his opponents were trying to "divert attention from the fact that the Democrats have no energy policy."
The Bush campaign presented the trip to Natrona High School as a sentimental journey to the hometown where Mr. Cheney met his wife, Lynne. He was the class president and a captain of the football team. She was the prom queen, and as Mr. Bush added today, a "nationally ranked champion baton twirler."
It was not a long and lingering homecoming. The appearance in the school, the lone rally of the day, lasted about 45 minutes. Aides said Mr. Cheney had to return to Dallas for a business meeting.
A cheering crowd in the hundreds packed the gym and another 1,000 people waited in a spillover room.
Gov. Jim Geringer warmed up the audience and dismissed the talk of Mr. Cheney's voting record. "I'd rather have Vice President Cheney with his heart, than President Gore with no backbone," he said.
Mr. Cheney gazed out at the crowd and said, "They never treated me this well when I was their congressman." And he joked that when he and his wife were in high school, many would have expected her to return one day along with the candidates for president and vice president. "But they never would have guessed it was going to be me," he said.
It was Mr. Bush, not his running mate, who seemed in a feisty mood. As he brought Mr. Cheney down the aisle of his campaign plane, reporters asked the governor what he thought of the Democrats' reaction to Mr. Cheney.
"What was it?" he asked. "Belittling? I'm not surprised that they would try to belittle the pick. Typical."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford to Lift Fuel Economy Of Sport Utility Vehicles
Ford Motor has decided to increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years, people involved in the company's plans said. The increase would be the first significant change in the fuel economy of any class of passenger vehicle in almost two decades.
Ford is convinced that Americans want to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles and will steer their purchases to companies they perceive as environmentally responsible. Page A1. 

Ruling Could Shut Down Napster
In a major victory for the recording industry, a federal judge ordered the Napster online music service to stop permitting the exchange of copyrighted music owned by the major music labels. The lead lawyer for Napster said the company would immediately appeal, but he added that if a stay was not granted by a higher court, the ruling could have the effect of shutting down Napster altogether. A1.
 
Xerox Shares Fall as Profit Declines
Xerox said that its second-quarter profit fell by half on lower sales and that efforts to turn around operations would take longer than expected. Although the results met analysts' lowered expectations, shares of Xerox fell $3.1875, to $15. Xerox is facing increased competition and is trying to recover from a failed reorganization that prompted the ouster of its chief executive in May. C6.
 
Auditors Criticize Consulting Plan
At a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing, representatives of three major accounting firms strongly criticized a proposal to restrict the types of consulting work that the firms can provide for the companies whose financial statements they audit. C9.
 
Stocks Fall on Profit Warnings
Stocks tumbled after several companies warned that their profits would be lower than expected in the second half of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 183.49 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,516.48. The Nasdaq composite index fell 41.85 points, or 1 percent, to 3,987.72, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 22.05 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,452.42. C11.
 
Daimler Posts Stronger Earnings
DaimlerChrysler posted stronger second-quarter net income but warned that full-year operating profit would face pressure as it disclosed plans to cut costs. "We will not fully match last year's level," the company's chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp, said in a statement, referring to operating profits. The results beat forecasts that were adjusted after previous warnings from the automaker. Its shares rose $1.3125, to $53.5625. C6.
 
Sale of Japanese Bank Postponed
Japanese regulators postponed by one month the sale of the nationalized Nippon Credit Bank to a group of investors led by Softbank, one of the world's largest Internet investment companies, after some of Japan's most powerful politicians applied intense pressure to the Financial Reconstruction Commission. C4.
 
Microsoft Argues for Appeals Court
Microsoft filed a legal document arguing that the government's antitrust case is "completely unsuitable for direct appeal" to the Supreme Court and should go first to the federal appeals court in Washington. C2.
 
Exchange-Traded Funds Gain Favor
Exchange-traded funds -- investment pools that are similar to mutual funds but trade like stocks -- are gaining favor among investors and may soon evolve into a viable alternative to a broad range of traditional mutual funds, two new reports predict. Market Place. C10.

HEADLINE: FORD SAID TO PLAN IMPROVED MILEAGE IN SPORT UTILITIES

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 26

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company has decided to increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years, people involved in the company's plans said today. The increase, amounting to roughly five miles a gallon, would be the first significant change in the fuel economy of any class of passenger vehicle in almost two decades.
Ford is convinced that Americans want to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles and will steer their purchases to companies they perceive as environmentally responsible, the people said. The company's new stance is also a response to environmental concerns about the automobile's role in global warming. 
 At least at first, the company does not intend to pass the extra cost of producing more fuel-efficient vehicles directly to American customers, two people close to the plan said. The company is betting instead that improved fuel economy will increase sales more than enough to offset lower profits on each vehicle. Better gas mileage and lower operating costs for Ford sport utilities could eventually increase demand enough to allow the company to sell them with fewer rebates, and possibly even raise prices.
Ford executives hope that the more fuel-efficient sport utilities will give all of their brands an image of environmental responsibility, people close to the company's planning said. That could help sales of the company's cars, minivans and pickup trucks.
The move by Ford, which sells 800,000 sport utilities a year -- representing about a fifth of its total domestic sales -- is a sharp reversal. The company started and led the decade-long trend toward sport utility vehicles, the biggest of which consume more than twice as much gasoline a mile as the average car. The Ford Excursion is the world's largest sport utility, getting 10 miles to the gallon in the city, and 13 on the highway.
The decision to improve mileage comes even as recent efforts in Congress to mandate an increase in fuel economy have failed, partly because of lobbying by Ford and other automakers.
Much of the mileage improvement will be achieved through changes to Ford's larger sport utilities: the Ford Explorer, Expedition and Excursion, the Mercury Mountaineer, the Lincoln Navigator and the Range Rover. Ford engineers say that there are many small steps that they can take to improve fuel economy, from making auto parts lighter to adjusting engines. But lighter auto parts are usually more expensive, because they need to be made from aluminum instead of steel, while engine design alterations must be made with great care to avoid reducing vehicles' towing capacity. Ford executives declined to estimate the cost of these changes.
Part of the improvement in Ford's average fuel economy will come from the introduction in September of the Ford Escape, which is slightly smaller than the Ford Explorer and uses a lightweight car underbody instead of a heavy pickup-truck underbody. With a four-cylinder engine, the Escape gets up to 28 miles a gallon on the highway
Ford will not achieve its fuel-economy improvement by taking advantage of either of the loopholes that it and others have used in recent years: building vehicles like the Excursion to be so large that they are excluded from the federal averages, and building vehicles that qualify for alternative-fuel mileage credits. The Excursion will be counted as Ford pursues its 25 percent improvement.
Ford, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler are building huge numbers of minivans, pickup trucks and midsize cars that can burn either gasoline or nearly pure ethanol. These vehicles are counted in the averages as though they have triple their actual mileage, even though only 100 of the nation's 170,000 service stations sell ethanol.
Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, is scheduled to fly to Washington on Thursday to announce the company's decision at the National Press Club, people involved in the company's plans said.
DaimlerChrysler and G.M., Ford's main rivals in the sport utility market, declined to comment on Ford's move, saying only that some of their models were already fuel-efficient. Detroit automakers, including Ford, have said in the past that improved mileage for sport utilities would require sacrifices in engine power and vehicle size that American consumers would not tolerate.
Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler each have a quarter of the sport utility market. Foreign automakers divide up the remaining share.
G.M. has just finished improving the gas mileage of its full-size sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks by 5 percent over the last three years by completely redesigning them for the first time in a decade. But G.M. and other automakers have not improved their fuel-economy averages, increasing the power, size and gas consumption of some models even as others have become more efficient.
Ford voluntarily cleaned up its sport utility vehicles' tailpipe emissions two years ago to make them as clean as cars' emissions. While the cost has approached $100 a vehicle, and while many rivals have not yet followed suit, Ford officials say that decision has been a selling point.
William C. Ford Jr., Ford's chairman since the start of last year and a great-grandson of Henry Ford, is an outspoken environmentalist who has called for the auto industry to address global warming. At the company's annual meeting two months ago in Atlanta, he acknowledged the environmental and safety drawbacks of sport utilities.
There have been a few small signs in Washington that Federal fuel-economy standards, little changed since the mid-1980's, might be reconsidered next year. But there is no indication that the government might require nearly as big of an improvement as Ford is planning. Mr. Nasser intends to present the plan as an example of how the auto industry can improve fuel economy voluntarily, and will not call for tighter federal regulations.
Automakers are currently required to sell cars with an average fuel economy -- based on 55 percent city driving and 45 percent highway driving -- of 27.5 miles a gallon and so-called light trucks with an average fuel economy of 20.7 miles a gallon. Sport utilities, vans and pickup trucks are all counted as light trucks and now represent half of the American auto market, partly because manufacturers have switched production away from cars as low gasoline prices and a strong economy in the 1990's produced a soaring demand for large, but gas-guzzling, vehicles. Until now, Ford has barely met the averages, and its sport utilities have done especially badly.
President Clinton raised the fuel-economy standard for sport utilities, minivans and pickup trucks by two-tenths of a mile per gallon in 1993 and 1994, to 20.7 miles per gallon. When Republicans took control of the House and Senate in 1995, they began amending the federal budget each year to prevent the Transportation Department from spending any money to study the issue or tighten standards. Each annual budget since then has included the same prohibition, but support for the provision has dwindled as light trucks have increased as a share of the market.
High gasoline prices prompted an effort this spring by Western senators, whose constituents drive long distances, and by environmentalists, to overturn the ban. Under a recent Senate compromise, the freeze on fuel-economy standards will remain for another year while the National Academy of Sciences reviews federal fuel-economy policy.
Representative Joe Knollenberg, a Michigan Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, has blocked fuel-economy changes on the House side. His chief of staff, Paul Welday, said that Ford's latest move was a good one if it helped sell sport utility vehicles, but would strengthen those who want tighter standards.
"Inside the Beltway, it will only fuel the fires of those who believe that if Ford can do that, everybody else should be forced to do that," Mr. Welday said.
Daniel Becker, the energy policy director at the Sierra Club, said environmentalists would use Ford's decision in their lobbying. "This shows that the people who say you can't make cars cleaner and more fuel-efficient are wrong," he said. "This shows that a company that wants to improve fuel economy can do so."
Ford officials believe that they can improve mileage while maintaining the safety of their vehicles' occupants. Occupants of lightweight, subcompact cars tend to fare poorly in collisions. But a variety of recent studies have found that vehicles weighing 3,000 to 3,500 pounds -- the weight of a midsize or large car -- tend to be very safe; further weight provides only a little additional safety for the occupants, while tremendously increasing the risk to other motorists during collisions. Ford's current sport utilities weigh from 3,700 pounds for a two-wheel-drive Explorer to 7,200 pounds for an Excursion with four-wheel drive.
Mr. Nasser's plans have provoked some nervousness within Ford that the automaker may be limiting its ability to respond if gas prices fall or if consumers begin demanding even more powerful vehicles. "There is a lot of struggle within the company over whether this is the right number and the right time frame," a person involved in the plan said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chief of Spain's Big Phone Company Quits

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN JONES 

DATELINE: MADRID, July 26

 BODY:
Juan Villalonga, the chairman of Spain's vast telecommunications company, Telefonica, resigned today, leaving a once-stodgy Spanish monopoly that he had turned into a giant with fast-growing holdings in Latin America and the Internet.
Speculation had spread that Mr. Villalonga, 47, would resign after today's board meeting in the wake of an abandoned $58 billion merger with the Dutch phone company Royal KPN. The failure of the deal in May, because of Spanish government opposition, humiliated Mr. Villalonga, people close to the company said today. 
 In addition, Mr. Villalonga's clashes with government supporters on the Telefonica board suggest that as much as the revitalized Spanish economy had become more open and entrepreneurial in the last decade, there are limits to antagonizing the country's clubby elite.
Cesar Alierta, 55, chairman of the Spanish tobacco company Altadis, was named to succeed Mr. Villalonga. "The appropriate time has come for a change in the company's leadership," Telefonica said in a statement. What compensation Mr. Villalonga will receive was not disclosed.
Mr. Alierta, who has an M.B.A. from Columbia University, is no stranger to privatization and cross-border deals -- he led his company's $2.4 billion merger with Seita of France. Still, he will be following a remarkable act on the European business scene. Mr. Villalonga took the helm of Telefonica in 1996, when the company was still state-owned. Under the direction of a new center-right government, it was privatized a year later and Mr. Villalonga quickly moved to transform Telefonica into a stellar performer, outpacing other newly privatized European phone companies.
Telefonica made some $21 billion in acquisitions, gaining a huge share of the Brazilian market, as well as chunks in Argentina and Peru. Under Mr. Villalonga's leadership, the company became the largest supplier of telecommunications services in the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world. Telefonica says it reaches a potential market exceeding 550 million customers in 24 nations through affiliates in Europe, the United States, Latin America and Africa. Sales in 1999 approached $21 billion.
Mr. Villalonga also spun off cellular phone and multimedia businesses, as well as the Internet arm, Terra Networks. The spinoffs -- taking advantage of the market's voracious appetite for such businesses -- and Mr. Villalonga's aggressive, flashy style won over investors. Shares of Telefonica have risen sharply since Mr. Villalonga took over, though dropping amid the management uncertainty in recent months. Today, the company's American depository receipts rose $1.875, to $67.3125.
The change of leadership seemed largely a relief to investors and analysts, who said Telefonica was likely to maintain its course. "Over the medium term, there might be some volatility in Telefonica shares," said Glen Spencer Chapman, an analyst with Ibersecurities here. "But it's a good company and cheap compared to other telecoms in Europe. It would appear that Telefonica will go ahead with the deals it has on the horizon."
Another analyst, Nahum Sanchez de la Madrid, of Benito Monjardin, said Mr. Villalonga's resignation "eliminates the uncertainty which has sapped confidence in the company over the past several months."
Telefonica's $12 billion planned acquisition of Lycos, the American Internet portal, will not be affected by the change, executives said today. Robert J. Davis, Lycos's chief executive, said Mr. Villalonga's resignation removed a cloud over the merger. "It now becomes clear to our shareholders that the deal will get done," he said, noting that the merger agreement did not give Telefonica or Terra the right to back out. Lycos shares gained 10 percent today.
Mr. Villalonga's departure came after signs that the close political ties that had put him at Telefonica's helm were starting to unravel. He was a high school classmate of the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, and after years with the consultants McKinsey & Company and with Credit Suisse First Boston and Bankers Trust, he was put in charge of privatizing Telefonica by Mr. Aznar's new government. With official support, he challenged ingrained Spanish business practices.
But his rough-and-tumble deal-making ways in time exacted political costs. In March's general election, the opposition Socialists made much of the millions of dollars of stock options Telefonica had awarded Mr. Villalonga and other top executives. They accused Mr. Aznar's government of rewarding cronies while ignoring the poor.
And last month, the newspaper El Mundo reported that Spain's stock market authority had reopened an investigation into accusations that Mr. Villalonga purchased company options as Telefonica was negotiating an alliance with WorldCom. The accusations first circulated two years ago, but regulators said then that they had found nothing illegal.
Mr. Villalonga has denied the insider-trading charges, saying he had bought the options on 264,244 shares two months before the alliance was announced.
He has also became fodder for Spanish gossip columns after he separated from his wife last year and began dating a former Mexican beauty queen who lives in Miami. His jet set lifestyle did not find favor among ordinary Spaniards.
More important, Spanish nationalism derailed Telefonica's biggest cross-border deal. In May, the government and two banks represented on Telefonica's board, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and La Caixa, helped scotch the KPN merger. While Mr. Villalonga had sought a deal so as to create a pan-European network of fixed-line, data and wireless services, Madrid officials opposed the linkup, arguing that the Dutch government would be the biggest shareholder in the new company. The government threatened to use its golden share in Telefonica to torpedo the deal.
Mr. Villalonga "was maybe too independent for BBVA and La Caixa," Mr. Chapman of Ibersecurities said. "Sometimes, Mr. Villalonga was perceived as too aggressive."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Samaranch Says I.O.C. 'Has a New Philosophy'

 BODY:
With only 50 days remaining before the opening ceremonies of the Summer Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, was interviewed yesterday by Christopher Clarey of The New York Times. The interview took place in Samaranch's office overlooking Lake Geneva at the I.O.C.'s headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland, and it covered a wide range of topics, from preparations for the Summer Games to the continuing investigation into possible bribery and fraud in Salt Lake City's bid to be host of the 2002 Winter Olympics.
 
Q. How important do you think Sydney is for the future of the Olympics and how important is the success of Sydney after the problems of the last couple of years? 

A. I would not like to link what happened in Salt Lake City with Sydney. Because what happened in Salt Lake City, the I.O.C. really was affected. It affected some of our members, the organization, myself and so on. But I can assure you the Olympic Games was not affected and I can tell you for example that now we are waiting for the candidates for 2008. That decision will be made next year. We have 10 candidates, 10 very strong candidates, and that means that the prestige of the Games are not affected.
Speaking with regards to Sydney, we want to have a great Games. If it's possible, the best one. We don't know. The day before yesterday I was in Athens. I had a lovely tea with the president of the organizing committee of the Sydney Games, Michael Knight. And he's very happy, and if he is very happy, I am very happy.
 
Q. What are the positive aspects of Sydney from your point of view at this stage, and what are the aspects that concern you?
 
A. The positive aspects is that they work very well. They work on time. All the sports facilities were ready one year before. We could have pre-Olympic events to test these events at all the Olympic sites and Australia is a country which is crazy about sport. They expect great results from their team, around 60 medals. This is fantastic for a country of 19 million people and the bad thing for me regarding the Games is that they are in the spring in the Southern Hemisphere . Spring is not very warm. It could be cold. We could have rain, and that is, for me, the main problem.
 
Q. Has there been progress on the idea of having South Korea and North Korea marching together in the opening and closing ceremonies in Sydney?
 
A. I wrote to the two presidents to have the possibility of a joint team with the same uniform maybe and they discussed it during the visit of the president of South Korea to North Korea, and we got the official answer from South Korea:. they agree. But as of today we have not had an answer from North Korea.
 
Q. Do you expect you will have one soon?
 
A. We need it soon. In two weeks it will be too late. Not to parade together but to parade together in the same uniform, it will be too late in two weeks. Because the I.O.C. offered to present the same uniform for both teams. It was a present of the I.O.C.
 
Q. What will the I.O.C. do in Sydney to attempt to project a more open, accessible approach, to combat the image it has as a closed, pampered club?
 
A. The most important thing is that the I.O.C. has a new philosophy and that inside the I.O.C. we must have many members coming from international federations, many members coming from national Olympic committees. And also we have a fourth partner now, a very important partner, those are the athletes.
At this moment, we have 113 members and 30 of these members, they took part in the Olympic Games and 16 of these 30 members, they won medals in the Games. And that means that more than 25 percent are athletes or ex-athletes. In Sydney, during the Olympic Games, we will elect eight new members of the I.O.C. coming from active athletes. They will be elected by 10,000 athletes in the Olympic Village. And one of these eight will even sit on the executive board of the I.O.C., which means the government of the I.O.C.
 
Q. How will the I.O.C. project itself in Sydney? Will you still be in the finest hotels and driving around in chauffeured cars?
 
A. We will be in a hotel, a normal hotel. I will have my bedroom and a living room to meet with the people from the delegations who want to see me. That is what I need.
 
Q. And for transportation?
 
A. We will have a van to have some people with me, and we'll see. Listen, I need a car, don't I? But it will be a van.
 
Q. Do you have any research that shows the effect of your reforms on public opinion of the I.O.C.?
 
A. I think the situation is much more quiet. This very big scandal that you mentioned was a very big scandal in the United States and some other countries but I can assure you that this was not the case in all the countries.
 
Q. There are very likely to be Aboriginal protests of some form in Sydney. Are you concerned there will be any negative impact on the Games?
 
A. I don't think so. Because all the Aboriginal people are Australians. Maybe they will demonstrate on the occasion of the Games because they have a very important showcase, but also I think they are very much interested in the success of the Games. I will arrive in Sydney on the third or fourth of September. If I can meet with them again, I am ready.
 
Q. Michael Johnson and Maurice Greene are not going to be running in the 200 meters in Sydney, because of what happened in the American Olympic trials. Would the I.O.C. ever consider giving a wild-card berth to defending champions as the International Amateur Athletic Federation has done with track and field world championships, or do you believe the system is fine the way it is now?
 
A. The wild cards are not the responsibility of the International Olympic Committee. It must be a request coming from the I.A.A.F. If the I.A.A.F. makes this request, I think the International Olympic Committee is ready to study this request in a positive way.
 
Q. Does the I.O.C. want to ensure the best athletes are at the Games in their best events?
 
A. It is an American problem, 100 percent. If Greene and Johnson are not there, then two other Americans will be there, and as you know, in your country, you have a lot.
 
Q. Tom Welch and Dave Johnson have been at the center of the Salt Lake City scandal and now they have been indicted. Is that a sign of Salt Lake City's failings or the I.O.C.'s failings? And how do you view their indictments on a personal level?
 
A. I was not surprised, because all the people said that Welch and Johnson would be indicted, but personally I can say that with them I had a very good relationship. They were very friendly and very cooperative always with me and the I.O.C.
 
Q. But is it primarily a failure on the Salt Lake City end or I.O.C. end?
 
A. What I have a right to say is that it was a mistake by some members of the I.O.C. and also, it was a mistake on the other side.
 
Q. You have been to Athens recently. How is the situation evolving there since you expressed your concerns publicly about the organization there?
 
A. Much, much better. The day before yesterday I was with the prime minister, Costas Simitis, and I also had a short talk with the president of the country, and the appointment of the new president of the organizing committee is Madame Gianna Angelopoulos and I think it was the best decision. She was a great victor when she brought the Games to Athens for 2004. Now she is there and she is running the team she had during the bid and we are confident now that things are going in the right way.
 
Q. You have been quoted as saying you wish you had stepped down as president after the Barcelona Games. Is that true and if so, why?
 
A. Yes, it is true. Because after the great success of Barcelona in my city, I was at that moment 71 or 72. It was the right moment maybe to leave. But on this occasion, I allowed myself to ask for re-election for four more years, because in the four years to come there would be the centennial of the I.O.C. and a big congress in Paris and to be the president of the I.O.C. was a great honor on the occasion of the centennial. But after, there came the last election in 1997, and maybe yes, that was a mistake. Maybe.
 
Q. Six of the seven I.O.C. presidents have been Europeans and there has been one American, Avery Brundage. Do you think it is desirable to have a greater geographical representation in the future?
 
A. Maybe yes, but Europe is very important in the Olympic movement. Speaking of the Summer Games, maybe 60 percent of the medals and 60 to 65 percent of the participants are from Europe and for the Winter Games, maybe 85 percent of the medals and participants are coming from Europe.
 
Q. What sort of qualities do you think your successor will need to succeed in the role of president in the years ahead?
 
A. I think it serves no purpose to give advice or to recommend certain types of qualities for the next president. After you're gone, you're gone. But maybe one important thing is that the next president must be a full-time president, like me, and living in Lausanne, because if not, you are giving all the powers to the I.O.C. staff. And the staff of the I.O.C. and also in all the other organizations must be responding to the decisions of the elected people.
 
Q. Do you think that unlike you, he or she should draw a salary?
 
A. Why not? If he does not have the economical means to not be paid, he must be paid, like many international federation presidents and international organization presidents are paid.
 
Q. Some people believe that the 2008 Games will be the last in which the Internet does not play a major role in viewing and the last before the sports program evolves. Do you agree and how do you envision the I.O.C. negotiating this transition?
 
A. Maybe the next president can change many things in the program. Maybe. I couldn't, because to accept new sports is very easy, but to get rid of sports is quite impossible. But maybe the next president can succeed where I did not. As for the Internet, we don't know. That is something which is a mystery for us about the future of television and the Internet and for this reason in November we are organizing a big congress to have some light shed on what the future of the Internet and television will be. What we have to guard against is not to pit the Internet against television. I'm speaking for today. I don't know what can happen one or two years from now. At this moment, I believe we have to put the Internet and television together.
 
Q. There has been an increasing number of prominent athletes switching nationalities. Eunice Barber, the heptathlon world champion who was born in Sierra Leone, became a French citizen shortly before winning. Lyudmila Engquist became a Swedish citizen shortly before winning a gold medal in the hurdles in Atlanta. Does it concern you that as nationality becomes a commodity, it might dilute the impact of the Games?
 
A. In the I.O.C. we have a rule and the rule is that if you are to change nationality, there must be an agreement between the two Olympic committees and if there is no agreement, you must wait three years. If a boy is marrying a German girl and gets German nationality, normally he can compete for that new country. I think in your country, you have a good example with your professional leagues. They are full of foreign people. We have our rule that's all, and we are respecting this rule.
 
Q. You said last year that "I used to be happy to open the door of my office. Now, I am happy if I close it behind me." How do you feel now?
 
A. I said this because last year was not an easy year for me, to be the leader, to try to get through these reforms, because the members of the I.O.C., when they were elected, they had a lot of powers and prerogatives and to convince them it was time to change and to give up many prerogatives, like the visits to the bidding cities for the Olympic Games and so on, was not easy.
So that means at that moment, it was not easy. Now, it's a pleasure again, but I'm also thinking that this pleasure will not last very long.
 
Q. You're referring to the end of your term next year?
 
A. In 11 months, I will be an ex-president.
