HEADLINE: Ford Says Research Inspired New Push for Fuel Economy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
For years, automakers insisted that the technology did not exist to improve the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles and that Americans were not especially interested in gas mileage.
But today, the Ford Motor Company reversed course and announced plans to improve the gas mileage of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over five years, or roughly five miles a gallon, saying that the technology already exists to do so and that customers actually want better fuel economy. 
 Until recently, Detroit carmakers cited research showing that fuel economy was near the bottom of 25 criteria considered by buyers of sport utility vehicles. But Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said today that fuel economy was among the top 10 criteria for buyers of the vehicles. Ford's market research, rather than the gut instinct of executives, prompted the company's decision to make changes, he said.
Kelly Brown, Ford's director of vehicle environmental engineering, told reporters here that the technology already existed for improving fuel economy affordably through engine and transmission changes and lighter auto parts.
"Everything we're doing is something already tested and proven, and some of it is already in production elsewhere" within Ford, he said.
Martin B. Zimmerman, Ford's vice president for government affairs, said after Mr. Nasser's speech that while customers seldom volunteered an interest in fuel economy, in-depth research disclosed that buyers wanted better gas mileage.
"You ask them, 'Do you like our vehicles?' and they say, 'We love them,' " he said. "But you ask them, 'What would you like to change?' and they say, 'We'd like greater range, better fuel economy.' "
Standing near Mr. Zimmerman, Janet Mullins Grissom, Ford's vice president for Washington affairs, interjected that market research into Americans' views on fuel economy "is just like polling -- it depends on how you ask the question."
Mr. Nasser and Mr. Brown refused to discuss the technologies or the cost of Ford's decision, saying that this would be valuable information for rivals. People involved in the plan said the cost was considerable but declined to provide figures.
Analysts said it was impossible to distinguish Ford's fuel-economy spending from other vehicle design costs. And competition from foreign automakers is already forcing Ford to invest more in the design of sport utility vehicles, they added.
Sport utility vehicles used to be strictly the province of Detroit manufacturers, which were under little pressure to respond to consumer demand. Federal fuel economy rules are much more lenient for sport utility vehicles than for cars. And until a series of court decisions in the early 1990's, the sport utility market, unlike the car market, was protected by stiff import taxes that discouraged foreign automakers.
Now, foreign automakers are shipping more sport utility vehicles to the United States, while Honda and Toyota are preparing to build full-size sport utility vehicles in the Midwest. The foreign brands tend to be much more fuel efficient than the American brands because most of them are based on lightweight car bodies instead of the heavy pickup-truck underbodies that Detroit still uses. The market has been growing swiftly for small car-based sport utilities, which tend to be less polluting and more fuel efficient than bigger models and less dangerous to other motorists during crashes.
During a question-and-answer session after Mr. Nasser's speech, which was delivered at the National Press Club here, he challenged Ford's rivals to match its decision to raise average fuel economy for sport utilities by 25 percent. "If General Motors and Chrysler and others want to make that commitment -- that's a commitment; it's not words; it's a commitment -- then we'd welcome their inclusion in this," he said.
He later added that G.M. and Chrysler also had the technical capability for such an improvement.
William Noack, a G.M. spokesman, said that General Motors models had better fuel economy than Ford models in many market segments, including full-size pickups, and that G.M. intended to keep that lead. But he added, "I don't think we're going to be making any commitments, but we're going to make progress."
DaimlerChrysler declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Tensions Build for Inauguration in Peru

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 27

 BODY:
In this capital today women were washing Peruvian flags they say have been sullied by President Alberto K. Fujimori, vendors were selling crude gas masks and riot police were taking up positions.
Mr. Fujimori is to begin his third five-year term on Friday, having resisted pressures for democratic reforms. It promises to be a raucous inauguration. 
 Through a mix of economic populism, political repression and deal making in Congress, he has tightened his grip on power since his re-election eight weeks ago, which was roundly criticized for vote tampering and campaign dirty tricks.
After the voting, Mr. Fujimori promised to work with the Organization of American States to strengthen the independence of the judiciary, to revamp electoral agencies and to expand freedom of the press. He has, however, reduced the influence of officials in his government who have most advocated reform.
The opposition, led by Alejandro Toledo, the business professor who dropped out of the presidential race a week before the May 28 runoff, has organized more than 100,000 people across the country to march in an attempt to discredit the inauguration. But efforts to block the ceremony have been dropped.
Mr. Fujimori has appeared oblivious to criticism from the United States and many Latin American and European governments. "The opinions of other countries are not important to us," he said recently.
In the lame-duck Congress, Mr. Fujimori pushed through legislation that gives the agency regulating telecommunications more power to monitor private phone conversations and to obtain access to computer and telephone records without court order. He also has broken with his usual free-market policies, through a new law that removes tax benefits for foreign mining companies that reinvest profits in the country. He has blocked several privatizations in order to maintain control over gas and water prices as well as to shore up a government pension fund.
The moves have upset businessmen and Wall Street analysts, who express concerns that Mr. Fujimori will use populist economic policies to buttress his political position.
In addition, Congress acted not only to clear high-level Fujimori campaign officials of charges that they led an effort to forge a million signatures to put the president on the ballot, but also voted to make four whistle-blowers who exposed the forgery criminally liable. The charges of forged signatures, substantiated by the newspaper El Comercio, were a large factor in Mr. Fujimori's failure to win a first-round victory.
The Organization of American States is continuing to press for a democratic opening, but Mr. Fujimori has refused to follow a demand that he fire his intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, for campaign abuses.
So far, Mr. Fujimori has not faced international sanctions aside from a few mostly symbolic actions by the United States Congress, which delayed delivery of $42 million in foreign aid and excluded Peru from a recent $1.3 billion antinarcotics package that primarily helps Colombia, but also Ecuador and Bolivia.
The Clinton administration has signaled that it will continue to work with Mr. Fujimori, particularly on antinarcotics programs. Still, it expressed strong comments about Mr. Fujimori when Ambassador John Hamilton told a July 4 gathering here that "cosmetic or superficial changes will not resolve the crisis of credibility."
Mr. Hamilton will lead a spare United States delegation to the inauguration. The only foreign presidents to attend will be Hugo Banzer of Bolivia and Gustavo Noboa of Ecuador. Nine Latin American presidents attended Mr. Fujimori's last inauguration in 1995.
Mr. Fujimori has tried to head off a chilling of relations with Washington by ordering the air force to deploy 18 Sukhoi-25 tactical fighter jets, formerly used as a deterrent against Ecuador, to fight the drug trade.
The opposition had placed its hopes on international influence, believing that the United States and the Organization of American States might even prevail on Peru to hold new elections. But now Mr. Toledo and other opposition leaders are expressing bitter disappointment, going so far as to accuse the regional group of complicity in Mr. Fujimori's election victory.
A dozen or so opposition legislators have changed sides in the last two months, so Mr. Toledo's ability to pressure Mr. Fujimori has decreased. In one case, a former Toledo ally in the new Congress changed his allegiances after judges friendly to Mr. Fujimori reversed an embezzlement conviction against him.
In one gesture today, the Fujimori government pardoned and freed eight people who, according to a government-appointed commission, had been falsely prosecuted on terrorism charges. But 46 other pardon requests presented to Mr. Fujimori last December remained unanswered.

HEADLINE: Alvin Alm, 63, a Leader in Environmental Policy

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Alvin L. Alm, a businessman and senior government official who helped create environmental and energy policy in Republican and Democratic administrations for four decades, died on Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 63.
Mr. Alm was stricken at his home in nearby Falls Church, Va., apparently with heart failure, said Allen Moore, a colleague at Chambers Associates, a public policy consulting firm where Mr. Alm was president. 
 As an expert in budgeting, economics, regulation and the other fine details of environmental policy, Mr. Alm operated just under the bureaucratic rank where public service translates into renown. Although virtually every policy maker in his field knew of his work, the influence of the jobs he held, like assistant secretary of energy for environmental management and deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, far exceeded his public name recognition.
Mr. Alm spoke lightly of his many moves into and out of government, once saying, "I have to confess I am a recidivist." One reason he came and went was that the most powerful figures in the federal government called upon him at critical moments.
For example, when the Environmental Protection Agency was in crisis during the Reagan administration, with Administrator Anne Gorsuch's resignation under pressure for her handling of the Superfund and other programs, Mr. Alm returned for a second stint at the agency under William D. Ruckelshaus, whom President Ronald Reagan had called back to salvage the E.P.A.'s bruised reputation.
Alvin Leroy Alm was born in Denver, graduated from the University of Denver in 1960 and earned a master's degree in public administration from the Maxwell Graduate School at Syracuse University.
He worked on environmental matters in the Washington bureaucracy for several years and by 1970, when the modern environmental movement reached full flower, held a crucial post as staff director of the newly created White House Council on Environmental Quality.
He helped develop the landmark Clean Water Act of 1972 and moved to the Environmental Protection Agency, then in its infancy, as assistant manager for planning and management. There, from 1973 to 1977, he helped devise the system of water pollution permits that put the law into force.
During the energy crisis of the late 1970's, he worked on energy policy for the Carter administration and moved to the Energy Department for the first time.
Throughout his long career, Mr. Alm took on some of the most intractable of problems. His most recent tour in government was from 1996 to 1998, as President Clinton's assistant secretary of energy in charge of cleaning up the nation's nuclear weapons complex, overseeing a program of about $6 billion a year.
Outside government, he was chairman and chief executive of the Thermal Analytical Corporation, an environmental testing concern, from 1985 to 1987; chief executive of another technical consulting company, the Alliance Technologies Corporation, from 1987 to 1989; and senior vice president of yet another, the Science Applications International Corporation, from 1989 to 1996.
In the early 1980's he was at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard as a lecturer and head of a research program.
His marriage to the former Ronnie Elwell ended in divorce. He is survived by a daughter, Jessica Alm of Boston; a sister, Carol Birza of Denver; and his companion, Mary Clark of Washington.

HEADLINE: Luba Journal;
A Corner of Africa Where Dreams Gush Like Oil

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: LUBA, Equatorial Guinea

 BODY:
Not counting the yapping cocker spaniel that was terrifying some men who were practicing witchcraft in the jungle the night before and now feared being found out by the sharp-eyed dog, this town was pretty much dead on a recent Saturday morning.
A drizzle from the clouds on this side of the volcanic island of Bioko -- slightly more than half the size of the state of Rhode Island -- had kept most people indoors. A handful of children splashed in the murky canal that snakes through this town. A large monkey lay dead on a front porch, waiting only for the kitchen. 
 A knock on the governor's temporary house (the longtime president of this tiny Central African nation, Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, has grown so fond of the governor's house that he has appropriated it for his visits here) found the man in question, Deogracias Miguel Olomo, looking relaxed in sweats.
"Just a couple of years ago, there was absolutely nothing here," Governor Olomo told an unexpected visitor. "Now Luba can be, well, not the capital. But it can be the economic capital."
If Luba, population 3,000, is thinking big these days, it is merely a reflection of the national mood. Equatorial Guinea, once the penniless neighbor in a region awash with oil, has finally hit the jackpot. With perhaps 120,000 barrels a day of crude, and much more to come, forgotten towns are now daring to dream of El Dorado.
After the Spanish colonialists left in 1968, Luba, despite being the second town on this island after the national capital, Malabo, sank into darkness. With nothing going on here, people stepped back into the jungle to hunt and grow crops. The roads linking Luba to Malabo to the north and Riaba to the east became virtually impassable.
Today, while much of the road to Riaba remains hidden under overgrown trees and bush, workers are digging up and paving over the way to Malabo. A new port for the oil companies is being built here.
As for Equatorial Guinea's government, it says it wants to develop every town in the country. And to that effect, it has adopted a novel strategy: in June it moved the entire government, or most of it, off this island and onto the mainland in the city of Bata.
Gabriel Nguema Lima, the secretary of state at the Ministry of Mines and Energy and a son of President Obiang, explained that the move would perhaps last six months. After that, the government will keep moving to other towns, returning to Malabo after an indefinite journey, Mr. Nguema added.
In Malabo, the move caught most people unawares. That was hardly a surprise in a country with no daily newspapers and a history of authoritarian, corrupt governments.
At El Sabroson, a restaurant on Avenida de la Independencia, a couple of days before he was scheduled to join his colleagues in Bata, the information minister, Lucas Nguema Esono Mbang, was having lunch with a ponytailed Spanish businessman.
"By moving the government away from here," the information minister said, picking at his plate of antipasto, "we can redevelop the entire country."
The Spanish businessman, who was awarded a government contract earlier that day, nodded.
"In fact," the information minister went on, "Spain should follow our example by moving the government to Barcelona or the Basque country."
"Exactamente," the Spanish businessman said, looking down at his plate.
"You know, he is a great admirer of Franco," the minister said of the businessman.
"It's true," the businessman said. "Authority is good! That's why this country is good. You can leave 100,000 francs on this table," or about $150, he went on, "and no one will take it. Liberty! What is liberty if you cannot leave 100,000 francs on this table without worrying?"
A few blocks away, at the headquarters of the Union Popular, an opposition party, people ascribed different motives to the government's move to Bata.
Fabian Nsue Nguema, the party's secretary general, brought up the point that in the final months of the administration of Francisco Macias Nguema, the country's first president, the government was also moved to the mainland. President Macias, a brutal dictator, eventually placed the government in his hometown, Mongomo, at the country's easternmost point. Shortly after that, he was toppled and then executed by his nephew, the current president, in 1979.
"It's a dictatorship," Mr. Nsue said of the government. "What distinguishes dictatorships is that they are afraid. So they are afraid and want to move from place to place."
Agapito Ona Nguema, another party officer, added: "Why do they have to move from place to place to develop the country? Your government in Washington, does it have to move to New York or Los Angeles to develop them? And yet they are developed, right?"
The president's family, a subclan of the Fang ethnic group, has controlled the country since independence. Though they come from the mainland, they have governed from Malabo, the capital established by the Spaniards. An ethnic group known as the Bubi makes up the indigenous people of Malabo and the rest of the island of Bioko.
A couple of years ago, enough resentment toward the mainland rulers had built up that some Bubi rebels killed two soldiers here in Luba and marched north toward Malabo. They were stopped near the capital by soldiers, who are believed to have carried out reprisal attacks in and around Luba.
These days, things seemed to have settled down. Filiberto Estrada, 27, a mason, is one of the many people who have gravitated here after hearing of job opportunities. He has not found one yet, complaining, as do many other jobless young men, that the jobs go to those with connections to the governing party.
He did not understand why the government was packing up and going to Bata.
"It's the first time I've heard of it," Mr. Estrada said. He added, with a smile: "Each country has its own way of doing things. And here in Equatorial Guinea, we have our own way of doing things."

HEADLINE: Data Leave Rate Picture Unclear

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Employment costs rose moderately in the second quarter but orders for durable goods skyrocketed in June, the government said today in two closely watched reports that left the outlook for short-term interest rates wide open.
The Labor Department said the pay and benefits of workers rose 1 percent in the April-June period, less than expected, possibly giving the Federal Reserve some comfort as it debates whether to raise interest rates again to slow the economy. 
 But in another report, the Commerce Department said soaring demand for commercial aircraft had increased orders for costly manufactured goods in June by the sharpest rate in nine years, indicating that the industrial sector might be speeding up instead of slowing.
Analysts said the data did little to clear up the fundamental issue facing the Fed: Has the economy slowed enough to eradicate the threat of higher inflation?
Fed policy makers will next meet on Aug. 22. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has told lawmakers he will need to see more firm evidence of the much-awaited slowdown to determine whether the Fed's six rate rises since last June have done the trick or whether more are needed to keep the lid on inflation.
The report of a 1 percent gain in the second-quarter Employment Cost Index, a broad gauge of what employers pay in wages, salaries and benefits, was below both the 1.4 percent increase in the first quarter and the 1.1 percent increase forecast by economists for the second quarter.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Accord With Vietnam: Exports in Place of Enmity

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, July 26

 BODY:
Just a few weeks ago, foreign executives here looked at Vietnam and saw a Communist backwater dabbling halfheartedly in free enterprise and foreign investment.
Today, they see a budding market in a country that has signed an agreement granting the United States, a former enemy, access to many sections of its economy. 
 The change is largely due to that trade agreement, signed by Washington and Hanoi officials on July 13. Lawyers, economists and executives are only starting to make sense of the new accord, a densely worded volume of diplomatic and legal language. The consensus is that the agreement is the most significant business development here since the country reopened to foreign investment almost 15 years ago.
"It has changed the landscape completely," said Nigel Russell, a lawyer who has worked for seven years in Vietnam advising American and other foreign clients for Phillips Fox, an Australian law firm.
The agreement, which is subject to approval in both countries, would give Vietnam the same normal trade relations, subject to annual review by Congress, that China had until it secured permanent status this spring. In return for gradually opening its economy to United States investment and exports, Vietnam immediately gains improved access for its products in American markets, with the average tariff on Vietnamese goods falling to 3 percent from almost 40 percent.
"This is a very comprehensive agreement that will open a lot of doors to U.S. business in Vietnam," said Frederick Burke, a lawyer with Baker & Mackenzie at a briefing to the American Chamber of Commerce here. The agreement, he said, also represents "dramatic progress for Vietnam in its integration into the global economic community."
That said, few people here are under the illusion that change will come easily or that a recent exodus by disenchanted foreign investors will quickly be reversed. Much will still depend on the willingness of Vietnam's elderly Communist rulers to enforce the agreement.
"Implementation is going to be a serious question," said Anthony Salzman, who sells Caterpillar products in Vietnam. "As an American businessman, I'll be looking at that."
Vietnam has been experimenting with market reforms of some sort since 1987. Since President Clinton lifted the trade embargo in 1994, American companies have been trying with mixed success to participate in that experiment, but it took almost five years for the two nations to reach an agreement formalizing the terms of a trade and investment pact.
Its immediate effect on Vietnam's economy may be relatively small. The World Bank estimates that Vietnamese exports to the United States would rise to $768 million a year, compared with $504 million last year. Even in an economy as small as Vietnam's, that would increase average incomes by less than 1 percent, the agency estimates.
"The real economic impact is not as great as people expect," said Dinh Tuan Viet, an economist at the World Bank's office here.
The quickest beneficiaries are likely to be foreign textile and apparel manufacturers with plants in this country, such as Nike and the lingerie maker Triumph. United States tariffs on brassieres and panties, for example, would drop to zero from about 60 percent, contributing to the World Bank estimate of a potential 1,500 percent increase in clothing exports from Vietnam to the United States.
Although Vietnamese workers would earn the wages from such a boom, the country does not supply the raw material and so the broad economy would reap relatively little benefit, Mr. Viet of the World Bank said. A greater benefit to the economy, he said, would come from cuts in tariffs on processed food, especially fish and shrimp products.
More profound are the changes the agreement makes to Vietnam's rules on foreign investment. Economists say these will force the country to adopt international norms on accounting and corporate governance, and accelerate economic changes already under way, especially the transfer of state-owned industry to private ownership. Last week, for instance, Vietnam opened a long-awaited stock exchange in the hope of mobilizing private capital.
"It opens up the economy to a whole series of competitive forces," Wong Yit Fan, regional economist at Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore, said of the agreement.
For American companies interested in Vietnam's market of nearly 80 million people, the agreement offers important concessions. It phases out quotas on a range of exports from meat to motorcycles and gradually cuts tariffs on everything from Maybelline mascara to Motorola cellular phones. It establishes the right of United States accounting and law firms to establish wholly owned subsidiaries in Vietnam and over time opens the country to American banks and insurers.
The agreement also protects intellectual property rights, including software and semiconductor designs, and prohibits Vietnam from applying different product standards to American companies or from charging foreign business higher fees for phone calls, utilities or airfare. Perhaps most tellingly, it seeks to eliminate the regulatory caprice that is the subject of many investor complaints. The agreement would oblige Vietnam to end the arbitrary application of rules to foreign companies and to set forth rules well in advance.
Mr. Burke of Baker & Mackenzie said the agreement's significance was amplified by nondiscrimination clauses in Vietnam's trade agreements with other nations. Companies from China, Japan and Europe would also benefit from the new terms.
Even so, it stops short in many areas. Hanoi retains restrictions on trade in economically critical products like oil, rice and gold, as well as in publications and films.
The agreement apparently does not do much to improve Vietnam's Internet infrastructure. It mimics China's limits on foreign involvement in telecommunications and does little to promote the flow of venture capital to finance the high-technology start-ups that other developing nations have deemed crucial to taking part in a new economy.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 578 words

HEADLINE: Ford's Clean Air Breakthrough

 BODY:
The various industries responsible for much of the country's air pollution -- the oil companies, the automakers, the big utilities -- have usually resisted federal clean air regulations, routinely overestimating the costs of the regulations while underestimating the ability of their engineers to satisfy them. In the 30 years since the passage of the Clean Air Act, industry has rarely been out in front of government. Yesterday, however, the Ford Motor Company reversed this paradigm with the announcement that it would increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years. It did so even though Congress recently rejected yet another effort by environmentalists to tighten up fuel economy standards.
The company's move deserves applause from anyone who worries about carbon dioxide, a so-called greenhouse gas that is thought to be a major contributor to global warming. Cars and trucks are responsible for about one-third of the carbon dioxide produced in the United States, and S.U.V.'s are responsible for a big chunk of that. S.U.V.'s, pickup trucks and vans now account for half the vehicles sold in America. This has been a boon for Detroit but not for cleaner air, mainly because S.U.V.'s, which are officially classed as light trucks, have been allowed to emit up to three times as much pollution per mile as standard cars. They also consume about one-third to one-half more fuel than ordinary cars. 
 Last year the Environmental Protection Agency began a crackdown on S.U.V.'s, using the so-called tailpipe standards authorized by the Clean Air Act. It issued new rules that will require S.U.V.'s to meet the same emission standards that apply to ordinary cars and govern pollutants like nitrogen oxide, a precursor to urban smog. At the same time, the E.P.A. required the oil companies to produce a cleaner-burning gasoline to increase the efficiency of a car's catalytic converter, the device that strips most pollutants from auto exhaust.
But the catalytic converter does nothing to decrease emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas. The only way to reduce carbon dioxide, short of installing an engine that does not use fossil fuels, is to increase fuel efficiency. That is what Ford's new strategy for its S.U.V.'s would do.
While committing itself to more fuel-efficient S.U.V.'s, the company remains opposed, along with other automakers, to legislative efforts to increase fuel economy standards generally. These standards have not significantly changed in nearly 20 years. Ford's answer to what some see as an inconsistency is that it opposes top-down regulation but will respond to consumer-driven market forces. Ford says it is convinced that consumers are ready to sacrifice a modest amount of engine power and size in exchange for a cleaner S.U.V. It also argues that it has the technology to increase the fuel economy of S.U.V.'s without increasing prices -- the implication being that it will be able to do the same for other cars if allowed to proceed at its own pace.
Environmentalists on the whole were delighted. They noted that if Ford can build S.U.V.'s that yield much better mileage per gallon, other companies are sure to follow. If they do, William C. Ford Jr., Ford's chairman and the great-grandson of Henry Ford, will further solidify his reputation as the most adventurous executive in an industry not previously known for environmental stewardship.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: PARATROOPER POLITICS: A special report.;
A Combative Leader Shapes Venezuela to a Leftist Vision

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 27

 BODY:
He promised a revolution, and he has kept his word. Since being swept to power here 18 months ago, Hugo Chavez has uprooted every institution, assaulted every elite and derided every orthodoxy with the unrelenting combativeness of the army paratrooper he used to be.
The Congress and Supreme Court he called "corrupt" and "worm eaten" are gone, and the two political parties that governed for 40 years have collapsed. The military's role has been vastly expanded, the powerful government oil company he criticized as "a state within the state" has been purged, and the authority of governors and mayors has been curtailed. 
 In speech after speech, he has attacked the business, opposition and media leaders who have expressed doubts about his methods and objectives, calling them "degenerates" and "squealing pigs." When Roman Catholic bishops dared suggest that he should be less confrontational, he dismissed them as "devils in vestments."
The centerpiece of Mr. Chavez's plan to transform Venezuela, which has been the United States' leading source of imported oil in recent years, is a new Constitution he hails as "the most democratic in the world." Hand-tailored for him in a Constituent Assembly dominated by his leftist Patriotic Pole movement, it enlarges the powers of the state while weakening the legislature and judiciary.
Now the former army colonel, who will be 46 on Friday, seems assured of at least six more years in office, thanks to provisions in the new charter that extend the presidential term by one year and eliminate a ban on immediate re-election. An election scheduled for Sunday to "relegitimize" his rule and choose governors and a new Congress is expected to hand him a sweeping victory.
"Oligarchs tremble, because now is when the revolution is going forward," he warned recently. "This is going to be delicious: we're going to deliver a knockout punch to the counterrevolution."
For the Latin American left, hungry for a home-grown hero, Mr. Chavez is a godsend: a charismatic military man who condemns "savage capitalism," embraces Fidel Castro and promises social justice. An orator who is by turns spellbinding and funny, Mr. Chavez has gathered the poor into a powerful force that is demanding change.
But for many others, unwilling to forget the unsuccessful coup he led eight years ago, Mr. Chavez reawakens memories of the authoritarian caudillo -- the classic military strongman with little patience for the give-and-take of democracy. To them, his language reeks of class hatred and demagoguery, his vituperative attacks foreshadowing even greater conflicts to come.
"His movement is contradictory, and Hugo Chavez is a divided soul," said Teodoro Petkoff, a former guerrilla and government official who is now editor of an irreverent new daily newspaper here, Tal Cual. "At the same time he is Menshevik and Bolshevik, Girardist and Jacobin, Danton and Robespierre."
In Venezuela, Hugo Chavez seems to be everywhere, his image plastered on posters, his voice booming over the airwaves. But the man himself -- as well as a clear picture of how he intends to exercise the enormous power he has been accumulating -- remains elusive.
He was elected in a landslide in December 1998 by promising a "peaceful social revolution" that would usher in a "golden age." So far he has failed to deliver either prosperity or equality: the Venezuelan economy shrank by 7 percent last year, and more than half the work force remains unemployed or is working in the underground economy. The well-off, fearful of his declarations, have spirited more than $8 billion out of the country, mostly to the United States, since he came to power, according to Venezuelan central bank data.
He has ordered government security forces not to move against squatters who invade buildings or farms, and has just backed a measure that would expropriate landholdings that the government deems to be "idle."
His followers, drawn from the 80 percent of Venezuelans who live below the poverty line, have been kept in a permanent state of agitation. His speeches refer to his "plan of battle," the need to "take every piece of space by assault" and efforts to "force the adversaries of the people into their caves and foxholes," but offer few policy specifics.
 
Former Officers at His Side
"Now brothers, let us unsheath the sword of truth," Mr. Chavez intoned in a recent speech. "All of you are warriors, so let us once again seek the oracle of war and put on our combat boots. I am certain that from today on the popular offensive will be as implacable as ever and that the attack will come from all sides because the Venezuelan people have clasped their banner and are going on to battle and victory again."
Given his two decades in the army, it is hardly surprising that Mr. Chavez's public declarations have a martial tone or that he has brought large numbers of former military officers into his government.
"Von Clausewitz said that war is the continuation of politics by other means, but it also works the other way around," he said in an interview. "Whether it be war or some other kind of challenge, you are always talking about struggle, battles, advances and retreats."
But he also draws heavily on religious imagery, comparing himself to Jesus and his opponents to the demons of the apocalypse. When Roman Catholic bishops sent him a letter last spring cautioning him that it was false to suggest that "God has blessed one political project" above others, he responded with a 20-page letter that read like a papal encyclical, complete with biblical citations.
Mr. Chavez leavens his aggressive remarks with jokes, proverbs, bits of popular songs, asides to his wife, Marisabel, and anecdotes about friends, his boyhood and his days as a baseball player. His opponents say they find his performances coarse and clownish, but his folksy approach has helped cement his ties to ordinary Venezuelans. "He is one of us," said Beatriz Tovar Mendieta, a washerwoman here. "We've never had another president like that before."
Mr. Chavez is also more closely identified with the masses in terms of the ethnic or racial divide that characterizes Venezuela. The predecessors he attacks as members of a "rotten oligarchic elite" are typical "mantuanos," as people with European features and pretensions are called here.
In contrast, Mr. Chavez is a typical "pardo," or brown-skinned person, with traces of Indian blood, "curly hair, Chinese-looking eyes, a thick mouth and an aquiline nose," in the words of one of his biographers, Angela Zago. In speeches, the president has been known to underline his resemblance to his followers by referring to himself as "the Indian from Barinas."
William Lara, who met the president when both were studying political science in a postgraduate course a decade ago and is now one of his closest political advisers, said: "Like Hugo Chavez I am from the plains, which is a place that has very few trees. So when a plainsman sees a tree, his first impulse is to look behind it to see if someone is waiting there to ambush him. Hugo Chavez has that characteristic."
Combined with that self-reliance is a distrust of and disdain for technocrats that leads him to rely on his own instincts more than advice from experts. "You need to take an aspirin, but they prescribe Viagra," Mr. Chavez complained in a recent speech.
Mr. Chavez's relationship with the United States is no less complicated. Aside from a passion for baseball that works its way into almost every speech, he is a fan of American movies and television, referring to them almost as frequently as he adorns his speeches with quotations from Abraham Lincoln, John F. Kennedy and Walt Whitman.
 
U.S. Help Is Rejected
But when floods and mudslides inundated the Caribbean coast last December, killing thousands, Mr. Chavez refused help from an American military team. Their presence, he said, would offend Venezuela's sovereignty, even though he allowed in doctors from Cuba, relief workers from Spain and Mexico, and aid from China and Pakistan.
He personally takes responsibility for the dramatic rise in oil prices and record gasoline prices in the United States. On the campaign trail here, he reminds voters it was his government's decision to lower production and adhere to OPEC quotas that has resulted in a quadrupling of the price of a barrel of Venezuelan crude since he took office 18 months ago.
Not only has Venezuela often been the leading source of oil for the United States, but the country's minister of energy, Ali Rodriguez, is now OPEC president. In recent speeches, Mr. Chavez has bragged to Venezuelans about telephone calls from President Clinton asking for relief on oil prices, but he has also made it clear that he does not intend to give any ground.
Once the election is over, Mr. Chavez plans a Mideast tour to discuss with "our Arab brothers," as he calls them, an OPEC heads of state meeting scheduled here in late September. Although he plans stops in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, Mr. Chavez seems bent on tweaking Washington by visiting Iraq, Iran and Libya, and inviting their leaders to the conference.
"Imagine what the pharisees will say when they see me with Saddam Hussein," Mr. Chavez said with a big grin in a recent speech.
Indeed, his foreign policy has shown a fascination with rogue elements around the world. One peculiar example is his correspondence with Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, the Venezuelan-born former guerrilla known as Carlos the Jackal, who was convicted of murder and kidnappings across Europe and once organized an attack on OPEC ministers.
In addition, Mr. Chavez has cited the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya as a model for participatory democracy. He has also repeatedly praised Mr. Castro's rule in Cuba, much to the distress of Venezuelans still resentful of Cuban support for past guerrilla movements here, saying both nations are "swimming together toward the same sea of happiness."
Mr. Chavez withdrew Venezuela from annual American-sponsored joint naval maneuvers and this week accused the United States of trying to install a missile base in neighboring Guyana. But perhaps most immediately troubling to Washington is his decision to ban American drug surveillance flights from using Venezuelan airspace.
For now, the American response has been restrained, arguing, no doubt with an eye on oil supplies, that forbearance and dialogue are the best way to avoid further radicalization of the situation here.
But Republican members of Congress are clamoring for sanctions against Venezuela, and the United States ambassador who has been carrying out the wait-and-see policy here is to be succeeded next month by Donna Jean Hrinak, who as ambassador to the Dominican Republic took a hard line against that country's wily authoritarian president, Joaquin Balaguer.
 
'A Tough Little Kid'
Hugo Rafael Chavez Frias was born in Sabaneta de Barinas, a small town in the vast, sparsely populated savannah that is Venezuela's equivalent of the Great Plains. As teachers in the local elementary school, his parents, Hugo de los Reyes Chavez and Helena Frias, had social but not material status.
"We grew up there selling bananas and sowing corn" and when students finished the sixth grade "we had to go somewhere else, to the state capital, if we were going to continue our studies," Mr. Chavez recalled in an autobiography.
The new student in the capital was first ridiculed as a bumpkin but soon stood out for his ability to recite poems and speeches at festivals and for athletic prowess. Baseball is the national pastime, and Mr. Chavez excelled as both a left-handed pitcher and a power-hitting first baseman.
"He was a tough little kid, mischievous, a real talker and dreamer, but as tenacious as hell," Jose (Tintan) Lopez, Mr. Chavez's baseball coach, said in an interview. "Even when he was 7 or 8, he could put the ball where he wanted and wasn't afraid to come in on a batter with his fastball."
Indirectly, it was baseball that led to Mr. Chavez's military career. His plan was to qualify for the army's team and capture the attention of major league scouts.
But he soon developed arm trouble, and his ambitions shifted. "When I met some officers and read a bit of history, I felt something stirring inside me," he has said. He drew inspiration from Latin American military leaders like Juan Velasco of Peru, Juan Peron of Argentina and Omar Torrijos of Panama -- men who used their power to shake up the status quo, not reinforce it.
After graduation he was assigned to a succession of posts: an armored unit, antiguerrilla duty along the Colombian border, a military ethics instructor, paratrooper training and eventually staff duty at the Ministry of Defense. But there was also a conspiratorial side he was careful to keep hidden from his superiors.
"We were a group of four or five captains who used to jog together in the afternoons, and one day in 1983 Chavez suggested we swear an oath to fight against corruption and for the welfare of our country," recalled Jesus Urdaneta Hernandez, a former classmate and friend who recently broke with the president. "From that moment on, we began to study the problems of Venezuela in a systematic way, and as time passed we got more and more young officers to join us."
After world oil prices collapsed in the early 1980's, neither of the country's two political parties proved able to govern effectively or honestly in a situation that called for belt-tightening. In 1989, a popular uprising against an International Monetary Fund austerity program resulted in the deaths of several hundred people and convinced Mr. Chavez and his co-conspirators that the system could no longer function.
 
A Turning Point in Life
On Feb. 4, 1992, Mr. Chavez, Francisco Arias Cardenas, then his closest comrade in arms but now his challenger in Sunday's vote, and other officers attacked the presidential palace. It was a bloody failure, resulting in the deaths of more than a score of soldiers. But most Venezuelans caught their first glance of their future leader then, and Mr. Chavez has described the episode as the turning point in his life.
After surrendering, he was paraded in front of television cameras, wearing the bright red military beret that he and his followers today wear as the symbol of their movement, to call on the last holdout units to lay down their arms.
"For now, comrades, the objectives that we established have unfortunately not been achieved in the capital," the young army colonel said, with a touch of bravado that resonated deeply among ordinary people. Then he was bundled off to jail.
By Mr. Chavez's own account, the two-plus years he spent there were devoted largely to reading and debating. In an interview last year, Mr. Chavez described himself as "a promiscuous reader," with a reading list that included Camus, Cicero, Martin Luther King, Mao, Montesquieu, Neruda, Nietzche, Ortega y Gasset, Rousseau, Alvin Toffler and Walt Whitman.
Visitors of all political persuasions were allowed to see him, including some of the most influential members of what is now his government. Among them were two veterans of the left who would become his mentors: Luis Miquilena, now head of the Congress, and Jose Vicente Rangel, his foreign minister.
After Mr. Chavez was freed in 1994, Mr. Miquilena and other admirers decided he needed to travel abroad because he knew little of the world.
Because of his role in the attempted overthrow of a democratically elected government, the United States refused to grant him a visa, a policy that remained in effect until he was elected president. But he traveled throughout Latin America, and on one trip he met an obscure Argentine sociologist named Norberto Ceresole.
Mr. Ceresole's language can be murky, but in essence he envisions political leadership as an almost mystical bond between the masses and a charismatic figure. Such a "post-democratic" relationship eliminates the need for political parties, he argues, because the military can more reliably serve as a sort of conveyor belt between the leader and the led.
To critics, such notions are little more than warmed-over fascism. Mr. Ceresole also denies the Holocaust and calls for third world coalitions to counter the power of the United States.
Just after Mr. Chavez was elected, Mr. Ceresole visited Venezuela and proudly described the president-elect as "my disciple." Mr. Chavez was clearly irritated by the remarks and, according to Mr. Urdaneta, then his secret police chief, ordered the Argentine to leave.
Nevertheless, many Venezuelans remain convinced that Mr. Ceresole's ideas influence Mr. Chavez's government.
As he was discovering Mr. Ceresole, Mr. Chavez made his first trip to Havana, where he was welcomed by Mr. Castro. At a 1994 news conference there, Mr. Chavez, clearly dazzled by having been treated almost as a head of state, was full of admiration for Mr. Castro and the Cuban revolution. He has continued to visit Havana as president, even playing baseball with Mr. Castro last year, and has offered Cuba economic aid.
To Mr. Chavez's critics, the president's fascination with two figures as ideologically divergent as Mr. Castro and Mr. Ceresole indicates he has no core beliefs of his own, only a set of postures that he tailors for his audiences.
"On Wall Street, he talks about the wonders of capitalism, in China he quotes from Chairman Mao, and in England, he praises Tony Blair and the Third Way," Mr. Urdaneta said. "He wants to be on good terms with everybody, so he says what people want to hear. We will only see the true Hugo Chavez emerge after this election."
 
A Time to Deliver
That chapter will open after the vote on Sunday when pressure to deliver results can only mount.
But "there doesn't seem to be a coherent plan," said Robert Bottome, editor of Veneconomia, the leading business newsletter here. "The formal economy is being more and more destroyed, and I don't think it is deliberate. It's just that he doesn't understand, he doesn't know what he's doing."
And even as the hour of his greatest triumph draws closer, Mr. Chavez has passed up an opportunity to be magnanimous or conciliatory. Instead, he has stepped up attacks on all who question his vision or recoil at the conflict he says he relishes.
"There is no third way here," he said recently. "No, here there is only revolution and counterrevolution, and we are going to annihilate the counterrevolution."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE;
Potential Voters Skeptical, Lacking Passion for Candidates

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill., July 21

 BODY:
It is a puzzling political season for George Gauthier.
Although the major presidential candidates were identified months ago, Mr. Gauthier, a builder, has no idea whom he will vote for. 
 He knows where he stands on the issues and has thoughtful, nuanced ideas about what a president should be. But so far, no candidate has given him enough to go on.
"Bush doesn't have the strengths in foreign and national politics that his father did," said Mr. Gauthier, 59, who also runs an organization to help lower-income people obtain homes, "and there's been good and bad state governors as presidents, so he comes into it having to answer why he should be executive of the United States."
"With Gore, my fear is that his programs would be too big, too expensive," said Mr. Gauthier, who voted for Republicans in the last four presidential elections, Democrats in the previous three and knows only that he will not vote for a third-party candidate this year.
"I think both of them show leadership potential, an ability to project their vision of the future," he said. "Neither is going to effect major radical change. It's a question of how they would lean, which bias they have. It's hard to find the best candidate."
With the Republican and Democratic conventions coming up, Mr. Gauthier is hardly in the minority, interviews with voters suggest. In dozens of discussions in Evanston, a diverse, middle-class suburb just north of Chicago in a critical swing-vote state, people were studiously skeptical, awaiting answers and wary of the campaign games politicians play.
In the absence of a single urgent issue like war or economic crisis, voters were sizing up candidates as managers, stewards and respect-worthy leaders rather than as rallying, agenda-driven politicians. Voters were more interested in what kind of cabinet officials and Supreme Court justices the candidates would appoint and in how they would work with Congress than in where they stood on every issue.
And while most said they wanted a president with consistency and integrity, someone unlikely to be swayed by interest-group pressure, they doubted whether any candidate had those qualities.
"I'd like to see a leader who's not a captive of special interests, but it may be impossible," said Edith Eisner, a 75-year-old retired English teacher who said she would vote for Al Gore. "I think both the candidates now can be pushed around."
Al Butkus, the president of an engineering firm who said he would vote for George W. Bush, said: "My big concern about presidential politics is once you get to be able to run for president you've had to make so many promises and compromises that you've compromised yourself coming through the system."
In Evanston, home of Northwestern University and one of the few racially diverse communities in the Illinois suburbs, more people vote for Democrats. But the interviews focused on people across the political spectrum. All except one of those interviewed said they had ruled out voting for the third-party candidates, Ralph Nader of the Green Party and Patrick J. Buchanan of the Reform Party. Most considered them extreme or narrowly focused, although some said they found Mr. Nader appealing but unelectable.
Strikingly, among people who said they would support Mr. Gore or Mr. Bush, there was frequently little passion about the candidate.
Cindy Wilson, a 40-year-old civil rights lawyer, said she had always voted Democratic and would again this year.
Still, she said: "I think Gore is questionable. I don't think he tells the truth all the time."
Ms. Wilson, with two children and a husband who is also a lawyer, said she was fairly certain that Mr. Gore agreed with her on education, the environment, affirmative action and other issues, but she had reservations about "him as a person." She said she believed, for example, that he was "pandering" when he said that Elian Gonzalez and his father should be given permanent residency status, and she called his ethics on campaign financing "a little loose."
"He seems to always say what people want to hear. I can't get excited about him and trust him."
Mr. Butkus, 48, who typically backs Republicans for president, said of Governor Bush: "He doesn't have a lot of political experience. There's just not a big book on him to let you now how he'd act in situations." He said he was "not happy" with Mr. Bush's vague response about whether he had used cocaine, but added, "There's abuses on the other side."
"The one thing I'm impressed with Bush about is that he has been picking good people and they're sticking by him," Mr. Butkus said.
People seem well aware of what presidential power can and cannot do. Their priorities included Supreme Court appointments and keeping Alan Greenspan as Federal Reserve chairman. Some would like a foreign policy leader to help resolve the Middle East conflict, deal firmly with Russia and either scrap or build a missile defense system.
Some mentioned health care that would be affordable for all citizens and progress in race relations. Most said they believed the economy would continue strongly under either candidate. And no one linked his or her vote to a single issue, like school vouchers or the death penalty -- indeed, a few said such issues should be left to the states.
Mr. Butkus's wife, Ellen, 47, said she strongly opposed abortion, but would not make that a litmus test. "The check mark in the little box just doesn't give you a sense of all the different ways that this candidate could affect things," said Mrs. Butkus, a nurse.
Rather, Mrs. Butkus, who is undecided and would not rule out Mr. Nader, is more concerned about how candidates would deal with racial issues and what impact they would have on issues like the death penalty and school choice.
Several people seemed to favor both the probusiness, smaller-government approach historically associated with Republicans and the sense of social justice and inclusiveness typically linked to Democrats.
"I want someone who's going to have a balance in being generally businesslike in the management of government," said Don Colleton, a 58-year-old lawyer leaning toward Mr. Bush. "But I'm not one to play around with some of these social issues. I want folks to behave in a way that is just resolute in acknowledging the intrinsic equal dignity of members of the human race, whatever color or size they come in."
Mr. Gauthier exemplifies the sense of wanting to borrow from both Republicans and Democrats. He says that the federal government should deal with social problems by financing private nonprofit agencies like his housing coalition, which he contends are more cost-effective than government agencies. He says he thinks a prescription drug plan should include means-testing so that those people most in need will benefit, and that eventually, there will have to be means tests for Social Security and Medicare. He also contends that school vouchers are unworkable, and that the government should take some of the money now being spent on the military and battling illegal drugs and put it into drug treatment.
Indeed, Mr. Gauthier is so concerned with balance that he said he might vote for the candidate whose party appeared as though it would not have a majority in Congress.
Several people expressed concern that Mr. Bush might be influenced by radical right-wing voices in the Republican Party, but none seemed concerned that Mr. Gore would be similarly pulled from the center.
"I think Bush's heart is one place and his head is another," said the Rev. Larry Bullock, an African Methodist Episcopal minister who also owns construction businesses. "I think he is a compassionate conservative, but I think he's too beholden to certain wings of his party."
Mr. Bullock said he would probably vote for Mr. Gore, but wanted the Democratic candidate to "show a freshness and a newness."
"He's really got to rattle those bones," Mr. Bullock said. "Clinton gave us the bridge to the 21st century. Gore needs to tell us what's on the other side of the bridge."
Most of those interviewed said their view of President Clinton would not affect their vote. Supporters and critics said Mr. Gore was appropriately loyal in defending the president in the Monica Lewinsky matter. And most said that he deserved neither credit nor criticism for Clinton administration policies.
One exception was Lorraine Morton, the Democratic mayor of Evanston, who said she did not have "great enthusiasm" for Mr. Gore, but "Clinton did a fantastic job," and if elected, "Gore can pick up the telephone and say, 'Bill. what do you think about so and so.' "
Although most people said Mr. Bush made a good choice in Dick Cheney as his running mate, those interviewed said it would not affect their views.
As the campaign heats up, the candidates might do well to listen to the likes of Barry Slotnick.
Mr. Slotnick, 28, who works in his family's travel business and owns a fitness equipment company, considers himself "fiscally conservative and socially liberal," pro-entrepreneur and pro-abortion rights. He voted Republican in 1992 and 1996, but started this campaign admiring Bill Bradley, especially his progressive views on race relations. "As Bradley's situation started to fade," he said, "I really took an interest in John McCain."
Now, Mr. Slotnick is "very much on the fence," he said.
"I like the Republican platform when it comes to small government," he said, but added that he was worried about "some very frightening people in the far reaches of the Republican Party, the far right."
With Mr. Bush, he said, he is unsure "how much has been attained because he's daddy's boy."
"I don't think there's any question that Gore brings more experience, having been vice president for eight years," he said.
Still, Mr. Slotnick said he believed that Mr. Bush "could probably get a good cabinet together." And while "Bush seems to me like a grown-up frat boy," Mr. Slotnick said, he also "seems like a more approachable, more normal guy."
"He seems less political," Mr. Slotnick said. "Gore, everything he does seems a little rehearsed."
Mr. Slotnick said he thinks "both Gore and Bush can keep the momentum in the economy going," adding: "So this year I'm really looking more at the person. At the end of the day you look for someone who really you can look up to and trust. Are they a good representation of the country?"

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Absolutely, Positively Unrealistic

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
ABSOLUT New York, as defined on a new billboard at Lafayette and Bond Streets, is a studio apartment in the shape of a vodka bottle. The three-dimensional apartment is fully equipped with real furniture, rugs, kitchen appliances and a bathtub that are all affixed to the billboard.
It's described as a life-size apartment, which is indeed the scale of the 49-foot-wide billboard, but anyone who has been hunting for real-life apartments in NoHo could quibble with the dimensions. This studio apartment has a total of 900 square feet of space, which is absolutely not New York in today's real-estate ads. That's more like the size of a two-bedroom. 
 But while the apartment may not conform to reality, it does conform to the popular image of a Manhattan apartment. Over-size homes are the norm on film and television. When New Yorkers see their alleged apartments on the screen, their reaction is often Robert Redford's in "Legal Eagles" upon entering the SoHo loft of Darryl Hannah, a performance artist who has just told him she inherited no money from her father.
"Lot of room," he says, looking in surprise around a space big enough to be a basketball court.
In "Desk Set," Katherine Hepburn lives in an Upper East Side apartment that seems grandiose for a magazine researcher, although it's nothing compared with the digs of a newspaper reporter, Lois Lane. In the movie "Superman," Christopher Reeve finds Margot Kidder waiting on a rooftop terrace fit for a wedding reception. It looks like the Peninsula Hotel's rooftop bar, but with a better garden.
Even before John Cassavetes and Mia Farrow get to know their strange new neighbors in "Rosemary's Baby," it's clear that supernatural forces are at work. How else could an unsuccessful young actor get an apartment in the Dakota?
How does Sigourney Weaver, playing a classical musician in "Ghostbusters," afford a co-op on Central Park West with a huge kitchen and a park view? How does Deborah Kerr, playing a school teacher in "An Affair to Remember" who says she's "on a budget," manage a one-bedroom apartment with a large sunken living room, marble fireplace and balcony?
There's been some realism on TV, as on "The Honeymooners" and "Seinfeld." The huge apartment of a waitress and an unemployed chef on "Friends' is explained away as a rent-regulated legacy. But the huge rooms on "Mad About You" remain a mystery to most New Yorkers, including Chuck Katz, the author of "Manhattan on Film: Walking Tours of Hollywood's Fabled Front Lot."
"The bathroom in 'Mad About You' looks bigger than most Manhattan apartments," Mr. Katz said. "It's not realistic for that young couple to be living in a place like that, but you can see the practical reasons for it. In one episode they get locked in the bathroom. If two people got locked in my bathroom, there'd be no room for a film crew."
LOCATION scouts for films are accustomed to suspending disbelief. "I've told directors dozens of times that an apartment is a little upscale for the character," said Dana Robin, who has 15 years of experience scouting locations. "But the directors need high ceilings and big rooms for light and cameras." They also have to consider the audience in the rest of the country.
"People in the rest of the country would be shocked to see how New Yorkers really live," Mr. Robin said. "Your hero, unless he's a down-and-outer, should live in what looks to the audience at least like a respectable place, if not better. The entertainment business likes to perpetuate a bigger and grander picture of life."
So does the advertising industry, which is why the studio on the billboard is so big. "We didn't set out to create an apartment for the New York Everyman," said Richard Lewis, worldwide account director for Absolut at the TBWA/Chiat/Day agency. "It's a place where the Absolut New Yorker would live."
These fantasy apartments can be disillusioning for the natives, because they must make our places look even more cramped by comparison. But in some ways we also benefit from the false images.
"These big apartments are a P.R. campaign for New Yorkers," Mr. Katz said. "We don't want the rest of the country to know how we live. We'd rather show a young actor in the Dakota instead of in a fifth-floor walk-up in Brooklyn. We don't want our friends back in Tucson or Chicago to know the real bargain with the devil here: you can get a great job, but you have to live in a shoe box."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RECORD;
Cheney Slips in Explaining A Vote on Freeing Mandela

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
As he made the rounds of the television talk shows this morning, Dick Cheney confidently defended his votes in the 1980's against gun control, abortion rights and education spending, but he slipped when he tried to justify his opposition to an obscure resolution in 1986 that called on South Africa to release Nelson Mandela from prison.
Democrats immediately pounced on the issue and vowed to use it against the Republican ticket in the fall campaign. 
 On NBC's "Today," Mr. Cheney, the expected Republican vice-presidential nominee, said his vote was based on a disagreement over whether economic sanctions were the best way to end apartheid.
"The debate that we had at the time had to do with how we could best pursue our policies in South Africa," Mr. Cheney said. "Nobody supported apartheid. We were all against it. But there was a big debate over the best leverage we could use to get Nelson Mandela free.
"One school of thought said that there should be sanctions imposed on South Africa, that American companies should be prohibited from operating in South Africa, that there shouldn't be any trade with South Africa. The other school of thought said, 'Wait a minute,' that, in fact, the only good jobs that were available to black South Africans were with American firms. If you wanted a company that was going to provide opportunities and not discriminate, you had to go to American firms, and the people that would be hurt if we forced American firms out of South Africa were those very people we were trying to help."
Mr. Cheney then said, "This notion that somehow I was opposed to freeing Nelson Mandela is a typical Al Gore distortion of a record, a point he's trying to make because he doesn't want to talk about real issues."
The disagreement over sanctions was a big issue in Congress in 1986, and Mr. Cheney's description of the two sides was accurate. Before the year was out, Congress overrode President Ronald Reagan's veto of a bill that imposed sanctions, the first time Mr. Reagan had been rebuffed like this on a foreign policy matter. Mr. Cheney supported the president.
But the question of sanctions never came up in the debate on the Mandela resolution. The opposition to it was based on the belief of the right wing of the Republican Party in the House that the African National Congress, Mr. Mandela's party and the leading political voice against apartheid, was dominated by Communists.
Representative Dan Burton of Indiana said: "Let us look at the A.N.C. and see what it consists of exactly. Nineteen of the 30 members of the A.N.C. are known members of the South African Communist Party, and we believe as many as 26."
Democratic strategists said today they expected to use the Mandela vote against the Republicans this fall, particularly in commercials on radio stations popular with blacks.
"George W. Bush has now said to the African-American community, 'I give you my person, my candidate for vice president, and my person said no to Nelson Mandela when he was in prison,' " said Mayor Dennis Archer of Detroit, co-chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
The 1986 resolution was nonbinding. The House debated it for less than an hour, and it was defeated, 245 to 177, shy of the 282 votes needed for a two-thirds majority.
On the vote, 215 Democrats and 30 Republicans were in favor; 32 Democrats and 145 Republicans, including Mr. Cheney, were opposed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Problem With Certified Mail Causes Delays in Delivery
Local postmasters have acknowledged that a failure to assign enough workers to move the mail and problems installing a computer system for tracking certified mail have led to pileups of letters -- which include tax payments, legal documents like foreclosure notices and court filings -- in postal warehouses.
In New York City, hundreds of taxpayers were sent notices demanding penalties and interest for failing to make June property tax payments on time before the city discovered what had happened. Page A1. 

Without Napster, the Swap Goes On
A decision by a judge to prohibit Napster from offering access to songs whose copyrights are owned by the major record labels is being viewed as a serious blow to those who had hoped to build a business on the online trading of copyrighted music. But the cultural phenomenon shows no signs of abating. A1.
 
Lawyers for Napster asked a federal court to stay a preliminary injunction, asserting it would effectively shut down the service. C2.
 
WorldCom Shares Fall on Warning
WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, reported a 53 percent rise in second-quarter earnings, matching Wall Street expectations. But the company also warned that sales growth for the rest of the year would be at the low end of its previous estimate, and WorldCom shares tumbled as much as 15 percent before recovering somewhat. Shares of WorldCom ended the day down $5.4375, or 12 percent, at $39.3125. C2.
 
Nasdaq Plunges, but Dow Climbs
Stocks were mixed as concern about the results of technology companies led investors to switch to old economy shares. The Nasdaq composite index fell 145.49 points, or 3.7 percent, to 3,842.23, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.80 points, to 1,449.62. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 69.65 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,586.13. C8.
 
Ex-Federated Chief Joins Penney
Allen L. Questrom, who headed Federated Department Stores for much of the 1990's and led Barneys New York out of bankruptcy, was named chairman and chief executive of J. C. Penney, whose shares rose 16 percent. C19.
 
15 From Blair Indicted in Fraud Case
D.H. Blair, a defunct Manhattan brokerage firm, and 15 of its officers and employees were indicted on securities fraud charges. C6.
 
Phone Giant Prepares to Lobby
Deutsche Telekom is considering ways to reduce the German government's stake in the company as it prepares to wage a behind-the-scenes political battle to win approval of its plan to buy VoiceStream Wireless, said Ron Sommer, the company's chief executive. The holdings could be lowered either through other acquisitions, which would dilute the stake, or through a sale of shares. C4.
 
U.S. Reaches Deal on Web Privacy
The government reached agreement with a group of Internet advertisers on how they will glean information from Web surfers and what they will do with it. Advertising. C6.
 
Ford Attributes Change to Research
Ford Motor said that its market research, not the gut instinct of executives, prompted the company's decision to improve the gas mileage of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over five years. C3.
 
Hearst Wins Ruling in Paper Deal
A federal judge in San Francisco ruled that the Hearst Corporation's $660 million purchase of The San Francisco Chronicle did not violate antitrust laws. A18.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PLATFORM;
DRAFT PLATFORM FOR G.O.P. SOFTENS HARD-LINE STANCES

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 27

 BODY:
The proposed Republican platform would drop several of the more hard-edged conservative positions adopted four years ago -- like calling for the abolition of the Department of Education -- and transform much of the document's tone to reflect the "compassionate conservatism" of Gov. George W. Bush.
But it also reflects the continuing power of the party's conservative base, most notably in its word-by-word reaffirmation of the abortion plank, calling for a ban on abortion with no exceptions and the appointment of judges who "respect traditional family values and the sanctity of innocent human life." 
 The draft of the platform was written under the guidance of Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, the platform committee chairman, and was distributed to members of the platform committee gathering here tonight. It will be reviewed -- possibly rewritten -- and voted upon by the 107-member platform committee over the next two days. The full convention will consider the resulting product on Monday.
Governor Thompson said tonight that he hoped the draft reflected "a more uplifting view of the Republican Party, one that's more inclusive, that attempts to build a winning team, that people can rally around." He said it was also intended to reflect the Bush philosophy, adding that he took the chairman's job "because my friend the governor asked me to do it."
Asked how much he expected the committee to change this draft, Mr. Thompson said, "I hope not much, but I know some."
Jenny Backus, spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that Republicans were simply putting "compassionate conservative wrapping paper" around the same old conservative dogma. She argued that the platform's changes were "around the margins" and asserted, "If the American people wanted one sign that the Republican Party had moved out of the 19th century, it would have been some understanding that American women want the right to choose protected."
As written, the document is in large part a road map of the Bush campaign's political strategy in the general election. The section on immigration, for example, no longer demands a constitutional amendment to deny automatic citizenship to the children born of illegal immigrants, as it did four years ago. Rather than calling for "the official recognition of English as the nation's common language," it declares, "Another sign of our unity is the role of English as our common language." The tone, in general, is far more welcoming, reflecting Republicans' efforts to reach out to Hispanics and other immigrant groups.
Similarly, the document includes a careful appeal to women, pledging the party's commitment to women's health issues, and to the elderly, considered a critical swing vote this year. It promises to give Medicare "a new lease on life," by giving each of its 39 million beneficiaries a choice of health plans, an allusion to efforts to get more private insurance plans involved in Medicare. And it accuses the Clinton administration of treating "Social Security as a slogan rather than a priority," while heralding Mr. Bush's proposal to allow people to invest part of their payroll taxes.
Still, for all these appeals to voters in the center, this is hardly a rebuttal of conservative orthodoxy. The platform reiterates that "we defend the constitutional right to keep and bear arms" and argues that "self-defense is a basic human right." The answer to gun violence, it argues, is stronger enforcement of existing laws.
The platform attacks the Supreme Court's recent decision overturning state laws that barred what opponents call "partial-birth" abortion, asserting that the decision "shocks the conscience of the nation." And while Mr. Bush says he would allow abortions in the case of rape, incest and to save the life of the woman, the platform remains unswervingly opposed. Mr. Bush and other Republican leaders had promised the anti-abortion movement early on that the abortion plank would not change.
Republican aides said the document was intended to sound a far less combative tone than the 1996 platform, which is in keeping with the Bush campaign's effort to present its candidate as "a uniter, not a divider." At times, the references are opaque: In a section titled, "Government for the People," the draft is apparently referring to the impeachment of Mr. Clinton when it declares: "At a time when the nation felt betrayed by misconduct in high office, the Republican Congress responded with gravity and high purpose. We applaud those members who did their duty to conscience and the Constitution."
The platform goes to great lengths, though, to try to build a case against giving the Democrats any credit for the current economic boom. It argues that the economy was a "shambles" under President Jimmy Carter, was saved by the Reagan and Bush administrations, and was jeopardized anew by the election of the Clinton administration in 1992, although that election occurred in a recession. Only the "honesty and guts" of a Republican Congress managed to erase the budget deficit and steady the economy for this boom, the platform draft declares.
Four years ago, when that Republican-controlled Congress was still in full-cry, the platform called for the elimination of the Departments of Commerce, Housing and Urban Development, Education and Energy. This draft generally calls for "downsizing" of the "mess" in Washington, where there are "too many departments and agencies with competing programs that waste resources and fail to deliver the goods."
Mr. Thompson said the draft was written by the staff of the Republican National Committee, the Bush campaign and his own operation, under the guidance of him and his two co-chairs, Representative Sue Myrick of North Carolina and Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee.
Some of the most scathing criticism in the draft comes in the section on foreign policy, where the administration is accused of mishandling crises from the Balkans to Mexico.
"Reacting belatedly to inevitable crises, the administration constantly enlarges the reach of its rhetoric -- most recently in Vice President Al Gore's 'new security agenda' that adds disease, climate and all the world's ethnic or religious conflicts to an undiminished set of existing American responsibilities. If there is some limit to candidate Gore's new agenda for America as global social worker, he has yet to define it," the draft declares.
"It is time for America to regain its focus," it adds.
Doug Hattaway, a spokesman for Mr. Gore, responded, "Sounds like the Republicans are turning back the clock to the days of isolationism and a head-in-the-sand view of the world. It's only common sense to address these problems before they develop into conflicts."
The platform draft also takes aim at Mr. Gore's environmental initiatives, arguing that a Republican president will reduce harmful emissions without "forcing Americans to walk to work."
