HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RUNNING MATE;
Once Again, Cheney Confronts the Questions

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., July 27

 BODY:
Dick Cheney tried today to beat back questions about his conservative voting record, appearing on the morning news programs of all three major networks as the Bush campaign fought to keep from being defined by the second man on the ticket.
Gov. George W. Bush jumped into the debate, accusing the Democrats of using a "constant line -- vote for me, I'm going to tear down the other person" -- in attacking the record of his running mate, whose service as defense secretary to Mr. Bush's father followed 10 years in the House. 
"Secretary Cheney brought people together and helped win a war," Mr. Bush said, "which stands in stark contrast to Vice President Al Gore, who tends to divide people to create war."
Mr. Bush spoke as Mr. Cheney, for a second straight day, was called on to explain positions he took as a congressman from Wyoming, including votes against the equal rights amendment, gun control and sanctions on South Africa's apartheid government.
Democrats have highlighted those stands to undercut Mr. Bush's efforts to define himself as a "different kind of Republican."
At times today, Mr. Cheney shot back by pointing to inconsistencies in Mr. Gore's own Congressional voting record. At other times, he defended his conservative views. And occasionally, he turned to talk of legislative process.
Asked, for instance, why he had voted against the equal rights amendment, he said Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., as the speaker of a Democratic-controlled House, had brought it up for a vote under a procedure "that prohibited amendments of any kind -- we had to accept or reject it." He said he had feared that the way it was written would have required the drafting of women into the military.
"Now, I didn't think that was a very good idea," Mr. Cheney said on "The Early Show" on CBS.
Several hours later Mr. Bush made a brief appearance before reporters, taking time out from practicing his acceptance speech for his nomination next week, and maintained that he had not been blindsided by Mr. Cheney's record.
"Of course I knew his votes," Mr. Bush said. "But I also know his record. What do you expect? I'm running against people who all they do is spend time tearing people down."
The Democrats kept up their efforts to use Mr. Cheney's record as a way of tying Mr. Bush to a Republican establishment of the past.
"What Cheney's selection has done is given us a rather vivid picture of old guard Republicanism," said Mark Fabiani, a deputy Gore campaign manager. And, Mr. Fabiani said, "some of his past votes are hard to explain away in any era."
The difficulty for Mr. Bush is that some of the stands of his running mate cut right to the heart of the way he has been seeking to define himself as a "compassionate conservative." Mr. Bush has put a heavy premium on education, for example, and Mr. Cheney voted against the Head Start program.
Mr. Bush regularly surrounds himself with members of minorities and recently spoke at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Mr. Cheney voted against imposing economic sanctions on the apartheid government of South Africa and against a House resolution calling for Nelson Mandela to be freed after 23 years in prison.
This morning Mr. Cheney said on the NBC News television program "Today" that "this notion that somehow I was opposed to freeing Nelson Mandela is a typical distortion by Al Gore."
He said the issue had been tied up in a debate over sanctions against South Africa. He said he believed that forcing United States companies out of South Africa would have left many blacks there worse off, because "any good jobs available to black South Africans were with American firms."
Of domestic matters, Mr. Cheney argued that the 1980's, when he served in the House, were a different era, when budget deficits required votes to control spending. And he said his rise in Congress up the leadership ladder of his party showed that he had not been viewed as an extreme conservative.
"So whatever the Democrats want to say about me now," he said, "the fact of the matter was many Democrats, as well as all of the Republicans, thought I was a reasonably respectable fellow in the 1980's."
On some issues, Mr. Cheney stood firm. When asked why he had been one of only 21 House members to vote against a ban on so-called cop-killer bullets, he said: "I consistently voted against gun control. I'm one of those people who believes that the solution to our gun problem is to enforce existing laws, not impose new restrictions on law-abiding citizens."
Pressed as to why in 1988 he voted against a ban on plastic guns that can make it through airport security, a measure that was not opposed by even the National Rifle Association, he said, "Well, obviously I wasn't in the pocket of the N.R.A."
And on ABC's "Good Morning America," he tried to turn the scrutiny to Mr. Gore, whose position on gun issues has changed since his first years in Congress. "At the same time that I was doing that, casting those votes, Al Gore was receiving an A rating from the National Rifle Association," Mr. Cheney said. "He was pro-gun and anti-gun-control."
As for his votes against creating the Department of Education and against spending on Head Start, Mr. Cheney cautioned against the assumption "that anything that's got the word 'education' on it is good."
"You've got to look at the substance of it," he said. "You've got to analyze the legislation. The fact of the matter is that education is primarily a state and local responsibility."
Mr. Cheney also answered questions about a Republican fund-raising brochure from 1992 that had a picture of him as defense secretary and promised large contributors the right to attend unspecified government briefings.
"We didn't do any fund-raisers in the Pentagon," he said, "never did. I did brief people from time to time, but as a general rule we stayed out of partisan politics in the Pentagon."

HEADLINE: Playing for (Political) Time on China Trade

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
When Commerce Secretary William M. Daley laid down the Clinton administration's strategy this past spring for forcing the China trade bill through a reluctant Congress, he insisted repeatedly that, win or lose, Congress had to vote before the summer political conventions.
"You just don't want to be debating China during the heat of the fall campaign," Mr. Daley said then. "You do that and all bets are off." 
 Now, Mr. Daley has left the administration to head Al Gore's presidential campaign, and the China trade bill, having cleared the House in May with seemingly unstoppable momentum, has become tied up in the Senate's arcane maneuvering on the budget, efforts to punish China for weapons proliferation, and general procedural gridlock.
The Senate will adjourn on Friday for the summer having barely begun to debate, much less vote, on the measure that Mr. Clinton repeatedly called a national security priority and his top remaining legislative goal.
Both the Clinton administration and the Senate leadership expect the bill to pass. The Senate voted 86 to 12 this afternoon to open a debate on China trade, overcoming a procedural hurdle to schedule full consideration of the measure in early September. Nearly 70 senators are thought to support the bill itself.
Yet the fears Mr. Daley expressed last spring over the fate of the China bill have come true: It became a political hostage while the White House and Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, clashed over annual appropriations bills and while Democrats focused on unrelated legislative goals. Meanwhile, the political needs of the Gore campaign sidelined Mr. Daley from the White House lobbying campaign to pass the trade bill, leaving Steven Richetti, a less prominent political hand, in charge of the effort.
"The patients' bill of rights is simply not an important matter compared to the possibility of nuclear stand-off in Asia," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who has argued that the United States could face a military confrontation with China if Congress fails to approve permanent trade ties.
"We -- and I mean the Democrats, the White House and the Republicans -- simply do not recognize the weight of this matter," he said.
Administration officials said that China remained one of Mr. Clinton's foremost priorities. But since the bill passed the House, the president and many of his top aides have been focused on other issues that will shape his legacy, including brokering a Middle East peace accord, rejecting Republican tax-cut initiatives and, perhaps most of all, helping Mr. Gore become president.
The president allowed Mr. Daley, who headed the aggressive lobbying effort on behalf of the China bill from January to June, to resign to take over Mr. Gore's lagging campaign. Mr. Richetti, the deputy White House chief of staff who was Mr. Daley's partner in shepherding the China bill through the House, was left to see it through the Senate.
Mr. Richetti said the prospects for passage were good in September, despite earlier concerns that Democrats might have a hard time voting for a trade measure staunchly opposed by labor so soon before a tight election. He urged Mr. Lott to stop using the China bill as a legislative negotiating lever.
"There is wide bipartisan support for this," Mr. Richetti said. "It's far too important a national security and economic issue to be used as a bargaining chip for other matters."
Few fault Mr. Richetti's political skills or his attention to the China trade issue. But several senators and business lobbyists who support the China trade bill said that Mr. Daley has been missed.
Widely considered Mr. Clinton's best political strategist, Mr. Daley has a no-nonsense style and, among Clinton administration officials, a rare track record of working successfully with the Republican-led Congress. He also demanded -- and was granted -- broad influence over Mr. Clinton's schedule, arranging many public and private events to show that the president had no higher priority than China.
"We had a sense of urgency in the House and then we lost it -- Daley leaving, the president had some other things, you had the appropriations bills," said Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "We need to get that urgency back."
He said that while there is plenty of support for the measure in the Senate, it will now be subject to intense political pressures and a crowded legislative calendar in the fall.
One senior administration official described the view that Mr. Daley's departure signaled a downshift on the China bill as "totally false." The official argued that the stall in the Senate began even before Mr. Daley left and that the strategy put in place by Mr. Daley and Mr. Richetti for dealing with those delays remained.
They and several Senate Democrats put the blame squarely on the Republican caucus and Mr. Lott, who exercises almost complete control of the Senate's daily agenda. Despite overwhelming support from their core constituency -- business -- Mr. Lott repeatedly refused to schedule a firm date for a vote in June or July.
Republicans see the China vote as a tough one for Democrats because it requires that they offend core labor and environmental constituencies, making a September vote politically appealing. "I think it's clear that the Republicans want to make it as difficult as possible on the Democrats," said Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader.

HEADLINE: San Francisco Newspaper Can Be Sold, Judge Rules

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
A federal judge in San Francisco ruled yesterday that the Hearst Corporation's $660 million purchase of The San Francisco Chronicle did not violate antitrust laws and that the company would have had legal justification for closing The San Francisco Examiner had it chosen to.
The Chronicle has been a fierce journalistic rival of The Examiner, the newspaper that gave William Randolph Hearst his start in publishing, for more than a century. The two newspapers have also been business partners for the past 35 years. 
 In his ruling, the judge, Vaughn R. Walker of Federal District Court, noted that The Examiner's financial condition was so weak that it "imposes a substantial drain on the profitability" of the newspaper agency whose profits were shared by both papers. The Chronicle's circulation of 464,943 is more than four times The Examiner's.
Since the closing of The Examiner would have been economically justified, its subsidized sale to the politically influential Fang family in San Francisco was laced with what Judge Walker called "malodorous aspects," in reference to the complicated political and legal dance behind the sale.
The sale to the Fangs came in March, after weeks of pressure from the Justice Department, which was threatening to use its regulatory authority to block the sale of The Chronicle. For months, Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr., a Fang ally, had also promised to fight any effort to close The Examiner.
In last fall's mayoral election campaign, The Examiner's publisher, Timothy White, offered to "horse trade" with the mayor. According to evidence presented in the trial, Mr. White suggested that The Examiner would give editorial support to Mayor Brown in return for his political support for the paper's business plans.
Last March, Hearst agreed to sell the newspaper to the Fangs' business and give it a subsidy of up to $66 million for three years to help keep a truncated version of the newspaper alive. While the judge was critical of the Justice Department stance that provoked the sale, he said that Clinton Riley, who had challenged the transfer of The Examiner, did not have legal standing to make that claim. .
Judge Walker's decision paves the way for Hearst to act on its plans to merge the Chronicle and Examiner newsrooms and to compete with Bay Area rivals. The San Jose Mercury News, owned by Knight Ridder, this week began delivering a special San Francisco edition, firing the first shot in the latest battle for readers in one of the country's wealthiest areas.

HEADLINE: A City With Too Much Housing;
Syracuse Hopes to Clear Deserted Eyesores From Streets

SERIES: THE OTHER ECONOMY: Struggling Against Blight

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
If only it were near New York City, 403 Rowland Street might be a handy home-buyer's dream. Sure, the side porch is collapsing, the chimney is crumbling, and the big front windows have been replaced by small squinty ones. But the vintage charms of this turn-of-the-century house, including sturdy construction and gingerbread trim, would probably look alluring to the housing-hungry hordes in southern New York State.
The view is quite different here, near the center of the state, near the center of Syracuse, near the center of a working-class neighborhood known as Skunk City. So it is hard to argue with Millie Compeau, sitting on the porch of the tidy house where she has lived for 89 of her 92 years, when she peers across Rowland Street at No. 403 and decrees, "That house should come down." 
 A lot of people are starting to agree. That is because Syracuse has more houses -- a lot more houses -- than its 152,000 citizens need or want. Like the place on Rowland Street, as many as 2,200 of them are empty or abandoned, more than 10 percent of the houses within the city limits.
Boarded-up houses mar some of Syracuse's nicest neighborhoods and fill blocks in some of the worst. Skunk City, where residents say the namesake critters still roam at night, is somewhere in between: a well-kept house is followed by a rundown place, then another nice one, then an abandoned wreck -- or two or three.
The problem is so bad that last fall, government and civic leaders began the Syracuse Neighborhood Initiative to try to bring back blighted areas of the city. Representative James T. Walsh, a Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, whose father grew up in Skunk City, has already gotten $15 million in federal financing for the initiative.
As part of the project, many in Syracuse are embracing an idea that has long been anathema to almost everyone trying to save urban areas: demolishing houses -- and not rebuilding them.
"The truth is, getting money to do tear-downs is very hard," said Allison Lee, a senior official in the Albany office of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. But after touring areas where problem properties have been knocked down, she said, "I have to tell you, the neighborhoods are better."
Syracuse is not the only place upstate suffering from abandoned housing, which afflicts almost every old city east of Detroit. But perhaps because Syracuse is so small and is not a corporate or government center, the problem seems more overwhelming than in other cities.
"Ours is the most serious problem because we have the least resources," said Eric Mower, an advertising executive who is chairman of the initiative.
How Syracuse came to such a pass is a tangled tale of failures in public policies and changes in private tastes, but most of all, of economics. The 1991 recession that hit all of New York State came to Syracuse and would not leave. Long after the economy began to rebound to the south, central New York stagnated.
That is no longer true, at least on paper. New jobs have been sprouting here at a faster pace than almost anywhere else north of New York City, and unemployment is only 3.7 percent, well under the national average of 4.2 percent.
The housing market is improving, too, after dropping sharply in the mid-1990's and treading water for years. Last year, the number of houses sold in and around Syracuse rose more than 10 percent, according to the Greater Syracuse Association of Realtors, and the median price edged up to $82,500 (which is still less than the median in 1994).
Within the city, however, house prices still seem to be dropping, according to a study by the federal Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation for the Syracuse Neighborhood Initiative. That is, when houses sell at all. In Skunk City, there were just four regular sales last year, according to the report. Tax auctions and foreclosure sales have become the norm.
City inspectors report that more than 1,000 houses in the city remain vacant, and the number has been rising. Minchin G. Lewis, the city auditor, says that the correct figure is more like 2,200, based on the number of water meters that have been unused for a year.
The vacant houses that people see all over the city remind them of the terrible economic times they have endured -- and help explain why the good news announced by economists does not seem to have sunk into the psyche of Syracuse's citizens. "They're shellshocked from the decline that has taken place," Mr. Lewis said.
That was clear at a city council hearing, held on July 19 to discuss plans to build a big mall in the city. Dozens of residents spoke, and many described Syracuse in apocalyptic terms.
"This city is in a real crisis," said Melanie Duer, 43, who after a disabling accident used her insurance settlement to buy and fix up a small apartment building in Skunk City, near where she grew up. In 1994, she told city officials, there were 6 vacant houses on the main road between her building and downtown; today, she said, there are 36.
In a later interview, Ms. Duer expressed frustration with politicians who, she said, find it easy to overlook her neighborhood. When President and Hillary Clinton visited Syracuse last year, the president played golf less than a mile away from her building, "but it might as well have been in Zimbabwe," she said. "They could really make a difference if they walked on this street. I'm just one voice with a weed whacker."
On the surface, Skunk City does not look like a slum. Each one- or two-family house has a little strip of grass in the front and a plot in the back, with just enough room for a shed or a garage. Many of the houses are trim and tidy. Marigolds and petunias edge walks. Children of all colors ride their bicycles up and down the streets.
Hang around for a while, however, and problems appear. Drug dealers, for instance.
On Rowland Street, a young man announces, "I'm gonna cop," and with money in his hand crosses to the corner where a couple loiter. A block away, there is a lot of furtive activity around a pay phone on the corner. Down the street, a high-stakes craps game continues in one driveway. Residents complain that illegal car-repair joints sprout on the bigger streets.
And on almost every block, like a bruise, is an unkempt house with a sagging porch, a trash-filled yard, a pile of old dumped tires, or broken windows partly boarded up.
There have been some shootings and stabbings, said Richard Puchalski, who as executive director of Syracuse United Neighbors seems to know every block of Skunk City. "A lot of folks who have lived here 40 or 50 or 60 years are finding it difficult to maintain their houses," he said. "They are being pressured by their siblings, who say, 'You'd better get the hell out of there.' "
Even in its heyday, Skunk City was not the fanciest part of town. It was too close to the swamp; developers crammed as many houses as possible in narrow lots along the new sewer line. In more recent decades, the threat of a highway project discouraged people from moving in.
But to the people who lived there, it was a "garden spot of Eden," according to the yellowing newspaper clippings preserved at the Onondaga Historical Association. For the children, there was fishing and skating and swimming; for the adults, there were plenty of saloons and a movie house.
The men in the neighborhood had steady jobs at the post office, the railroad or the auto plants. Some were more colorful: Florence Joslin's father sang on the radio, while the Schwald boys' dad had been a roller skater in a vaudeville act, the Whirling Hamilton Trio, before he settled down to raise a family.
"When we were kids, 15, 16 years old, our father could leave the car in the driveway with the keys in it," said Dennis J. Schwald Sr., 58. "Nobody touched nothing."
Back then, said his brother William, 61, "everyone owned their own home." He added, "We've seen it gone down and down." Both men, who retired from the Carrier air-conditioner plant, still live on Hartson Street, as did their parents and in-laws; now, Dennis's son owns two houses on the street.
But such roots have gone out of fashion, even in Syracuse. Today, many young families -- and older ones, too -- prefer to live out in the suburbs, where the houses are newer, the lots bigger and the schools better. The amount of developed land around the city has almost doubled in the last decade, said Vito Sciscioli, the city's commissioner for community and economic development.
Meanwhile, the region's population has been shrinking, with most of the drain coming from within the city limits. From 1990 to mid-1999, the population of Onondaga County shrank by 13,000, with 12,000 of the drop occurring in Syracuse, according to federal census estimates.
That left Syracuse with "a brutal oversupply of housing," said Eric Hangen, who wrote the report for the Syracuse Neighborhood Initiative. People who wanted to sell could not. People who wanted to fix up their homes would not because they feared rightly that they could not recoup their investments, he said.
Desperate homeowners took to renting out their unwanted houses, or selling them to slum lords, or abandoning them altogether because they could not pay the mortgages. Or the taxes, especially after the city started seizing delinquent properties a couple of years ago.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development alone now lists about 50 houses for sale in the city. Some of them are priced at less than $15,000, which is roughly what it would cost to knock them down.
In the 1980's, the Syracuse Model Neighborhood Corporation, a housing group, built houses on vacant lots and sold them for $78,000, but no more.
"In the last two years I've built one house," said Thomas Francis, who runs the group. "There's no demand, and I can't afford to hold on to them."
Fundamentally, Mr. Francis said, "there just are not enough people."
Ergo, demolition -- or de-densifying, as some people call it. The idea is to tear down not only those abandoned houses that threaten to collapse on their own, but also those that are simply unneeded and uneconomical. The land could be split between the remaining nearby houses, to give them bigger yards, or driveways, or garages (popular in snowy Syracuse). Big tracts could be turned into parks.
The plan, in other words, is to make the city more like the suburbs.
"The suburbs are the best part of America," said Greg G. Smith, a landlord with 60 units on the west side of the city. "Everybody loves having a decent-size yard and off-street parking. They want breathing room enough that when somebody's alarm clock goes off, it doesn't wake you up."
If the houses that get knocked down are simply replaced, he added, "you're preserving the streetscape that everybody hates." As part of the neighborhood initiative, he is hoping to get financing for a master plan and small grants to try out this idea on the west side of town.
Exactly how much housing will be demolished in Syracuse remains unclear. Each of the city's neighborhoods gets to make recommendations about what improvements it would like. In some of the more prosperous areas, residents are calling for improvements like period streetlights or a new botanical garden.
Representative Walsh said that no more than a third of the federal money, $5 million so far, could be used for demolition; at $12,000 a pop, the city's estimate, that would be about 417 houses.
No one is suggesting that demolition will solve all the problems in Syracuse's neighborhoods. "It's good to have that strategy," said Mr. Sciscioli, the city commissioner, "but if you don't address basic services, you can kiss it all goodbye."
Back in Skunk City, however, longtime residents like Patricia D. Masters are looking forward to some demolition. "I'd like to see them do it a little quicker," she said. "How long do you have to have a dead house on your street?"
 
The Other Economy
Upstate New York, a vast, diverse landscape of old cities, small towns, farms and forests stretching from Buffalo to Albany and north to the Canadian border, was once one of the most populous and prosperous regions of the country. But the national economic boom that swept into New York City and its suburbs passed it by. This is the fourth in a series of articles examining the region's quest for prosperity.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES;
New Translation For 'Rififi'

BYLINE: By Dave Kehr 

 BODY:
Usually, asking a director when he first encountered Stanislavsky is not a question about a literal meeting, but Jules Dassin has a literal answer.
"The man himself? Shall I tell you? It was in 1923, when the producer Morris Guest brought the Moscow Art Theater to New York. I was a boy, and I saw this with my own eyes. John Barrymore was playing 'Hamlet' at that time, and he had heard of Stanislavsky and his great actors. And it seems he cut big chunks out of his 'Hamlet' that night to run and see some of the Moscow Art Theater. He made his entrance still dressed in his inky black Hamlet costume, and rushed up to the stage and kissed the feet of the director and the actors. I saw that!" 
 Mr. Dassin, a vigorous 89, was in New York recently to introduce the rerelease of "Rififi," the classic caper film he made in France in 1955, after the blacklist forced him to leave Hollywood. "The title comes from the North African tribe, the Rifs, who were in constant conflict," he said. "So it's all about melees and conflicts and fighting, out of which the novelist Auguste Le Breton made the word 'rififi.'
"He went on to write 'Rififi in Tokyo,' 'Rififi in San Domingo,' 'Rififi in Flatbush' and so on."
Translating 1950's underworld slang into subtitles for 2000 posed a problem for Mr. Dassin, who worked with Bruce Goldstein (whose company, Rialto Pictures, has released the film in the United States) and the journalist Lenny Borger to create a new English text.
"Breton's characters spoke a very special language, and one unknown to many parts of France outside of the Paris circle," Mr. Dassin said. "When I was given the book to read, I understood nothing of it. It was a very special argot, and I should not be surprised if he invented some of it. To know what the book was about, I had a guy read it to me who was a specialist."
Mr. Dassin, born in Middletown, Conn., and raised in the Bronx, landed in Europe after the director Edward Dmytryk named him in the hearings by the House Committee on Un-American Activities into Communist influence in Hollywood. Having specialized in film noir in Hollywood ("The Naked City," "Brute Force") Mr. Dassin returned to the genre for his first film in France, and it became a worldwide hit.
In 1964 he went back to the form for "Topkapi," with its famous high-wire burglary scene -- a sequence that Mr. Dassin was surprised to find re-enacted without acknowledgment in Brian De Palma's 1996 "Mission: Impossible." "That shocked me," he said. "I think it was just too literal, the same thing. I said, 'Is this allowed?' Apparently it was."
After shooting "Rififi" in Paris, Mr. Dassin discovered Greece, where he met and married the actress Melina Mercouri, who starred in his 1960 film "Never on Sunday" as well as "Topkapi." Athens remained his home after her death in 1994. "I stopped working right after my wife died, to continue on with some of the unfinished projects she undertook when she was the Greek Minister of Culture. We've created a foundation in her name. And I'm trying to get a museum built. There are wonderful educational projects in schools, with fascinating results. That's all my time now."
 
The New Zemeckis
One of the handful of Hollywood filmmakers still able to put a personal stamp on his work, Robert Zemeckis made his name with big, broad comedies like "Back to the Future" and "Who Framed Roger Rabbit." But since "Forrest Gump" in 1994, a more melancholic strain has appeared in his films. His last two features, "Contact" (1997) and the current "What Lies Beneath," are both about emotionally isolated women whose attempts to break through to others lead them to relationships, possibly hallucinated, with otherworldly beings.
"Someday, some scholar is going to be able to line up my movies and watch the arc of my life," Mr. Zemeckis, 48, said by telephone. "There's some thread in there about understanding the importance of being able to develop an emotional intimacy with other people, and the wall you come up against from time to time. It's usually within yourself, of course."
"What Lies Beneath" is a suspense thriller, "written in the language of Hitchcock," said Mr. Zemeckis, about an unhappy housewife (Michelle Pfeiffer) who finds that an unwelcome entity has joined her marriage with Harrison Ford.
"You begin to understand more complex characters as you build up some years," Mr. Zemeckis said. "I couldn't have made this movie 15 years ago, and I couldn't have made 'Contact.' That's why I think it's important to take these little sabbaticals in between movies. If you're not careful, just making movie after movie can isolate you too. It's a very isolating job; even though you go all over the world and you do all these things, it's a very, very unrealistic way of living."
There has been no sabbatical for Mr. Zemeckis lately. "What Lies Beneath" was made while the director was waiting for Tom Hanks to lose weight and grow a beard for his role as a plane crash survivor living on a desert island in "Cast Away," which is to be released at Christmas.
"We did the first two-thirds of 'Cast Away,' and then we stopped," the director said. "I rolled the crew onto this movie, and then rolled them back on to the end of 'Cast Away,' which is the only way I could have done it, because no one except David Lean could stop the camera for 30 days. No one can afford to do that, so I had to figure out an economical way, and one way was to make a whole other movie."
For Mr. Zemeckis, "Cutting for comedy and cutting for jolts is the same. It's all timing, which ultimately comes down to individual frames. It's exactly like leading the audience to the punch line. You can literally be off by half a second and it won't be as effective."
 
An Iranian's Themes
Abbas Kiarostami's acclaimed Iranian film "The Wind Will Carry Us" opens in New York today (review, Page 7) accompanied by "Kiarostami 101," an instructive 20-minute short assembled by the film scholar Jamsheed Akrami. With brevity and wit, the short sketches out the characteristic themes and images of Mr. Kiarostami's work, which many critics place among the most beautiful being produced today.
Mr. Akrami, who is an associate professor of film at William Paterson University, first wrote about Mr. Kiarostami's work in the early 70's, when the director was making films for Kanun, the Iranian government's Institute for Intellectual Development of Children and Adolescents. Then came the revolution, and Mr. Akrami found a six-month visit to the United States turning into a 22-year stay.
There's more where these 20 minutes came from. "When I interviewed Abbas," Mr. Akrami said, "I shot six hours of video, and we only talked about his first two films. There's a lot more to cover."

HEADLINE: Resisting Gentrification

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 22 news article about gentrification in Park Slope, Brooklyn, humanized a complex issue that is affecting many low-income communities of color across the country. Effective solutions exist to enable residents in danger of displacement to stay in their neighborhoods and take part in the economic benefits of revitalization.
An emerging approach called equitable development emphasizes the positive effect of mixed-income communities, and helps residents to have a voice in decision-making and to acquire the skills and resources needed to stay anchored in their neighborhoods. 
 Longtime residents are afforded the opportunity to buy homes, gain jobs at a living wage, and build community-based businesses. This approach is essential to maintaining the diversity and vitality of American communities.
 
ANGELA GLOVER BLACKWELL
Oakland, Calif., July 25, 2000
 
The writer is president of PolicyLink, a national policy organization.

HEADLINE: Chief Is Selected For the Rebuilding Of Lincoln Center

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Lincoln Center has named Rebecca Robertson, a city planner who led the government effort to redevelop West 42nd Street, to be the field marshal in its $1.5 billion rebuilding project.
The appointment, confirmed yesterday, is part of a new management plan to oversee and finance the redevelopment project, by far the largest in the center's four-decade history. 
 The actions were detailed by Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, in a telephone interview after word of Ms. Robertson's appointment began circulating informally.
She said construction could start in two years and would take until 2010 to complete, upsetting many performing schedules as it proceeds.
"We are moving ahead quite steadily," Ms. Sills said.
As outlined in December in a consultant's study, the projected work -- new structures, rooftop additions, skyboxes and widespread repairs -- is likely to cost more in adjusted dollars than the original Lincoln Center, the world's biggest and busiest performing arts presenter. The city has committed $96 million to the project, but the bulk of the money remains to be raised. Difficult questions also remain about how to reschedule performances around the construction work.
Ms. Robertson, now vice president for real estate and special projects at the Shubert Organization, said in an interview yesterday that she would begin work part time at Lincoln Center on Aug. 7 and full time in mid-September, "supervising the master-planning of the complex, its vision and implementation." She is to report to a new renovation committee under a vice chairman of Lincoln Center, Marshall Rose, a leading real estate developer.
That panel, in turn, is answerable to a new Project Leadership Committee composed of the chairmen and artistic directors of the center's 12 resident arts organizations, including the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the New York City Ballet and Opera.
The chairwoman of the leadership committee, which first met on Jan. 31, is Ms. Sills, who is also supervising the search for a new president of Lincoln Center to replace Nathan Leventhal, who is leaving on Dec. 31 after 17 years. The panel met most recently on Thursday, when Ms. Robertson was introduced.
Ms. Robertson will be the executive director of the reconstruction committee, and a second committee will supervise fund-raising for the project. Its co-chairmen will probably be four major money-raisers, but they have not been appointed.
Ms. Robertson, 50, described the Lincoln Center project as "the great urban renewal project of New York City."
She said she envisaged the job's taking easily as long as the decade she spent on the overhaul of 42nd Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. For the last seven years of her tenure, which ended in 1997, she was president of the 42nd Street Development Project Inc. The state-chartered entity attracted Disney, Livent, Forest City Ratner and other entertainment and redevelopment companies as replacements for evicted sex storefronts and X-rated movie houses.
Before that Ms. Robertson, who was born in Canada, worked in planning and development in Toronto and Caracas and in the New York City Planning Department. She joined the Shubert Organization, Broadway's largest theater owner, in 1997 and, among other projects, helped develop the new 499-seat Shubert theater being built on Theater Row on West 42nd Street.
Ms. Sills said that the leadership committee was intended to reassure Lincoln Center's constituent groups that they would have a central say in the rebuilding.
The scope of the project covering the 18 acres Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues and 62nd and 66th Streets has not been determined. In its three-inch-thick report to the board last December, the Manhattan architectural firm Beyer, Blinder & Belle laid out a range of needs, from repairs to the cracked plaza paving blocks and deteriorating travertine cladding on the buildings to additional rehearsal, performing and reception space.
In particular, the study says, the options included rooftop additions and skyboxes for Avery Fisher Hall, where the Philharmonic performs, another rooftop addition for the Juilliard School, a loft for Alice Tully Hall, new space for the New York State Theater, an expanded lobby and museum for the Metropolitan Opera, a new central visitors' center and ticket office and a new administrative building in Damrosch Park.
Last December some Lincoln Center executives described some items as part of a wish list that was to be fulfilled.
Ms. Sills said yesterday that the cost might grow beyond $1.5 billion. "At first we thought a lot of it was just wish list," she said. "I do not think it's a wish list any more."

HEADLINE: A Spike in Electricity Prices Sets Off Debate in California

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 28

 BODY:
With electricity prices soaring in San Diego, and consumer anger rising even faster, California politicians are backing away from the state's ambitious plan to deregulate its power industry fully by 2002.
The fight in California, which four years ago led what has become a national movement to deregulate the electric industry, is likely to presage a debate across the country over whether deregulation is working, politicians here say. 
 "It's a nationwide problem," said State Senator Steve Peace, a San Diego Democrat who helped write the deregulation legislation but is now calling for some government controls on prices.
High demand and tight supplies have given too much market power to a few generators and power marketers, causing prices to spike unreasonably, Mr. Peace said.
"The market can either prove that it's disciplined enough and stable enough to address its problem," he said, "or, inevitably, whether it's the right thing to do or the wrong thing to do, the political system will cut them off at the pass."
That view gained momentum on Thursday, when Gov. Gray Davis asked the federal government to impose controls on the wholesale price of electricity across the West. Residential consumers and businesses need relief from price spikes that caused the average monthly electric bill in San Diego to more than double in June, the governor said.
"When California deregulated the electricity market in 1996," Mr. Davis said, "consumers were promised that competition in the marketplace would be mature enough to ensure stable, if not reduced, prices. That is clearly not the case in California."
Big swings in the wholesale price of electricity are not unusual in the summer, when high demand taxes generators' ability to supply power. In New England, the wholesale cost of power reached more than 100 times its usual level for a few hours during an unexpected heat wave this May. But because of regulation, consumers and businesses have always been insulated from the swings, paying one price for electricity year-round, regardless of its true cost.
Now, as California makes the complex transition from a regulated to a competitive market, San Diego has become the first market in the nation where consumers must pay retail prices that move with the true wholesale price as it changes from month to month. And they are not happy.
"San Diego in many ways is the poster child for how not to do deregulation," said Michael Shames, executive director of the Utility Consumers Action Network, a 42,000-member group based in San Diego, where the average monthly residential bill rose in June to more than $100, from about $50.
But power companies and many economists argue that price controls are a misguided and shortsighted measure that will only increase the risk of blackouts in both the short run and the long. Price caps failed on both natural gas and gasoline, and they will fail on electricity, said William Hogan, a professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard who has studied deregulation and worked as a consultant for utilities.
"We used to have lots of shortages of natural gas; now we have lots of natural gas," Professor Hogan said. "The reason we had shortages is we had price controls. That's what electricity is facing now."
Nationally, independent power generators are moving quickly to add new plants to bring supply and demand back into line, said Jeffrey K. Skilling, president of the Enron Corporation, a Houston company that is the world's leading trader of electricity and natural gas.
"Let the market do its thing," Mr. Skilling said. "The system is tight around the country, but there's been an enormous supply response."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Seeks W.T.O. Talks On Mexican Phone Market

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Just weeks before Mexico's president-elect, Vicente Fox, is scheduled to make his first visit to Washington to discuss commercial relations with the United States, the Clinton Administration took the first steps yesterday toward filing a formal complaint against Mexico for failing to ensure open competition in its $12 billion telecommunications market.
As she had warned several times since April, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, is asking the World Trade Organization to hold formal consultations between the United States and Mexico on the way Mexico supervises its recently deregulated telecommunications industry. 
 Several American corporations, including AT&T and WorldCom, have invested millions in Mexico since deregulation began in the mid-1990's. They have complained for the last year that they have been stymied by the actions of Telefonos de Mexico, the dominant carrier, and by weak-kneed Mexican regulators who have failed to stand up to the company, known as Telmex.
AT&T, along with Mexican partners, owns Alestra, a long-distance company. WorldCom owns a controlling share of Avantel, another long-distance company, also with Mexican associates.
The trade representative accuses Telmex of several anticompetitive actions. The United States contends that Telmex overcharges to connect local calls to the long-distance networks, applies unfair fees for incoming international long-distance phone calls, and denies competitors the high-traffic lines they need for Internet service.
Telecommunications regulators are accused of failing to properly enforce deregulation commitments that Mexico agreed to in 1998.
The issue has become a sore point in commercial relations between the United States and Mexico, its second-largest trading partner, giving rise to harsh statements in a field usually noted for diplomatic restraint.
"Clearly, the regulatory system in Mexico is entirely broken," Ms. Barshefsky said in a conference call with reporters yesterday morning. She said she had little faith that Mexican officials in the outgoing administration of President Ernesto Zedillo would keep promises to resolve the regulatory issues before Mr. Fox is inaugurated on Dec. 1.
"We've heard that song before," she said.
In Mexico, Jorge Nicolin, president of the Federal Telecommunications Commission, said that the trade representative's complaint was "unfounded and not substantiated." He said he was confident Mexico would successfully defend its position.
"We've met with U.S.T.R. three times already this year and as we explain at every step, it is because we have competition in Mexico that we have these problems," he said.
By Mr. Nicolin's count, 12 competing long-distance carriers operate in Mexico, along with 7 local carriers. He acknowledged that competitive problems exist, but said that formulation of new regulations to promote competition had been delayed by legal challenges from Telmex and other telephone companies. They should be ready by the end of October, he added.
A Telmex spokesman, Arturo Elias Ayub, refuted the trade representative's claim that Telmex had actually increased its share of the long-distance market to 81 percent from 74 percent three years ago. "We wish it were that high," he said, contending that Telmex handled no more than 60 percent.
If no settlement is reached within 60 days after the World Trade Organization consultations begin, Ms. Barshefsky said the United States would file a formal complaint before the W.T.O.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Take a Daily Hit, and the Nasdaq Gets a Downright Beating for the Week

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled yesterday as a report of unexpectedly strong economic growth increased the threat of another Federal Reserve interest rate increase.
The Nasdaq composite index plunged 4.7 percent, finishing the week off 10.5 percent, its third worst week ever. Its technology stocks have been under pressure for more than a week because of concerns about weaker corporate earnings in the second half of the year. And that concern has begun to spread, adding to the selling pressure yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.7 percent. 
 But interest rates rose only slightly, probably because inflation remained in check despite the strong second-quarter growth.
A strong economy is usually positive for stocks because growth is good for corporate earnings. But at a time when the nation's central bank has pledged to slow the economy's growth to a noninflationary pace, the 5.2 percent second-quarter surge in the gross domestic product that the Commerce Department reported yesterday was read as a negative.
The jolt from the report was intensified by two factors. One was the surprise. Most economists had been expecting the economy to slow to a pace of around 3.5 percent to 4 percent, from over 5 percent in the first quarter. "Signs of a slowing economy are hard to find in this latest batch of numbers," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
In addition, many investors had begun to think that the Fed might be finished with its interest rate increases, after pushing up its benchmark federal funds rate six times, to 6.5 percent, since June 1999. The chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, may have inadvertently re-enforced this view when he outlined the reasons he believed growth was slowing when he testified before the Senate Banking Committee July 20.
But another rate increase is still not a certainty, some analysts argued. This is because the data yesterday also reflected several positive trends: a slowdown in consumer spending, contained inflationary pressures and strong business investment that could lead to even higher worker productivity.
It has been the surprising increase in worker productivity the last several years that has allowed the economy, which is now in its longest expansion on record, to grow briskly without a surge in inflation. And Mr. Greenspan indicated in his recent testimony that if these positive trends continued, a rate increase might be avoided.
So the path between now and the Fed's policy-making meeting Aug. 22 could be bumpy. The data for July, which will be released between now and then, including that on jobs, retail sales and consumer inflation, will probably determine what the Fed does, a point that Mr. Greenspan made in his appearance before Congress on Tuesday.
"If the consumer looks like he is ramping up again, then that is a threat," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank.
Mr. Glassman thinks the pace of consumer spending is slowing, in part because higher oil and gasoline prices are cutting into income and in part because some big companies are worried about sales slowing in the second half of the year. But yesterday's data, along with the June jumps in existing-home sales and orders for durable goods and the July increase in consumer confidence, do give him pause. Even so, he is still not predicting a rate increase in August.
William Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, thinks consumer spending has not slowed significantly. Instead, he argued that the 3 percent growth in spending in the second quarter, down from 7.7 percent in the first quarter, was just a pause. The key for Fed policy makers and investors, he said, "is why did the consumer pull back in the second quarter and will it continue."
He expects another interest rate increase in August. "This idea that the Fed is done with tightening is premature because the economy has more momentum than people think," Mr. Dudley said.
Only a small rally in the last minutes of trading prevented all three major stock indexes from ending at their lows for the day. The Nasdaq composite index fell 179.23 points, to 3,663.00, led lower by Cisco Systems, JDS Uniphase and Intel. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes many of the same big technology stocks that pulled down the Nasdaq, dropped 29.73 points, or 2.05 percent, to 1,419.89. The Dow, which has a lighter load of technology stocks, dropped 74.96 points, to 10,511.17. The Dow was led lower by declines at American Express and J. P. Morgan & Company.
For the week, the Dow was down 2.1 percent, while the S.& P. was off 4.1 percent. For the year, all three indexes are down, with the Nasdaq off 10 percent, the Dow down 8.6 percent and the S.& P. slipping 3.4 percent.
Despite yesterday's selling, the stock of Corvis, a maker of equipment for fiber optic cables, more than doubled on its first day of trading. The stock jumped 48 23/32, to 84 23/32, although the company has yet to show any revenue.
In the bond market, prices and yields were little changed as one measure of inflation in the gross domestic price data showed price increases falling to a rate of 2.5 percent in the second quarter from 3.3 percent in the first. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 6.03 percent, from 6.00 percent on Thursday. The note's price, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, fell 8/32, to 1031 2/32.
The confusion among investors about what the Fed might do is understandable because the central bank's job is not just to slow the pace of economic growth. Instead, policy makers want to slow growth to a noninflationary pace. But as they are trying to do this, the acceptable noninflationary speed limit for growth is rising because of stronger worker productivity. The Fed's speed limit has already jumped from around 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent in the early 1990's to 3.5 percent to 4 percent now. And who knows whether it will move higher.
"If people are disoriented, it certainly makes sense," Mr. Glassman said. "We are not used to this type of growth."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Breaking The Silence

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Imagine a country, a democracy, with a domestic program that is increasingly costly and socially disruptive. The problem it is supposed to solve has actually grown worse over the years -- but neither major political party will talk about changing the policy.
That is a picture of the United States and its drug policy. By any rational test the war on drugs, with its use of the criminal law and harsh sentences to solve the problem, is a costly failure. The number of Americans in prison for drug offenses has multiplied by 10 since 1980, from 41,000 to 458,000. But drugs are more available than ever, and more young people are using them. 
 In the face of this political and social disaster the Republican and Democratic parties offer: silence. Their leaders are evidently afraid that even discussing different approaches might get them labeled as soft on drugs.
But the silence is about to be broken. In tandem with the Republican National Convention starting Monday in Philadelphia, and later with the Democrats, there will be shadow conventions that discuss the failed war on drugs and two other issues that the major parties have not solved: campaign finance and the gap between rich and poor.
Senator John McCain and other politicians brave enough to break with their parties' wishes will participate. Senator McCain will be the keynote speaker tomorrow, talking about the idea that makes him anathema to so many other Republicans: ending the scandal of campaign money and influence.
The shadow conventions are the brainchild of Arianna Huffington, the columnist and gadfly. She has moved from the political right toward the left -- or perhaps to a position of dislike for all evasive politicians. The shadow conventions will have participants from all camps.
Representative Tom Campbell of California, the Republican candidate for Senate against the incumbent Dianne Feinstein, will talk about the failed drug war. So will another Republican brave enough to challenge the policy, Gov. Gary Johnson of New Mexico, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Walter Cronkite, the greatly respected former broadcast newsman, has made a 10-minute video special for the shadow convention on the cost of the drug war.
The staggering figure mentioned above -- that 10 times as many Americans are in prison for drug offenses today as in 1980 -- comes from the Justice Policy Institute in Washington. It has just issued a report that shows, in fresh ways, some consequences of the war on drugs.
The 458,000 men and women now in U.S. prisons on drug charges are 100,000 more than all prisoners in the European Union, whose population is 100 million more than ours. The annual cost of incarcerating them is $9 billion.
Nearly 80 percent of drug arrests in 1997, the most recent year for which figures are available, were for possession. Of those, 44 percent were for possession of marijuana.
Blacks are overwhelmingly more likely than whites to be imprisoned for drug offenses, a study by Human Rights Watch showed. Just 13 percent of regular drug users in this country are black, but 62.7 percent of drug offenders sentenced to prison are black. Evidently juries and judges treat offenders less seriously if they are white.
The Justice Policy Institute report found that in 1986, 31 out of every 100,000 young people in America were put in state prisons for drug offenses. By 1996 the figure had nearly quadrupled, to 122 per 100,000.
The institute studied states with higher rates of imprisonment for drug offenses to see whether that had a deterrent effect. It found, to the contrary, that states with higher incarceration rates also had higher rates of drug use.
There are already signs around the country of unease with the human cost and practical failure of our drug policy. Perhaps the shadow conventions will move more political leaders to face the reality recently stated by The Economist of London: "That misguided policy has put millions of people behind bars, cost billions, encouraged crime and spread corruption while failing completely to reduce drug abuse."
Ralph Nader has chided me for saying that he has paid little or no attention as a candidate to the civil liberties record of the major parties. In fact he has called the Clinton administration's record "abysmal."

HEADLINE: Economy Grew at a Robust 5.2% Rate in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Despite a pullback in consumer spending, the American economy grew at a surprisingly robust 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
A widely expected slowdown failed to materialize. In fact, the economy actually grew faster in the second quarter than in the first. But for all its strength, the second quarter offered just enough signs of weakness to raise doubts about the future of the longest economic expansion in the nation's history. 
 Business investment, particularly in computers and software, sustained the growth, and so did corporate willingness to churn out consumer merchandise, although consumer sales weakened. Goods piling up unsold in warehouses and stores accounted for nearly a percentage point of the 5.2 percent growth.
A surge in federal government spending, mainly for the military and for the now largely completed 2000 Census, added nearly another percentage point to the growth of the gross domestic product, which is the value of all new goods and services.
But the economy's future path is in the hands of consumers, whose spending accounts for most of the now $9 trillion economy.
"The real question is what happens next to consumer demand; will it rebound," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "My guess is that it will." Wall Street seemed to agree that economic growth in the second half of the year would remain well above the 4 percent level. That is the maximum growth rate that the economy can sustain, in the Federal Reserve's view, before shortages of goods and services appear and prices rise. Stock prices fell in expectation that the Fed will raise interest rates again to slow the economy, if not at its next policy-making meeting on Aug. 22, then later on. Higher rates encourage investors to shift their money from stocks into interest-bearing securities.
The Commerce Department also issued a revision yesterday of economic growth rates going back to the fourth quarter of 1996. The average quarterly growth rate since then was nudged up to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent. The revisions helped President Clinton to declare that economic growth since he took office in 1993 has averaged 4 percent a year, "the best growth America has had since the Kennedy-Johnson years."
There were big revisions for last year's fourth quarter and this year's first quarter, mostly because of inventory swings. Stockpiles swelled in the fourth, particularly stockpiles of farm produce, and as a result the growth rate was revised to 8.3 percent from 7.3 percent. In the first quarter, however, inventories were drawn down, and growth was reduced to a 4.8 percent annual rate, instead of the originally reported 5.5 percent.
An upward revision in business investment also played a role in swelling economic growth in the fourth quarter. In the first quarter, however, investment in new equipment and software turned out to be weaker than originally reported, partly because of a strike at the Boeing Company, which reduced aircraft production.
Business held up its end handsomely in the second quarter. There was robust spending for equipment, software, office buildings, warehouses and other commercial buildings. And the federal government raised its spending by nearly 18 percent in the second quarter, after a fall of 14 percent in the first quarter.
Some of that swing reflected quirks in government accounting, but the Commerce Department reported a significant increase in military spending, not for new weaponry but for various support functions, including research, weapons repair and personnel services.
Rising investment holds out the hope of rising productivity. The new equipment, in effect, helps workers increase their output and their employers' revenue. The additional revenue is then available to feed profits or raise wages, or both, without an increase in prices. Labor costs, in fact, rose at a fairly mild 4.6 percent annual rate in the second quarter -- edging up from last year's rate of increase, but unchanged from the first quarter, the Labor Department reported on Thursday.
Inflation has also risen slowly. The gross domestic product report includes a price measure that is far broader than the Consumer Price Index, covering almost every price change in the economy. This price measure showed inflation rising at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter. While that rate was higher than last year's levels, partly because of gasoline prices, it declined from a rate of 3.3 percent during the first quarter.
The consumers, however, will determine the pace of economic growth in the future, and the second-quarter gross domestic product report suggests they are pulling back. Consumer spending in the second quarter increased at a rate of only 3 percent, or less than half the 7.6 percent growth rate registered for the first quarter.
"Consumer spending slowed for basically everything, but the really big slowdown was in motor vehicle sales," said Brent Moulton, associate director of national economic accounts in the Bureau of Economic Analysis in the Commerce Department.
As a result, inventories of unsold goods built up at almost double the pace in the first quarter, with most of the increase in motor vehicles parked in dealers' back lots. The auto buildup almost certainly will result in a production slowdown until the inventories are worked down, said Wynn Van Bussman, corporate economist at the DaimlerChrysler Corporation.
"What you will probably see is a delay or a cutback in the production of new models," he said.

HEADLINE: Albright Meets North Korean but Learns Little About Missile Plans

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright held talks today with North Korea's foreign minister, and said that although the meeting was friendly, she learned little about the country's reported intentions to curb its missile program.
"My meeting with Foreign Minister Paek constitutes a substantively modest but symbolically historic step away from the sterility and hostility of the past," Dr. Albright said. 
 The meeting ran nearly an hour over the allotted 20 minutes.
Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun gave Dr. Albright no details of an offer made recently by North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, to Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, to transform the North's missile program into peaceful efforts to launch satellites into space.
"I was direct in stating American concerns about the missile threat, nuclear weapons-related activity," Dr. Albright said.
Despite Mr. Kim's reaffirmation last month of a moratorium on long-range missile launchings, his missile program has leaders on both sides of the Pacific jittery.
A missile test over Japan in 1998 awakened the world to North Korea's growing prowess in long-range missiles and spurred the United States' drive to develop a national missile defense. The United States still has 37,000 troops in South Korea.
American officials have suggested that North Korea should be allowed to launch satellites only from neutral nations and should be prevented from obtaining technology that could improve its missiles.
Still, both nations said today's meeting -- the highest-level talks between the United States and North Korea since the 1950-53 Korean War -- contributed to the thaw on the Korean peninsula, which began with last month's summit meeting between the leaders of the two Koreas.
"I remain realistic in expectations and fully committed to coordination with our allies," Dr. Albright said. "I'm also somewhat more hopeful than before for the long-term stability on the Korean peninsula and throughout the region."
North Korea issued a statement saying the two sides had conducted "serious deliberations on the ways to normalize and expand" relations and agreed that recent developments led to a "positive atmosphere."
Before the talks, Mr. Paek was asked about news reports that North Korea would send a high-level delegation to Washington to discuss improving ties.
The Americans have been seeking such an encounter, Mr. Paek said, "but the atmosphere is not ripe yet."
North Korea first wants the United States to end economic sanctions and remove it from the list of nations accused of sponsoring terrorism.
New Zealand, meanwhile, agreed today to normalize relations with North Korea, becoming the second nation, after Canada, to announce diplomatic relations with the Communist state this week.
New Zealand's foreign minister, Philip Goff, said Mr. Paek had reiterated North Korea's denial that it has nuclear weapons but had told him that it was "no secret" that missile systems had been developed.
"His response was also that this must be expected from North Korea, given the fact that other countries also have missiles trained on his country," Mr. Goff said.

HEADLINE: Germans Say Nine Wounded By Bomb Were Immigrants

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 28

 BODY:
The nine people wounded by a bomb on Thursday in Dusseldorf are immigrants, with six of them Jews, the police and prosecutors said today.
Johannes Mocken, a spokesman for state prosecutors in the western city, said the victims had just left their daily German class at a language school when the bomb exploded on a metal footbridge leading to a commuter station. "We cannot exclude that somebody purposefully intended to kill members of this group," Mr. Mocken said. 
 Interior Minister Otto Schily said it was reasonable to assume that the attack had a racist motive.
The leader of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, Paul Spiegel, said: "I don't want to create any hysteria. But the fact is most of the victims were Jewish, and it appears that they passed on the same route from school every day."
The number of Jews in Germany has been growing rapidly over the last decade, bolstered by waves of immigrants from the former Soviet Union drawn here by the relative ease of obtaining residence papers and generous financial aid. The country has 85,000 registered Jews compared with 29,000 at the beginning of the 1990's.
A bombing against those immigrants would be a blow to Germany's international image and a worrying indication that the extreme right is becoming bolder and more organized.
But no organization, rightist or other, has claimed responsibility for the bombing. The police said all possible motives, including reports of a feud among the immigrants, remained under examination.
One of the wounded, identified by the police only as Tatyana, 26, was 6 months pregnant. The unborn child was killed when shrapnel pierced her stomach. Her condition, and that of her husband, Michael, 28, were listed as critical. Two other people were listed in serious condition.
The immigrants came from Azerbaijan, Russia and Ukraine, the police said. Their German lessons were part of the government's aid for immigrants, and the group was about to board a train to nearby Solingen, where five Turkish women and girls were killed in 1993 in a racist firebombing.
Anti-immigrant violence has steadily risen in Germany in the 1990's, spurred by high unemployment, frustration among idle youths and well-organized, if marginal, neo-Nazi movements.
Last month, a 39-year-old black immigrant from Mozambique was beaten to death by neo-Nazi skinheads in the eastern town of Dessau, and the police dismantled what they described as a highly organized and heavily armed rightist youth group near Dresden, finding grenades, ignition devices and parts of rockets.
The openness to Jewish immigration is rooted in a deep-seated political conviction that the Holocaust makes any other policy unthinkable, as well as a calculation that such receptiveness is generally good for Germany as it asserts its growing economic power, particularly in the United States.
But protracted recent negotiations over compensation for Nazi-era slave and forced laborers showed a growing, if still rarely expressed, impatience with what is sometimes described as "Jewish blackmail." In October, more than 100 headstones in Europe's largest Jewish cemetery, in Berlin, were smashed or overturned.
Dusseldorf has been a major center of Jewish immigration. Michael Szentei-Heife, leader of the branch of the Jewish council there, said 6,300 Jews lived in the area, with 5,100 being recent Russian emigres. Their move stems from a decision to accept Jews from the former Soviet Union by Helmut Kohl, who was then the chancellor, shortly after the Berlin Wall fell.
But that decision was never the subject of a parliamentary vote or national debate, and the public view of the de facto rebuilding of a German Jewish community all but extinguished by Hitler remains unclear.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said this week that anti-immigrant violence by rightist groups had reached unacceptable levels.

HEADLINE: Nortel Agrees to Buy Alteon For $7.8 Billion in Stock

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
The Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada continued its push to become a major developer of Internet systems yesterday as it announced that it had agreed to acquire Alteon WebSystems Inc. for $7.8 billion in stock.
Alteon, based in San Jose, Calif., makes equipment that allows Internet servers -- the computers that hold information on the Web -- to perform more efficiently. Alteon's gear splits up requests for Internet information among a company's individual servers, allowing the servers to perform at their best, and can spare those servers the electronic burden of performing routine tasks like encryption. 
 As big communications carriers try to offer a full package of Internet services, equipment like Alteon's can allow them to maximize the value of the Web servers they already have and to offer more finely tailored services to their corporate customers.
The value of such a product is reflected in the move by Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of Internet equipment, to acquire Alteon's main competitor, ArrowPoint Communications, based in Acton, Mass., for $5.7 billion in May. At the time, that deal was seen by some communications analysts as a negative for Alteon. With Cisco's acquisition of ArrowPoint, the argument went, it would be tougher for Alteon to sell itself.
Clearly, it was not that tough. North America's Big Three makers of communications equipment, Cisco, Lucent Technologies Inc. and Nortel, are engaged in a furious battle to dominate the market for the next generation of communications technology, and the sort of gear Alteon makes fits that bill perfectly.
For the next few years, there will probably be three major "sweet spots" in the communications equipment business. One is in the sale to communications carriers of wireless systems that can transport Internet data. Another is in the sale to communications carriers of optical systems that can transmit billions of bits of information in ways that are both flexible and robust. (Earlier this week Nortel ended discussions to combine its optical components unit with that of Corning Inc.) And the third is in the sale to carriers of advanced data networking equipment.
Alteon fits into the third category, one that Cisco, Lucent and Nortel are approaching from different directions.
Cisco's roots are in the sale of data communications equipment to corporate customers for office networks. Now that the corporate market is largely mature, Cisco is furiously trying to reinvent itself as a vendor to big international communications carriers, whose technical requirements are far more complex and stringent than those of everyday corporations. In Cisco's favor, however, is its legacy of experience with data communications systems.
Lucent and Nortel have the opposite problem. For decades, those two companies have been meeting the requirements of the world's biggest carriers, but mostly by providing systems for voice telephone calls. Only over the last few years have Lucent and Nortel made significant strides in data networking.
A company like Alteon can jump-start that effort, not least because it already has significant customers and partners, including Akamai Technologies Inc., which helps transmit electronic "content" on the Web. Unlike many of the start-up optical communications companies that are being snapped up these days for billions of dollars, Alteon has revenue, $110 million in its most recent fiscal year, which ended in June.
"In the new economy, the value and richness of content across the Internet is increasing on a massive scale," Clarence Chandran, Nortel's chief operating officer and heir apparent to John A. Roth, Nortel's chief executive, said in a statement. "Our acquisition of Alteon WebSystems will accelerate the delivery of an Internet data center capable of moving content seamlessly and rapidly."
Dominic Orr, Alteon's chief executive, said in a statement, "Alteon WebSystems and Nortel Networks share a common vision of high-performance content delivery services that exploit the high-performance Internet and create new profit opportunities for service providers."
The Alteon deal is Nortel's biggest acquisition since it agreed to acquire Bay Networks Inc. for $9.1 billion in 1998. Under yesterday's agreement, Alteon stockholders are to receive 1.83148 shares of Nortel for each of their Alteon shares. Based on Nortel's closing price Thursday of $78.625, the deal is worth $144 for each Alteon share, $1 more than Alteon's closing price Thursday.
Yesterday, shares of Nortel fell $5.125, to $73, amid a broad stock market sell-off. Shares of Alteon closed at $129, down $14.
