HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russians Want Beauty With Scent of Home

BYLINE: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 28

 BODY:
When Russia began picking apart its economy in 1992, Oleg Nasobin spotted an opportunity. After 70 years of Soviet deficits, his country was brimming with pent-up demand for lipstick, face creams and body lotion. It was a business opportunity he could take up only by leaving.
That year, Mr. Nasobin packed his family off to Prague. He was looking to build a business on safe ground, away from the constantly shifting turf of Russia's early days of capitalism. He also was leaving his home -- the place that would later make him a wealthy man. 
 "We left carrying two suitcases," said Mr. Nasobin, a 33-year-old former peddler of ginseng. "It was a very grim situation in Russia in those days -- no personal prospects in sight."
Now his company, Green Mama, is one of Russia's top five cosmetics producers. Since starting the company in the Czech Republic in 1996, Mr. Nasobin and his wife, Irina, have expanded sales to 36 countries including the United States and Canada, and employ about 500 people. They later moved the factory to France and two years ago began some production in Russia. The pair hit upon a winning recipe: homegrown extracts with a made-in-France label that increased allure in a market still curious about foreign goods.
Imports flooded Russia's cosmetics market after the fall of Communism in 1991. Kiosks were crammed with deodorant, face cream and shampoo with brightly colored English labels. Local residents, starved for foreign brands, snapped up everything from detergent to candy bars.
But locally produced cosmetics have made a comeback since the country's 1998 currency devaluation. The weaker ruble drove up the price of imports, which became too expensive for locals to afford. Domestic car sales boomed while some foreign food and beverage makers were pushed out of the market altogether. Advertising on city billboards, television and radio changed from flashy foreign images to familiar designs and scenes.
Russian-made cosmetics are especially popular outside of Moscow in Russia's vast regions, where average salaries are much lower. Last year, Russian-made shampoo in the regions held 39 percent of the market, up from 17 percent in 1998, according to ACNielsen, an international market research firm. Local face-care products -- one of Green Mama's biggest sellers -- rose to 83 percent of the market outside Moscow last year, from 68 percent the previous year, according to the researcher. Locals' market share was lower in Moscow where imports still dominate.
Mr. Nasobin's treasure is face cream, body lotion and shampoo. The plastic tubes and bottles are dotted with sketches of flowers, plants and berries and are named Taiga Formula after the vast forests of central and northern Siberia. Extract of sea buckthorn, a bright yellow Siberian berry, colors a new face cream. Ribwort, a Russian roadside weed, makes face masks green. A new line of larch sap lipstick has just been released.
The familiar ingredients are appreciated by Russian buyers, who over the last decade have had their fill of foreign-made products they say are packaged alluringly but just do not measure up to Russian items. Even before the ruble's collapse drove up prices on imports, buyers had already begun to turn away from many foreign products, seeking familiar brands of ice cream, soap and hand lotion. Green Mama, though made mostly in foreign factories, plays on that nostalgia.
"I like the way it smells," said Valentina Surkova, a 43-year-old accountant who grew up in eastern Siberia and now lives in Moscow. "Sea buckthorn berries -- this is my childhood."
Competition is intense, as local producers scramble to find a niche in the market space that has been created by the currency devaluation's impact on imports. Green Mama ranks third and fourth among local sellers of face-care and body-care products, its biggest selling items, according to Nielsen. However, sales are far below its biggest domestic competitor, Kalina, a company based in the Ural Mountains. Large foreign companies, like Beiersdorf of Germany, maker of Nivea cream; Proctor & Gamble; and L'Oreal occupy about half the market, according to the Russian Perfume and Cosmetics Association. The association, a group of about 60 local producers, was formed five years ago to monitor trends in Russia's cosmetics industry.
Russian women like to preen. Beauty care product sales this year will exceed $3.5 billion, according to the Perfume and Cosmetics Association. That is up from $3.2 billion last year, and includes sales of major foreign producers.
After decades of fitting the image of a factory worker dressed in a shapeless smock and head scarf, women these days meticulously accentuate their femininity. A traveler to Moscow today would be hard pressed to spot unlaquered fingernails or bare lips in a crowd.
Mr. Nasobin said he did not believe in marketing. He avoids expensive national advertisements and gets the word out mainly through local newspapers, radio and television. But the lack of aggressive advertising also has helped limit Green Mama's share of the market. Its annual sales total about $20 million, compared with the $90 million in sales by Kalina, which also sells household cleaning supplies produced at its factory in the Siberian city of Omsk.
The son of a schoolteacher, Mr. Nasobin grew up in Yekaterinburg, the town in the Ural Mountains where former President Boris N. Yeltsin rose to fame. In the late 1980's he made his first forays into capitalism in the eastern port city of Vladivostok, where he bought Chinese ginseng from local traders. His wife and two small children live in France, but his parents and extended family have stayed in Russia.
The Russian-foreign duality that has helped shape Mr. Nasobin's personal story is also reflected in his attitude about the future of his business.
Though foreign countries helped Mr. Nasobin prosper, they also have crimped his company's development, he said in an interview in his central Moscow office, wedged between a cigarette factory and a Soviet-era clock maker.
Green Mama, named for a drawing Mr. Nasobin's son made of his wife dressed to go out in green jewelry, has received unfair treatment simply because it is Russian, Mr. Nasobin said. Last year, foreign banks closed his company's accounts without explanation after United States authorities began investigating charges of Russian money laundering through the Bank of New York, though the company was not linked to the inquiry. As the investigation gathered momentum, banks tightened security for Russian companies and citizens.
"We brought our business to its feet abroad -- if we had been based inside Russia this whole time, we would never have been able to do the same thing," he said. Still, he said, "there's a bad image of Russians abroad," adding, "I often have to explain that I also eat with a fork and knife."
Nor has he been able to persuade a foreign bank to give him a loan. He diverts a small amount from profit each year to help the business grow. That makes expansion slow, though he said he would prefer a bank loan to a partner.
Next year, Mr. Nasobin said, he plans to expand Russian operations, which now pump out only the simplest of products, shampoo. The French factory is set to buy new equipment with some of last year's savings, and the Russian factory will inherit its used machinery.
More Russian production will also help cut costs. Russian workers are paid about $300 a month, while company employees in France make an average of $3,500.
Still, business in Russia has its problems. Heavy taxes weigh on profits and property rights are not always protected. Mr. Nasobin is embroiled in a struggle with local authorities in a small town near Ryazan in central Russia over a ceramics factory he has leased. He has organized Green Mama's Russian operations as a series of small companies, registered separately, in order to help insulate the business from threats of seizure in any possible property disputes.
Nor is finding supplies easy. Green Mama has an in-house furniture maker, clothing producer and a packaging plant to ensure supplies.
For now, Green Mama will remain Russian with a French address, just like Mr. Nasobin's children. But that will change, he said.
"I migrated; I didn't emigrate," he said. "We need to decide where Russia should go from here."

HEADLINE: Con Ed Runs Tests in Bid to Restart Indian Point Plant

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: BUCHANAN, N.Y., July 28

 BODY:
Despite mounting criticism of its inspection procedures, Consolidated Edison renewed its claims today that the Indian Point 2 power plant could be safely restarted with its existing steam generators and even ran heat and pressure tests in preparation for the restart.
Con Edison engineers elaborately defended their inspection procedures with charts and numbers during a five-hour public meeting with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission at the plant site, 35 miles north of New York City. Last week, the commission sent a letter to plant managers requiring further, extensive analysis of the steam generators before it could be reopened. 
 The commission delivered another blow yesterday in a second letter that cited Con Edison's lax inspection of the steam generators in 1997 as a contributing factor in the Feb. 15 radioactive leak that shut down the plant. In that leak, a tiny amount of radioactive steam escaped after a tube carrying superheated radioactive water cracked from corrosion. No injuries were reported, but the accident was the worst in the 26-year history of the plant.
James S. Baumstark, vice president of nuclear engineering for Con Edison, said he disagreed with the nuclear commission's findings in the 1997 inspection. He also emphasized that the company had improved its methods since then to include an electronic probe that is better able to spot minute cracks in the tubes.
"We've made significant improvements in both equipment and processes," he said.
But Nuclear Regulatory Commission officials said today that they would need more time to review the company's responses and study the processes involved before making a final decision. Still, Jack R. Strosnider, director of the division of engineering at the commission, said that the Indian Point 2 plant could reopen in a matter of weeks.
"It's possible," he said. "If they provide the right engineering answers. We haven't reached a final decision at this point."
Although Con Edison officials have pledged to replace the plant's aging steam generators by the end of the year, they want to restart the existing generators to increase the company's power reserves during the hot summer months, when energy use rises. Today, workers raised the temperature of the nuclear reactor in a routine test to check for leaks or other problems. A few weeks ago, they performed a similar test after receiving permission from the nuclear commission, said Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for Con Edison.
In recent months, local government officials, advocacy groups and others have petitioned the nuclear commission to demand that Indian Point 2 remain closed until the new generators are installed.
State Assemblywoman Sandra R. Galef, a Democrat from the nearby town of Ossining, was one opponent at today's public meeting. "I think it was a waste of time, money and talent to debate whether these steam generators should be allowed to run for a few months," she said. "I just don't understand why they let the engineers argue about this when they're going to change it anyway. Just get it done."
But Mr. Baumstark said it could take nine months to a year before the new generators are fully operational because of the detailed preparations involved. During that period of transition, he said, the existing generators could supply power that is currently being bought from other power companies. Since the shutdown, the company has passed on the cost of that arrangement -- about $600,000 a day -- to its utility customers.
"We're very concerned about the ability to get some reserve power on the grid," he said. "The grid's done well to this point, but we haven't had a lot of very demanding days, and we could have a backup for our customers."
But still others today raised the possibility that the most economical decision for Con Edison may be to keep the Indian Point 2 plant closed permanently.
Edward A. Smeloff, executive director of the Pace University Energy Project, said that replacing the plant's four existing steam generators would cost between $150 million and $250 million. He said that Con Edison should undertake a comparative cost analysis to determine whether it would be cheaper in the long run to keep buying energy from other companies.
Mr. Smeloff said that two power plants, one in Oregon and one in Maine, were closed by their owners in the mid-1990's because it was cheaper than replacing the costly steam generators. "So the question becomes: Can that investment be recovered in future operations of the plant through the market?" he said. "If it can't, then the plant wouldn't be economical and should be shut down."
But Con Edison officials today dismissed the idea of shutting down the plant to save money. The company is in the process of selling the power plant, which has been licensed by the nuclear commission to operate until 2013. "We believe it's less costly to have the plant running than to have to go purchase power from other sources," Mr. Clendenin said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Bush and His Rivals Touring the Same Highly Contested States

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SPRINGDALE, Ark., July 28

 BODY:
Brimming with confidence, Gov. George W. Bush flew into President Clinton's home territory today, proclaiming that he intended to contest areas that the Democrats won solidly in the last two presidential elections.
With his stop in the rolling green farm country in the northwest corner of Arkansas, Mr. Bush began a five-day march to the Republican National Convention that will take him through the highly contested states of Missouri, Kentucky, Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. 
 In the district where a young Bill Clinton lost a race for Congress at the age of 28, Mr. Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, were greeted by a roaring crowd packed into a high school auditorium and chanting a football fight cheer. Dozens of children were arrayed on the stage behind them and a banner proclaimed, "Renewing America's Purpose."
Mr. Bush pointed to two local boys-made-good -- Senator Tim Hutchinson and his brother, Asa, the congressman who gained renown as one of the impeachment managers who prosecuted Mr. Clinton.
"They whispered something in my ear that made Dick Cheney and I feel really great," Mr. Bush said. "They told us we're going to carry Arkansas next fall. They told us not to worry about the last two election cycles. Something else is taking place in this state."
"It buoys my heart," he told the cheering crowd. "It buoys my spirit to know as we're working our way to Philadelphia for the national convention, and we're working our way across battleground states that the Republican ticket has not been able to carry for the last two elections."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney took turns taking shots at the integrity and trustworthiness of the president, who was impeached, but later acquitted for his efforts to cover up his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky. Neither man mentioned impeachment directly or even Mr. Clinton's name, but again and again they harked back to the Lewinsky scandal.
Mr. Cheney said he and his running mate were "on a great crusade to restore dignity and integrity to Washington." And as the crowd cheered he called Mr. Bush "the man who is going to give our kids and our grandkids a government we once again can be proud of."
Mr. Bush praised Mr. Cheney in turn, and in the process took a shot at Mr. Clinton for his effort to sidestep questions about Ms. Lewinsky. "This man is a good man," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Cheney. "He's a solid man. He's a man who understands what the definition of is is."
At one point out in the audience, someone thundered, "No more Slick Willie."
As he began his swing into the Republican convention, Mr. Bush had some good news -- two new polls showing him in the lead. Even in Arkansas, a Mason-Dixon poll just last week showed Mr. Bush leading Vice President Al Gore, 46 to 40 percent. It had a four-point margin of error.
The Democrats kept up their assault on Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney as the "big oil dream ticket," and circulated a Reuters report from 1999 saying that Mr. Cheney, the chief executive of the Halliburton Company, a worldwide oil services firm, had praised an OPEC decision to cut oil production.
Karen Hughes, Mr. Bush's spokeswoman, said that Mr. Cheney had been speaking at a conference of industry analysts and telling them of projections by economists that OPEC would cut production and that the "price situation" for the industry would improve.
"Unlike the Clinton-Gore administration, he was not caught napping about OPEC's actions," Ms. Hughes said.
From the moment he came aboard his campaign plane this morning, with his wife, Laura, Mr. Bush seemed relaxed and in good spirits. He ambled down the aisle joking with reporters and anticipating his nomination speech next Thursday.
"I'm really looking forward to this speech," Mr. Bush said. "This is going to be an unbelievably interesting moment in my life -- to walk out on that stage and to speak from my heart for however long it takes to get through the speech."
The Bush campaign has worked hard to plan a feel-good Republican convention with none of the sharp conservative edges of the past. The evening proceedings will have star turns for nonpoliticians -- a single mother, a teacher, a union member, a grandmother and granddaughter.
On Monday and Tuesday nights Mr. Bush will be beamed by satellite into the convention from places around the country. He is to arrive in Philadelphia on Wednesday morning at a Latin American music festival, symbolic of Republican efforts to reach out to Hispanics.
And on Thursday night one of the speakers welcoming him will be a Democrat, Jan Bullock, the wife of the late Lt. Gov. Ray Bullock of Texas, a Democrat who worked closely with Mr. Bush.
Even today on what was supposed to be a partisan tour, Mr. Bush tried to soften the tone. Before his rally he toured the Jones Center for Families, a community center founded by a family that ran one of the nation's largest trucking businesses.
"We're here to hear and see and feel first hand the acts of this particular platoon in the armies of compassion," Mr. Bush said.
As he took a quick tour of the center's computer operation, one of the first people to greet him was Charles A. Huffer, who tightly gripped the governor's hand and began speaking. Mr. Bush looked bewildered and brushed him off quickly.
"I told him that I thought he had a good chance to be president," Mr. Huffer, 61, said later, "and I asked him if he would be willing to finally tell the American people the truth about unidentified flying objects."

HEADLINE: A Robust Economy Raises Interest Fears

 BODY:
The American economy grew at a surprisingly robust 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter. The news of the unexpectedly strong growth sent stocks plummeting as investors feared the Federal Reserve might increase interest rates again. The Nasdaq composite index plunged 4.7 percent, finishing the week off 10.5 percent, its third worst week. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 74.96 points, to 10,511.17, and was down 2.1 percent for the week. 
 Consumers, whose spending accounts for most of the $9 trillion economy, reduced spending in the quarter, but the federal government and businesses increased spending.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Trade in Vietnam, But Confusion Takes Over
With just two stocks, two hours and $5,000 in trades, Communist-governed Vietnam opened its first stock exchange for business and took the first faltering steps into the uncertain world of free markets.
Hopeful investors packed into the three brokerage offices taking orders for the shares to watch the market's birth on electronic boards. But curiosity and excitement quickly turned into confusion and disappointment, when minutes before the Ho Chi Minh City Securities Trading Center opened, the government imposed a ceiling on bids that invalidated many people's orders -- some of which were more than 50 percent above the government's artificially imposed prices. Page C2. 

Nortel to Buy Alteon for $7.8 Billion
Nortel Networks agreed to acquire Alteon WebSystems, which makes equipment that improves the efficiency of Web server computers, for $7.8 billion in stock. Earlier this week Nortel ended discussions to combine its optical components unit with that of Corning. Shares of Nortel fell $5.125, to $73, after setting a 52-week high of $87 on Tuesday. C4.
 
U.S. Faults Mexican Phone Market
The Clinton administration took the first steps toward filing a formal complaint against Mexico for failing to ensure open competition in its $12 billion telecommunications market, just weeks before Mexico's president-elect, Vicente Fox, is scheduled to make his first visit to Washington to discuss commercial relations with the United States. C2.
 
A New Chief Executive at iVillage
Candice Carpenter, the founder of iVillage, the Web site focused on topics of interest to women, has stepped down as chief executive and named Doug McCormick, who joined the company in April as president. Ms. Carpenter, who will remain chairwoman, will focus on strategy and international expansion. C3.
 
NBC Executive Promoted at G.E.
Robert C. Wright, the longtime president of NBC, was named to the additional post of vice chairman of General Electric. Mr. Wright, left, is not considered a possible successor to the G.E. chairman, John F. Welch Jr., who is scheduled to retire in nine months, but industry executives said the move emphasizes the importance of NBC in G.E.'s future. C14.
 
Interpool Buys Rail Cargo Company
Interpool, a unit of the Dutch insurer Aegon that leases cargo containers, said that it had agreed to buy a rival, Transamerica Leasing Inc., for about $675 million to add Transamerica's strength in rail cargo to its own operations in maritime shipping. C3.
 
Industrial Output Increases in Japan
Japan's economic recovery seems to be continuing, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Industrial output rose 1.7 percent in June from the previous month, bringing output growth in the April-June quarter to 1.6 percent, the fourth consecutive quarterly increase. C2.
 
Hyundai Unit Seeks Emergency Loan
Hyundai Engineering and Construction, a subsidiary of South Korea's largest business conglomerate, the Hyundai Group, requested emergency loans from creditors to repay about $161 million in loans. The move raises concerns that another huge bankruptcy may be in the making and comes a year after the Daewoo Group collapsed under debts estimated at $80 billion. C2.
 
Viacom Expects $1.5 Billion Charge
Viacom will take charges of about $1.5 billion in the second quarter for costs related to buying CBS and for new film accounting rules, according to a recent filing and analysts' estimates. C14.

HEADLINE: Bank of America to Cut Up to 6.7% of Work Force, or 10,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Bank of America Corporation announced yesterday that it would eliminate 9,000 to 10,000 jobs over the next year, or 6.7 percent of its work force, and use the savings to improve its Internet offerings, promote its brand name and improve services, especially for wealthy individuals and corporate clients.
Middle-level and senior managers are expected to be the principal targets of the job cutback, along with workers whose jobs will be erased by new technology. With these new steps, roughly 34,000 jobs will have been eliminated at the bank since September 1998, when it was created by the combination of Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., and the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco. 
 Those two cities remain the primary addresses for senior executives, but a spokesman at corporate headquarters in Charlotte, Robert L. Stickler, declined yesterday to say where the cuts would be made. "They will really come across the franchise," Mr. Stickler said. The banking company now employs 150,000 people.
Bank of America's chairman and chief executive, Hugh L. McColl Jr., in a statement announcing the plan, said: "Our days of growth by merger and acquisition are behind us. For the most part, our merger transition work also is behind us."
The challenge now, Mr. McColl said, is to make the bank's management structure, the product of multiple mergers over the years, more efficient.
The main interpreter of the new strategy to Wall Street yesterday was Kenneth D. Lewis, the bank's president and chief operating officer. Reducing management costs without alienating customers will be something of a final exam for Mr. Lewis, 53 -- widely seen as heir apparent to Mr. McColl, 65, who is expected to retire next year.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Lewis emphasized that the job cuts did not conflict with the bank's announced determination to increase customer satisfaction. In fact, he said, some of the savings would be used to identify specific customer complaints and fix them.
"For example, the bank gets a huge number of requests from customers who want a copy of their canceled checks," Mr. Lewis said. For each request, employees have to look the check up on microfilm, copy it and mail it to the customer -- a process that requires 800 people over all and still provides customers with a poor-quality copy that arrives days after the request.
By investing in new imaging technology, Mr. Lewis continued, the bank can both eliminate 800 jobs and enable customers to look up canceled checks online or even at an automated teller machine.
Mr. Lewis acknowledged that making the strategy work "is something I'm in charge of," but he said that Mr. McColl "was very supportive of what we wanted to do." He declined, however, to comment on Mr. McColl's retirement plans.
The rolling cutbacks at Bank of America will inevitably be felt in the economy of Charlotte, a city it has come to dominate, said C. W. Sealey, chairman of the finance and business law department at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte. But "so long as they don't slip too far," he said, "the impact should not be too severe."
The bank spokesman, Mr. Stickler, said the company had a "competitive" severance plan to cushion job losses for management employees, who first began to hear rumors of the job cuts about two weeks ago. The bank expects to take a charge against its third-quarter earnings as high as $350 million, reflecting severance costs and other expenses in the plan.
Wall Street analysts and institutional investors seemed to take the news in stride yesterday. On a sharply lower day in the market, bank stocks were particularly weak, reflecting investor concerns that bank profits would be hurt if a strong economy prompted the Federal Reserve to again increase interest rates. Despite that, Bank of America shares were stronger than most, closing at $46.50, down 25 cents. But that is substantially below the stock's intraday high of $76.375, which it reached in July 1999.
The bank's top executives have reassured analysts that they still expect to meet their revenue and profit forecasts, said Ron Mandle, a senior research analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. The bank expects revenue to grow 7 to 9 percent a year, with earnings per share increasing 12 to 15 percent annually.
According to Mr. Mandle, that would allow Bank of America to meet Wall Street's profit expectations for the current year -- $5.21 a share -- and perhaps exceed them next year, when earnings are now forecast at $5.76 a share.
"They're really just changing the mix, not making absolute cuts," he added.
At the top of the bank's new to-do list is to steer an additional $70 million into "e-commerce initiatives" in the next six months and speed the introduction of Internet technology at its offices and call centers. The bank, which serves 30 million households and two million businesses, currently has 14,500 branches in 21 states and the District of Columbia.
The bank expects to reduce the number of branches by about 200 by the end of the year, Mr. Stickler said, but that entails closing 350 offices and opening 150 new branches in more promising locations.
Another element of the new strategy involves investing more in investment banking operations at home, and in Europe and Asia, to serve business customers in 190 countries. Through a previous merger, Bank of America inherited the Midwestern corporate business of Continental Illinois Bank in Chicago, Mr. Mandle noted, and it continues to serve the corporate customers of the old BankAmerica and Nationsbank.
Mr. McColl and Mr. Lewis also plan to promote the bank's brand more aggressively, through increased advertising, and to cater more energetically to high-income individuals by improving asset management services and opening 10 private banking offices in wealthy areas, especially on the West Coast.

HEADLINE: Fujimori Takes Oath as Protests Blanket Area in Smoke

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 28

 BODY:
President Alberto K. Fujimori was inaugurated to a third term today as the police and demonstrators engaged in running battles that engulfed the downtown area in tear gas and smoke.
Mr. Fujimori, on his 62nd birthday, enjoyed the pomp of military marches and a special Mass. But waves of demonstrators, angered by their belief that he was elected in a fraudulent vote, tried to interrupt the proceedings, only to be turned back by police officers firing water cannon, tear gas and bullets. 
 The demonstrations were far smaller in size and more violent than organizers expected. The protesters threw rocks and sticks at the police, set bonfires at the gates of the presidential palace and vandalized several government offices. They threw homemade gasoline bombs and set fire to the building that houses the Supreme Court.
Three people were wounded by gunfire and at least six others were reported to have died in fires set today. About 100 others were injured and scores of protesters were dragged away in handcuffs.
As President Fujimori took the oath of office, opposition congressmen -- some wearing gas masks in a rebuke to the president -- jeered and walked out of the congressional chamber. But Mr. Fujimori made scant reference in his 40-minute address to the turbulence that has followed two rounds of balloting during which, international observer teams and opposition leaders have charged, there were irregularities and dirty campaign tricks perpetrated by his intelligence agency. "Many of our people are not in agreement with our program," Mr. Fujimori said. "That's democracy."
But he stopped short of asking for a reconciliation in a nation that has become increasingly polarized in the two years since Congress dismissed three judges who ruled that Mr. Fujimori was disobeying the Constitution by seeking a third five-year term.
In a speech short on rhetorical flare and delivered in a business-like fashion, he reminded Peruvians of his past successes at halting years of hyperinflation and in making peace with Ecuador. He also pledged to "fortify democracy and generate employment and well-being, with discipline, prudence and realism."
Mr. Fujimori outlined promises that he would work to improve the judicial system and reorganize the security services now that two terrorist groups have been virtually defeated. But he did not address complaints by the Clinton administration, the Organization of American States and several Latin American and European governments that he has governed in an increasingly authoritarian manner.
"Let's remember that in no country in the world does the minority govern, and certainly not in Peru," he said defiantly.
Even as civilian democracy has progressed in Latin American countries like Mexico, Argentina and Chile, Mr. Fujimori has become the symbol of a counter-trend that disturbs many officials in Washington and around the region. One elected president was overthrown in a coup this year in Ecuador, and President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela has appeared to take lessons from Mr. Fujimori as he led a populist crusade.
But Washington has been reluctant to take tough action against Mr. Fujimori because of his commitment to root out drug trafficking and for fear that the leadership of the opposition is too erratic to govern.
Alejandro Toledo, the opposition presidential candidate who dropped out of the race a week before the May 28 runoff, originally said the demonstrators would block the inauguration altogether. But with his support flagging, Mr. Toledo lowered expectations and called for a longer-term strategy to force democratic change.
"This march will not end until the dictatorship falls," Mr. Toledo told a rally of 40,000 protesters in downtown Lima on Thursday night. "Mr. Fujimori must understand that the people will not stop demonstrating until there are new elections."
Tonight, Mr. Toledo blamed the government for the violence at the marches, saying intelligence agents infiltrated the demonstrations to discredit them. The government had no immediate response.
The demonstrators, mostly students and young workers, traveled to Lima from around the country by bus, train and even boat down Amazonian tributaries.
In his speech, Mr. Fujimori tried to bolster his base of rural Indians and shantytown residents with repeated promises that he would make new jobs his first priority. To promote development in the Andean highlands, he pledged to foster projects to improve irrigation and wool production from alpacas and llamas.
He vowed to build 3,000 schools, pave roads in urban shantytowns and expand supplies of clean water and electricity. He also pledged to expand a public school breakfast program to include lunch.
"The highlands must be transformed into something where more than despair grows," he said.
But Mr. Fujimori also tried to reassure investors, who in recent weeks have grown alarmed by his increasingly populist rhetoric. He promised to curb an expanding government deficit and to keep the annual inflation rate under 4 percent.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
U.S. May Move Embassy In Effort to Aid Barak
President Clinton, acting to help shore up Prime Minister Ehud Barak's shaky political base, went on Israeli television and promised concrete rewards for peace, hinting that he was ready to move the United States Embassy to Jerusalem. The move would be a triumph for Jews around the world who have long sought international recognition for Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. A1
 
Disagreement on Crash Cause
France's transportation minister said that evidence so far pointed to a burst tire as the cause of the fire that engulfed the left side of the Air France Concorde that crashed shortly after takeoff on Tuesday. But investigators seemed to play down any notion that tire fragments had been sucked into the engines and had caused the fire. A4 

Racism Suspected in Bombing
German police and prosecutors said that the nine people injured by a bomb on Thursday in Dusseldorf, including six Jews, were immigrants. An official said it was reasonable to assume that the attackers had a racist motive, but the police said other possible motives, including reports of a feud among the immigrants, remained under examination. A4
 
Putin Meets with Tycoons
President Vladimir V. Putin convened a meeting at the Kremlin with Russian tycoons, and after the session business leaders said they were prepared to abide by government rules if the Kremlin would create a fairer business climate. In return, they said they had won Mr. Putin's assurance that they could hold on to their wealth gained during the post-Soviet privatizations. A3
 
Riots as Fujimori Sworn In
President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru was inaugurated for a third term as waves of demonstrators, driven by a belief that he was elected in a fraudulent vote, tried to interrupt the proceedings, only to be turned back by the police. NATIONAL A7-10, 14
 
New Primary System Is Quashed by Bush Camp
Gov. George W. Bush ended the last bit of uncertainty surrounding the Republican convention next week by killing an effort to allow voters in all states to cast primary ballots that actually counted. The Republican National Committee's plan was intended to lengthen the primary system by making the big states vote last. Members of the committee attributed the Bush camp's opposition to the plan to a desire to have a convention free of conflict. A1
 
Republicans fought passionately over abortion at a meeting on the party platform, with the anti-abortion forces easily prevailing, as the platform committee made its way through a document intended to balance the party's core conservatism with Governor Bush's attempt at a more centrist appeal. A9
 
Governor Bush flew into Arkansas, proclaiming that he intended to contest areas in President Clinton's home territory that the Democrats won solidly in the last two presidential elections. With his stop in the rolling green farm country in the northwest corner of Arkansas, Mr. Bush began a five-day march to the Republican National Convention that will take him through the battleground states of Missouri, Kentucky, Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. A9
 
I.R.S. Suspends Workers
The Internal Revenue Service has suspended at least eight Chicago-area workers in a criminal investigation into bribery and other offenses. Lawyers familiar with the case said a federal grand jury was expected to hand up indictments, in what would be the first major corruption case brought against a group of I.R.S. workers since Congress passed the I.R.S. Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998. A7
 
Electric Prices Rise in West
Gov. Gray Davis of California has asked the federal government to impose controls on the wholesale price of electricity across the West. The average monthly electric bill in San Diego more than doubled in June. California politicians are now backing away from the state's plan to deregulate its power industry fully by 2002. A7

Economy Continues to Grow
Despite a pullback in consumer spending, the American economy grew at a robust 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said. A widely expected slowdown failed to materialize. But the second quarter offered just enough signs of weakness to raise doubts about the future of the nation's longest expansion. C1

HEADLINE: Where We Lived as We Turned Into Americans

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Louis Winnick's overview of the origins and transformation of Co-op Village from union-sponsored, moderate-income cooperatives to market-rate housing (Op-Ed, July 22) is both nostalgic and timely. Because of the loss of thousands of affordable apartments to the booming market, today's union members and moderate- and middle-income workers cannot find a decent place to live at prices they can afford.
Mr. Winnick deplores the inadequate public and private responses to this crisis. Our political leaders must understand that housing is the building block for a safe, healthy environment and economic stability. 
 The early union pioneers built a model community on the Lower East Side. We need that type of commitment today from unions, companies and government.
 
CLARA FOX
Co-Chair, N.Y. Housing Conference
New York, July 24, 2000

HEADLINE: Out in the Cold

BYLINE: By Elena Lappin; Elena Lappin is the author of "Foreign Brides," a novel.

 BODY:

 HARRY GOLD
 By Millicent Dillon.
 280 pp. New York:
 The Overlook Press. $26.95. 
 To be a spy is a bit like having a secret love affair. Despite the occasional sense of romance and adventure, spying involves leading a double life concealed behind a filigree of deceptions and betrayals. If you're caught at either, you're likely to be punished for daring to subvert society's moral framework. Espionage involves drama, risk and danger. Or does it? Millicent Dillon's new novel about Harry Gold, the American chemist who acted as a spy for the Soviet Union in the 1930's and 40's, suggests otherwise.
In a scene depicting Gold's trial in 1950, Dillon quotes Gold's lawyer, John D. M. Hamilton, as saying: "I come here to explain a crime and not to excuse one. I come here to state a case and not to plead one." Dillon follows this lead by tracing Gold's story in precise and subdued prose, and combining her factual knowledge of his life with imagined detail and poetic texture. Like her character, the author has a double identity here, alternating between a biographer's and a novelist's voice and point of view. (It is a double identity that may come naturally to Dillon: the author of three previous works of fiction, she has also published biographies of Paul and Jane Bowles, among others.)
Unusually, Dillon the biographer inserts herself into the novel as a first-person narrator, and in this role she is honest enough to define her main weakness -- and the book's most rewarding challenge -- which is, as she puts it at one point, "watching from the outside, thinking I was watching from the inside."
From the outside, Dillon shows us a small, barely noticeable man who leads a simple, poor, dutiful life with his Russian Jewish parents and younger brother in Philadelphia. It is 1932, there is rampant unemployment and he is the family's sole support. When he too loses his job and is miraculously offered a new one by the friend of a friend, Harry doesn't realize that this friendship is motivated by a plan to recruit him as a courier for the Russians. Dillon shows an interesting dichotomy between Gold's refusal to join the Communist Party, whose teachings he finds unimpressive, and his readiness to become a spy, simply out of a sense of commitment to a friend and his belief that the Russian people need his help.
He begins by sneaking scientific information out of his own lab and sharing it with the Soviet Union via a clandestine contact; although his tasks grow in importance, he will always remain a minor courier -- dependable and practically invisible. His greatest claim to fame will be his connection with the German emigre physicist Klaus Fuchs, one of the masterminds behind the first atom bomb. He is also a witness for the prosecution at the trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg.
But who is this man, and does his story give us any clues about his inner life? If a biographer is a well-informed voyeur, what, then, is a novelist? Where is the boundary between fact and fiction when writing about the life of a real person? Dillon's Gold is perfectly convincing as a fictional character, but for all we know he may not correspond to the real person: somewhat confusingly, biography bleeds here into fiction.
This secret agent is well removed from our romantic image of spies. He never seeks to be paid for his services; he has no ideology; he is unusually kind, reliable and selfless. He is a painfully ordinary man and -- it must be said -- a boring one; yet his blandness is a cover for a terrible neediness and loneliness. Harry becomes infatuated with almost every single one of his contacts (especially Fuchs, with whom he feels "caught up in the forces of history, at a critical juncture of life and matter"), sees them as friends and is crushed when they leave him. It seems that he is not so much spying for the Soviet Union as looking for soul mates. And no wonder: his double life results in his being doubly lonely -- he is not allowed to marry. One of the novel's most moving touches is Gold's attachment to an imaginary wife and children.
By the time we are shown Gold's trial, where he is jeered by a hostile, anti-Semitic crowd and sentenced to 30 years in prison, he has become an almost tragic figure -- yet still an enigma.
"Harry Gold" is a fascinating and original book. It answers few questions, and asks many good ones. Yet it would have been a better and more interesting novel if the biographer had been less inclined to interfere with the novelist's freedom to tell a good -- even if not necessarily true -- story.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3283 words

HEADLINE: George Herbert Walker Bush;
The Accidental Vice President

BYLINE: By Richard V. Allen; Richard V. Allen served as President Reagan's first national security adviser.

 BODY:
What I remember most about entering Ronald Reagan's suite early on the third evening of the 1980 Republican convention, the night of his nomination, was the silence. It's not that there weren't plenty of people around. William J. Casey, Reagan's campaign manager, Richard Wirthlin, his pollster, and his advisers Peter Hannaford, Michael Deaver and Edwin Meese were all there in the candidate's elegantly appointed rooms on the 69th floor of the Detroit Plaza Hotel. So, too, was Reagan, dressed in a casual shirt and tan slacks. The entire group was seated on a large U-shaped couch, hushed, as if they were watching some spellbinding movie on TV.
The silence in the room was in marked contrast to the steadily rising noise at the Joe Louis Arena. There, word was spreading that Reagan was going to choose Gerald Ford, the former president and his bitter adversary in the 1976 primaries, to be his running mate. 
 As Reagan's foreign policy adviser, I didn't have much business getting involved in the selection of a vice president. But as someone who signed on with Reagan because I admired his principled criticism of the foreign policy of the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations, I couldn't help venturing to the suite to see what was going on. And so, at 5:30 in the evening, before I was to head over to the convention, I walked up the single flight of stairs that separated Reagan's floor from mine. It didn't take long for my suspicions to be confirmed. As I stepped into the hallway, there, coming out of Reagan's rooms and flanked by his Secret Service detail, was a tanned and fit Gerald Ford.
Once the former president and I had exchanged pleasantries, I made my way past security to Reagan's suite. Alone among those gathered on the couch, the nominee looked up and greeted me. I asked if he needed anything before I left for the arena. "Oh, no," he replied, "but thanks."
As I turned to leave, he asked, "What do you think of the Ford deal?"
"What deal?" I responded, genuinely surprised that the two parties were already working out details. In addition to the vice-presidential slot, Reagan said, "Ford wants Kissinger as secretary of state and Greenspan at treasury." My instant response was, "That is the craziest deal I have ever heard of." And it was.
This summer, as we approach the Republican and Democratic conventions, both major presidential candidates have conducted highly structured searches for their running mates. Richard Cheney, the former secretary of defense, has spent months vetting candidates for George W. Bush. Former Secretary of State Warren Christopher has been doing the same for Al Gore.
Though it was only 20 years ago, the process in 1980 could not have been more different from the one today. It is hard to imagine an unexpected vice-presidential pick at the last minute, like John Kennedy's selection of Lyndon Johnson in 1960, Richard Nixon's choice of Spiro Agnew in 1968 or even George Bush Sr.'s elevation of Dan Quayle in 1988 -- all of which caught the candidates' advisers by surprise.
But it was Ronald Reagan's nomination of Governor Bush's father that bears special telling. Reagan's selection of Bush in Detroit represented a turnabout within six hours; it came only when the negotiations with Ford, having taken on a life of their own, appeared to have reached an impasse. Had the talks succeeded and had Ford been selected, the Reagan campaign, crippled by infighting, might well have lost to the Carter-Mondale ticket in the fall. Had Reagan and Ford managed to win the election, it's very likely that their administration would have been hobbled by an unworkable power-sharing arrangement. It's also possible that the Republicans might have a different candidate today.
There are many plausible versions of how and why Reagan chose George Bush as his running mate, but most are wide of the mark. One conventional view is that Reagan, about to be nominated, recognized that he "needed a moderate" like Bush to balance the ticket; another version has it that Reagan, supposedly unschooled in foreign affairs, saw the wisdom of naming someone with extensive experience in the field to offset his own shortcomings. Yet another explanation holds that Reagan, a Californian, needed "geographic balance" and got that in Bush, with his Connecticut and Texas lineage.
These explanations are wrong. George Bush was picked at the very last moment and largely by a combination of chance and some behind-the-scenes maneuvering. Many Reagan advisers have claimed a deal was never close. The post-convention media commentary has largely reflected this view. In fact, Meese and Deaver have gone so far as to declare that Bush was their first choice all along. I take exception to their account. I saw a very different story unfold, and saw it from a privileged vantage point. From the moment I walked into that suite until the moment Bush was finally selected, I was the only person to remain in Reagan's presence throughout the adventure. With detailed notes to back up my memory, this is what I saw at the dawn of the Reagan Revolution on that long night in Detroit.
Ronald Reagan's search for a vice president started as soon as he clinched the nomination with a string of primary victories in the spring of 1980. Before long, a short list of prospective running mates had been put together, including Howard Baker, William Simon, Jack Kemp, Richard Lugar, Paul Laxalt and George Bush.
None of these prospective running mates were actually "vetted" in the way the process works today. Reagan knew all these men in varying degrees, but as was his style, he expected his advisers to do what was necessary to prune the list. The job fell largely to Ed Meese, who knew Reagan's mind better than anyone except Nancy Reagan.
It wasn't until several weeks before the convention that Gerald Ford's name entered into the mix. While it has never been established how it happened, most attribute it to Bryce Harlow, a respected adviser to Eisenhower, Nixon and Ford. Harlow probably initiated the idea in a discussion with his friend, William Casey, who then took it to Reagan and Meese.
As the convention approached, the Ford rumors became stronger. Although Reagan was running even with or behind President Carter in most polls, the idea struck several of us on the senior staff as a highly impractical, if not silly, idea. After all, Reagan and Ford had fought intensely for the nomination in 1976. In 1980, the G.O.P. platform carried Reagan's conservative message down the line. Its foreign policy planks in particular were, under cover of assailing Carter, a de facto indictment of the Nixon-Ford-Kissinger policy of detente with the Soviet Union. Unlike many of his predecessors, Reagan actually believed in the platform and was determined to see it put in place. The platform alone, we thought, would make a Reagan-Ford ticket unthinkable.
In Reagan's suite, however, the unthinkable had become the possible. In less than 24 hours, Reagan was going to have to go before the convention to announce his vice-presidential nominee. And yet for reasons that to this day remain baffling, not only had Reagan given his political advisers free rein to negotiate with Ford, he had also refrained from initiating conversations with other potential running mates. With no alternate plan in sight, it seemed that Reagan was prepared to embrace the wing of the Republican Party that had ridiculed him, probably disliked him and would surely do its best to undermine his agenda.
At 5:50 p.m., Casey and Meese, who had left the suite shortly after my arrival, returned. They seemed pensive. Lyn Nofziger, a longtime aide, joined us a few minutes later, asking, "What did Ford want?"
Reagan again described the deal being negotiated, complete with Ford's demands for Kissinger and Alan Greenspan, adding "I thought that was more than a little sacrifice." Then Reagan went to his bedroom to take a short nap. He knew it would be a long night.
Shortly after 6:30, Kissinger entered the suite to talk to Meese, evidence that a serious negotiation was indeed in progress. Half an hour later, he emerged; we chatted briefly, but the former secretary of state revealed nothing of the talks. Meese, who was similarly guarded, said that Kissinger wanted to proceed with discussions.
This was serious. And so I did something rash: I decided to try to contact George Bush. Until that moment, the campaign inner circle had treated important issues in a collegial manner; there had been no secrets among us. But on this issue, Casey, Meese, Wirthlin and Deaver were keeping the lid on. If my colleagues could play it close to the vest on such a crucial issue, it was a game that could be played by others as well.
Although nominally still on a list of frequently mentioned running mates, George Bush was not really on Reagan's radar screen. Since the primaries, the two men had barely spoken, and they certainly hadn't discussed the vice presidency. Apart from serious policy differences, Bush had refused to admit defeat in the primary battles despite being vanquished by Reagan in 29 of 33 primaries and did not withdraw from the race until just before the California primary in June. Reagan considered the belated departure willful and unnecessary and was offended by it. Still, I thought Bush a viable alternative to Ford; he had the best credentials of the possible running mates mentioned. If not for the unsettled relations between the two, Bush could bring more to the ticket to help Reagan than anyone on the list of choices.
There was no question that a Bush candidacy would be a hard sell. Among Reagan's advisers, Nofziger and Casey viewed Bush as a liberal, and others were almost unanimously against him, some even contemptuous. I considered Bush a capable man whose positions were actually much closer to Reagan's than were Ford's, especially on foreign policy and defense matters. In 1978, Bush had requested my assistance on his campaign, but my commitment to Reagan was firm. Of the Reagan inner circle, I had the clearest channel to Bush and knew him the best.
Shortly before 7:30, I reached Stefan Halper, a Bush aide. Talking to him from the nearly empty suite, I asked him, in as circumspect a manner as possible, to seek Bush's assurance that he could support the platform "with no exceptions." Halper knew what I meant: Was Bush interested in the job? Would he implicitly abandon his support for abortion and his opposition to supply-side economics by embracing the platform? I then called an old friend, Richard Fairbanks, to ask him to approach Bush with the same question. I wanted two sources of independent confirmation and knew Fairbanks was close to Bush.
At this point, Reagan emerged from his bedroom refreshed by the catnap and sat down in front of three muted television sets in the suite. Within moments, Gerald Ford appeared on CBS with Walter Cronkite, and Reagan asked that the volume be turned up. Cronkite wasted no time asking Ford if he and Reagan were discussing a "co-presidency," which Ford affirmed by not disagreeing. Reagan looked appalled.
After the broadcast, the room cleared out. Reagan and I were alone. Reluctant to question him, but knowing that another track could never be started unless he agreed to it, I asked Reagan why he would not simply issue a statement denying that he had agreed to a co-presidency. There was a sense of resignation in his voice when he said, "I can't." After a few seconds, he said aloud, almost rhetorically, "Who else is there?"
"There's Bush," I suggested, half expecting him to close off the discussion. Instead, he paused and then said, "I can't take him; that 'voodoo economic policy' charge and his stand on abortion are wrong."
Sensing an opportunity, I reached for a copy of the platform lying on the coffee table, passed it to him and said, "Governor, this is your platform, every word of it." I added that Martin Anderson, Reagan's chief domestic policy adviser, Peter Hannaford and I had scrutinized it carefully. "If you could be assured that George Bush would support this platform in every detail," I asked, "would you reconsider Bush?"
Reagan mulled this for a moment and then said, deliberately, "Well, if you put it that way, I would agree to reconsider." The opening emerged.
At 7:50 Fairbanks called to say that Bush could indeed embrace the platform; soon thereafter, Halper phoned with the same message. Meanwhile, negotiations with Ford continued upstairs on the 70th floor, with Casey, Meese, Deaver and Wirthlin representing Reagan, and Greenspan, Kissinger and the Ford advisers John O. Marsh, Robert Barrett representing the former president.
Reagan continued to sit before the televisions, snacking on his favorite jelly beans. Senator Bob Dole appeared with the television commentator Max Robinson and declared that "Ford and Reagan can work it out." Reagan commented, softly: "No, Bob. I cannot give him what he wants."
Seeing another opening, I then informed Reagan that Bush had given unequivocal assurances that he could embrace and defend the entire platform, emphasizing "with no exceptions." He listened carefully, but did not respond. I simply could not read his reaction, and the thought crossed my mind that he was angry that I had opened a channel to Bush.
At 8:05, Reagan announced to no one in particular, doesn't Ford "realize there is no way in the world I can accept? What kind of presidential candidate would I be in the eyes of the world if I were to give in to such demands?" It seemed odd that despite his instincts, Reagan did not call a halt to the talks. It seemed odd, too, that so many of those who felt uncomfortable about the deal remained quiet.
Just before 8:30, Meese reported progress: Ford had modified his demands and now wanted to be "chairman" of the National Security Council. The notion should have been rejected outright, as the President is the head of the N.S.C. A few minutes later, Anderson and Deaver rejoined the group in the suite, and Deaver told Reagan that Ford would like to speak to him on the phone. At 8:55, Reagan went into his bedroom to call Ford. He returned five minutes later, reporting that Ford had told him that Kissinger "now takes himself out" of the running for secretary of state. It was clear that Ford and Greenspan had not taken themselves out of anything.
By 9:30, Sam Donaldson was reporting that Reagan would go to the arena with Ford in a matter of hours, reinforcing speculation about the "dream ticket," and at 9:45, Cronkite announced that Ford and Kissinger were meeting with Reagan operatives. At 9:50, Meese came into the room: "We're wanted upstairs" in Ford's suite.
At 10:05, former Treasury Secretary William Simon entered, and Reagan and I sat with him in a corner. Simon, who had been mentioned as a vice-presidential candidate, was determined to stop the deal in its tracks, which was surprising since he had served in Ford's cabinet. "Ron, take me out of this," he told Reagan. "But under no circumstances take Ford. If you did that, you'd be totally compromised, and you know it." Simon, never a man to mince words, left; he had made a deep impression on Reagan.
By 10:45, Casey and Meese returned to the suite to present the latest version of the deal. "It's kind of hard to describe how it would work in practice," Meese began. "The president will nominate the secretaries of state and treasury, with the veto of the vice president. The vice president will name the director of the Office of Management and Budget and the national security adviser with the veto of the president. It boils down to a mutual veto power." In this version, Kissinger, "taken out" as secretary of state, would run foreign policy from the vice president's office.
At that late hour, despite its obvious and fundamental flaws and without any sort of backup plan, our side seemed determined to try to make this constantly changing arrangement work. It was almost surreal: how could a president limit his constitutional powers and prerogatives by allowing a vice president to veto his choices?
Just before 11, Nancy Reagan and the Reagan children came in to watch the convention roll call. At 11:13, Montana put Reagan over the top, and there was jubilation. At the moment of triumph, though, the negotiators were not present; they remained upstairs, locked in discussions. Meanwhile, the convention was drawing to a close -- if the Ford talks went on much longer, and failed, there would be no way to heal the disappointment. Over the course of the preceding hour, I had told Hannaford, Anderson and Nofziger that a channel had been opened to Bush and that Bush was on board with the platform. Hannaford then began to argue that the logjam had to be broken. He collected Deaver and Nofziger at the entrance to the suite and mounted the stairs to tell the negotiators that a decision was needed.
At 11:25, the negotiators returned; Casey reported that "the answer is probably no." Five minutes later, Ford, accompanied by Barrett, entered the suite to talk with Reagan, and we left the room. The two men spent a few minutes alone, and at 11:35, Ford departed. We rushed back into the room, and Reagan said: "I have to say the answer is no. All this time, my gut instinct has been that this is not the right thing. I have affection and respect for Ford. He said he would go all out to help." There was complete silence.
Reagan glanced around and asked those assembled -- a group that included Casey, Meese, Wirthlin, Hannaford, Deaver and me -- Well, what do we do now?" There was no immediate response. No one offered an alternate plan. No one tossed out a name. Expecting instant opposition, I ventured, "We call Bush." Once more, silence. Reagan again looked at each of us; hearing no objection, he said, "Well, let's get Bush on the phone."
At precisely 11:38, the phone was in Reagan's hand; though they barely knew each other, Reagan dove right in. "George," he said warmly, "I would like to go over there and tell them that I am recommending you for vice president. Could I ask you one thing -- do I have your permission to make an announcement that you support the platform across the board?" We could hear Bush agreeing at the other end. Reagan then left for the convention center where, shortly after midnight, he took the podium to praise Ford and then to announce his running mate, George Bush.
And so it came to pass that Ronald Reagan averted what would have been a disaster for his candidacy and the Republican Party. The following morning, Ed Meese called us together and declared the official line should be that the process of selecting a running mate had been orderly and measured and that there "never was a deal with Ford" for the vice presidency. Technically, he's right, since no deal was ever consummated.
Months later, while on the campaign plane, I asked Deaver what was in his mind as he sat in those discussions. He thought for a moment and said, "Look, I'm a guy from Sacramento, Calif., and there I was sitting at a negotiating table with Henry Kissinger, and Kissinger had negotiated with Mao." Astonished, I waited for something more, then asked, "And so, that's it?" He looked at me as if I didn't understand and said, sharply: "Of course that's it. I was sitting right there!"
For his part, Kissinger, no stranger to balky negotiations, later told The Washington Post that "if it had been possible for both the principals to go to bed, sleep on it, meet again in the morning, we could have wrapped up this thing in two hours in the morning," adding, "that's how close it was." And I believe him.

PUB-DATE: July 30, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2332 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Off the Hippies: 'Joe' and the Chaotic Summer of '70

BYLINE: By J. HOBERMAN; J. Hoberman, film critic for The Village Voice, is completing a book on the media culture of the 1960's.

 BODY:
THE regime of the summer blockbuster dictates that entertainment build the largest possible consensus. The notion that a movie might succeed by polarizing audiences seems absurd. Thirty summers ago, however, the landscape was quite different. The most talked-about and likely the most profitable movie to open that season was a cheaply made political button-pusher that riled audiences by mixing social satire with confrontational carnage: "Joe."
The summer of 1970 was bracketed by the release of the X-rated "Myra Breckinridge," perhaps the most reviled studio production ever, and "Soldier Blue," a phenomenally violent and tendentious cavalry western that showed American soldiers committing civilian massacres a century before My Lai. "Joe," which climaxed with the vigilante massacre of a hippie commune, was even more a movie of its moment -- opening at two Manhattan theaters in mid-July, barely two months after the shootings at Kent State and Jackson State. 
 For many of the nation's college students, the spring term ended in chaos. Some 30 R.O.T.C. buildings were burned or bombed. Over 500 colleges closed early. On Wall Street -- where news of Kent State triggered the Dow's worst one-day loss since the assassination of John F. Kennedy -- an anti-war rally was attacked by 200 laborers from a nearby construction site. The construction workers -- whose hard hats subsequently became a patriotic symbol -- assaulted demonstrators and bystanders, tore down the Episcopal banner at Trinity Church, invaded City Hall to demand the American flag be raised to full staff and smashed windows at nearby Pace College.
For probably the first time, American civilians fought in the streets over the war in Indochina. Although no movie captured this conflict better than "Joe," the scenario was conceived the previous summer. Norman Wexler, a 42-year-old Harvard-educated advertising executive and unproduced playwright, was inspired by Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's "silent majority" rhetoric, and a New York magazine article on the murder of an upper-middle class girl who had taken up with an East Village drug dealer, to write a movie treatment in which a pair of World War II veterans, one a disgruntled worker and the other the well-to-do father of a wanton hippie, wreak bloody vengeance on the younger generation.
Wexler, who died last summer, had no luck pitching his idea to the major studios. John G. Avildsen, a younger colleague with recent experience directing sex exploitation films, brought the idea to his employers at Cannon, then looking to produce more legitimate fare. Wexler wrote the script in eight days and Mr. Avildsen, not yet a union director and so technically only the cinematographer, was given a month to shoot the movie.
Made in early 1970, entirely on location, with the actors providing their own costumes, Cannon's first non-porn feature opens with the hippies Frank (Patrick McDermott) and Melissa (Susan Sarandon) sharing a bath in the kitchen area of their squalid East Village apartment.
Instead of lovemaking, explicit close-ups show Frank cooking and shooting his heroin. Melissa ingests too much speed and winds up in the hospital, after first freaking out and trashing a 14th Street sundries store -- a scene that Ms. Sarandon, who made her professional acting debut in "Joe," recalls being shot without retakes. Melissa's father, the haute WASP account executive Bill Compton (Dennis Patrick), ventures downtown to collect her effects from the pad of depravity. At that moment, Frank returns to taunt him with details of Melissa's unresolved family drama. In a splendidly cheesy effect, complete with crude psychedelic superimpositions, the enraged adman bludgeons the hippie scuzzball to death.
Redneck duck hunters had shot the hippie antiheroes of the previous summer's "Easy Rider," but this was something new! Anything seems possible as Compton picks up Frank's dope-filled shopping bag and flees. Cut to the dank neighborhood tavern where the steamfitter Joe Curren (Peter Boyle) holds forth, mind crammed with phantom antagonists. His blunt use of profanity and racial epithets instantly captured the viewers' attention. Ignored by a weary bartender, Joe continues his obscene anti-welfare harangue.
What could now match the initial frisson provided by this heavy-set working stiff installed on barstool in the middle of the afternoon shooting off his mouth as though he were a proletarian Lenny Bruce? When a haggard Compton -- desperate himself for an alcohol fix -- enters the establishment, Joe turns to the impeccably dressed newcomer and demands that he find a liberal who doesn't pander to blacks, offering a sexual favor to him if he can.
Joe expressed sentiments that no American politician -- not even George Wallace -- had the nerve to articulate, at least in public. These sentiments, however, were not those of Mr. Boyle. A member of Chicago's satirical Second City, he had been radicalized by the street disturbances around the 1968 Democratic Convention. For the actor, Joe was a character he might have invented on the Second City stage. Although Mr. Avildsen was impressed with Mr. Boyle's spontaneous embellishments when he read for the part, the film's producers felt the 34-year-old actor would seem too young to have served in World War II, and in fact their first choice for the role was the B-movie gangster Lawrence Tierney.
In giving on-screen presence to those blue-collar workers whose income was eaten away by wartime inflation even as the counterculture eroded their moral code, "Joe" developed in tandem with the social spectacle. The movie was not only retitled (from "The Gap"), but reconfigured in the wake of May's Wall Street rumble. Originally a supporting character, Joe became the protagonist. The requisite soundtrack album even included his opening diatribe -- which escalates to a call for vigilante vengeance. When the ad man confesses his crime, Joe is ecstatic: "I just talk about it, but you did it!"
There was a sense that only extralegal force could contain the disorder. A week after "Joe" opened, the presidential aide Tom Charles Huston presented a plan to coordinate all domestic intelligence gathering, including wiretaps and break-ins, under White House direction. In 1972, Norman Wexler, who had been diagnosed as manic depressive, would himself be arrested and jailed for making threats against President Richard M. Nixon during the course of a commercial cross-country flight.
Opening on July 15, the same day as "The Revolutionary," Paul Williams's sober view of campus radicalism, "Joe" waded into theaters in a season of rampant youth exploitation. "Love Story," the 32-year-old Yale professor Erich Segal's best-selling campus romance, was in production for its Christmas release. Mr. Segal's screenplay about a campus riot, "R.P.M.," would appear in the fall. It was "Getting Straight" -- with Elliott Gould as a hip Viet-vet grad student and Candice Bergen as his co-ed girlfriend -- that had the luck to open 10 days after Kent State. Two weeks later, "The Magic Garden of Stanley Sweetheart" recounted the picaresque adventures of a longhaired college junior (Don Johnson) without mentioning either the draft or Vietnam. The movie was shot on the Columbia campus, unlike "The Strawberry Statement" which, opening in June, transposed James Simon Kunin's account of the 1968 disturbances there to San Francisco after the university refused to serve as a location.
SMALL wonder Joe was furious. These draft-dodging rich kids -- who, he imagined, spent their vacations at fancy resorts and had orgies -- were being presented as the crown of creation even as their opposition to the war threatened to obliterate the event that defined their fathers. Joe and Compton bond across the class divide; the movie reaches its comic high point when they tour the East Village in search of the runaway Melissa. After dinner at a macrobiotic restaurant, the pair is picked up by a gaggle of hippies and winds up partying with Frank's stash. Neither bothering to phone home, each gets himself a chick, only to discover, by the dawn's early light, that the girls' male confederates have made off with their wallets.
The two guys are now living in the moment. After violently extracting an address from the girl, they drive upstate to the hippies' rural farmhouse. There, in a scene that struck some as a domestic My Lai, Joe turns avenging angel. Kids are cowering in the corner begging for mercy as Joe persuades Compton to pick up the gun. A final freeze frame has Compton shoot a just-arrived hippie chick -- it is, of course, Melissa.
Hailing "Joe" as "a film of Freudian anguish, biblical savagery and immense social and cinematic importance," Time magazine ranked the final sequence with the climax of "Bonnie and Clyde." Getting away with murder might not be impossible. "A lot of Joes sit in jury boxes these days," the reviewer warned. And in movie theaters: Mr. Boyle recently recalled that at the Embassy on Broadway, where "Joe" was screening around the clock, he and a friend snuck in at 2 a.m. to find "people screaming at the screen." Mr. Boyle became an instant celebrity -- hailed as a long-lost buddy by New York hard-hats.
"I had no idea that anybody would see the movie," Mr. Boyle said by telephone. "It was a very strange experience -- people coming up and saying, 'That's what they ought to do with all these hippies.' I was in an identity crisis." Rather than revel in his new fame, Mr. Boyle spent the summer afraid for his life. "Kids are standing up at the end of the movie and yelling, 'I'm going to shoot back, Joe,' " he told an interviewer at the time. "The other night I was walking down 46th Street and I had a flash of myself being shot down in the street, just because someone thought I really was Joe."
The 1970 election was dominated by events of the previous May -- as The New York Times suggested with an article on the semiotics of construction-work apparel, "A New Hat in Political Ring." Meanwhile, college students were the enemy. In mid-September, Agnew took to the hustings to campaign against that "disruptive, radical and militant minority."
A Yale student, Bill Clinton, got his political education in that election -- working for an antiwar Democratic candidate, the Reverend Joseph Duffey. Attacked by Agnew as a "revisionist Marxist," Mr. Duffey was dogged throughout his Senate campaign by hard-hat demonstrators. Still, the most notorious figure at Yale that fall was Professor Charles Reich, who attributed a new consciousness to his students. First published in The New Yorker, Mr. Reich's "Greening of America" maintained that the nation was in the midst of an unstoppable, pot-smoking, love-making, bellbottom-wearing, non-violent revolution against the Corporate State. Mr. Reich's analysis had little interest in racism or Vietnam but much to say about the stunted consciousness of the Joe generation. The professor advised readers to "look again at a 'fascist' -- tight-lipped, tense, crew cut, correctly dressed, church-going, an American flag on his car window, a hostile eye for communists, youth, and blacks."
The president was, of course, devoted to the blue-ing of America. Plunging into the campaign, trailed by the student demonstrators who unwittingly served him as foils, Nixon attacked the "fawning approval" of antiwar violence that in certain "fashionable circles has become the mark of being 'with it.' " The rhetoric was black and white but the election proved inconclusive. The Republicans lost nine House seats while gaining two in the Senate, where eight "peace" candidates won and six were defeated.
Still, "Joe" was scarcely played out. In New York, the movie concluded a 21-week first run and then moved to selected neighborhood theaters over Thanksgiving -- a few days before J. Edgar Hoover placed the Weatherman leader Bernadine Dohrn on the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list. A stone cast in the pool of American consciousness, "Joe" had a continuing ripple effect. On Jan. 20, 1971, the movie again went wide. The next night, a new situation comedy had its premiere -- it featured a domesticated Joe (Archie Bunker) and was called "All in the Family."
"Joe's" screenplay was nominated for an Oscar, and Mr. Avildsen estimates that the movie (whose budget, reported to be around $300,000, was likely exaggerated) eventually grossed $20 million. But, however sensational in its day, "Joe" is a movie without a reputation -- rating not a mention in "Easy Riders, Raging Bulls," Peter Biskind's 1998 account of the old "new Hollywood."
Perhaps "Joe" belongs more to the history of American political image-making. As suggested by the minimalist title tune ("Hey Joe, don't it make you want to go to war . . . once more?"), its protagonist was the literal-minded infantryman of that Emerging Republican Majority that the political analyst Kevin Phillips detailed during the 1968 campaign. Rather than introduce a new auteur, "Joe" projected a new character -- and was thus precursor to such subsequent guerrilla productions as "Sweet Sweetback's Baadassss Song" and "Billy Jack." Indeed, Mr. Avildsen enjoyed his greatest success six years later when he directed the movie that introduced another, more positive, working-class hero: Rocky.
For a time, Cannon periodically took out ads for unmade sequels to its greatest hit. In 1980, the company promised "Joe II" and, in 1985, announced the coming of "Citizen Joe": "The man has changed but the times have not. . . . He's back." But, of course, the times had changed. The cult of direct action that seemed so shocking in 1970 was all too characteristic of the films of the 80's -- not only were characters played by Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger accustomed to taking the law into their own hands, their exploits served to burnish the image of our movie star president, Ronald Reagan. Or so it might have seemed to Joe.
