SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2035 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Far Out in the Land Of Shakespeare

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: CEDAR CITY, Utah

 BODY:
FLAGS on Main Street here proclaim "Tony 2000." At the town's Utah Shakespearean Festival, not far from the majestic Bryce Canyon and Zion national parks, the organizers, actors and volunteers are still a bit dazed about having won the regional theater Tony Award last month.
"We began in 1962 with just about nothing, a budget of $1,000 and lots of volunteers," said Fred C. Adams, 69, the buoyant founder and executive producer of the festival. "This Tony Award was a validation of what we've been striving for over the last four decades." 
 It was also a validation of a resilient regional theater that was virtually unknown in New York until the Tonys but well known among a Shakespeare underground in the heartland. As many as 155,000 theatergoers, mostly young families and older people from the Midwest and Far West, surge into this sedate mountain town in the southwestern corner of Utah each summer for afternoons and evenings of professional theatrical productions.
The fact that there is a substantial and, yes, adoring audience "out there" for Shakespeare as well as other dramatists -- not in New York or Chicago or Los Angeles but in Utah -- might surprise the Broadway and Off Broadway crowd.
"This is destination theater," said Anthony DeFonte, who is performing three roles this summer, including Shylock in "The Merchant of Venice," and has appeared in a number of television series. "It's a place where people decide to take a vacation -- to see six plays in a few days and visit the national parks nearby. And they're a wonderfully attentive and responsive audience. They love the ritual of theater and we frequently get standing ovations. They are really moved by Shakespeare's work."
Another actor at the festival echoed Mr. DeFonte. "Audiences gasp openly, they laugh openly, they applaud, there's deep silence," said Kathleen McCall, who is playing Portia to Mr. DeFonte's Shylock. "And they are willing to be challenged," she added, seated on the theater's lawn in the pulsing heat before rehearsals.
"It's daunting for me," Ms. McCall said, "as for all of us, because they know their Shakespeare so well. Some will come with the plays, actually reading them as you perform. They'll look at you strangely if you say a wrong word. They really know the text. I'm sure at some point I'm going to have people from the audience saying 'the quality of mercy' speech with me."
Like some of the other 18 Equity actors who have the top roles this season, Ms. McCall has worked on Broadway, Off Broadway and in regional theaters. Auditions are held in January and February in major cities like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Some roles are cast with undergraduates; actor-interns are hired for nonspeaking parts and musical choruses.
The mood at the festival, with its two theaters -- outdoor and indoor -- its behind-the-scenes tours, lectures and festivities on the lawns of Southern Utah University (part of the festival grounds are on the campus), seems ebullient -- almost innocent. The afternoon that Mr. Adams and other executives of the theater returned from New York after the Tony ceremony, the 350 members of the festival's company and 400 volunteers lined up around the theaters and passed the award from one person to another.
"Those were the hands that made it possible," Mr. Adams said. "It was a very moving hour."
As he spoke, nearly 200 people were sitting on the lawn at dusk, waiting to enter the 888-seat outdoor Adams Memorial Shakespearean Theater. It is modeled after the Globe Theater in which Shakespeare's plays were produced in London, and it is named after a major benefactor of the festival, Grace Adams Tanner (a distant cousin of Mr. Adams's), and her parents. The audience, which would see "The Merry Wives of Windsor," was being entertained by "The Greenshow," half a dozen dancers and singers in Renaissance costume.
Watching them, Nancy Lindon, who grew up on Long Island, and her husband, Arthur, who retired in 1992 as director of public works for the Village of Old Westbury, N.Y., said they had been visiting the festival for three or four years and loved the plays -- at least most of them. The retired couple live in Pinehurst, N.C., but spend their summers in Park City, Utah, in the northern part of the state, the home of the Sundance Film Festival.
"The caliber of acting is first-rate," Mr. Lindon said. "We saw 'Peter Pan' today, and it was fantastic."
His wife nodded. "We come here for two days and see four shows, and I love it. I'm from New York. I've seen a lot of theater. That's top-drawer theater. Well, so is this."
The Lindons voiced one qualification. "The musicals -- sometimes," Mrs. Lindon said. "Last year we saw 'Damn Yankees' and it was not good. Doing a musical is not easy. We did see 'A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum' here. That was excellent."
Nearby, Heather Hill, an electronics teacher in Bountiful, Utah, and her husband, Warren, a dean at Weaver State University in Ogden, Utah, north of Salt Lake City, said they had been making the five-hour drive from Ogden to the festival for 10 years.
"All kinds of people come here; you meet a lot of teachers and people interested in the theater and Shakespeare," said Mr. Hill, who with his wife used to live on the East Coast and in Detroit.
THESE plays are utterly timeless," Mrs. Hill said. "I remember going to Stratford, Ontario, to see 'Henry V.' It was during the Vietnam War. He made the speech to the soldiers going into battle and they were asking, 'What are we fighting for?' And I thought, 'My goodness, nothing has changed.' Last year we saw 'King Lear' here. The dynamics of the family is absolutely the same today as it was back then."
Because of the repertory schedule, a typical visitor can see all six productions in three days by choosing matinee and evening performances in both theaters. The roster this 39th season -- from June 26 to Sept. 2 -- is, in many ways, typical of the selections each year. In addition to "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Merry Wives of Windsor," the third Shakespearean production is "The War of the Roses" (an adaptation of "Henry VI: Parts 1, 2 and 3" by Howard Jensen, a festival director).
Shakespeare may dominate the calendar but other authors, of usually mainstream dramas, comedies and musicals, are equally popular. This year the festival is presenting Chekhov's "Cherry Orchard," Michael Frayn's farce "Noises Off" and an adaptation of "Peter Pan" by Mr. Adams, who is also directing. A separate fall season, held indoors in the Randall L. Jones Theater, runs from Sept. 14 to Oct. 14. The productions there this season will be the musical revue "Always . . . Patsy Cline" and "Driving Miss Daisy."
Because the festival takes place in a conservative state founded by Mormons, the selection of non-Shakespeare plays has stirred some delicate issues for the organizers, many of them Mormon themselves. Dramas, comedies or musicals with sex, blunt language or edgy themes can be unwelcome. In "Noises Off" this season, the festival received permission from Mr. Frayn to alter the line "Oh, my God." Now it reads, "Oh, my Lord." Tennessee Williams's "Glass Menagerie" was a big hit several years ago, as was Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman." But while "A Streetcar Named Desire" has been done, Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" (in which a main character is a gay Mormon) would very likely be avoided.
A festival press representative put it this way: "We don't restrict ourselves because of the content of plays but rather because of whether the audience would go. So we wouldn't do 'Angels in America' because we probably wouldn't get an audience to watch it."
Yet it would be inaccurate to label the festival tradition-bound and cloaked in the culture of conservatism. Ina Marlowe, the director of "The Merchant of Venice" this year and the managing director of the Organic Theater in Chicago, said: "I didn't know any of these people when I came here and it's been an amazing experience. They have been totally open and welcoming to me as a woman director. I don't often get that in larger cities. I was not expecting it."
Kathleen F. Conlin, who staged "The Cherry Orchard" this summer and is the festival's casting director, put it another way: "When you look at the history of Utah, right from the beginning the church was pro art, music and drama. Brigham Young said drama was the best way to teach moral values -- especially for those people who couldn't read. One of the first major buildings constructed in Salt Lake when the pioneers arrived was a theater."
Similarly, Mr. Adams, the festival's founder, said that Shakespeare's dramas struck a chord for audiences in general: "We haven't changed since Shakespeare's time. The same longings, the same cravings, the same desires." Mormons, he said, were especially stirred by Shakespeare: " 'The Merchant of Venice' is one of the popular plays for Mormon audiences. They see the victim in Shylock. Having been victimized themselves in their own history, Mormons take great comfort in seeing this portrayal of humanity victimized by people who profess to be Christians."
By every account, the festival owes its birth and growth to Mr. Adams, a friendly and exuberant former actor with an obsession for theater. A Mormon, he grew up in central Utah, yearning to be an actor. After a stint in the Army he went to New York, where he worked in several Off Broadway shows and was a "swing" dancer, an understudy, in the 1953 Cole Porter musical "Can-Can." By the late 1950's, though, he had moved back to Utah.
"New York didn't need me and it was important to find a place that did," he said. He took a job in Cedar City at the small junior college that grew into the university. His task was to set up a drama department.
"The community was going through a real letdown," he recalled. "The iron mines had closed. The economy was shattered. At that point I said to the mayor and the city council that I wanted to start a Shakespeare festival. They thought I was crazy. The idea of Shakespeare didn't seem to impress any of them."
With the help of a local Lions Club, Mr. Adams began the festival in 1962 with "Hamlet," "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Taming of the Shrew." Students and local townspeople played the roles on a makeshift stage. Most of them made their own costumes. They also put on productions of "On Borrowed Time" by Paul Osborn and the Jule Styne musical "Bells Are Ringing." The festival made a profit of $2,000 -- and Mr. Adams was home free.
Today, the budget has climbed to more than $5 million, nearly 80 percent of it from the sale of tickets, which cost from $18 to $40. The rest of the money comes from foundation support and private donors, mostly in Salt Lake City, Las Vegas, Los Angeles and Phoenix. In 1989, the company opened its second space, the stylish Randall L. Jones Theater (named after the father of tourism in the region), at a cost of $5.5 million. And now there is a Web site: www.bard.org.
The festival's appeal has started to lure travelers from the East Coast. "I was dubious at first about Shakespeare in Utah -- and very reluctantly I went," said Kenneth Adelman, a director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency during the Reagan administration, who has taught Shakespeare courses at Georgetown and George Washington universities. "And it blew me out of the water. This place is in the middle of nowhere. And what you get is extraordinary."
Mr. Adelman and his family began attending the festival a dozen years ago. This year, he and about 35 friends from New York, Chicago, Washington, Buffalo and other cities are attending.
Certainly the Tony Award has given the festival a visibility it never had, and Mr. Adams said he expected audiences as well as fund-raising to surge.
In the meantime, he still seemed almost overwhelmed by the award. At the festival's opening night this summer, Mr. Adams described walking along the red carpet to enter Radio City Music Hall to accept the Tony.
For the man who didn't make it on Broadway nearly 50 years ago, it was an especially sweet triumph. "At long last," he said. "We've been recognized!"

PUB-DATE: July 30, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Treasures Of a Past Glowing With Hope

BYLINE: By SHERMAN YELLEN; Sherman Yellen is the author of "Say Yes! The World's Fair Musical" and a collector of memorabilia from the 1939 World's Fair.

 BODY:
THE tip of this Trylon was perfect. Not a chip or a bend. The Perisphere was pristine, unscratched, unspotted, its surface gleaming after 60 years. Whoever owned these brass-plated pot-metal bookends had treated them with the reverence they deserved.
I entered my high bid in this Internet auction, under my nom de guerre, WF39, but as I surveyed the user ID's of the other bidders, I foresaw trouble. Here were my nemeses; the well-named "Fairfiend," "GroverW" and especially "exNY1940"; men and women possessed of pockets so deep and passions so large that seconds before the end of an auction, trigger finger on their mouse, they would make off with my Trylon and Peri sphere trophy, slamming my bid with a higher one, leaving me stunned and defeated. 
 It was kitsch I craved, tchotchkes if you prefer, collectibles if you must, that had reduced me to this Dostoyevskian desperation, as time and again I prepared to go beyond my limits to possess that which I had to have, something wonderful from the fair.
On my desk was a small Bakelite pencil sharpener, depicting the fair's symbols, the Trylon and Perisphere, in a smoky orange plastic, and though I honored it, I knew it was but a puny example of the T. and P. wonders that survived the fair. I hungered -- no, I lusted for -- more, knowing that more would never be enough. My sons had even jokingly threatened to hold a World's Fair intervention if I didn't stop my obsessive buying. I didn't need that to recognize that my life had been spinning out of control, dominated by a sphere and a spire that had been constructed on a former Corona, Queens, garbage dump.
These ashtrays, lamps, thermometers, andirons and salt and pepper shakers shaped as sphere and spire are, for me, that fair in miniature. If I step on the gas, I'd have to say they will always mean to me and the other fair fiends a better tomorrow. Who wouldn't want to own a piece of that? Forget the fairs of Chicago, St. Louis, Paris and San Francisco. We know that there was only one world's fair that ever mattered, and it took place in New York in 1939-40.
For the last three years I have been working as book writer and lyricist with the composer Wally Harper on a new musical comedy, "Say Yes!," set in that World's Fair of 1940. It was developed with the director Jay Binder by the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center and will have its premiere at the Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., on Aug. 15. But its true origins can be found 60 years ago, when as a small boy my family took me to the fair. It was a life-changing experience.
At the time, my family, like many middle-class families in New York, lived in an apartment where brown ruled. Forget your Fred and Ginger dancing against gleaming silvery white settings. For most of us, America in the late 30's was drab; shabby before that word was tied to chic; it was linoleum floors and oilcloth tablecloths, and it smelled of furniture polish and Murphy's Oil Soap. And then came the dazzling moderne whiteness of the New York World's Fair to open up a new vision of how to live.
The theme of that fair, "Building the World of Tomorrow," was not a come-on, it was a pay-off for the hard years of the Depression, which were coming to an end. New York was still suffering under a major economic slump. A committee headed by Grover Whalen, the city's official greeter, determined that the fair would celebrate the wonders of the consumer society. "Consumer" in 1939 was not a pejorative term; to be consumers was the wish of every family who looked in wonder at the inaccessible General Electric dishwasher and the streamlined Ford cars.
A central-theme exhibit was needed to dramatize the fair's message. Enter Wallace K. Harrison, the architect behind Rockefeller Center and later the United Nations, a brilliant, pragmatic American modernist. Awarded the contract to design the theme center, Harrison began his design work for the monumental Trylon and Perisphere with a hairpin and a ball of putty. He claimed that the sphere he created was the ideal shape for the fair because a ball can enclose the largest possible amount of space with the smallest amount of material, while the natural contrasting form to a sphere is a tower. Further inspiration for the theme can be found in the drawings of the Russian Constructivists. Later it would be discovered that the closest ancestor of the fair's icons was the very antithesis of modernism, an 1875 engraving, "Within the Gates" by A. I. Rice, a scene of swooning spirits facing a fully formed Trylon and Perisphere, the artist's paradisiacal dream of heaven. There is no denying that there was something in these shapes, their great size and their relationship to each other that was magical. And to bottom it off, the fountain below the Perisphere created the illusion of a huge ball floating on air.
The path to the fair was also paved by the movies. The Emerald City of Oz would have fit in comfortably at the fair, Munchkins and all. That hidden city of peace and brotherly love, Shangri-La, in the film "Lost Horizon" (1937), was a modern white pavilion, another candidate for fairdom. The hunger for peace in a war-torn world, expressed in that film, met its match in reality at the fair, as the 1939 theme, "The World of Tomorrow," gave way to "For Peace and Freedom" in 1940.
The pull of the future must have been remarkable, because my parents, wary of crowds with their threat of polio epidemics, conquered their fears and took my sister, Simone, and me to view "The World of Tomorrow." Despite its architectural distinction, the fair was primarily family fun, and there was more than a bit of carney in its heart.
It is claimed that Walt Disney got his notion for Disneyland from the '39 fair. But to say that it was the precursor of Disneyland is to diminish it, for the early Disneyland offered a cozy make-believe past, while the fair gave us a spacious, gleaming make-believe future, far preferable to most Americans, who saw their recent past as something to surmount, not celebrate.
The fair set its sights on 1960 as its future. Many of its predictions would come true: machines would wash dishes and clothes, cars would be streamlined, suburbs would abound, television would entertain us and interstate highways would connect, and separate, us.
But the futurists of the time did not foresee the possibility of abandoned inner cities or the devastating consequences of economic and racial inequality. With World War II just around the corner, the fair's architects and industrial designers seemed to suggest that many of the world's ills could be cured by the judicious use of pale geometric shapes, with fountains and lagoons, leading to a new, modernist aesthetic that would assure a just society.
There was a breathtaking innocence to that fair. There was also that inexorable American optimism symbolized in the Trylon and Perisphere, undefeated by the Depression, strong despite the victories of fascism in Europe and the closing of the pavilions of the conquered nations.
With all this in mind -- well, actually with none of this in mind -- Wally Harper and I set out to memorialize the world of the fair in our musical, abetted by the souvenir Heinz pickle pins and Planter's Peanut men, hoping to capture the comic postcard charm that was also its hallmark. So, if I cannot repossess the symbols of my youth on eBay, I am privileged to relive it onstage with "Say Yes!" And if the show is successful, watch out Fairfiend, WF39 will be unstoppable.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The 400 Block of East 91st Street;
A West Side Food Name Shapes an East Side Block

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
FREE ASSOCIATE "Zabar's," and after "smoked salmon" you'll probably get "West Side." But there's another Zabar in the business, and for the last decade Eli Zabar has been remolding the low-rise block of East 91st Street from First to York Avenue from a street of miscellaneous light industry into a sprawling upscale food village centered on his Vinegar Factory at 429 East 91st.
In the mid-19th century, the East 90's near the East River had little of the development that was dotting the rest of the Upper East Side, perhaps because the large flatland north of 90th Street was a marshy swamp. Fill dumped from building operations gradually produced drier ground, and by the 1880's industries began locating in the area because of its nearby water access. 
 The most prominent of the newcomers was the large stoneyard that the contractor Thomas Osborne built. It covered several lots, including the site where the Vinegar Factory now stands. Osborne, who built the big brownstone-faced apartment house at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue that bears his name, died in his stoneyard in 1892, seven years after he lost the Osborne apartment house in foreclosure.
The oldest buildings now on the 400 block of East 91st Street date from that period, like the two factories at 403 and 407 built in the mid-1880's by another stone contractor, John J. Schillinger. He specialized in the new "artificial stone," which was rapidly replacing traditional bluestone sidewalks, and put his monogram, J S, on 403 East 91st.
Building records are contradictory for the gemlike brick and terra cotta building at 419 East 91st, but it appears that it was built in 1886 by the ironworkers James and Thomas Hunter as a combination residence and workshop, designed by the architect George Spitzer. The block also had a cigar factory, laundry and similar businesses.
In 1909 Charles Roos built the copper works at 429 East 91st Street, designed by Kastner & Dell. Across the street, the contractor and alderman James E. Gaffney built 434 and 440 East 91st in the early 1910's, at the time he owned the Boston Braves, now the Atlanta Braves.
The most striking architecture on the block came in 1930, when Horace Ginsbern designed the Art Deco garage at 406 East 91st, with zigzag decoration in multicolored brick.
Except for some big apartment buildings on York Avenue, the block had changed little when Eli Zabar arrived in the early 1990's. Mr. Zabar's father, Louis, founded the famous Zabar's at 80th and Broadway in the 1930's. After attending the Fieldston School and Hobart College, Eli Zabar tried business school and teaching. He decided, however, to follow in the family footsteps, but at some distance from his older brothers, Stanley and Saul, who run the West Side store with an unrelated partner.
ELI ZABAR founded E.A.T., a combination of takeout delicatessen and prepared foods and eat-in cafe, at 1064 Madison Avenue, between 80th and 81st Streets, in 1973, and in 1991 he rented the lower floors of 403 East 91st Street to make bread for E.A.T. and other customers. In 1993, the year the popular Aquacenter athletic facility opened at 91st and York, Mr. Zabar bought the old copper works at 429 East 91st, which by then was a Baker's Brand mustard and vinegar factory.
He and his architect, Richard Lewis, adapted the building to sell and serve food, keeping or reusing much of the original character -- like the giant hooks and lifts left over from the copper works -- and cutting old vinegar barrels in half for tables.
"We try to find the story in things," he says, "and here the story was very clear: a factory building, sort of rough, and we wanted to keep it rough."
Since then Mr. Zabar's food operations have come to dominate the block, from the aroma of bread to the sound of shovelfuls of ice sprinkled over produce to the occasional barricades of pallets of supplies. Now they include, moving from York Avenue west to First, a cafe and magazine store on the York Avenue corner; an old tinware factory at 430 East 91st, which he bought last year and is converting to a bakery; the original Vinegar Factory with its rooftop greenhouse at 429 East 91st Street; the adjacent garage building at 421 East 91st; the David Garage at 422 East 91st; a repair shop for his trucks at 420 East 91st; and his existing bakery operation at 403 East 91st. Mr. Zabar owns all the buildings except for the original bakery. He also operates a large store and restaurant at 80th Street and Third Avenue.
Every day the restless Mr. Zabar zooms through his side-street empire, constantly tinkering, rearranging, improving. And it is a handyman's fantasy: the bakery, for instance, has a Piranesi-style complex of rolling belts carrying bread through, around and over the ovens; the Vinegar Factory has unusual touches such as giant wooden window hatches suspended from the ceiling with complicated pulley mechanisms. There's nothing cutesy, nothing that looks restored. Architecturally it's more salvage than preservation, which fits into Mr. Zabar's innate sense of economy: "Working with leftovers excites me," he says, referring to both food and nonfood items.
IN 1998 Mr. Zabar added a tomato greenhouse on the roof of the Vinegar Factory and the adjacent building. It's a light, airy plastic shed. The tinkerer in him loves the fact that he uses the hot air from the pastry ovens below to moderate the temperature of the tomatoes on the roof.
Across the street at 430 East 91st, Mr. Zabar's newest project is rooftop steel for another greenhouse, this one for lettuce. Mr. Zabar can't give a bottom line account of whether the original $100,000 greenhouse has been a good investment: "I don't really calculate costs," he says. "If you do things right, it will work out."
Mr. Zabar has more than 200 employees chopping, kneading, broiling, icing, wrapping, checking, driving and everything else necessary to feed the stream of shoppers who make the block a destination. "I don't think there were 26 people who walked down the block 10 years ago, and now we have 9,000 a week just go through the cash registers," in addition to the restaurant traffic, Mr. Zabar says.
Mr. Zabar's operation spreads over about 38,000 square feet of mostly contiguous real estate.
Has the idea of building instead of baking come up?
"Periodically we look at it, but then we get confused and move on to something else" says Mr. Lewis, the architect. "Someday, maybe," says Mr. Zabar, drifting off and looking a little vacant. But then he snaps back to attention when he sees a problem on the sidewalk -- a parking stanchion out of alignment -- that needs fixing.

HEADLINE: More People Calling Cincinnati's Downtown Home

BYLINE: By JOHN ECKBERG 

 BODY:
WHEN the Hofmeyer family bought the decrepit Biltmore apartment building on West Fourth Street in downtown Cincinnati in 1990 and two years later the Lombardi, a historic but condemned apartment building on an adjacent lot, banks balked at loans to update the units. Housing in the city's central business district was in a downward spiral. Parking was scarce. There was no grocery, and few young professionals were ready to live in a Midwestern downtown.
Nevertheless, Max and Angela Hofmeyer and their five sons, who own a plumbing company, concluded that their out-of-pocket investment in upgrading the two distressed buildings would pay off. 
 Mr. and Mrs. Hofmeyer -- both are now 68 -- sold their house on two acres in a suburban neighborhood on the west side of town, and at an age when many Americans would be looking to retire to a beach community became part of a Cincinnati back-to-the-city movement, living in one of the buildings that they were refurbishing.
They knew there would be challenges. After all, the Biltmore was half-occupied and four of the 28 apartments had never been completed after a previous attempt at renovation. The family was confident, however, that the building could be returned to its former glory. There were tall ceilings, white marble hallways, exposed brick walls and distinctive windows in a building that at one time had been a coveted address.
"There was risk, but we knew felt comfortable knowing that after a lot of work we would have quality apartments, and quality apartments will have renters," said their son Paul, who helped update kitchens and bathrooms in both buildings.
Because of investors like the Hofmeyers -- and heavy public subsidies for other projects -- the population of the square-mile Cincinnati Central Business District has reached levels not seen for decades.
The population increase is similar to the trend back to downtown that has been noted in other cities across the nation. Eugenie Birch, who heads the department of city and regional planning at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, has compared housing trends in 40 American cities from 1990 to 1999 and found that one in four have returned to 1970 population levels.
In her 1999 study, "Downtown Living: A Deeper Look," she reported that Cincinnati had one of the more robust markets for downtown housing in the nation.
She estimated that 4,810 people lived downtown in 1999, up from 3,838 in 1990. Kathy Schwab, residential development adviser to Downtown Cincinnati Inc., a nonprofit group, said that there were about 2,100 housing units downtown, with 10 or so buildings restored or converted, five more under construction and two projects in development.
"What people were reflecting anecdotally -- that more people were moving back downtown - was really happening in some cities like Cincinnati," Professor Birch said. "This is a fragile trend that has happened for a lot of reasons. People want to walk to work. They like an urban life with all its attachments: good restaurants, theater and art museums."
"They are living in lofts, converted factories," she added. "It's a lifestyle choice."
Professor Birch initiated her study when she reviewed a 1998 report by the Brookings Institution and Fannie Mae, the federally chartered mortgage financing corporation, that showed many American cities expected to see a healthy increase in downtown housing. In that report, however, Cincinnati was not in the top tier. Planners had projected that only 3,500 people would be living in the central business district by 2010, about the same number they thought were living downtown in Columbus and Pittsburgh today. But that study of 26 cities did not have fixed central business district boundaries, and planners had estimated downtown boundaries and populations.
While Professor Birch thought that the methodology of the report could be sharpened, she agreed with the finding that there was a broad trend of people moving back to downtown. IN preparing her study, she focused on the growth in the number of downtown households, and restricted the geographical scope of the report to core blocks. Instead of relying on rough estimates by local planners, she bought data from Claritas, a company that specializes in demographic and economic data. Cities with downtowns that posted significant gains, according to her study, included Dallas, Denver, Colorado Springs, Atlanta and Charlotte, N.C., and Portland, Ore.
The Hofmeyers never regretted their move from suburbia to downtown, though they have now returned to a suburb to be closer to grandchildren. "We had a rooftop deck with views of downtown and the river," Mrs. Hofmeyer said. "But at the beginning friends told us we were nuts."
The Hofmeyers' two buildings had a waiting list until earlier this year, when some tenants fled because of inconveniences from the construction of a new football stadium for the Cincinnati Bengals about three blocks south. Seven vacancies resulted, all of which have since been filled, although the waiting list is a thing of the past, at least for now. Other buildings where young and single tenants live include a former cigar warehouse called East Eighth Lofts, where all 45 units were rented in 60 days last fall. Other apartments have gone into the former Shillito Department Store.
Nicholas Bonner, a professor of art at Northern Kentucky University, moved into East Eighth Lofts last fall after spurning "cookie-cutter" complexes in nearby suburbs. The central location means he spends less for gasoline and has a manageable commute to the university six miles south. Also, he said, he is not contributing to urban sprawl, though the lack of a grocery downtown remains an inconvenience. He pays $670 a month in rent, which does not include utilities, and $120 a month for two parking spots.
"I bet half the people in the building are lawyers, doctors or professionals," Mr. Bonner said. "I love it downtown: to walk out the door and see an opening at the Contemporary Arts Center or go grab something to eat."
Among the challenges for developers has been competition from other neighborhoods and the city's historically low housing costs, said Ralph D. Bolton, the former head of Cincinnati downtown development and now a principal at the architecture firm of Brashear Bolton.
"There were and are very good neighborhoods close to downtown that were accessible and had relatively inexpensive housing stock and apartments," he said. "What has to happen for downtown housing to be attractive is it must attract people from those neighborhoods: offer some kind of vitality and value."
Rising rents and property values in recent years in nearby neighborhoods like Clifton and Hyde Park that have long attracted young professionals has also added to the attraction of downtown housing. In the 1970's and 1980's, most housing downtown was aimed at low-income residents. Today the mix includes more upper- and middle-income residents, and as a result restaurants and clubs are opening in long-vacant buildings.
Apartments in the Biltmore and Lombardi bring $350 to $725 in rent, but that does not include $75 a month for a parking slot.
A few units go for more: the rent for a two-bedroom townhouse with deck is $800 a month and approaches $900 when parking is included. Although that may seem a bargain when compared with rents in major cities like New York and Chicago, it is pricey by Cincinnati standards.
The Hofmeyers are in the market to buy another apartment building downtown, but times have changed. A nearby shell carries a $325,000 price tag -- far from the $10 that the Hofmeyers paid the city for the Lombardi nearly a decade ago.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
In Bayonne, Selling Shares to a Home-Grown Bank

BYLINE: By ANITA DENNIS

DATELINE: BAYONNE

 BODY:
Bailey Building and Loan. Bayonne Community Bank. Different places, same idea.
In a city where children often attend the same grammar schools their parents did, and where parents and their grown children often live together in two-family houses, merchants had become annoyed at the impersonal service they were receiving at banks owned by the larger out-of-town institutions. 
 The solution? They decided about a year ago to open their own place to put their money, and the result is the Bayonne Community Bank, a grass-roots venture that is being financed by longtime residents of this working-class waterfront town.
"I've been in business here 27 years," said H. Mickley McCabe, who is chairman of the new bank. "I'm president of the economic development corporation, I was vice president of the chamber of commerce. But now I go into a bank and they ask me for ID. If you go into a community bank, you know them and they know you."
As a result, the bank's founders worked hard to cultivate community support, beginning with an open house last November on the bank's planned site at 40th Street and Broadway, in the heart of the town's commercial district. After two subsequent informational meetings at local restaurants, a large percentage of the 250 to 300 people who attended ultimately bought shares in the bank at $10 each, said Donald Mindiak, the bank's chief executive.
The bank, which is awaiting charter approval from state and federal regulators, has the $5 million initial capitalization required by the state and is hoping to have $6 million before it opens in September, Mr. Mindiak said.
Long a vibrant industrial stronghold, Bayonne has in the last decade been abandoned by large employers ranging from Texaco to the Army. Moreover, 50 years ago this city of about 60,000, which sits on a three-square-mile peninsula, was cut off from its nearest neighbor, Jersey City, by the turnpike's Newark Bay extension.
But about three months ago it became much more accessible with the opening of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line, which can deliver Manhattan-bound commuters from Bayonne to the Exchange Place PATH station in as little as 15 minutes.
"Bayonne is the unclaimed jewel," Mr. McCabe said in a recent interview.
Although the city missed out on previous real estate booms in Hudson County, Mr. McCabe and his fellow investors hope Bayonne can finally attract the kinds of young professionals who flocked to Hoboken in the early 1980's in search of affordable housing, as well as families who are tired of long commutes to Manhattan from the distant suburbs.
"The city of Bayonne is in a perfect position to revitalize itself through the advent of light rail," he said, pointing to the two most evident symbols of the city's hard times -- a 70-acre former Texaco site that needed years of environmental cleanup, and the shuttered Military Ocean Terminal, which not long ago employed 2,500 people.
Newly created, or de novo, banks, are often run by people like Mr. Mindiak -- who was born and raised here but lost his job as treasurer of the First Savings Bank of New Jersey when it was bought out by Richmond County Savings, which has its headquarters on Staten Island. Indeed, about 25 such banks have opened in New Jersey in the past couple of years, said Jim Meredith, senior vice president of the New Jersey League-Community and Savings Bankers.
"They are defined by their philosophy more than anything else," Mr. Meredith said. "Management tends to be very involved in the community and in local civic organizations."
One recent day, Mr. Mindiak was greeted by several passers-by during the one-block walk from the bank's temporary offices at 42nd Street and Broadway to its 4,700-square-foot construction site a little more than a block away. He said the bank's neighbors were shown blueprints before the building was even begun, and they were asked to offer suggestions or concerns.
"This is an extremely traditional town with traditional values," he said. For instance, he said research had found that in Bayonne, regular passbook savings accounts rather than high-interest-bearing CD's or money market accounts made up the highest percentage of deposits.
Once the new building opens on 40th Street, it will feature off-street parking, a three-lane drive-through window and two automated teller machines -- one of them a drive-through. They hope to keep the bank open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. seven days a week, although they concede that those hours may not be feasible at first. "People shouldn't be waiting for us to open up, we should be waiting for them to come," Mr. Mindiak said.
His philosophy is in sharp contrast to many of today's large financial institutions. "In New Jersey, several out-of-state banks have come in and acquired banks," Mr. Meredith said, "and they are often not as responsive to the local communities and their small or mid-size businesses and local retailers."
In this instance, Mr. McCabe, who lives and works within a block of the bank, says that all of the board members and executives were born, raised or own businesses in Bayonne, which he believes distinguishes it from other area savings banks.
One Bayonne resident, John Halecky, a councilman whose family owns a pharmacy one block from the new bank, said he had recently bought shares in the bank because the board included so many familiar names.
"It's all the local movers and shakers," said Mr. Halecky, who added that he was also attracted by the prospect of investing in his hometown. "I think the future of Bayonne is bright."

HEADLINE: A Deep-Water Discovery;
Virtually Unknown a Few Years Ago, The Stonington Red Is Catching On

BYLINE: By JOE WOJTAS

 BODY:
FROM November to June, customers hound Jo Bomster of Stonington Seafood Harvesters for what the locals call "Stonington Reds."
"They think we're hiding it in here. They think we've got secret pockets or something," said Ms. Bomster, whose family operates a wholesale and retail seafood operation near the Town Dock in the borough. 
 What people are clamoring for are royal red shrimp, a species that lives in such deep water that they are caught by just a handful of boats in the Northeast and only one in Connecticut. The shrimp was almost unheard of before 1995, but since its discovery word of the shrimp has spread. They have increasingly been turning up on dinner tables and in restaurants around the region, where, chefs say, the Red's higher fat content make them sweeter and more tender than Gulf Coast shrimp.
The shrimp can be found at the Daniel Packer Inne in Mystic and on the fruits de mer platter, as a fancy garnish, or as part of a ceviche in a large martini glass at London Lennie's in Forest Hills, N.Y. They're being sold at Citarella, a gourmet food store in Manhattan and the Hamptons. And at Rent A Chef, an upscale fish market with four locations in northwestern Connecticut, they're being bought by customers, many of them New Yorkers who have weekend homes in the area.
"We buy 200 to 300 pounds at a time," said Carol Herman, the owner of Rent A Chef. "One lady buys four or five pounds a week from us."
 The shrimp became available in the state out of pure economic necessity, when Ms. Bomster's husband, Bill, a scallop fisherman who was worried about his dwindling catch, decided to search for another way to make a living from the sea.
He obtained a $118,000 federal grant to look for scarlet shrimp, which were known to live in deep water off the coast of New England. With stocks of cod and other popular species overfished, the National Marine Fisheries Service was giving grants to Northeast fishermen to find and market so-called underutilized species.
Mr. Bomster headed to the Atlantic with his crew and also on board was a scientist from the University of Connecticut to help identify whatever Bomster found. He found few scarlet shrimp, but thousands of its cousin, the royal red shrimp. When he and others tasted the surprise catch, they knew they were on to something.
 Distributors such as Gambardella Wholesale Fish Dealers of Stonington and East Haven, and Emerald Seafood in New York City's Fulton Fish Market, are trying to get the word out about the shrimp to restaurants and fish markets in the tri-state area. Greater demand may convince other fishermen to make the $50,000 to $100,000 initial investment for the nets, gear, freezers and other processing equipment needed to catch and process the shrimp.
"People love them. Especially the high-end restaurants. They remember them from last year and they ask for them," said Thomas Flanigan, president of Emerald Seafood. "I could sell them all year long if I could get them."
But Alan Chaplaski, captain of the Stonington-based fishing boat, Neptune, who is renting Mr. Bomster's shrimping gear, can only fish the area from June through November because it is reserved for offshore lobster gear the rest of the year. Mr. Chaplaski, the only Connecticut fisherman catching the shrimp, would be unable to tow a shrimp net through the area during those times without damaging lobster pots.
Michael Gambardella, whose company sells about 20,000 pounds of the shrimp each year, said it has been a little bit of a battle to introduce a product most people have never seen. Much of the demand has been local and distributors have been trying to introduce the shrimp to the rest of the state and to New York.
"We've been doing it in bits and pieces," Mr. Gambardella said.
Nancy Balcom, the extension educator with the Sea Grant College program at the University of Connecticut in Groton, helped write the report about Mr. Bomster's grant results. She said there are not enough shrimp in the area Mr. Bomster explored to support a large number of boats. She is not surprised more fishermen have not started to catch the shrimp because of the expense of new gear and the uncertainty of finding new areas.
If the popularity of red shrimp increases, Ms. Balcom said more fishermen may decide to catch the shrimp, especially on a part-time basis. She said some red shrimp are also caught in the deep water of the Gulf of Mexico, but they are not sent to other parts of the country. In both places, they are found in about 50-degree water.
Mr. Bomster received the grant to locate areas where scarlet shrimp and other deep-water species live and do a marketing study and a scientific analysis. The goal of the study was to determine if there were enough scarlet shrimp to sustain a commercial fleet.
The grant paid for deep-water nets, almost two miles of wire need to tow it and other gear. It also paid for his crew, fuel, food, ice and the salary of a scientist who accompanied the crew. Without the grant, Mr. Bomster would not have been able to afford the search.
"We didn't have to worry about making money. We could move around and try different depths and different places," he said.
Mr. Bomster and the crew of the Patty Jo made three 10-day trips in 1995, covering an area from Block Island, R.I. to Virginia. Mr. Bomster hauled up few of the scarlet shrimp. But what he did find in his nets were hundreds of pounds of royal red shrimp. The shrimp, which can be as long as 10 inches, were mostly found in a 20-mile-long by half-mile wide stretch of the Continental Shelf about 100 miles southeast of Stonington. The focus of the grant quickly shifted to the royal red shrimp and the results were reported in a detailed booklet.
Today, the 50-year-old Mr. Chaplaski fishes that same 1,200-foot-deep stretch of ocean, leasing the gear and nets from Mr. Bomster, who returned to scalloping when that fishery improved.
Mr. Chaplaski and his three-man crew begins the four-day shrimp trips by steaming 12 hours to the fishing grounds. His crew works long hours with only a few short breaks for sleep. With no freezer capability on board, he must put the shrimp on ice and get them back to the dealer before they spoil.
He and his crew spend four days in port unloading shrimp, doing repairs and loading supplies before heading out to sea again.
Catching red shrimp is hard work for the crew. After they haul the bottom trawling net on board, they chill the shrimp and break off their heads by hand. They sort, wash and place the shrimp in a solution that prevents unsightly black spots from forming on their shells. They then put the shrimp back on ice. At the dock the crew has to remove the shrimp from the ice, wash and sort through them on a conveyor belt, weeding out damaged ones. On a typical trip, the crew will handle 80,000 shrimp.
The shrimp also move around the fishing grounds. This forces Mr. Chaplaski, who had been fishing his whole life and has associate degrees in science, engineering and commercial fishing, to make an educated guess about where they have gone.
"Learning their spots is a trade secret," he said with a smile.
Mr. Chaplaski said he knows of only two other boats, one each from New Jersey and Massachusetts, that catch red shrimp. He said there might soon be another Connecticut boat joining the group.
"It's a lot of work and people are making money doing other things," said Mr. Chaplaski, who catches squid, whiting and fluke the rest of the year. "Some people are also not as adventurous. They like doing something more conservative."
He decided to lease the equipment from Mr. Bomster in 1997 when fishing became poor in the summer.
"It looked like something good. I said, "This is a chance for me to get in on the ground floor," he said, referring to boats that typically flock to a new fishery once they see others being successful.
Ms. Balcom of the University of Connecticut said there has to be a steady supply to make the shrimp popular with consumers.
"If you can't meet the demand continuously, people tend to lose interest in a product," she said.
Ms. Balcom said a scientist at the University of Connecticut is hoping to obtain some live red shrimp from Mr. Chaplaski so he can attempt to raise them in an aquaculture setting. That could result in a more steady supply.
Mr. and Ms. Bomster freeze some of the shrimp and sell it to local restaurants and individual consumers. The shrimp is also sold at the Stonington Farmer's Market every Saturday morning and sells out quickly. Consumers can also buy it off the dock when it arrives.
Mr. Gambardella is selling it to restaurants and fish markets along the Connecticut coast. He has also shipped some to Spain and is trying to break into the trendy Los Angeles market.
Michael Stafford, the executive chef at the Daniel Packer Inne in Mystic, has been serving the shrimp ever since Mr. Bomster first caught them.
"Everyone who has them just loves them," he said. "On the menu I say they are 'amazingly sweet and incredibly tender.' Nobody has ever called me a liar."
Mr. Stafford serves the shrimp lightly sauteed with sundried tomato pesto, fresh Swiss chard, roasted garlic, Chardonnay and angel hair pasta. Others say the shrimp are so flavorful they eat them plain.
Royal red shrimp cooks much quicker than Gulf shrimp. Searing takes just 90 seconds. Mr. Chaplaski drops them in boiling water and then removes them when the pot boils for a second time. It's easy to overcook the shrimp, turning them to mush.
Some factors preventing the shrimp from making a big splash have been the limited supply and higher price. Without expensive freezing equipment on board, boats have to return quickly to sell the shrimp. This also limits the money boats can earn.
For the shrimp to really catch on with the public, Mr. Flanigan from Emerald Seafood, said the price would have to drop about 30 percent from it current $8 to $9 a pound.
"It's a nice item, but it's still pricey," he said.
Mr. Gambardella said that if a few high-profile New York chefs tried the Stonington Reds, they would become the next big thing.
"But we'll get it to the next level. I'm confident we'll do it," Mr. Gambardella said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Conversions and New Construction;
New Manhattan Hotels Are Finding a Ready Market

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE seemingly unending boom in the hotel business in New York continued unabated during the first half of this year, despite an influx of new rooms and the prospect of more to come.
According to a survey by PKF Consulting, which specializes in the hospitality industry, the occupancy rate in Manhattan reached 84.4 percent, a record for any six-month period since the firm began collecting statistics in the 1920's. 
 The average cost of spending a night reached $224.83 during the period, also a record, and an 8.0 percent increase compared with the same period last year. And the trend is upward. PKF reported that the average room rate for the month of June was $236.54, an 11.7 percent increase over June 1999.
PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, which conducts a similar survey, reported the occupancy rate at 84 percent and the average room rate at $249 a night.
"Occupancy and room rates were at record levels, and this is supposed to be the slow half of the year," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF, who explained that demand for hotel rooms is typically lower in the January-to-June months than in July to December, a period of vacations and holidays when people are more apt to travel to New York.
"Hotels in the city are selling out 200 to 250 nights a year, which means they are turning away business, so I am not concerned that we are going to be adding some rooms," Mr. Fox added.
He said the strong market of the last few years has encouraged the development of hotel projects, including the conversion of office buildings and the upgrading of single-room-occupancy hotels to those catering to transients.
Some 4,000 to 4,500 hotel rooms are expected to be added to the New York market this year, one of the largest expansions in recent years.
Tourist interest in New York accounts for much of the demand for lodging in the city, as the crowds surging through Times Square and along Fifth Avenue every day attest.
But the buoyant economy, which is gobbling up office space in the city, is increasing demand from business travelers as well.
Bjorn Hanson, the global leader of the PricewaterhouseCoopers hospitality practice, has calculated that every additional 100 square feet of office space that is occupied in the city generates 0.7 room nights of hotel demand.
Responding to this demand, developers are rushing to complete new hotels, most of them conversions of existing buildings. An exception to this trend is the Sofitel that opened earlier month on 44th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas; it was new construction from the ground up. Rooms cost $350 a night, andsuites, $450.
Another new entrant in the market is the Red Roof Inn Manhattan, the franchise chain's first in New York City, on 32nd Street just west of Fifth Avenue in a converted office building not far from Herald Square. The hotel was developed by Apple Core Hotels, a company owned by the Horn and Kohane families that has four other moderately priced hotels in Midtown Manhattan and a hotel and conference center in Hempstead, N.Y.
The $23 million conversion of the 17-story loft building on 32nd Street has produced a hotel with 171 guest rooms plus a business center, exercise room, meeting space and a breakfast room.
Room rates will range from $89 to $329 a night, which is in marked contrast to some of the other new boutique hotels scheduled to open soon, where room rates will start at nearly $300 a night.
Vijay Dandapani, Apple Core's chief operating officer, said converting the old loft building to a hotel was difficult, particularly so because a retail store on the first floor refused to leave, limiting the size of the lobby. He said that passenger elevators are now where the freight elevators were in the old building, and the shafts for the old passenger elevators are occupied by a stairwell.
"Just about everything is new, but the four walls on the outside," he said.
Since the building is hemmed in on three sides on the lower floors, most of those floors were unsuitable for guest rooms, which have to have a window. So that is where the exercise, conference, business and breakfast rooms were situated. On the upper floors, windows have been punched through the walls, even though the view is often only of the roofs of lower buildings nearby.
BUT there will be some sweeping views from a glass-enclosed rooftop bar, which Mr. Dandapani hopes to complete within a year.
A similar rooftop bar already exists at the Best Western Manhattan, which Apple Core also owns. It is on the north side of 32nd Street, just to the west of the Red Roof, and hotel guests there can take in the sight of the Empire State Building looming in the background only a block away.
Apple Core's other hotels, all developed in the last five years, are the Quality Hotel & Suites at 59 West 46th Street; the Comfort Inn at 129 West 46th Street; and the Quality Hotel at 161 Lexington Avenue (30th Street).
Although all the hotels are operated in collaboration with national chains, Mr. Dandapani said Apple Core has its own reservation system, which brings in about 50 percent of the reservations independent of the franchise affiliations. It is staffed 24 hours a day, he said, to avoid forcing front-desk clerks to make reservations in addition to their other duties.
Mr. Dandapani said the Apple Core's occupancy rate runs well over 90 percent and said that the group was looking for other properties to develop as hotels in New York. But, he added, they must be well located and suitable for conversion.
One building that Apple Core bought but later decided was not suitable for its market is the old Leavitt Building at 130 West 46th Street. Acquired from Apple Core for the Mass Mutual Financial Group by Cornerstone Real Estate Advisers, the new hotel is scheduled to open next month as the Muse, with 200 rooms. It is being described as a boutique hotel that will emphasize personal service at rates that will range from $295 to $395 a night.
The hotel's proximity to the theater district will be emphasized in a ground-floor restaurant -- so far unnamed -- that was designed by David Rockwell, who did such restaurants as Nobu and Heartbeat. The exterior will have a simulated curtain of woven stainless steel drawn up to one side as if opening onto a stage. Inside, the decorations will include simulated theater scenery with banks of spotlights.
The restaurant will have 85 seats and will provide room service for the hotel and a complimentary buffet called the "midnight pantry," where guests can find cookies and desserts, fruit and cheese plates and ice cream after a night at the theater.
Another boutique hotel scheduled to open late this summer is the Dylan, in the former Chemists Club at 52 East 41st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues. The renovation of the 1903 building cost Morris Moinian, the developer, $30 million and produced a 108-room hotel, with rates of $295 to $450 a night.
The hotel's restaurant will be called Rx, with a nod to the building's past. The hotel will have two conference rooms that can be combined to seat up to 75 people. Guest rooms will have high-speed access to the Internet and a television set with Web access.
The Grand Central Partnership, the local business improvement district, is planting trees along the sidewalks in the area and installing antique-style street lamps with hanging flower baskets. Plans are to designate that section of 41st Street as Library Walk in recognition of its proximity to the New York Public Library and to install plaques in the sidewalk with quotes from famous books.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Democrats Pick an Odd Time To Fight Over a Distant Race

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Leave it to those fractious Democrats to remind everyone what is important in New Jersey politics.
Anyone who gave even a thought to politics in midsummer might have believed that the important events on the landscape were the presidential campaign and the race for the United States Senate between Representative Robert D. Franks and Jon Corzine. 
 Wrong. The important race is for governor, the one job in the state with real power, and Senator Robert Torricelli, who is still in his first term, reminded voters of that this month when he decided that he wanted the job after all.
Until now, the Democratic front-runner had been James McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge and the man who came within a percentage point of beating Governor Whitman in 1997 when other incumbent Republicans in the Northeast were winning by 20 percent. Mr. McGreevey has been assiduously raising money and corralling support for a second try ever since, and it seemed to be working -- until the man they call the Torch lit things up.
Until 10 days ago, Senator Torricelli had said he was interested only in running the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, of which he is chairman, apparently because he believed there would be plenty of time to toy with the race for governor before next April's primary filing deadline. But Mr. McGreevey was rapidly sewing up the nomination and Mr. Torricelli evidently decided that he could not wait.
"He saw that he was crossing the Rubicon," State Senator Ray Lesniak, a long-time McGreevey supporter, said. "McGreevey was about to lock up the nomination -- he had raised more than $3 million for the party and the major counties were coming out for him."
But it was probably not only Mr. Torricelli who was suddenly interested in the governorship. The outpouring of support for him from around the state, from the leadership of Bergen and Somerset Counties, from -- of all people -- a roster of South Jersey Democrats appealing to the Bergen County man to run, suggest that, once the senator had informally announced, the party leadership was ready to rally to his side in the belief that Mr. Torricelli had the best chance to win.
"When the people in South Jersey said we like this guy from North Jersey, our ears picked up," said Rocco A. Mazza, executive director of the Democratic Committee of Bergen County. "We don't know of many times when that's happened."
So the Bergen Democrats, including Joseph Ferriero, the county chairman, issued a statement last Wednesday calling on Mr. Torricelli to announce formally and implicitly gave him their endorsement. The Somerset County Democrats, eager for a candidate who could pull swing voters from their suburban county, also jumped on board.
And in Hudson County, Robert C. Janiszewski, the county executive who is a rising power in the state Democratic Party, switched sides and came out for Mr. Torricelli. This prompted Mr. McGreevey to try to take back the appointment of Mr. Janiszewski's wife, Beth, to the $95,000-a-year job as director of the state committee on the ground that he had raised the money for her salary.
Significantly, Thomas P. Giblin, the state party chairman and originally a McGreevey supporter, denied the request.
Mr. Torricelli's backers say nice things about Mr. McGreevey on the record and less nice things about him under the shadow of anonymity. Publicly, they say the wholesale abandonment of Mr. McGreevey's camp owes simply to the view that Mr. Torricelli, a national figure with statewide recognition, is most likely to win, particularly if his opponent is another Italian-American, Donald DiFranceso, president of the state Senate.
"The party senses that McGreevey would make a fantastic candidate," Mr. Mazza said, "but the difference is that Torricelli has statewide stature and national stature, and is far superior in the gravitas department. It's the difference between filet mignon and New York strip steak."
Mr. Mazza said the choice amounted to having a good chance with Mr. McGreevey and a sure thing in Mr. Torricelli, and a sure thing is particularly what the Democrats say they need next year. For one thing, they believe that the Whitman administration has proved that, barring scandal or economic recession, a competent Democratic administration is good for at least eight years and in all likelihood a majority in the Legislature.
By last Thursday, Mr. McGreevey had regrouped his forces at a rally in Newark, which was attended by about 200 supporters from his core constituencies in unions and in the cities. They were loud in their support for the man who took on Mrs. Whitman in 1977, and loud in their contempt for Mr. Torricelli, who they say is dropping out of the sky at the last moment to reap what Mr. McGreevey has sown.
So the Democrats will end up with the one thing they did not want next year, a divisive primary fought out between the party leadership backing Mr. Torricelli and grass-roots sentiment for Mr. McGreevey.
Senator Lesniak seemed resigned to the idea that Democrats would fight among themselves, as they so often had, if only they would do it in the proper election cycle.
"We all wish this didn't happen," Mr. Lesniak said, "but we also wish that if there was going to be a fight, it would wait until after November, and after we've elected Al Gore and Jon Corzine."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Sohmer Building Being Converted to Apartments;
From Piano Keys to Condo Keys

 BODY:
The century-old, 13-story Sohmer Building at 170 Fifth Avenue, at 22nd Street, which once attracted piano purchasers to its showroom, is being converted to a residential condominium as its commercial tenants leave. Topping the building is a $7.5 million, 4,936-square-foot duplex that includes a golden-domed octagonal cupola featuring a 360-degree view, a 40-foot-high ceiling and a band of eight 8-foot-high clerestory windows atop another set of eight 10-foot-high windows at living-room level.
The 1897 Beaux-Arts building, which is part of the Ladies Mile Historic District, is to have 10 full-floor, 2,736-square-foot apartments below the duplex. 
 The structure was originally designed by Robert Maynicke, just southwest of the Flatiron Building, to house the Sohmer piano showroom and offices. Its exterior gold dome, recently regilded, is a familiar sight, glittering by day and illuminated by night.
Leslie Gill whose architectural firm is working with Bryce Sanders Architecture/Design on the conversion of the building, compared being in the cupola to "standing in the lantern of a church." She said that they were trying to make the space feel like "an urban retreat."
Mr. Sanders envisioned the 307-square-foot space as a library, including bookcases between windows and a telescope.
Sheldon Stein, president of the Valhal Corp., the developer, said that "shadows dance around the room from sunrise to sunset." Valhal paid $7.2 million for the office building in 1989.
Living in the dome isn't a new idea. Richard Welling, a founder of the City Club and a friend of Theodore Roosevelt, called the cupola home in 1908. His family had owned the building.
Valhal began converting vacated office space in the building a year and a half ago. A complete conversion was approved by the New York City Planning Commission early this year.
Besides the duplex, three other apartments are now available, costing from $1.75 million to $2.15 million. Five others have been sold, and four are occupied. The remaining commercial tenants are expected to move out over the next year.
Mr. Stein said his company was spending $7 million on the conversion into apartments. An additional $2 million is going toward new building systems, common areas and exterior renovation. The mansard roof is to be reclad with Vermont red slate, and modern storefronts are to be replaced by bay windows, each with metal ornamentation and copper roof. In the 1990's an aluminum flagpole replaced a rotted wood mast from which the piano company once flew its banner atop the dome.
A concierge will be on duty from 3 to 11 p.m. daily. Two elevators are to open into each apartment. Tenants can purchase space for storage or a wine cellar. The exclusive broker for the duplex is Sotheby's International Realty.
At Valhal's Web site, www.170fifthcondos.com, inquiries have mistakenly come in for piano appraisals and repairs.
