HEADLINE: For Once-Gritty TriBeCa, a Golden Glow

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
TRIBECA, the old butter-and-eggs district of Lower Manhattan, isn't sizzling any longer. It's deafening.
More than a dozen construction and large-scale renovation projects are clamoring simultaneously. Jackhammers and backhoes are carving up Greenwich Street, which is being narrowed to create more of a pedestrian promenade. Equipment in the telecommunications hub at 60 Hudson Street rumbles into the night. 
 With all the activity spurred by a robust economy, walking through the once-somnolent TriBeCa is now "like walking through a war zone," said Madelyn Wils, the new chairwoman of Community Board 1, who has lived on Duane Street for 15 years.
But the din includes the playful shrieks of youngsters outside P.S. 234 on Chambers Street, a reminder that while TriBeCa has lost some of its diversity -- and the aroma of roasted coffee and roasted peanuts in the air -- it is "much more of a neighborhood now than it ever was," in the words of Bill Barrett, a sculptor who has lived and worked on Worth Street since 1976.
Even after the opening of the swank TriBeCa Grand Hotel, even under the global spotlight that followed the late John F. Kennedy Jr., who lived on North Moore Street, TriBeCa is still small town -- albeit a town that is industrial at its Belgian-block, iron-canopy core, where residents fight for every inch of lawn and garden.
Its villagelike insularity extends to development, which is dominated not by the mid-Manhattan giants but by smaller builders, mostly in their 40's, many of them local, some of them architects.
What they are building, make no mistake, is housing for the rich. Lofts overlooking the Holland Tunnel exit command $1 million and more. Warehouses and factories where space rented for $1 a square foot in the 1960's are being sold as condominiums for $500 to $800 a square foot.
Roughly half of TriBeCa lies within four historic districts that were designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1991 and 1992. Jennifer J. Raab, the current chairwoman, sees TriBeCa as a "textbook example of how economic development and preservation go hand in hand.
"The real estate market provided the investment that led to the stunning restoration of these gems," she said, "but without historic preservation regulation, there would have been no guarantee that restorations and new construction would have been as sensitive, which would have limited the economic value of the investment."
The rehabilitation of TriBeCa landmarks, though, has come literally at a high price.
"Their preservation and prettification proclaimed a new social reality," Joshua B. Freeman wrote in "Working-Class New York" (The New Press, 2000). "Workers of the type who once created the wealth of Gotham in these very buildings could not afford to enter their portals, nor would they be made to feel welcome if they could."
Carl Glassman, the editor of the monthly Tribeca Trib, belonged to a food co-op 20 years ago. There were no grocery stores then, let alone four-star restaurants.
"I bemoan the fact that only wealthy people can move into the neighborhood," he said. "But I don't have bad feelings toward the people who do move in. I would posit that they are a different breed from other Wall Streeters or new-money types. If you're going to spend $2 million to live in a warehouse, you're different from somebody who wants to live in the suburbs."
So, by and large, are the builders who cater to this market. Glenn D. McDermott, probably the busiest of the lot, has just formed Society B23, a nonprofit group whose mission, he said, is to "preserve the lifestyle" of the world below 23rd Street.
Mr. McDermott, 42, ran the Mudd Club on White Street in his youth and now runs GDM Projects, a 30-person design and development office in NoHo. He said he has 450,000 square feet of space in development in TriBeCa, with much more to come.
His 48 Laight Street project is a six-story loft with bold, horizontal bands of multipane windows along Hudson Street that create an industrial sense. The plan, designed by Dana Sottile of GDM, working with Fritz Johnson, won unanimous approval from the landmarks commission this month. "We appreciated the architect's attempt to make a contextual but modern statement in a historic district," Ms. Raab said.
Before he can build, Mr. McDermott must win a variance from the Board of Standards and Appeals since this residential project is within an M1-5 manufacturing district.
Working with the Whitehall Fund, Mr. McDermott is developing 124 Hudson Street, a nine-story condo at Ericsson Place, one of the first big new buildings in the TriBeCa historic districts. It was designed by Byrns, Kendall & Schieferdecker.
The superstructure is barely up and 18 of the 26 units have been sold, at an average of $750 a square foot, said the broker, James Lansill, director of development at Stribling Marketing Associates. The project, to be completed next May, will cost about $40 million, including land and construction.
Five of the buyers are expectant couples, Mr. Lansill said. Evidently, they are undaunted about moving next to the Holland Tunnel exit plaza (a distant successor to St. John's Park), a tangle of roadway and lawn, with Mark di Suvero's "Joie de Vivre" sculpture at the center.
Both 124 Hudson Street and Cobblestone Lofts, on the north side of the plaza, will have double-pane windows with soundproofing laminate. Barrie Mandel, of the Corcoran Group, the broker for Cobblestone Lofts, said 24 of 29 units had been sold to buyers drawn by the prospect of southern views of open skies and a work by di Suvero.
With Arthur Fefferman and Mark Wallach, Mr. McDermott is developing the Fischer Mills Building at Greenwich and Beach Streets, a 32-unit condo created from 19th-century buildings with two- and three-story additions. The $40 million project, designed by Byrns, Kendall & Schieferdecker, will be largely finished this year.
Also on Mr. McDermott's plate are 3-9 Hubert Street, a 12-story apartment building that is to rise along tiny Collister Street, in a venture with the Whitehall Fund, and 161 Hudson Street, at Laight Street, a renovation that will include eight floors of apartments and offices, with a penthouse.
John Petrarca, 48, a partner in the architectural firm Guenther Petrarca and a 20-year TriBeCa resident, is another ubiquitous figure. A leader in the "Greening of Greenwich" project, to broaden and relandscape the pedestrian way on Greenwich Street, he is also working on "Hidden TriBeCa," an illustrated book on the distinctive penthouses sprouting around the area.
He is developing the Reade Street Townhouses, five single-family homes on Reade and Greenwich Streets, one of which will be his. The other occupants come from the advertising, entertainment, financial and garment industries. All are under 50. All have children. At 40 Laight Street, a seven-story warehouse, Mr. Petrarca is designing a 14-unit condominium conversion for Bernhardt Development and Geometry Realty.
FOR Robert A. Levine, of the R.A.L. Companies of Hempstead, N.Y., Mr. Petrarca is designing Tower 270, the renovation of the 28-story Arthur Levitt State Office building at 270 Broadway, on Chambers Street, as residential and office space. The broker, Bruce L. Ehrmann, vice president of Stribling Marketing Associates, said the rehabilitation of City Hall Park made this location central to TriBeCa. The project will be finished in 2001.
Mr. Levine, 49, who has worked as a designer and planner, developed the Franklin Tower condominium, a renovated 17-story building at Franklin and Church Streets. Mr. Petrarca was the architect.
Another architect-developer, 47-year-old Aldo Andreoli of Sanba Design and Development Consultants, is creating 12 condos out of an exceptionally handsome 113-year-old former wrapping-paper factory at 140 Franklin Street. Mr. Andreoli has commissioned a lobby mural from Sol LeWitt.
To the north on Varick Street is the 17-story Atalanta, a former warehouse from which some 250 new windows have been carved, in a design by Richard Cook & Associates. The developers include Robert Tiburzi of Houlihan-Parnes Realtors; Angelo Cosentini and John Carson, partners in On the Level Enterprises, a construction company; Michael Greco and John Jacobson.
Mr. Cosentini, 41, and Mr. Carson, 44, are partners with Tom Currier in 58 Thomas Street, a new seven-story, six-unit building for which ground was broken last month. The architects are DeLaCour & Ferrara, who designed 5 Harrison Street, a new six-story, eight-unit building, for Mr. Currier and Philip Mendlow. Mr. Currier, 41, has lived on Jay Street since 1992.
An exception to the home-grown rule is the TriBeCa Grand Hotel, 2 Avenue of the Americas, developed by Hartz Mountain Industries, which opened in May. Its 203 rooms are arranged around a trapezoidal, eight-story atrium. The architect of record was John Prince, but Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain, credited his father, Leonard, with much of the design.
"He wanted a building that echoed the architectural character of the neighborhood," the younger Mr. Stern said.
Not every developer strives to be contextual. The Munitions Building condo at 60 Warren Street, and West Broadway, has a boxy four-story addition atop an intricately detailed five-story 1860's structure. The developers said they saved the building, which is outside the historic district and landmarks regulation, by making it economically viable. That is not how neighbors see it.
"The level of angst over 60 Warren has been astonishing -- people in court, emergency meetings of neighborhood groups, the community board up in arms," said Hal Bromm, president of the Historic Districts Council. Mr. Bromm, an art dealer and interior designer, has lived in TriBeCa since the early 70's and was a founder in 1984 of the Committee for the Washington Market Historic District, which sought a broader landmarked area than was designated.
Angst has also greeted the conversion of the former Western Union Building, 60 Hudson Street, between Thomas and Worth Streets, into a telecommunications center filled with mechanical equipment.
"I hear that building and I'm over at Independence Plaza, on the 20th floor," said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, who represents Lower Manhattan.
The argument that 60 Hudson Street has always been a communications hub does not persuade Mr. Ehrmann, who has lived across Worth Street for 12 years with his wife, Sandi Slone, an artist. "That's like saying trolley tracks used to run down Broadway, so let's put in a jetport," he said.
The building is "making every possible effort to minimize noise," said Robert B. Getreu, senior managing director of GVA Williams, the managing agent for 60 Hudson Street. For example, he said, there are sound attenuators on all generators and new noise standards for tenants. Cooling towers are being erected on the rooftop, to keep heat exhaust away from neighbors.
"We end up being the scapegoat for the additional activity in TriBeCa," Mr. Getreu said. "It becomes frustrating. Everyone wants high tech in Manhattan. Our infrastructure is what allows that to be here. Then they say, 'Your infrastructure affects the people around you.' "
Residents of TriBeCa are also anxious about two city-owned development parcels. Last month, the Economic Development Corporation designated Halpern/Plaza Development Associates, which includes the Fisher family's Plaza Construction Corporation, to build a 13-story apartment building on a site known as 5C, bounded by Chambers, West and Warren Streets.
THE big question at Site 5C for the community is how much indoor recreational space, if any, the developers will provide. "We have a huge population growth down here and they are all families," Ms. Freed said.
Last month, the city requested proposals for a commercial building on the two-acre Site 5B, between Murray and Warren Streets, prompting concerns about "massive development encroaching on a residential neighborhood," Ms. Wils said.
These sites are the last open parcels in the 39-year-old Washington Street Urban Renewal Area, created by the clearance of 25 blocks along Washington Street, once the spine of a wholesale food district anchored at the south by the Washington Market hall.
The east edge of the renewal area, from Chambers to Hubert Streets, is being transformed by the $3 million "Greening of Greenwich" project under the Economic Development Corporation. The roadbed is being narrowed to create a pedestrian corridor with honey locust, maple and birch trees, benches, bike racks, a serpentine walkway and space for a farmers' market.
The project was designed by Signe Nielsen Landscape Architecture, which was also responsible for the recent recreation of Duane Park to evoke its lush, undulating appearance in the late 19th century. This $180,000 project was undertaken by the Friends of Duane Park, led by Lynn Ellsworth and her husband, William Duggan, and Deborah Allen and her husband, Oliver E. Allen, the author of "Tales of Old Tribeca" (The Tribeca Trib, 1999).
The Allens moved to Hudson Street in 1982. "Two years later, and we wouldn't have been able to afford it," he said. One index of the astonishing change in the neighborhood can be had at street fairs. "You've never seen so many people under three feet high," Mr. Allen marveled.
Steven Wils also noticed the growing number of children in the neighborhood, but it made him anxious. He operated Harry Wils & Company on Duane Street, across from the park, with 18 trucks coming and going around the clock, laden with butter, eggs, cheese, olives, chocolate, spices and oils.
"If there were 50 kids, now there were 150," Mr. Wils said. "It just wasn't safe anymore." Happily accustomed to living over the store, Mr. Wils reluctantly moved the business to Secaucus, N.J., in 1998.
He and his wife, the community board chairwoman, still live over the store, only the store is now a row of fine antique and furniture dealers, including Room.
Mr. Wils was the last butter-and-egg man but there is still an aromatic trace of Washington Market downwind of Transit Trading Corporation, 29 Leonard Street. "We're the only ones left," said the middle-aged man on the loading dock, before refusing further word and withdrawing behind sacks of oregano, fennel and caraway.

PUB-DATE: July 30, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: THE CITIES;
For 25 Years, a Point of Light

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
When Sister Mary Vincent Sharp got the call that there was some free furniture at a house in Northeast Philadelphia, she had to get there.
When no one else was available to make the run over there during the Memorial Day weekend, the 74-year-old nun took her aging Ford Econoline truck into Philadelphia because she knew there were families here who could use the tables and chairs. 
 When a man called from Princeton and said he had a computer to give away, Sister Mary Vincent agreed to drive to Lindenwold -- where he would be spending the weekend -- so she could get it from him. She already knew the single mother with two school-aged children who could use it.
For the past 25 years, Sister Mary Vincent has lived in Camden and tried to connect people with what they need. In the Catholic Social Services office across from St. Joan of Arc Church, she is storing a few end tables for a woman who is getting a house and fielding calls from people who want to donate anything from appliances to dining room sets. A local newspaper once called her the chief recycler of nearly everything.
"She was on the forefront of everything, she was a pioneer," said Joseph Lafferty, who worked with Sister Mary Vincent here before going to work for the archdiocese of Philadelphia.
Seven years ago, for instance, Sister Mary Vincent and some volunteers came up with the idea to open a warehouse where low-income people could buy household goods for less than $20. When the Catholic church did not have a building that would work, she formed a corporation, got donations and opened the Community Resource Warehouse.
"Nothing she's done has been for herself," Mr. Lafferty said. "Everything is for the most disadvantaged person. If you need rent money or a doctor or food, she would get it for you. She's a tough cookie, but always with the grace of God."
Tough as she is, Sister Mary Vincent is wrestling health problems these days, though she is still trying to work and recruit volunteers. She has diabetes, high blood pressure and two knees that have been replaced. And she wants the work to go on, even when the day comes that she can not be a part of it. For now, She says she keeps going by napping every day from 4 to 6 p.m.
"She doesn't want to give up,' said Monsignor Robert McDermott of St. Joseph's Pro Cathedral in East Camden. "Sister is a very charismatic person, willing to do the little things that don't get a lot of attention. She's one of the real giants. This is her life and these are her people."
Her only passion outside of helping the poor is the orchids she tends at work and in the high-rise apartment she lives in here in the shadow of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.
"She always eats the three-day old bread and wears second-hand clothes," said Mr. Lafferty. "She does just what the Gospel says. She lives it. She lives with the poor and she'd travel 50 miles to get a fan if she thought someone could use it.'
Growing up in a middle-class family in Newark, Sister Mary Vincent did not live in poverty, though she saw it all around her and would volunteer to help the nuns there.
"I just got attached to them," she said. "I wanted to serve and work with the sisters and I wanted to do social work. The people were poor. They needed clothing, they needed everything."
After working as a typist in an insurance office for a year following her graduation from West Side High School, Sister Mary Vincent moved to Philadelphia and became a nun with the Missionary Servants of the Most Blessed Trinity. At the age of 23, she was sent to Puerto Rico, where she taught English for 13 years and got her bachelor's degree at the University of Puerto Rico.
When she returned to the United States, she got a masters degree in social work from Fordham University and worked with poor Spanish-speaking families out of a Catholic Social Services office there. In 1975 she was assigned to Camden and until a few years ago, she served as coordinator of El Centro, a Catholic agency here that provides services to the the city's poor, of which there is an abundance.
Since 1975, Camden has lost one in three jobs, and its residents' income is about half the state average. The city itself has been functionally bankrupt for more than a decade, kept afloat with cash from Trenton, which pays for 70 percent of the municipal and public school budget.
Recently, because of her failing health, Sister Mary Vincent has cut back on work to three days a week in the St. Joan of Arc office. But even on days off, she keeps an ear to the ground to learn where someone can pick up a donation or get a desk for their child.
"Everybody has a need," she said. "They run short of food every month after the 20th. We often need to give out toilet paper, shaving cream and detergent. Right now things are a lot worse. We have a lot of poor, large families and they can't make ends meet. There are jobs, but they are low-paying jobs. And today, kids ask for so much more."
Still, Sister Mary Vincent says she never loses hope for Camden or for the people she meets here. She sees hard-working families and volunteers every day.
One 85-year-old woman who lives near her office -- where there is a food pantry -- will run across the street to help unload bread deliveries from the truck.
"If she sees the truck pull up, she comes to help," said Sister Mary Vincent. "We have so many good helpers and good people who come in. One man with four boys comes to get bread or just comes to visit. Things just fall into place for us all the time. It's divine providence."

PUB-DATE: July 30, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3062 words

HEADLINE: Call It 'Ayatollah' or 'Caesar,' It's the Imperial Governorship;
When Comparing Power, New Jersey's Chief Executive, Unlike Peers in the Other States, Holds All the Cards

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
FROM Washington, it seems odd that Senator Robert G. Torricelli would want to be governor of New Jersey.
"He had really begun to build himself a power base in Washington," observed Norman Ornstein of American Enterprise Institute, who has analyzed politicians' behavior for years. "I'm still trying to get my arms around it." 
 From Trenton, it makes a lot more sense. Here, the governor's office is the place to make legislation happen, to reward and punish and to generally see people trailing obsequiously in one's wake. When it comes to power, the governor, as the only elected state official, has minimal competition.
So while the political conventions in Philadelphia and Los Angeles soak up the media attention and Jon S. Corzine and Robert D. Franks battle toward the most expensive Senate campaign in history, the conventional wisdom in New Jersey is that the election in November 2001 -- choosing a successor to Governor Whitman -- is the only one that really counts.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean put it this way: "In the interest of the political establishment, it outweighs the presidential race. We have a Senate contest this year, and nobody cares. Everybody is already talking about who's going to be the next governor, and they have been for a long time. And the election isn't even till next year."
Mr. Kean recalled that John Sununu, President George Bush's one-time chief of staff and a former governor of New Hampshire, called him "Ayatollah Kean," and he quoted a line from the conservative columnist George Will that a New Jersey governor is "an American Caesar." And in crediting his
advisers with talking back to him, Mr. Kean said, "It's easy for people to be afraid of the governor."
This state is nothing like New York, for example, with a lieutenant governor, attorney general, comptroller and at least one big-city mayor who are willing and often able to sabotage the governor. And in Texas, Gov. George W. Bush does not have a formal cabinet but a collection of sometimes wayward officials, like the agriculture commissioner, who are elected and have power of their own.
Governor Whitman, while laughing amiably one recent afternoon at the notion that people are afraid of her, concurred that 'the governor does have extraordinary powers in this state."
Sticking to the tangible, constitutionally granted variety, she cited the conditional veto, by which she can effectively tell the Legislature what terms she will require for her signature, and the line-item veto.
Indeed, after State Senator John Lynch, a Democrat from New Brunswick, cast the Senate's only dissenting vote on Mrs. Whitman's budget last month, she penciled out $300,000 worth of projects for his district.
"There's hardly anybody who's active in public life who doesn't want something from the governor,' said Carl E. Van Horn, a political scientist at Rutgers who was Gov. Jim Florio's policy director. "The line I always heard was, 'Why would anyone care who's the U.S. Senator from New Jersey? After all, its only 24 jobs. The governor has thousands of jobs.' "
Moreover, the governor's thousands of jobs include all the important ones: attorney general, treasurer, secretary of state, many subcabinet positions and all the county prosecutors and state judges. They also include appointments -- some unpaid but ego-enhancing -- to every board from the New Jersey Birthplace of Football Monument Commission to the Rahway Valley Sewerage Authority.
There are a few other states -- Tennessee, Maine and New Hampshire -- where the governor is the only elected state official, but those governors have to share appointment powers with the legislature. Here, the Legislature -- specifically, the Senate -- can only consent.
Then there are the media advantages. Carl Golden, who was press secretary in both the Kean and Whitman administrations, said Mrs. Whitman in particular, "a terrific television presence," knew how to work her way into a national forum.
"That wouldn't have come her way if she were the governor of Delaware," Mr. Golden said. "If you want those New York and Philadelphia stations, you're in the right place. That's why God invented Bergen County and Cherry Hill."
Whatever their measure of power, scholars generally agree that among governors, New Jersey's is at the top of the list. Altogether, the governorship "is like royalty" here, Mr. Van Horn said. "Its very different from other states."
To the small cast of those willing to complain out loud, who in Governor Whitman's case are principally environmental groups and activists with black and Hispanic constituencies, it is indeed an imperial office. And as public crises tend to illustrate, the state's business is administered by a limited circle that owes its allegiance -- and salaries -- to the governor.
Take the volatile issue of racial profiling that showed the State Police had a history of stopping an inordinate number of minority motorists. The governor appoints the State Police superintendent, who reports to the attorney general, also appointed by the governor. When accusations reached a critical level last year, the investigation fell to the attorney general, Peter G. Verniero -- Governor Whitman's former chief of staff and now a State Supreme Court justice appointed by her -- who had insisted for two years that incidents of bias were isolated at most. At the same time, Mr. Verniero's office was appealing a Superior Court decision in Gloucester County that had found "a de facto policy of racial profiling" by troopers.
While Mrs. Whitman publicly deplored the practice and dismissed the police superintendant, she defended her attorney general and, after the intervention of the Justice Department, named him to the state's High Court. There, incidentally, he joined four other justices out of six who had been top staff members of the governor's who appointed them.
WALTER FIELDS, a Democratic political consultant in Trenton who has worked in New York, said such a scenario was unlikely in that state. "There are a lot of layers of politics in New York that you don't have in New Jersey," Mr. Fields said.
First are the elected counterweights to the governor, and not just the other state officials. "To be borough president of Manhattan or Brooklyn is really important," he said. "In New Jersey, the analogy is county executive, and they dont really matter."
Then, Mr. Fields said, there are the unofficial centers of power: "You have the third parties, the advocates. You have Al Sharpton, Calvin Butts. Those people, outside the institutions, become larger than life. Even the labor unions have more power. Even the Catholic Church."
Professor Van Horn said that while New Jersey was "a model of efficient accountability, it did not succeed in insuring diverse voices and viewpoints."
"Accountability and efficiency are not the only things that matter," he said. "On balance, I think it's better to have diversity. I believe in the distribution of power across institutions."
But when New Jersey's Constitution was rewritten in 1947, in the state's first attempt at modern government, power was purposely telescoped into one office. "The governor has the institutional power to make things happen," said Larry Sabato, a political scientist at the University of Virginia who has written extensively on governorships. "Everyone is responsible to that one executive, and then the voters know who to credit or blame."
Indeed, government by competing officials can be inefficient, if inventive and interesting.
In New York, even though the governor and lieutenant governor run as a ticket, some lieutenant governors have been famously uncooperative. Lt. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak, for instance, ran against Gov. Hugh Carey in the primary after his first term. Later, Lt. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross feuded openly with Gov. George Pataki, who removed her police escort and removed her from the ticket for the next election, at which point she left the Republican Party to run against him.
In Mississippi, Gov. Kirk Fordice went to court to stop the lawsuit that the elected attorney general, Michael Moore, filed against the tobacco companies. The governor, claiming that such a step required his approval, said the suit "makes me want to throw up."
Or in Alabama, when Gov. Fob James Jr. questioned the federal courts' jurisdiction over the states, Attorney General Bill Pryor, a fellow Republican, declared that the governor's views "do not state the legal position of the State of Alabama."
For his part, Professor Sabato said he preferred the New Jersey model to those -- like his own, where the governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general are elected independently -- that diffuse power. "The conflicts that occur between the lower elected officers and the governor are not awe-inspiring or revealing," he said. "They're about petty things."
Not surprisingly, New Jersey's former governors like the system here, too.
Mrs. Whitman's predecessor, Jim Florio, while citing the drawback that "you have no place to hide," said that "our system is wonderful in that you have real, fixed accountability."
"You can effectively be the legislative branch because of the veto," Mr. Florio said. "You can go out and mobilize people. The power is a legislative, an executive and a public-opinion-forming authority."
Former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne uses the example of the Pinelands -- which, he said, is what he most wants to be remembered for. "When I decided the Pinelands ought to be saved, I saved them," Mr. Byrne said, "first by telling my commissioner not to issue permits. Then I issued an executive order, then finally got a statute passed."
"What makes the job fun is you can get something done," he added. "It's a great satisfaction."
IN 1993, the job went to Christine Todd Whitman, whose experience in elected office consisted of serving as a Somerset County freeholder. With startling speed, even before she could deliver on her famous promise to cut taxes by 30 percent, she achieved celebrity.
Polls showed her approval rating jumping as much as 20 percentage points during her first year. In the meantime, the tax cuts inspired copycat efforts around the country.
Mrs. Whitman was one of People magazine's most intriguing people of the year in 1994, along with Heather Locklear and O. J. Simpson. In 1995 she delivered the Republican response to President Clinton's State of the Union message. Her future in the Republican Party seemed to be checked only by her pro-choice stand on abortion, which turned out to raise her stature with the party's recovering moderate wing.
But the glow faded with time. Talk of a vice presidential nomination flickered and then died, as it did again this year.
At home, property taxes were rising, along with Democrats' protests that the Whitman cuts were endangering the state's long-term fiscal health. And even though her party controlled both houses, she was not making friends in the Legislature. Nor has she made many since.
Even Democrats are guarded in their criticism, and many insist that they find the governor personally likable. But many say she has frozen out the Legislature.
"Has she ever learned to deal with it?' said the Senate minority leader, Richard E. Codey of Essex County. "Very rarely does she reach out."
"I was in Kean's office all the time," Senator Codey said. "Florio said, 'You guys control the Legislature, come on in.' Kean would pick up the phone and and say, 'I love what you said about so and so.' "
And while Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, who plans to run for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, said Mrs. Whitman had made considerable progress on such big issues as auto insurance rates and open-space preservation, he added, "She came at the Legislature in a different way than I would."
"On just about every issue," Mr. Collins said, she could have smoothed the way by going to the Legislature earlier.
When she did not notify the Senate of her first choice for a new State Police superintendant, it was the Republicans who derailed the nomination; Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco chided the administration for "bungling" it.
Senator Wayne Bryant, a Democrat from Camden County, said no one from the administration consulted him or even notified him of the legislation it introduced recently to enable a state takeover of the city government. And when the governor goes to Camden, he said, "half the time, if she comes at 4 in the afternoon I get called at 9 in the morning, if I get called at all.
"You start to get the sense that this governer doesn't want you to be involved," Mr. Bryant observed.
Governor Whitman, while not quite acknowledging a diffident posture, said she usually met with Senate and Assembly leaders at the outset of a big legislative initiative and then left the rest to her staff.
Legislators often rely on her conditional and line-item veto powers by pursuing a project "because it responds to the needs of their supporters or constituents back home," she said, while "it's the governor's responsibility to keep imposing the broad picture on them."
As for her own initiatives, she said: "It's never troubled me, and I don't know if it's a male-female thing, but I never worry about compromise being a bad thing. Once I put something out there, as long as I get my overall goal, I don't care if all the lines are written exactly the way I want."
OF course, many point out that governors and legislatures are natural
enemies. State Senator William L. Gormley, a Republican from Atlantic County who has fought with Mrs. Whitman -- "heatedly," he added -- on some environmental issues, said: "I never questioned her intent; she intended to do what was right for New Jersey.'
He added, "I've noted an absolute lack of anything you could call prejudice."
Assemblyman Leonard Lance, the chairman of the Budget Committee, said Mrs. Whitman's relationship with the Legislature was good -- no worse than Mr. Florio's or Mr. Kean's -- and he commended her tax cuts and initiative to preserve a million acres of open space. "The proof of the pudding is that what she has requested has been enacted," Mr. Lance said.
Still, Mr. Lance, a Hunterdon County Republican whose father helped draft the 1947 Constitution, said: "I would prefer to see slightly greater constitutional power in the branch of government in which I serve. I wouldn't mind seeing one or two other statewide elected officials."
As for how Governor Whitman has put her clout to use, opinions divide, understandably, along party lines. Republicans, who appreciated the tax cuts, were generally amenable to her social programs like expanded health insurance for children; Democrats said she had done little beyond happening upon a booming economy and allowing the state's debt burden to escalate.
"Hers is a traditional Republican approach that doesn't want to do a lot of things," Mr. Florio said. "It's easier to achieve your goals that way. What you've seen, in the last year especially, is the problems associated with too much of a passive approach to government, thinking that it runs by itself, whether it be E-ZPass or auto emissions."
The governor, after saying that Mr. Florio "must be a little envious," responded with a long list of accomplishments: tort reform, health insurance programs for children and working adults, increased education spending and farmland preservation, a new building code to encourage building in the cities.
She also defended her environmental record in fervent detail, saying of the environmental advocates, "Sometimes those people don't know when they've won."
To be sure, they are probably the governor's most relentless critics -- in part because she has cast herself as an ally. Bill Neil of the New Jersey Audubon Society said the administration's anti-sprawl campaign had not produced significant protection for undeveloped areas because "it would take a big, heavy political lift to do that for the state, and she avoids making tough choices."
"I think it's the mood of the times," Mr. Neil added, "whether it's Clinton or Whitman, to shoot low."
The public's judgment has been more favorable than not, although she came within one percentage point of losing re-election in 1997. In the Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers Poll, after overcoming very early voter skepticism she has consistently been ranked "good" or "excellent" by about 50 percent of respondents.
The poll's director, Cliff Zukin, said that put Mrs. Whitman well ahead of Mr. Florio and Mr. Byrne, though clearly behind Governor Kean. "Whitman is liked and Kean was loved," Mr. Zukin said. "When he was governor, people had an emotional attachment that they don't have to Whitman."
Being liked -- and having firm control of the state party -- was enough to assure Mrs. Whitman of the nomination for this year's United States Senate race, but last fall she abruptly dropped out of contention.
Now the conventional speculation places her in a cabinet post or ambassadorship if George W. Bush is elected president. But she maintained that "I really haven't spent a lot of time focusing on what's next," adding that the governor's office is "not a good place to look for your next job."
"It's going to be a tough transition no matter what," she said. "You go to a cabinet and it's the environment, or its commerce. It's just one thing. It's obviously going to be hard to funnel down, to take on a particular issue, or to be, say, in an ambassadorial post where you really don't have any influence over foreign policy at all.
"So whatever it is," she added, "it's going to be a real change."
THE angling for the governorship in 2001 began the moment James E. McGreevey almost defeated Mrs. Whitman in 1997. Until Senator Torricelli elbowed him aside, Mr. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge and a former state senator, was the Democrat's presumptive nominee. And all the while the two most powerful legislators, Senator DiFrancesco and Assemblyman Collins, were already competing for the Republican nomination.
Senator Torricelli is bad news for all of them. Given his capacity for rainmaking and revenge, he has realigned loyalties in his party leaders in just two weeks. Mr. McGreevey, on the other hand, is known as an inexhaustible worker but does not inspire fear.
Unless, of course, he becomes governor.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Quiet on the Set Is Sounding Like Thunder

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
DRESSED in a pink tutu with double-decker wings, Todd Susman and his grouchy persona are trying to change the image of the tooth fairy forever.
For Mr. Susman, a 53-year-old actor, the offbeat role in ads for Sonicare electric toothbrushes is an opportunity to play a memorable personality like Mr. Whipple, the vigilant grocery-store manager of the Charmin commercials, and Clara, who asked "Where's the Beef?" for the Wendy's fast-food chain. 
 But with a strike by commercial actors against advertisers and agencies entering its 14th week, Mr. Susman will not be shooting new commercials for Sonicare, which is made by Optiva, as scheduled. Although he knows that the character, and the advertising campaign, could be jeopardized, he said the risk was ultimately worth it.
"Advertisers want to change the status quo forever," he said. "They have the money. They have the resolution, and if they can possibly do it they will."
As the strike stretches on, it appears to be more and more a sign of things to come. Movie and television production are already being accelerated as Hollywood prepares for the possibility of strikes by screen and television actors as well as writers when their contracts expire next year.
In a recent newsletter, the Writers Guild of America warned its members: "Now is not the time to be buying the biggest house or the nicest car you can afford. If you have a TV staff-writing job, begin putting money away now. If you make a feature deal, bank every penny you can."
The writers and actors share a key complaint, about their pay for work shown on cable TV. In the early days of cable, union representatives say, actors and writers cut special deals below network rates to help the fledgling industry get off the ground. Now, they say, it's time for payback. "Cable has become a mature cash cow industry, very successful," said John McLean, executive director of the Writers Guild of America, West. "And we want our piece."
More broadly, the disputes arise from the changing face of television and the multitude of options created by advances in electronic media, including the Internet. Compensation for work shown on the Internet is another issue in the contract talks.
"We're in a whole new world here; we'll agree with them on that," said Todd Amorde, chairman of the national strike strategy committee for the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
For decades, television was dominated by the three major networks -- ABC, NBC and CBS. Now, there are seven broadcast networks and at least 50 national cable networks that are tracked by Nielsen Media Research, plus many regional channels that are not even monitored. Until the late 1970's, the three big broadcast networks captured more than 90 percent of the viewing audience. That share is now less than 50 percent.
"It's basically a different economic model," said Tim Brooks, co-author of an annual directory of prime-time network and cable shows. "You get this collision of interests as times change."
The Writers Guild's contract with producers expires May 1 next year, followed by the movie and television actors contracts July 1. No proposals are yet on the table. But union representatives said they want compensation for the increasing profitability of cable and of shows that are broadcast overseas. They also want a guarantee of fair pay for work that appears on the Internet.
In the strike by actors in commercials, the primary difference is simple: the actors want to be paid every time an ad is shown on television, and advertising agencies and marketers want to pay a flat rate.
On network television, actors who appear in commercials are paid under a system known as "pay for play." They receive a daily rate, currently $478.70, which includes the first broadcast. They are then paid each time the commercial is shown again, starting at $122.70 and decreasing over 13 weeks to $46.65. On cable, they are paid $1,014 for the 13-week cyle, no matter how many times the commercial is shown.
A commercial runs an average of 44 times over 13 weeks on the networks, according to Mr. Amorde. On cable, with more channels and lower costs for time, he said, advertisers have told him that commercials run 225 to 233 times over 13 weeks. But he says the Screen Actors Guild has found some ads that were shown as many as 5,000 times on cable.
Though actors usually spend only a day or two shooting a commercial, they spend much more time searching for assignments and auditioning. Apart from celebrities, the most successful actors who specialize in commercials can earn more than $50,000 in a good year. But most make just a few thousand dollars and rely on other jobs for most of their income.
Unions representing commercial actors have proposed a pay-for-play arrangement for cable at 37 percent of the network rate.
The Joint Policy Committee, representing advertisers and their agencies, has proposed to increase the payment for filming a commercial to $500, followed by a flat rate of $2,575 for 13 weeks of appearances on network TV. On cable, they have proposed increasing the rate for 13 weeks to $1,627.
Agreeing on these terms is essential before the negotiators start dealing with new technologies, said John A. McGuinn, chief negotiator for the Joint Policy Committee. "This strike is about modernizing this contract and bringing it into the Year 2000 so we can deal with the Internet," he said.
NEGOTIATORS have been finding little common ground. The talks, which had been suspended, resumed on July 20 after federal mediators called the two groups back to the table. But the negotiations quickly broke down again.
Actors want Internet use of advertising included in the contract, but Mr. McGuinn said he had not been authorized to negotiate in this area. The advertisers and agencies want both sides to study the issue and meet at least once a year, but they stress that they do not agree that the unions have a right to negotiate Internet rates.
A third sticking point involves the unions' desire to verify how many times a commercial is shown. The Screen Actors Guild says its survey of 38 commercials uncovered $110,000 in unpaid wages. The advertising industry proposes joining with the unions to choose a consultant who can search for the best way to monitor commercials. Recommendations from a committee representing both sides would be due 60 days before the expiration of a new contract in 2003.
Some advertisers are producing commercials with the blessing of the actors unions by agreeing to pay what the unions have proposed. But many other commercials are being made in defiance of the strike.
The unions, affiliates of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., are trying to keep the heat on advertisers. Members are picketing production of nonunion commercials in an attempt to shut them down. Earlier this month, the actors picketed major offices of AT&T, which has been making commercials using nonunion actors.
In New York, the protesters were addressed by labor leaders, including the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, John J. Sweeney, and by actors like Susan Sarandon and Jerry Orbach.
Mr. Susman said he had been lucky enough to work during the strike by providing the voice of a dog in commercials for Laidlaw's Greyhound bus line, which signed the unions' proposed contract. Still, he marvels that commercial actors, among the hardest-working and lowest-paid members of the actors' unions, are bearing the brunt of the larger struggle. "How God and luck aligned in this particular situation so that we are the ones at the forefront of this fight, I will never know," Mr. Susman said. "But we know the fight we're in."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE;
When Keeping Cool Is Not a Nicety, but a Necessity

BYLINE: By BEN UPHAM

 BODY:
When Joe Nemecek, owner of Adolf Kusy Meats on Washington Street, got to work on the morning of July 10, he heard a terrifying sound: the quiet drip-drip of ice melting.
During the weekend, a pipe had ruptured in the century-old refrigeration system that keeps the meat cold in the enormous freezers and coolers of Mr. Nemecek's business, and of other wholesalers and butchers in the meat market district. He and the others spent that morning carrying in blocks of dry ice to keep their freezers cold, or scrambling to find space for their stock in other warehouses before it began to rot. 
 "We have trouble every summer," said Mr. Nemecek, who had to throw away $10,000 worth of spoiled food. But he said he thought the Gansevoort Refrigeration Cooperative, which eight owners in the district formed in 1980 to run the refrigeration system, would fix it, as it had before.
Instead, co-op officials decided to shut the system down except for pipes serving one block-sized building known as the Gansevoort Market. And they told the other businesses that they were on their own.
Frank D. Platt, a lawyer for the co-op, said the pipes serving Gansevoort Market were above ground and so were easier and less expensive to fix than the pipes serving the other businesses, including Mr. Nemecek's, which are underground. "The economics just weren't there," he said, to fix the underground part of the system.
The pipes stretch from Jane Street in the West Village to West 15th Street, and from the West Side Highway to Hudson Street, an area once brimming with meat packers. But as meat businesses moved to cheaper space in the other boroughs, the outlying pipes were gradually turned off, or not repaired. Some remaining companies bought their own systems. Fewer companies using the pipes meant less money for maintenance, furthering decline. By this summer, only about a dozen companies on Washington Street and those in the Gansevoort Market were using the system.
A district manager from the United States Department of Agriculture said that food safety was never compromised during the recent breakdown.
Marty Heller of Endicott Meat and Poultry on Washington Street was already planning to move his business to Hunts Point in the Bronx. But he said the breakdown cost him thousands, and he called the co-op's decision not to fix the pipes insensitive.
Mr. Nemecek, who lost his lease in April when his building was sold to a real estate developer, said the breakdown "really put an extra nail in the coffin" for him, and for many of the other firms that have been struggling to keep up with rising rents.
Mr. Platt said that the market would be a different place in five years. "It's gotten to the point that the value of the real estate has overridden the value of having a meat market," he said. BEN UPHAM
 
A Rich History Lurks Behind the Sides of Beef
The meat market district is roughly defined by Hudson and Washington Streets east to west, and 14th and Horatio Streets north to south. It was originally the site of Fort Gansevoort, built during the War of 1812, and named for Peter Gansevoort, a Revolutionary War general. In the early 1880's, a farmers' market opened in the area; by 1888, meat wholesalers had moved in.
As recently as 1986, the district had more than 120 meat firms. But today fewer than half remain.
 With increasing real estate development in the West Village have come efforts to landmark the area, because of some significant events in United States history and cultural affairs. On July 11, 1804, after a duel with Aaron Burr in Weehawken, N.J., a mortally wounded Alexander Hamilton was ferried across the Hudson River to the Bayard Estate (near present-day Jane Street, one block south of the market area), where he died.
The De Lamater Iron Works, between 12th and 14th Streets on the river, built the boilers and engine for the Civil War ironclad ship Monitor, which defeated the Confederate Merrimac at Hampton Roads, Va., in 1862, after nearly sinking on the way.
From 1866 to 1885, Herman Melville, a grandson of General Gansevoort, commuted from his home in Chelsea to the Department of Docks building at the foot of Gansevoort Street, where he worked as a customs inspector. It was the writer's first steady paycheck. BEN UPHAM

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2916 words

HEADLINE: Four Corners;
When Shifting Groups of Immigrants Compete for the Same Turf, Even an Intersection Can Become Contested Ground

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL

 BODY:
THERE is a saying among urban historians: You can always tell how a neighborhood is changing. The name of the outgoing ethnic group is on the funeral homes, and that of the incoming group is on the grocery stores.
In New York, ethnic groups move like tectonic plates, drifting land masses, sometimes colliding at their edges with unhappy consequences, sometimes slipping past one another with relative ease. 
 The signs of shift are everywhere. In the span of a few years, a Little Italy, a Koreatown or a Little Odessa is newly defined by the Mexican bodegas or Chinese shoe stores or Indian delis that press at its borders.
The phenomenon, which sociologists call ethnic succession, is as old as the city itself and may be heightened in New York because of its size and the multiplicity of ethnic groups jostling for the same turf.
A single street corner can become central to a group's identity.
"In New York, because we live so much of our life in public and the sidewalk plays such a role in our perception of the city, busy street corners demarcate territory in a way that may be much more significant than in other cities," said Philip Kasinitz, a professor of sociology at Hunter College who specializes in immigration issues. "People feel an allegiance to a stretch of businesses or a corner because that's where the community is defined most publicly."
So, 20 years ago, Puerto Ricans in East Harlem knew that if they walked east past Third Avenue on East 116th Street, which was controlled by Italians, they faced the threat of physical violence. Today, the same corner is dominated by Mexicans, who were just as wary of the corner a decade ago when Puerto Ricans held sway there.
To outsiders, these shifts may be all but invisible. Sometimes the two groups occupying the same turf share physical attributes and speak the same language. But the differences are all too evident to groups trying to forge or maintain an identity.
The result can be out-and-out conflict, but more often it is a fluid process that involves intricate cultural negotiation. Here are four corners where those delicate negotiations are taking place today.
 
In Flatbush,
Russian Jews and Pakistanis
Yakov Semichan, 56, a Russian Jew whose barbershop has been at Coney Island Avenue and Glenwood Road in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn for nine years, was fighting the crosscurrents.
In the last five years, his original customer base, Orthodox and Russian Jews whose synagogues and kosher restaurants once dominated the corner, has been departing for wealthier sections of Flatbush. Pakistani immigrants and businesses that catered to them were replacing them.
But when two Pakistani barbershops opened across the street from Mr. Semichan's shop during the last six years, his business began to suffer.
Mr. Semichan, who has piercing blue-gray eyes and a gap-toothed grin, had bought Al's Barber Shop from another Russian Jewish barber in 1991, when he moved to Brooklyn from Moldova in the former Soviet Union, and renamed it Yakov's. At first, the shifting population did not affect his business. He was still the only barber on the strip.
"Hair is hair," he said over his shoulder as he passed the afternoon playing checkers with Nikolay Banov, a friend and customer from Kiev. "Jewish hair, Pakistani hair, it's all the same."
But Asghar Choudhri, president of the Pakistani American Federation of New York, whose headquarters is up the block, said many new immigrants saw otherwise.
"The Pakistanis all went to their own places," Mr. Choudhri said. "They stayed with their own. When the second Pakistani barber opened, that's when his business really went down."
In 1996, a Pakistani immigrant named Shabbir Hussain, who had owned four barber shops in his native city of Lahore, had arrived in Flatbush and was looking for a job. Mr. Semichan offered Mr. Hussain the battered red barber's chair in the front of the shop and put a bright green sign in the window advertising, "We speak Russian, English and Yiddish," along with Mr. Hussein's name translated into Urdu, the Pakistani language.
The two men now cut hair side by side in Yakov's Barber Shop, and the shop seems busy. But their situation is unusual. Although many elderly Jews still live on side streets like Glenwood Road and Avenue H, the two groups enjoy little interaction.
On Coney Island Avenue between Glenwood and Avenue H, almost all the businesses are owned by Pakistanis, Bangladeshis or other Muslims. These include Urdu Bazzar, a 99-cent store; Asian Grocery Halal Market; Bukhara Restaurant, which serves Pakistani, Indian and Bangladeshi cuisine, and Raheela Beauty Parlor. Children wear shalwar kameez, traditional Muslim garb.
But one block from Glenwood, the scenery changes. Just across Avenue H, the streets are populated by Hasidic Jews in black coats and hats. Though the two communities lead separate lives, they share certain traits. Both groups are religious and conservative, both observe restricted diets, and in both communities, women assume traditional roles. Both groups have had tense relationships with blacks and Hispanics in surrounding areas. On a recent afternoon, Mr. Choudhri of the Pakistani American Federation spent the afternoon on the telephone, complaining to the police that African-American teenagers were throwing bottles and rocks at a new mosque and cursing its congregants.
The Jews and Pakistanis lead largely separate lives.
"There has been no real interaction, except on the leadership level," said Rabbi Yechezkel Pikus, executive director of the Council of Jewish Organizations of Flatbush. "There's a sort of tolerance. You mind your business and I'll mind mine."

In Belmont,
Albanians Displace Italians
Felix Mastro, a former prizefighter, stood with his buddies, Sal, Johnny D., Guido and Mikey, in the blue light filtering through a canopy outside the Cosenza Fish Market at Arthur Avenue and 186th Street.
The four men were downing clams on the half shell and reminiscing about the old days, 80 years ago -- before any of them were born -- when pushcarts selling Italian goods rumbled along Arthur Avenue, the heart of the Belmont section of the Bronx.
"It all changed in 1933, when they opened the Arthur Avenue Retail Market," said Mr. Mastro, 70, still dapper in his brown sports jacket, who has lived in the neighborhood all his life. "They closed the last place where you could buy live chickens on the street over here just a couple of years ago. Very few Italians are left here now." It is a daily lament at this intersection.
At first glance, the Italian presence seems as bright as ever. Along Arthur Avenue, banners on lampposts proclaim "Welcome to Little Italy in the Bronx," beside Italian bakeries, meat markets and cheese stores. But in the last five years, as Italians have left Belmont for the suburbs, they have been replaced by Albanians.
Many Roman Catholic Albanians first moved to Belmont in the 1980's, when those who suffered under their country's fanatical Communist regime fled to the United States. The recent wars that drove thousands of Albanians from Kosovo produced the latest wave of immigration, which began about three years ago.
Albanians felt comfortable in an Italian neighborhood because Albanians and Italians are neighbors in Europe. They eat and drink similar foods, and they look somewhat alike. But the two groups have not always mingled peacefully, as shown by life on this corner. At Mike's Deli, an Italian specialty store inside the Arthur Avenue market, three of the countermen are Italian and three are Albanian. All the Albanian employees have adopted Italian-style nicknames -- Milane is Milano, Keno is Nino -- and each speaks some Italian.
"The Albanians get along fine with the Italian-Americans," David Greco, a second-generation Italian-American, said. "But the Italians from Italy feel as if the Albanians invaded Italy, so they're a bit hostile. One of my guys is constantly calling them ignorant. If I wasn't there, there would be a fight every day."
One combatant is Qamil Osmani, who goes by the nickname Ossie. Mr. Osmani, who worked for his country's Ministry of Defense under a previous regime, came to the United States in March to seek political asylum. He settled in Belmont because he knew that Albanians lived there and he had come to know Italians when he was serving in the Albanian Army a decade ago.
As for the Italian counterman who calls Albanians ignorant, he said: "I tell him, I'm not coming from the street. I have stayed with much better people than him."
Similar skirmishes are played out along Arthur Avenue between 186th and 187th Streets, which has become home to half a dozen Albanian stores, including the Kosova Commerce Corporation, which sells Albanian video and audio tapes and specialty goods; the Gurra Cafe, which serves Albanian cuisine; and the All Star Cafe, where the specials include typical Albanian dishes like chevapi and beef sausage.
Even though many Italians have left the neighborhood, they return to buy their prosciutto and osso buco. And some of the vendors of those items are now Albanian. George Dedvukaj, who was born in a small town in Montenegro, owns and runs Giovanni's Restaurant on Arthur Avenue near 186th Street, which serves brick-oven pizza in the Italian style. He bought the business two years ago from another Albanian.
"I think the Albanians helped the area," said Peter Servidio, an Italian-American who owns Peter's Meat Market across the street but moved to Westchester a few years ago. "They buy a lot, like the Italians used to, by the bucket. And as far as business is concerned, Italians are going to be here for years and years."

In Flushing,
Koreatown Becomes Chinese
The pungent scent of cilantro accompanied Sean Lee, wearing a cut-off T-shirt and a baseball cap, as he wandered through Green Farm, a Korean-owned greenmarket at Main Street and Maple Avenue in Flushing, Queens, furiously directing the movement of crates of watermelons and okra.
During a break, Mr. Lee, who has lived in the neighborhood for 20 of his 32 years, pointed to the last vestiges of the old Koreatown at the edge of Flushing's shopping district. "Rose Handicraft was the first Korean store," Mr. Lee said, pointing toward a shop that rents traditional Korean kimonos. "Over here, the pharmacy is Korean and the stationery store is Korean."
In the last five years, many of the names on businesses on the corner have switched from Korean to Chinese, as Korean businesses have moved 10 blocks north to Northern Boulevard.
"This has become like a second Chinatown," Mr. Lee said. "They're bringing a lot of money from Hong Kong and China and investing it in this neighborhood."
Two factors are cited to explain the departure of Korean-owned stores.
"It's possible they've been pushed out because of the increase in Chinese business," said Daeyoung Kim, who is studying Korean-Americans at the Center for Urban Research at the CUNY Graduate Center. "But it also could be because the Korean stores have become more diversified." As business owners diversified the products they sold, Mr. Kim said, they needed more space, and moved to a part of the neighborhood where larger, cheaper stores were still available.
Green Farm, which opened 20 years ago, is now encircled by Chinese businesses. Across the street is China Trust Bank, housed in a modernistic glass structure. Next door is Tai Pan Bakery. Just above Green Farm, restaurateurs from Hong Kong are putting the finishing touches on East Buffet and Restaurant, an ornate, 17,000-square-foot restaurant and catering hall. The three-floor restaurant, whose decor includes a sweeping marble staircase, a wrought-iron banister from Greece and a 120,000-piece crystal chandelier, is the third establishment created by the group, which also runs a wildly popular Chinese restaurant in Huntington, N.Y.
"Most Chinese work late hours, and if you get off at 8 p.m., they can't get out there before we are closed," said Betty Cheng, one of the partners, explaining the decision to open in Flushing.
Although East Buffet will concentrate on Chinese food, it will also offer sushi, Korean food and European specialties.
Local residents remember that East Buffet occupies a site that once housed a successful Korean restaurant called South River, and that a Korean restaurant up the block experienced what Ms. Cheng called "another Chinese takeover." But she said she and her Korean neighbors, like those downstairs at Green Farm, get along well.
"They speak in their language, which I don't understand," she said, "but they eat at our places and we eat at theirs."
But Sung Soo Kim, president of the Korean American Small Business Service Center of New York, is less sanguine.
"It is a bad thing that's happened here," Mr. Kim said. "Koreans have been pushed out by other ethnic groups. Landlords kick them out to get higher rents. We used to have 80 stores in that area. Now we have three or four."

In East Harlem,
Puerto Rican Into Mexican
Minutes after Mario Olmedo dropped his suitcase on the floor of his cousin's apartment in East Harlem 15 years ago, he heard a knock at the door. When he opened it, he said, three men assaulted him and robbed him of his watch, the only valuable he had brought from his home in Mexico City. Based on the tint of their skin and the cadence of their Spanish, Mr. Olmedo concluded that his attackers were Puerto Rican.
Whether or not he was correct, the encounter left him feeling that he had entered hostile territory. Until just about six years ago, Spanish Harlem was just one kind of Spanish, Puerto Rican. The corner of 116th Street and Third Avenue, where Mr. Olmedo opened a taco stand 13 years ago, was dominated by Puerto Rican-owned bodegas.
Puerto Ricans, in turn, had supplanted Italians, who first settled in East Harlem in the 1880's and numbered 80,000 by the 1930's. Conflicts erupted between Italians and Puerto Ricans as early as the 1920's. By 1930, most of the city's Puerto Ricans lived in the neighborhood, and the tensions between the two groups were legendary. Efrain Suarez, owner of Made in Puerto Rico Products, which sells CD's, books, coffee and other items from the island, stood on the corner and pointed east toward Second Avenue.
"When the Italians were here, Puerto Ricans couldn't go down that block," said Mr. Suarez, 55, who has worked in the neighborhood for three decades. "The farther you went down the street, the worse it got. If you went past Second Avenue, you were beaten up."
Until six years ago, it was Mexicans who had to confine their movements to the blocks west of Third Avenue. In the early 1990's, Mr. Olmedo bought a bodega owned by a Puerto Rican in the heart of the contested territory and replaced it with a tacqueria, La Hacienda, possibly the first Mexican restaurant in the neighborhood. "We used to see a lot of Puerto Ricans chasing Mexican guys down the street to beat them up," he said.
Mr. Olmedo now owns a second Mexican restaurant, La Tacquicanda, just down the block, as well as an apartment building. But it took time to catch on. "People used to pass by and make nasty faces," said his teenage son, Omar, a younger, Americanized replica of his father.
That has changed, and no one chases Mexicans away from the corner anymore. After Mr. Olmedo opened his first restaurant, other Mexican immigrants started asking for advice on starting their own. Along 116th Street between Second and Third Avenue, Mexicans have made inroads. Amid 14 Puerto Rican flags hung from windows and fire escapes are at least eight Mexican-owned stores, among them Mexico Shoes, Azteca Unisex barbershop, Taco Mix taqueria and the Mexico Discount Center, a 99-cent store.
A vast majority of recent Mexican immigrants to El Barrio came from Puebla, a state in northern Mexico that has been battered by economic troubles and natural disasters.
Mexicans feel more welcome today. As if to prove the point, Mr. Olmedo gestured toward the back of his restaurant, where three men were eating together. "One is Mexican, one is Dominican and one is Puerto Rican," he said.
But resentment still festers in the hearts of some Puerto Ricans, who feel they have lost control.
"Puerto Ricans still consider El Barrio 'la cuna,' the cradle of Puerto Rican experience," said Henry Calderon, president of the East Harlem Chamber of Commerce.
Pepe Castillo, a Puerto Rican musician who works at Made in Puerto Rico, stood at 116th Street and Third Avenue gazing east, his brow furrowed as he extolled the virtues of "hard working Mexicans" who now dominate the block. "And it all started with the guy selling tacos on the corner," he said, in a tone tinged with loss.
Mr. Suarez sighed.
"What can you do?" he said. "The Puerto Ricans created a vacuum here. The original Puerto Ricans who came here have now retired, moved to Rockland County, Florida or back to Puerto Rico. Their children are professionals."
But, he added, "there is no decent housing here for them."
And though the mix on the corner has changed, the tension is nowhere near as fierce as it was when Italians and Puerto Ricans were the two groups.
"There is the fact that we would prefer it to remain Spanish Harlem," Mr. Suarez said. "And if the Mexicans keep coming, it will be Spanish Harlem. It will be a different kind of Spanish, but still Spanish Harlem."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH -- John G. Goode;
Smith Barney Fundamental Value Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
SUNMAID makes raisins from the grapes grown on the 40-acre farm in Fowler, Calif., where John G. Goode grew up. Mr. Goode, who still owns the farm, also runs the $2.55 billion Smith Barney Fundamental Value fund -- and he says managing its portfolio is much like farming.
"You plant the fields and hope you get a good crop," Mr. Goode said from his San Francisco office, which has a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. "But you have to keep the field tended and spend time cutting down the weeds." 
 His careful management has yielded a bounty for shareholders. The fund returned 19.92 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 7.28 percent for large-capitalization value funds in general and 17.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc.
Mr. Goode, 55, looks for fallen stars among companies. "We're picking the leading franchises when share prices are depressed for reasons that we think are temporary," he said. "We find that even the best and brightest companies get involved in circumstances, such as product recalls, that make shares available at extremely attractive prices."
But a cheap price isn't enough; he wants to see a catalyst that will push a stock back up. "We try to pick rubber balls," he said, "not broken eggs."
He uses two computerized screens to whittle down the universe of roughly 10,000 publicly traded domestic stocks: One looks for excess cash flow over the past five years, while the other seeks high returns on the company's cost of capital. A few hundred companies qualify.
Mr. Goode then works with five analysts to select the 75 or so stocks that fit the themes and trends that they believe will be important over the next three to five years. The fund is now dominated by the market's biggest stocks, but he expects that to change.
"Our work suggests that smaller and mid-cap stocks will dominate the big S.& P. 500 stocks in the future," he said. Among the S.& P. 500 itself, he expects that "the not-so-nifty 450 will be much more attractive than the cult stocks" near the top of the list.
As inflation increases moderately, he is also moving toward hard-asset stocks like natural-resource companies. In that group, he especially likes Alcoa, one of the fund's top five holdings, because it is an efficiently run industry leader, he said.
He sees revived pricing power in many other old-economy stocks. "We're seeing higher prices for landfills, office space, electricity and natural gas," he said. "It will probably be a cyclical phenomenon, but it'll be a beauty over the next one to three years."
He spends about one-quarter of his time talking to company managers to gauge their acumen and their attitudes toward shareholders.
His valuation formulas vary by industry group, but Mr. Goode generally tends to buy shares when prices fall 20 to 40 percent from their 90-day moving average. When the price jumps far above that average or company insiders step up their selling sharply, he starts paring his position. Over all, the fund's turnover is a low 40 percent a year.
MR. GOODE regards Abbott Laboratories, the pharmaceutical company, as "the poor man's human genome play" because it specializes in drug-testing work, which will be required for new therapies emerging from genome research. Abbott's stock price is depressed, he said, because of concerns earlier this year that drug companies' growth rates were slipping. He added that the company's planned merger with Alza, the drug delivery company, "didn't happen, and that left a bad taste in investors' mouths."
The fund bought Abbott shares in January at $29.875; they now trade at $41.50, or 20.75 times Wall Street's earnings estimate of $2 a share for 2001. He expects Abbott's earnings to grow 13 percent a year through 2002.
About the same time, Mr. Goode bought shares of McKesson HBOC, the drug distributor. "We think the drug distribution business will be very attractive going forward," he said. "If you listen to Al Gore, more of the population will be covered, and drug distribution is one way to play that trend."
Wider use of generic drugs, which generate bigger profits for distributors than name-brand drugs do, will also help McKesson, he said, and he expects earnings to grow 15 percent a year for the next three years. The stock looked like a bargain, he said, after investors reacted sourly to a merger with HBO & Company last year, pushing down the price from $90 to less than $20 this spring.
The fund bought shares for $20.43; they now trade at $24.4375, or 18.79 times the consensus 2001 earnings estimate of $1.30 a share.
Another favorite is Countrywide Credit, the mortgage origination and servicing company. Mr. Goode called the stock an e-commerce play because the company does one-fifth of its business over the Internet. Interest-rate worries pushed down its stock price from $50 in early 1999 to the mid-$20's early this year; he got in for $24.99 a share in January. He noted investors' concern that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, "would tighten the screws in the economy, meaning that loan originators would be penalized as interest rates rose." But Countrywide's loan servicing business stood to benefit, he added, because higher rates would discourage homeowners from refinancing.
Mr. Goode expects Countrywide's earnings to grow 15 percent a year over three years. The stock now trades at $35.6875, or 10.1 times the consensus earnings estimate of $3.54 a share for 2001.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
An Epitaph For a Rule That Just Won't Die

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
IT sounded like an epitaph for a venerated principle of economics, one that the Federal Reserve still invokes as a justification for slowing the economy.
The epitaph, in fact, came from the Fed, from Alan Greenspan himself in his latest round of Congressional testimony. The principle he declared inoperative maintains that full employment and low inflation are incompatible. That may once have been true, but the old connections are not evident now. And Mr. Greenspan's epitaph makes the Fed's next interest rate increase harder to justify. 
 The principle in question, known by the acronym Nairu, holds that when the unemployment rate falls below a certain level, inflation accelerates. One goal in slowing the economy is to increase unemployment to its "natural" level, the one at which the inflation rate neither rises nor falls. Equilibrium is a holy grail in mainstream economics.
Raising unemployment is not a pretty thing to do, particularly if people are being asked, or forced, to sacrifice their jobs in the name of a malfunctioning thesis. Mr. Greenspan had been publicly skeptical for months about Nairu, but in reply to a question from Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida -- "Do we need to move the unemployment rate back higher than 4 percent to achieve price stability?" -- the Fed chairman seemed to push Nairu into the bygone.
"My forecast," he said, "is that Nairu, which served as a very useful statistical procedure to evaluate how the economy was behaving, over a number of years, like so many types of temporary models which worked, is probably going to fail in the years ahead as a useful indicator."
Hearing this, Senator Paul Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, asked sarcastically if Mr. Greenspan's fellow policy makers at the Fed would see a transcript of the chairman's epitaph. That was a jab at Lawrence H. Meyer, an influential Fed governor who embraces Nairu, which he puts at 5 to 5.25 percent. The Fed has already raised interest rates six times in 14 months to slow the economy, but Mr. Meyer would slow it more if unemployment fails to climb from its present 4 percent.
Mr. Greenspan's epitaph seems disingenuous. While burying Nairu, he embraces almost the same principle in a different incarnation. He speaks of running out of enough people to take jobs. Labor shortages would then give workers leverage to bargain for higher wages. Companies would raise prices to pay for the higher wages. Or, as Mr. Greenspan told Congress, "labor costs eventually would have to accelerate to levels threatening price stability."
That is Nairu, or lip service to Mr. Meyer's insistence that Nairu lives. For Mr. Greenspan, though, the natural unemployment rate appears to be 4 percent or so. The difference between Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Meyer is an additional 1.4 million people out of work, maybe more. For them, the debate over Nairu matters.
NAIRU, or the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment, is really a description, through equations, of a set of conditions that link unemployment to inflation. Those conditions seemed a lot clearer in 1967, when Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate, first described a natural rate of unemployment and mentioned the numerous factors, even states of mind, that must be "embedded" in the equations. In the 50's and early 60's, the math worked.
A low unemployment rate signaled a robust demand for goods and services. Encouraged by this, the United Auto Workers, for example, negotiated a wage increase with General Motors, and that increase became a pattern for other auto workers and for millions of employees in many industries. Employers, as a matter of course, raised prices to help pay for the higher wages. Demand made the price increases stick; today's flood of quick-to-discount competitors was not yet on the scene.
Since 1995, demand has been similarly robust, but raising prices is not as easy. Wages have risen in response to low unemployment, but not very much. The old Nairu links from unemployment through wages to inflation have not kicked in. All sorts of reasons are cited: rising productivity, falling computer prices, less expensive imports, low-wage immigrants, weak unions, corporate mobility, job insecurity. The list goes on, and the natural rate of unemployment, set at 6.5 percent in the 1980's, has declined today to 5 percent or less.
Or maybe there is no natural rate above zero. Maybe Nairu no longer works. Certainly Mr. Greenspan's disavowal makes it harder for the Fed to invoke tight labor markets as a reason to slow the economy in anticipation of rising inflation. Now more than ever, the Fed is under pressure to wait for inflation to actually accelerate before it acts.
