HEADLINE: 5 Rescued in Brooklyn Apartment Fire

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
In the chronicles of New York City firefighting, the things that happened at 315 Livonia Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday will hardly warrant a footnote. No one was killed or seriously injured, the flames were confined to one apartment on the 13th floor and five members of a family were rescued by firefighters.
But for those five family members -- and for two firefighters who ran into their blazing apartment, crawled down a smoke-filled hallway and shared their air packs with the trapped woman, her brother and her three children until help arrived -- it was a day of survival and heroism, a poignant day to remember. 
 "I have a 6-year-old son myself," Lt. Dennis Gordon, 42, said after the rescue, in which he and Firefighter Michael Cummings, 44, joined the family behind a wall of flames and shared their lifesaving air, as well as the peril, for eight minutes as deadly smoke encroached.
The drama began about 8:15 a.m., fire officials said, when Kim Williams, 32, awoke to discover flames engulfing the living room of her three-bedroom apartment, 13-E, at the S. J. Tilden Houses on Livonia Avenue at Mother Gaston Boulevard in the Brownsville section.
Ms. Williams, shrieking in terror, roused her sleeping brother Eric Mitchell, 36, and her children -- Marcus Russell, 5, Donnell Russell, 4, and Taquenan Russell, 3. They were forced to retreat down a hallway to a back bedroom, where they huddled for 15 minutes on the border of hope and dread.
"We couldn't get out," said Ms. Williams, who shut the door against the nightmare and huddled on the floor with her children and brother. The room soon began to fill with smoke. They opened a window, but that only seemed to draw more smoke from under the door.
There had been no time to call the Fire Department. But a next-door neighbor, Barbara Evans, 65, heard noises, saw smoke in the hall and called in the alarm. She and two sons, Kevin and Derrick Davenport, also threw wet rags to the family from a hallway window.
Under the command of Chief Robert Brown, firefighters of Ladder Company 120 and Engine Company 231, six blocks away at 107 Watkins Street, arrived within minutes. The plan was to hook up a hose to the nearest standpipe, on the 12th floor, tapping into a tank on the roof of the 16-story building and a hookup from the standpipe's base to a hydrant on the sidewalk.
But the standpipe valve on the 12th floor, apparently unused for years, was sealed up with paint, and the firefighters lost precious minutes struggling to open it.
Meanwhile, Lieutenant Gordon and Firefighters Cummings and Brian Gallagher, 35, all of Ladder Company 120, entered the apartment and found the living room and kitchen area almost completely engulfed. Furniture and cabinets were burning, flames were shooting out shattered windows and blinding smoke filled the rooms.
The firefighters each carried about 130 pounds of gear, including air packs that each held about 17 minutes of compressed air, and face masks that enabled them to breathe in rooms where the gases from smoke can quickly be deadly.
Firefighter Gallagher also carried a portable fire extinguisher. While he attacked flames to cut a momentary path, Lieutenant Gordon and Firefighter Cummings plunged across the kitchen and into a 25-foot hallway, which in two zigzag turns led to the three bedrooms.
Smoke already filled the hallway, and they fell to the floor, where it was least dense, and crawled forward to search for victims. They could see almost nothing.
They searched two bedrooms and found no one. Minutes later, they reached the back bedroom, where the family members were trapped. The firefighters could hear them gasping, coughing and trying to scream, but could not see them until they were virtually face to face.
"They were all huddled on a mattress under the window," Lieutenant Gordon recalled. "The smoke was burning their eyes and throats. The kids were going limp from lack of air. The littlest one looked like she was going to pass out. She was not responding."
By that time, Firefighter Gallagher's portable extinguisher had run out, the flames had begun to fill the hallway, and the firefighters, too, were trapped. "There was nowhere we could go," Lieutenant Gordon said. "We had to stay there until help came with water."
As they waited, the two firefighters immediately took off their air masks to share with the family members. Each was given 20 to 30 seconds of air before the mask was moved onto another face. Lieutenant Gordon said up to eight minutes elapsed before help came.
"I was pretty confident," he said. "We were in radio contact. The others knew we were there. It was just a matter of time until they got through with water."
The two youngest children, Donnell and Taquenan, fell unconscious.
Finally, firefighters cleared the standpipe and brought heavy water to bear on the flames. Firefighter Gallagher was the first to follow his comrades down the hallway, crawling under the smoke. He carried Taquenan out to safety, while Firefighter Cummings carried Donnell out. Lieutenant Gordon then led the two adults and Marcus safely out.
Mr. Mitchell was taken to Kings County Hospital Center and treated for smoke inhalation. Ms. Williams and her three children were treated at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, also for smoke inhalation, and the children were admitted overnight for observation.
The Red Cross sheltered the family, and relatives, neighbors and friends said they would help, too. Ms. Williams is unemployed but enrolled at Medgar Evers Community College. The family's apartment was a charred shambles: the furniture, the clothing, photographs, the children's drawings and collages, all destroyed.
"We lost practically everything," a downcast and exhausted Ms. Williams said at the hospital last night. It had all happened so fast -- the fire, the rescue, the rush to the hospital -- that there had been no time to thank the firefighters.
But Lieutenant Gordon, 22 years in the department, and Firefighters Cummings and Gallagher, both sons of New York City firefighters, had not waited around to be thanked.

HEADLINE: Officials Say Chavez Wins In Venezuela

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 31

 BODY:
Rallying to President Hugo Chavez's call for radical social and political change, Venezuelans on Sunday granted the former paratrooper a new six-year term with enhanced powers, top officials said.
"This is a day of revolution," Mr. Chavez, 46, who in 1992 led an unsuccessful military coup attempt, said after casting his ballot this morning at a suburban polling station. "Today a new republic is being born." 
 The ease with which Mr. Chavez will be able to carry out his revolution, however, depends on the outcome of races to elect 165 members of Congress and 23 state governors.
Results of those races were still being tallied early today. Supporters of the president are expected to win a majority of the posts, but polls indicate that Mr. Chavez may fall short of the two-thirds majority he needs in the National Assembly in order to govern without constraints.
Mr. Chavez has promised to use his time in power to sweep away the last remnants of the traditional political order in this nation of 23 million people that in recent years has been the United States' top oil-supplier.
Hours after the polls were supposed to close, there were no official results. However, both the head of the outgoing legislature and the interior minister, Luis Davila, said on national television that preliminary official results showed that Mr. Chavez had won handily.
Voter surveys posted by the the newspaper El Nacional gave Mr. Chavez as much as a 20-point margin over his main challenger, Francisco Arias Cardenas.
In the last 18 months, Venezuela's poor, disillusioned by decades of corrupt and unresponsive government, have united around Mr. Chavez and his plan for a complete overhaul of society.
The preliminary results, announced late Sunday night, were quickly followed by fireworks and other celebrations across the capital. Thousands of jubilant Chavez supporters wearing the red beret that is the emblem of their movement marched with flags and banners on the Miraflores presidential palace downtown, demanding that Mr. Chavez appear on "the people's balcony" to address them.
When he finally emerged, wearing the same red beret and a military-style uniform, Mr. Chavez called for national "unity, persistence and patience." But he once again resorted to the language of conflict and confrontation that has become his trademark, boasting that "we have routed the forces of the adversary" and warning that "one battle has ended and another is beginning."
The vote on Sunday was the culmination of a contentious process of sweeping political change that began with Mr. Chavez's landslide victory in a December 1998 presidential vote. As a candidate, he promised voters a "peaceful social revolution" if elected, but also said he would need a new constitution with expanded powers in order to carry out the transformation the country needed.
In three elections last year, a constitutional assembly was first convoked and next selected and then finally it submitted a new charter to voters for approval last December.
As a result, Mr. Chavez's term of office was expanded from five to six years, and a ban on sitting presidents seeking immediate re-election for one more term was removed -- creating the possibility that Mr. Chavez could remain in office until 2013.
Even before the changes were approved, though, the Congress, dominated by discredited opposition parties, and the Supreme Court were eliminated and replaced by weakened entities that have proven subservient to Mr. Chavez and his leftist Patriotic Pole coalition.
The authority of governors and mayors was also reduced, the role of the armed forces was vastly expanded and a Chavez loyalist was placed in charge of the powerful state oil company after it was purged.
With the new Constitution in hand, Mr. Chavez called a vote to elect a new unicameral congress, as well as governors, mayors and state and municipal legislators, a total of more than 6,200 elected posts. In what he described as an attempt to "relegitimize" his rule, he also submitted the presidency to a new vote, anticipating no real challenge.
But in February, Mr. Cardenas, a former army colonel who was Mr. Chavez's second-in-command during the 1992 coup and spent two years in jail with him afterward, broke ranks and announced his own candidacy.
Mr. Chavez, he charged, was assuming dictatorial powers, tolerating the corruption he had pledged to eradicate, alienating the United States and forging an undesirable alliance with President Fidel Castro of Cuba.
In an unusual last-minute incursion into the campaign, Mr. Castro invited a group of Venezuelan journalists to Cuba on Saturday and issued a ringing endorsement of Mr. Chavez, wishing him "good luck and lots of votes" during a rambling news conference that was televised live here. "Hugo, I am sure that nothing or no one can hold you back," the Cuban leader said.
Mr. Castro's remarks, which appeared to violate a ban on politicking here after the formal close of the campaign, came days after a man turned up claiming to be a Cuban intelligence agent and said that Mr. Castro has sent 1,500 operatives here to infiltrate the Venezuelan government. As the news conference was taking place, Mr. Chavez called Mr. Castro, and the two men discussed baseball before ridiculing the accusations of a Cuban spy network operating here.
Since taking office 18 months ago, Mr. Chavez has consistently praised Mr. Castro and the Cuban revolution while attacking his domestic critics as "a rancid oligarchy" and pursuing a nationalist and populist political line. The resulting polarization of Venezuelan society, with the poor overwhelmingly lining up behind Mr. Chavez and the middle class reluctantly supporting Mr. Arias, was once again on display during the balloting on Sunday.
One of Mr. Chavez's strongholds here is a working-class neighborhood called 23 de Enero, the site of a popular uprising in which hundreds of people died in 1989, after the government raised gasoline prices. The area voted heavily for Mr. Chavez in 1998, and appeared today to have rallied to his side again, with scarcely a supporter of Mr. Arias to be found during interviews with voters.
"Venezuela has awakened, and we will never let ourselves be fooled again," said Julia de Tirado, 61, who described Mr. Chavez on Sunday as the antidote to 40 years of corruption and misgovernment under a pair of traditional parties. She praised him for being "honest and hard-working" and said that "if he were not our president, things would be disastrous."
But across town, at a polling place at a private high school in the middle-class neighborhood of Chacao, a woman conducting an exit poll for a local firm said Mr. Arias appeared to have a two-to-one advantage over Mr. Chavez. Among the the most vociferous of those voting against the president was Irma Galindo de Baez, 50, who was wearing a button that proclaimed "throw the crazy man out."
Mrs. Baez said she voted for Mr. Chavez in 1998 because "Venezuela needed a change -- it couldn't go on with the dictatorship of the political parties." But "this government has been a disaster," she said. "This guy has really scared us" with his incendiary language, "there has been a lot of corruption," and the police have allowed a farm owned by her family to be seized by peasants.
Mr. Chavez himself voted early, thanked Venezuelans for choosing "a new horizon, a new path," and then spent several hours playing baseball. Later, though, he met with his economic team to draw up what he described as "measures of great impact for the first 100 days of the new government," and on Sunday night he said he will address the nation on Aug. 2 to announce the details of "a new economic model for Venezuela."

HEADLINE: Urban League Leader Advocates New Standard in Capital Cases

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The president of the National Urban League, Hugh B. Price, called on governments yesterday to institute a tougher standard of guilt for judges and juries in death penalty cases to ensure -- "beyond any doubt" -- that the innocent are not executed.
"It's barbaric for the state to kill someone who isn't a mortal enemy," Mr. Price told 1,500 people in a speech that kicked off his organization's annual convention at the Urban League's headquarters on Wall Street in Manhattan. "The folks on death row may not be angels, but they are children of God." 
 Aside from the new burden of proof in death penalty situations, Mr. Price voiced support for affirmative action, called for a new commitment to prepare the nation's youth for high-tech employment in the new economy, and called for blacks to use the strong economy as a springboard to self-sufficiency.
"We must summon the will and the resources to mount the next great surge toward the American mainstream," Mr. Price said.
In his speech, Mr. Price called for a repeal or nationwide moratorium on executions.
But if executions are not halted, he said, politicians should stiffen the standard of guilt in death penalty cases from "beyond a reasonable doubt" to beyond any doubt at all.
Of today's standard, Mr. Price said: "I believe that standard is too lax when someone's life is at stake. Politicians know full well that some innocent people will be executed. But most of them lack the courage to say what error rate they find acceptable." Under Mr. Price's proposal, if the judge or jury found that some doubt existed and the death penalty could not be imposed, they could find the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt and impose a lesser sentence.
The issue of the death penalty and how it is imposed has drawn heightened public interest with the execution of Gary Graham in Texas.
George W. Bush, the Texas governor and presumptive Republican presidential nominee, defended Mr. Graham's execution, but critics said his defense was doomed by incompetent counsel that failed to uncover evidence that could have cast doubt on his guilt.
